HEADLINE: Mentally Ill: Unmet Goals For Albany

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
Homeless and mentally ill, sometimes addicted and even violent, the combination is all too familiar in New York City. But behind the individual cases -- most recently dramatized by the troubles of Larry Hogue, the man who terrorized 96th Street for years -- lies a history of collective failure in Albany.
Legislative gridlock, budget shortfalls and not-in-my-backyard lobbying have left New York State tens of thousands of beds short of what is needed more than two decades after a pledge was made to treat the mentally ill outside of large hospitals. 
 While the number of mental patients in state hospitals has plunged from 93,000 in the 1950's to about 12,000 today, the state has never matched this with a concurrent rise in resources for group homes or outpatient programs.
 
Unfulfilled Pledges
 In fact, while more than 150,000 people in the state are suffering from serious mental illness, about two-thirds of New York's $3.8 billion mental-health spending is still used for hospital services.
And recent pledges -- modest in comparison to past promises to balance the emptying of hospitals under deinstutionalization by creating less-costly community-based programs -- have gone unkept. Two years ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo pledged to build nearly 2,000 apartments for the homeless mentally ill in New York City by this summer. To date, the number completed is 315.
The question of how to care for mentally ill homeless people came into clear focus in recent weeks with the repeated arrests of Larry Hogue, a mentally ill, drug-addicted homeless man who has terrorized Upper West Side residents in Manhattan. Although Mr. Hogue's is an extreme case, mental health experts say he is an altogether common example of how the system fails at the outset to point a disturbed person toward alternatives: a home for the mentally ill or some other supervised setting, where he might have been kept away from the plunge into drug use that doctors say led directly to his stalking and terror.
State leaders' attempts to explain why it is so difficult to move money from mental hospitals into less-expensive community-based programs often become an exercise in blame.
Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, cites the Republican-led State Senate as the chief obstacle. But he has had little problem persuading the Republicans to go along with construction of 30,000 new prison cells in his tenure, in part because prisons bring jobs to upstate districts represented by Republicans.
 
'Intelligent Downsizing'
 But shifting money to group homes from state-run psychiatric hospitals, mostly upstate, means sending money downstate. "All you need to do is call the politicians who represent the upstate hospitals and ask them," said Michael J. Dowling, the Governor's director of health, education and human services. "We have been pushing, as a policy, the intelligent downsizing of the institutions for years."
Many lawmakers staunchly defend the centers as a bastion of economic activity in depressed areas. For instance, the Willard Psychiatric Center in Romulus, N.Y., is the third-largest employer in Seneca County, which is struggling with the looming closing of an Army depot. State Senator John R. Kuhl Jr., a Republican who represents the county, says Willard should not be closed as a mental hospital until the state has settled on some alternative use for it.
Nonetheless, the costs of maintaining the outdated hospitals are staggering. New York is spending $2 million a year to treat just 14 remaining patients at the Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York, basically because the Legislature has never given the State Office of Mental Health the authority to shut it down.
Even in state hospitals with larger numbers of mentally ill people, the cost per patient still hovers around an average of $120,000 a year, about four times as much as it costs to keep someone in a group home. A state plan to close or downsize half of its 22 psychiatric hospitals in the next decade, which has run into resistance in the Legislature, would save about $360 million a year and could nearly double the Office of Mental Health's budget for the community programs.
Yet some of the mentally ill are so sick that a hospital is the only place for them. Mr. Hogue, who suffered damage to the frontal lobe in his brain while in the Navy and is now under psychiatric evaluation at Bellevue Hospital, may be one of them.
But Richard C. Surles, the state's Commissioner of Mental Health, estimates that up to half of the people now in psychiatric centers could be cared for in community settings.
The problem in Albany is that many legislators who say they agree that shifting money from the psychiatric centers is the right idea have balked at actually doing so in the state budget, in part because they say they have been unable to get guarantees from Mr. Surles or Mr. Cuomo about how the money will be spent.
 
Payroll Expenses
 Earlier this year, Mr. Surles conceded that money set for opening group-home beds had been used to meet his department's payroll expenses. And many mental-health groups fault Mr. Surles's office for what they see as its backing away from plans for many of the homes in the face of community opposition.
In shifting money into non-hospital programs, the state has gone from a little less than 30 percent of the mental-health budget in 1986 to about 38 percent now. Mr. Surles says that figure is still far too low, but some influential lawmakers are reluctant to proceed with the hospital closings.
"I don't think the answer when times get tough is to just put the locks on the psychiatric centers," said Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican who heads the State Senate Mental Hygiene Committee. "There has to be a mechanism to capture the financial savings and insure that it is reinvested in the community-based system. We've hit a stone wall with the Division of the Budget on that."
Even when money is available to open group homes, local opposition often arises. This, along with bureaucratic squabbles with New York City, is a primary reason state officials cite to explain the delay in providing the 1,900 apartments the Governor pledged two years ago in the city.
Mr. Dowling and Mr. Surles noted that despite the original goal of having all the units available this summer, the legal papers signed by Mr. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins provided something different: they said the "resources needed to fulfill the terms of the agreement" should be committed by now, with all units actually available by July 1993. "It is going to get done," Mr. Dowling said.
As Katina Zachmanoglou, housing committee chairwoman for Friends and Advocates of the Mentally Ill, a Manhattan group, sees it, "Most mentally ill people, with the right housing and support services, can live decent lives in the community, which they're entitled to. The point is we know how to care for people with mental illness. It's just not being done."

HEADLINE: Job Rights for Homosexuals Backed in Poll

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
An overwhelming majority of Americans suppport equal employment opportunities for homosexuals, according to a poll in this week's issue of Newsweek magazine.
The survey said 78 percent of Americans favored equal job opportunities for homosexuals, while two-thirds of the 547 registered voters interviewed by phone approved of inheritance rights and health insurance for gay spouses. 
 But less than one-third of those surveyed said they approved of legally sanctioned gay marriages, and only 32 percent said they thought homosexuals should be able to adopt children.
The poll found that 53 percent of Americans did not consider homosexuality an "acceptable" life style and 45 percent said they considered gay rights a threat to the American family and its values.
The poll was conducted for Newsweek by the Gallup organization and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
About 4 in 10 of those surveyed approved of Gov. Bill Clinton's and President Bush's positions on gay rights, while 16 percent of those polled said Mr. Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had gone too far in his support of gay rights. Twenty-seven percent said they objected to Mr. Bush's stated opposition to gay rights.
Newsweek said Americans were almost evenly divided over whether homosexuals should teach in elementary schools or be members of the clergy.

HEADLINE: Educational Virtuoso or Villain?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
In many ways Joseph A. Fernandez's first days as Chancellor of New York City's ailing school system were reminiscent of the breathtaking sweep and buoyant promise of Franklin D. Roosevelt's first 100 days as President.
In a matter of weeks, Mr. Fernandez stripped principals and administrators of their jobs, shut down a congested teacher-licensing bureau, overturned the hoary tenure system for principals and prescribed a host of offbeat remedies. Soon, the eyes of the nation were upon him as he made condoms available in high schools and shifted power away from principals to committees of teachers and parents. 
 But as Mr. Fernandez starts his third full school year on Wednesday, it seems clear that some of the sheen has worn off his image, and, while he has maintained many fervent supporters, he has also spawned some ardent detractors.
 
Enlivening Innovations
 To be sure, there are many education watchers who think he has been a masterful commander, invigorating a lackadaisical system, steering it roughly intact through a punishing economic slump, and throwing in some enlivening innovations as well.
"I think he's about the best chancellor we've had in a long time and he's done as well as anyone can do in a flawed system," said Robert Berne, a New York University professor of public administration who directed an influential study of New York's schools.
But there are others who think Mr. Fernandez's impact has too often been cosmetic, that he has been too preoccupied with flashy managerial strokes while scarcely lancing the system's instructional boils.
"He has not articulated a vision of what an educated child is like, what the educated child should learn, what the expectations are for every child," said Jeanne Frankl, executive director of the Public Education Association, the city's oldest educational advocacy group.
Some critics feel his stubborn temperament has alienated members of the Board of Education and some of the bureaucrats and city officials he must work with. For most of his two and a half years, Mr. Fernandez has been locked in bruising combat with a majority of the seven-member board over how to prevent AIDS, battling first over a condom program, then over an AIDS curriculum, and, in recent weeks, over a pledge requiring outside AIDS lecturers to emphasize sexual abstinence.
While Mr. Fernandez has more than held his own, the battle has been a distraction from more vital issues, and some feel he should have been more compromising.
Between champions and skeptics are urban experts who believe that even a pedagogic virtuoso can have very little impact in a system with almost one million students, 991 schools and 125,000 employees. The system has seen better and worse times, but its quality has been the product of factors beyond a chancellor's control -- the solidity of families sending children to schools, the attractiveness of the teaching profession, the city's economic state.
"The real Achilles' heel of the system is its size," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics at New York University. "And that will defeat any executive no matter how smart he is. If he keeps out of trouble he's doing all right."
This handicap, says Joseph Shenker, president of the Bank Street College of Education in Manhattan, is compounded by New York's fractured governing system, where elementary and junior high schools are primarily under the control of 32 local boards, not Mr. Fernandez.
"If they'd show that organization chart to anyone in private industry they'd say you're nuts," says Mr. Shenker, adding, "Even in that context, Joe's done an awful lot to push the system in the right direction."
In measuring Mr. Fernandez's performance, raw scores are inconclusive. Early results seemed promising as reading, mathematics, attendance and dropout rates improved. But last spring -- after a year that saw the retirement of 200 principals and 4,000 teachers -- there was a sharp setback, with every district falling in reading and all but two in math.
Nor is it clear that schools are safer. Assaults, weapons seizures and other incidents rose from 3,941 in the 1989-90 school year to 4,952 last year, capped by the murder of two students at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn just moments before a visit by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
 
Mixing Fresh Ideas With Accountability
 Almost everyone agrees that the tall, broad-shouldered 56-year-old Mr. Fernandez has roused a slumbering elephant. Since coming from Miami, he has ousted two district superintendents, two school board members, and five principals, and seven times has taken over various powers of floundering school boards.
As a result, supporters say, everyone is more alert, aware that their misdeeds could have consequences. Those who were already energetic feel there is strong support for fresh ideas and maverick approaches. Newcomers from outside the system feel welcome. Until Mr. Fernandez's intervention, a wealthy Manhattan couple, Joseph and Carol Reich, felt stymied in their efforts to do a generous turn -- finance a new school in Brooklyn.
"I think he has provided hope for the school system," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
Soon after Mr. Fernandez walked through the doors of 110 Livingston Street in January 1990, replacing Richard R. Green, who died suddenly the previous year, the city's economy began an unrelenting slide. Yet Mr. Fernandez and his deputy, Stanley S. Litow, universally draw high marks for their deft management in the last two years, a sharp contrast to the confusion that marked the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
Instead of slashing teaching positions, they pared 1,600 of the 5,200 jobs in the central bureaucracy and salvaged millions of dollars in money for the classroom by contriving an early retirement plan and a $40 million deferral of teacher pay. They were willing to go to the mat with City Hall, and after $750 million in budget cuts over two years, they managed to fend off major cuts this year. Many superintendents, though, are complaining that even this year's cuts are painful, as deep as 10 percent in some districts. Mr. Fernandez did manage to keep his $4.3 billion building program largely intact.
"Will kids feels that? Of course they'll feel that!" a heated Mr. Fernandez snapped, responding in an interview to criticism that his impact has not been felt at the school level.
Such accomplishments, said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a national policy group, are far more impressive than some other reforms that might get more attention.
"When you go to the circus and see the high-wire act and someone's doing somersaults, everyone says it's hard to do somersaults, but basically you have to stay on the high wire," said Mr. Newman.
 
Students, Condoms And Fighting AIDS
 Yet Mr. Fernandez has done a few somersaults as well. Although it remains deeply divisive, condom distribution was a response to what the Chancellor sees as the threat of a teen-age AIDS epidemic, a threat that some critics feel he has overstated and that school executives in some other cities have sidestepped.
"History is going to deal kindly with how we dealt with the AIDS issue," Mr. Fernandez said. "People will look back on this and say there was one system that led the charge."
Mr. Fernandez has enlisted 240 schools in "school-based management," which gives committees of teachers and parents a voice in school policy. He has upgraded requirements for mathematics and science and announced plans for 30 small thematic high schools, including schools for disruptive youngsters. He has chipped away at the bureaucracy's notorious secretiveness by publishing every school's budget.
Over all, said Mr. Shenker, Mr. Fernandez has succeeded in reviving confidence in the public schools. "If Joe ever left that level of confidence would just plummet," he said.
But there are some who think Mr. Fernandez's reputation is overblown, and even a few who believe he has been destructive.
 
Assessing if Changes Are Really Reforms
 Several observers like Mr. Tobier, the New York University professor, suggest that, in a system with ironclad mores and regulations, most school committees have been given only superficial tasks, the equivalent of shuffling the deck chairs on the Titanic.
However, Mr. Fernandez and his supporters argue that school-based management has revolutionized the ambience of many schools, transforming everything from how reading is taught to when teachers teach.
"For the first time," he said, "we have people talking about issues relating to kids, about curricular issues, how to get parents involved."
Mr. Fernandez burnished his reputation as a tough commander by winning the authority to transfer principals. Fewer than 10 of the 1,000 principals have been dislodged, and those were sent for brief retraining and then either returned to their old posts or reassigned. Mr. Fernandez contends that many principals have resigned rather than accept transfers.
Some school professionals say Mr. Fernandez has spent too much time on programs like condoms or longer school days without concentrating on improving the fundamentals of writing or social studies. Frank L. Smith, chairman of educational administration at Teachers College, Columbia University, said that instead of requiring more years of science, Mr. Fernandez should be igniting a debate on how science should be taught, whether, for example, computer simulations need to replace workbooks "because that's how adults do science."
"More of outdated science makes the problem worse not better," Mr. Smith said.
The root of the problem, adds Nona E. Smith, educational director of the New York State chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is that Mr. Fernandez blundered by appointing lieutenants masterful at the "political things," but not, until his recent appointment of Argie K. Johnson as deputy for instruction, at curriculum. "If the instruction doesn't work, it doesn't matter how good the administrative pieces are," she said.
 
A (Slow) Shake-Up Of the Curriculum
 Mr. Fernandez admits that a major regret is his failure to shake up the curriculum division sooner than he did, retaining an administrator long after it was clear her performance was disappointing. But otherwise he disputes attacks of his instructional leadership, citing his beefing up of mathematics and science and his push for more computer-assisted reading programs.
Ms. Frankl of the Public Education Association thinks Mr. Fernandez should move more forcefully against districts like No. 5 in Harlem and No. 9 in the west Bronx whose students perennially perform poorly in reading and math. But Mr. Fernandez replies that at least in District 9, he pushed the board to replace an inept superintendent with Felton Johnson, a highly praised former principal.
"There's a new feeling there, it's turning around," Mr. Fernandez said. "That didn't happen by accident. I don't know how anybody can say the things we've done don't directly impact kids."
Conversely, other critics like Philip Kaplan, executive director of the New York City School Boards Association, say Mr. Fernandez has gone too far, doing "more damage to decentralization than in 20 years of the law's existence."
"Saying we're all crooked demeans the job," Mr. Kaplan said. "There are people in the trenches who have the ability to make change and he hasn't tapped that resource."
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who is generally adulatory, feels Mr. Fernandez has been too submissive to the United Federation of Teachers, for example, supporting a too-generous raise of 5 1/2 percent in 1990.
Mr. Fernandez heatedly disputes this, saying that he meets with Sandra Feldman, the union president, no more than a handful of times a year and that he has taken the union to arbitration over the number of working days. Besides, he says, the "the ones who end up suffering" in an adversarial relationship "are the kids."
John C. Fager, co-chairman of the Parents Coalition, thinks Mr. Fernandez has paid lip service to the ideal of increasing the role of parents, putting only token members on the school-based committees. Mr. Fernandez points out that parents had a smaller role before.
Throughout this debate of whether Mr. Fernandez has done too much or not enough, no one ever accuses him of being anything but extraordinarily diligent, starting his workdays at 7 A.M. and persistently seeking new problems to tackle. And both critics and supporters are mindful that no chancellor has ever taken this behemoth of a system and suddenly made it flourish.
"It's very hard," said Mr. Newman of the Education Commission, "to make the Queen Mary turn."

HEADLINE: Harold Curtis Fleming Dies at 70; Tirelessly Fought for Civil Rights

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Harold Curtis Fleming, a white Southerner who became an early leader in the struggle for racial justice in a "new South," died Friday at his home in Washington. He was 70 years old.
Friends said he died suddenly after a brief illness. 
 As executive director of the Southern Regional Council, an organization formed in 1944 to promote equal opportunity for Southerners, Mr. Fleming joined the civil rights cause well before it became fashionable. And long after others had lost their fervor, he continued to work for that cause as head of the Potomac Institute in Washington.
Born on July 27, 1922, in Atlanta, he spent his formative years there and on a farm in northeast Georgia. After attending Boy's High School in Atlanta, he accepted a scholarship to Harvard University, where he worked on The Crimson, the college's newspaper, and The Advocate, Harvard's literary magazine.
 
Commanded Black Company
 When the United States entered World War II, he enlisted as an officer in the Army. Through "a quirk of fate," as he put it, he wound up on Okinawa as the captain of an all-black quartermaster company. He later described himself as being "shocked, traumatized" by the experience.
"I really came as close as anyone to realizing what it was like to be black in those days," he recalled in a newspaper interview 20 years after the war, "because I was intimately involved in these men and their treatment and on the receiving end in a sense myself. It amounted to being a straw boss in a very ugly, discriminatory system, which is rarely remembered today."
After the war, he finished his studies at Harvard and, returning to Atlanta, took a "temporary" job with the Southern Regional Council. It lasted 14 years, and he transformed the council from a fairly timid organization into a militant agent of racial equality.
He led creation of the council's Voter Education Project intended to get black citizens to register en masse. As it kept tabs of voter data, the council became the sole repository for black voter-registration statistics in the South, a treasure trove of numerical evidence used in hundreds of voting-rights lawsuits.
Mr. Fleming moved to Washington in 1962 to head the Potomac Institute, a not-for-profit agency that provided counseling in race relations to public agencies and the private sector.
In the Administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, he was deputy director of the United States Community Relations Service. He was also a founder of the National Urban Coalition, and for more than a decade he served as chairman of the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing.
In 1956, 11 years after joining the Southern Regional Council and two years after the Supreme Court decision that outlawed school segregation, Mr. Fleming co-wrote the book "Integration: North and South," in which he optimistically reported "extensive progress" in reducing discrimination.
But 29 years later, the goal seemed as elusive as ever. The more he and other civil rights advocates overcame rudimentary problems of racism, he observed in a 1985 interview, the more complex became the problems that remained. The struggle against discrimination, he said, had merely shifted from leaping simple political and judicial hurdles to curing stubborn economic and social ills.
And he observed: "There is a tiredness at the moment. We get tired very easily." Yet he counseled persistence, adding: "I think the things that are achieved in a field as complicated as this are achieved by people who stay with it."
Although he retired from the Potomac Institute about two years ago, he continued to write and consult about civil rights issues and affirmative action.
"The theme of Hal Fleming's whole life is summed up in the title of that Protestant hymn, 'Let Us Together Sweetly Live,' " said Claude Sitton, retired editor of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., who was chief Southern correspondent for The New York Times from 1958 to 1964. "A brilliant, effective, indefatigable worker for an integrated America in which blacks and whites could prosper alongside one another."
Mr. Fleming's survivors include his second wife, Jenna, and two sons, Gary and Tony.

HEADLINE: American Dream Put on Hold at Car Plant Doomed to Shut

SERIES: Closing Willow Run: Waiting for G.M.'s Telegram. First article of a series.

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich., Sept. 6

 BODY:
The day a General Motors manager stood on a stage at the Willow Run assembly plant here and told 2,000 workers the line would shut down forever by the fall of 1993, Chuck Kehrer watched as the man next to him bolted for the nearest trash can and threw up.
"The two women next to me went white," said Mr. Kehrer, who 22 years ago went from high school to a job as a spot welder in the body shop. "People were crying and running out. I didn't cry. I just had an empty feeling. I felt very, very sad. I felt as if the Titanic was going down, and everyone was running for the lifeboats, and the lifeboats had holes." 
 Mr. Kehrer, whose nickname, Animal, dates from his hell-raising youth, says he cried a month later, in March. It had taken him that long, he says, to realize all that he could be losing. He had had to tell his 18-year-old daughter, Heather, who wants to be a nurse, that everything was too uncertain for her to attend Eastern Michigan University, as planned. He was more worried than ever that his 20-year-old son, Jason, would never do better than a minimum-wage construction job.
 "I remember I was lying in bed with my wife and looking up at the ceiling," Mr. Kehrer said. "I'm not the kind of person who asks for things. If you want something, go out and get it. But I just started saying: 'I wish the plant weren't closing. I wish Heather could go to Eastern Michigan. I wish Jason could get a good job.' "
The news on Saturday that another local of the United Automobile Workers union, in Lordstown, Ohio, had ended its nine-day strike against G.M. offered little comfort here: at issue were 240 jobs, and G.M. won the right to eliminate them by January 1994.
Now, even as Mr. Kehrer and his fellow workers were preparing for the annual Labor Day parade in downtown Detroit, and for their final year at Willow Run, they were brooding over what happened to their vision of the future. It had always seemed as solid as the huge plant itself.
The assembly line could be brutal and numbingly monotonous, but for thousands of people, black and white, from Kentucky, West Virginia, Tennessee and Arkansas, it was a ticket out of the coal mines and away from dead-end jobs sweeping floors. The plant and G.M., the world's largest auto maker, had made the American Dream real for all of them.
"G.M. was the place to be -- top pay, good benefits," said Linda Robbins, whose husband has cleaned painting booths at Willow Run for 23 years, and whose father retired after 33 years as a repairman with the company. "G.M. was security. How could this happen? Why didn't anyone stop it?"
At the union hall across from the plant, at the annual retirees' picnic last month, and at home, the workers talk obsessively about how General Motors betrayed them.
Mr. Kehrer says their choices are limited. "What are you going to do -- go out and say: 'Hire me. I know how to shoot screws into a door with an air gun'?" he asked.
And so, even now, many are depending on the company to rescue them. They are waiting for telegrams summoning them to other plants -- in Texas, Tennessee, Ohio and other parts of Michigan. Most of them will receive telegrams, they have been told, but no one knows exactly when, or how many people will go where. It is too early to know what will happen over the next months.
"I've got a lot of years left to give General Motors," said Fred Mosley, 35 years old, whose wrists ache from 14 years of wielding air guns on the assembly line, installing dashboards and the trim on rear windows of cars. "They've got to keep me. I'm counting on General Motors."
Last year, G.M., the nation's largest manufacturer, lost $4.5 billion, the biggest annual loss ever for any American company. Declaring the imperative for "a leaner, more productive company," the chairman, Robert C. Stempel, announced plans to close 21 plants by 1995. One of those selected was Willow Run.
By 1995, Mr. Stempel said, the work force would be reduced by 74,000, including 50,000 hourly workers. Securities analysts on Wall Street said the changes were essential for the company's long-term survival.
"The auto industry has gone through a ruthless shakeout," said Harley Shaiken, an auto analyst at the University of California at San Diego. "These people are paying the price."
What makes Fred Mosley and his co-workers particularly bitter is not just that their plant is closing, but that for reasons G.M. has declined to specify, the cars they have been building will be produced instead in Arlington, Tex.
They say they understand that G.M. has to cut back. But why them? "We always made money for General Motors," Mr. Mosley said. And in turn, G.M. paid them wages -- about $17 an hour currently, with top benefits and full medical coverage -- that bought middle-class lives: ranch houses, new cars, fishing trips up north, college educations for their children.
Now, a group of men and women, mostly in their late 30's and 40's, with high school educations and 20 years or more in the plant, are confronting an America in which industrial jobs -- jobs for people like them, who like to work with their hands -- seem to be disappearing by the thousands. It is not only their auto plant that is shutting down. Plants that make steel, windows and typewriters have been closing all across the country.
 
The Psychology
Rumor and Denial Amid the Disbelief
 From General Motors headquarters in Detroit, only 30 miles away, little information is available for the workers of Willow Run. Bob Harlow, the president of the union's Local 1776, says he spends his days telling people what the company has told him: sometime by the end of next summer, the plant will close. But many in the rank and file do not believe him.
Wild rumors swirl -- the plant will stay open to produce the Saturn, or the next version of the Chevrolet Monte Carlo, or the Japanese will take it over. Ypsilanti Township has filed suit against G.M., arguing that the company is obligated to keep the plant open in return for tax abatements it received over the years.
The workers say they have to hope that Ypsilanti will win. "Can't roll over and die," said Doug Arter, a 34-year-old assembler. "That don't pay the bills."
A lawyer with the United Auto Workers, who insisted on anonymity, said victory is unlikely. "It's like trying to get an injunction against capitalism," he said.
Everyone talks about the deaths: six men from the plant -- four of heart attacks, two of brain disorders -- in six weeks last spring after the announcement, said Mr. Harlow, the local president. The youngest was 39, the oldest 49. No experts have connected the deaths to the plant closing, but they have saddened people and made them more afraid.
The end of Willow Run will mean the loss of nearly 4,000 hourly workers -- the 2,460 currently employed at the plant, as well as another 1,500 who were laid off 18 months ago, when the factory went from two shifts to one.
More than auto workers' jobs are at stake. Next door to the plant is Complete Auto Transit, which transports the finished cars; its 200 drivers, mechanics and car handlers are worried that they will end up unemployed. And down the road, at Howard's Hoagies, where auto workers have been buying lunch for 20 years, the four waitresses have already had their hours reduced.
In many ways, the auto workers are more fortunate than thousands of other displaced workers. Until at least next fall, when the current union contract runs out, they will receive nearly their full income and benefits, including medical coverage.
Workers with 10 years or more who are laid off receive 50 to 70 percent of their regular take-home pay until retirement age, or until they take another full-time job.
With thousands of other displaced G.M. workers scrambling for jobs at auto plants, it is unlikely that everyone will be placed. The company and the union will together provide millions of dollars for retraining -- Mr. Mosley has already made plans to study auto-engine repair -- but no one can promise a job in another field.
Transfers to other plants will be made according to seniority, and with 18 years the average among the company's 300,000 auto workers, the younger people are the most nervous.
"Why don't the older people retire and make room for the younger ones?" asked Mr. Mosley, who has a wife and a 4-year-old daughter.
That is also the hope of General Motors. After 30 years, any worker is eligible to retire, with income of $1,700 a month and full health coverage.
Jerry Krempitz, who has a nearly perfect attendance record for 33 years on the assembly line, and identifies himself as "a G.M. man," says he probably will retire. But he doesn't want to. He is only 51 years old.
"The plant's my life," he said.
 
The Decision
Abrupt Obituary For a Way of Life
 Schoolchildren here grow up studying the history of Willow Run. In the 1940's, the plant produced thousands of bombers for the Allies. After the war, the people of Willow Run built cars -- at the peak in 1973, 6,000 workers produced 1,000 cars a day. Chevrolet Corvairs and Novas, Pontiac Bonnevilles, Buick Roadmasters, and the car that many think doomed them, the most recent version of the Chevrolet Caprice, which has been poorly received by customers. The cars can be produced somewhere else. But what the workers fear cannot be transplanted is the way of life that has been built around their plant in Ypsilanti.
Willow Run means picnics, Christmas parties, bowling leagues and the union. Doug Arter met his wife, Kelly, when she broke him in on the assembly line nearly 16 years ago. Between them, Al Scutchfield and his cousin Curt Meadows, both from coal-mining families in Prestonsburg, Ky., have more than a dozen relatives at the plant.
 
The Announcement
Bitter Aftertaste Of a Victory Party
 There is one day here that all the auto workers relive over and over: Feb. 24, 1992. They had gathered for what was supposed to have been a celebration, an announcement by G.M. that their plant would stay open. The plant management had ordered 5,000 hot dogs, and the workers had built a stage for the victory speech.
But then, the disaster.
This is how Carla Pittman, a 36-year-old mother of two with 13 years' seniority at the plant, remembers it: "I have this picture in my mind of Doug and Kelly Arter," she said. "Kelly crying; Doug picking her up and hugging her. It was like, 'I've got you, it'll be O.K.' All I could think of was: 'I'm a single parent. Who's going to take care of me?' "
 Everyone -- auto analysts, labor reporters, top union officials -- had predicted that in the battle of the two plants, Willow Run would easily beat Arlington.
A bidding war of sorts was played out in the media, starting in December, when Mr. Stempel, the chairman, announced that production would be consolidated at one plant. Sales of large, rear-wheel-drive cars that both plants were making, like the Caprice, had been lagging badly.
Among other things, its location gave Willow Run a $325-a-car advantage in freight costs over Arlington, 1,000 miles southwest of Detroit. Its quality was highly rated. Only a few years ago, G.M. had invested $75 million in Willow Run.
Defying U.A.W. headquarters, the Arlington local voted for three-shift production, with nearly round-the-clock output, among other concessions.
Mr. Harlow said Willow Run had ruled out three-shift production as inefficient. "We sat down with the plant manager and asked if there was anything we had to do," he said. "He said: 'Everything is fine. There's no problem.' "
Mr. Stempel has denied U.A.W. accusations that he was pitting the two plants against each other. In deliberating, he said, G.M. took into account cost factors including overall efficiency and the flexibility of local union work rules.
Mr. Shaiken, the auto analyst, said G.M. had "set off a feeding frenzy over a game of musical jobs."
"Willow Run was a very cooperative plant," he said. "What makes this such a bitter experience for those workers is that they played by the rules, and the rules got switched. And nobody told them."
 
Recriminations
Plenty of Blame Is Passed Around
 The auto workers have all sorts of conspiracy theories about what happened. They blame President Bush along with Mr. Stempel; Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican, and the people who drive Japanese cars. They also blame the recently negotiated North American Free Trade Agreement, noting that American auto makers have been paying Mexican workers about $1 an hour for similar production work.
Last month, the President flew into the Willow Run airport, behind the plant, and was whisked to a rally with Governor Engler in nearby Canton, which bills itself as a recession-proof town.
Among 5,000 Republicans, many of whom wore coats and ties and dresses in the heat, Al Scutchfield, Fred Mosley, Carla Pittman and about 100 other auto workers, all supporters of Bill Clinton, were there in U.A.W. T-shirts that said, "Fed Up, Can't Take No More."
Mr. Bush pledged to save jobs for auto workers. The auto workers, who stood less than 75 yards from him, shouted: "What about Willow Run?" Whether the President did not hear them or chose to ignore them, he did not mention their plant.
As the auto workers kept shouting, the crowd around them grew hostile. Mr. Mosley was next to a boy of about 10.
The boy looked up at him and said, "Pick up your welfare check on the way out."
Mr. Mosley, whose father died of black lung after a life in the coal mines, has supported himself since he was 17. He says he takes enormous pride in building American cars.
"That hurt me bad," he said later. "I've never taken any handouts. I just want a job."

HEADLINE: Albert Rees, 71, Labor Economist And an Adviser to President Ford

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Albert Rees, a labor economist who was the chief inflation monitor in the Ford Administration, provost of Princeton University and president of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, died on Saturday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 71 years old.
He died of cancer that had spread from his kidneys to other parts of his body, said Justin Harmon, a spokesman for Princeton University. 
 Mr. Rees influenced a generation of labor economists with his analyses of wages, unemployment and labor markets. He was one of the first economists to conduct studies that compared the relative wealth of people in different eras.
He was also an expert in explaining how the Government's institutions of economic policy, like the Federal Reserve or the Treasury Department, interact as they juggle the conflicting goals of equality and efficiency, full employment and stable prices.
 
Led Wage and Price Council
 "He combined an interest and awareness of the importance of data with an ability and inclination to use it and economic theory to examine issues of public importance," said Daniel Hamermesh, an economics professor at Michigan State University in East Lansing. "He conditioned how we think about economic and labor history in this country."
Mr. Rees was appointed by President Ford in 1974 to lead the new Council on Wage and Price Stability, which was authorized by Congress at a time when the public was expressing alarm about the inflation rate. Mr. Rees believed that the council, which had a $1 million budget and was not allowed to take steps to lower inflation, was supposed to alert the Government and the public about sources of inflationary pressure, like shortages in a particular industry.
He was undaunted by criticism that the council would be overwhelmed by its mandate. He was asked after taking office, for instance, whether a small Government agency could have any effect on the price of an internationally traded commodity like sugar.
"I'm unwilling to concede that until I try," Mr. Rees replied with a smile.
Mr. Rees was born in New York City on Aug. 21, 1921. He graduated from Oberlin College and received his master's degree and his doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago. He became a full professor there in 1961 and served as chairman of the economics department from 1962 to 1966.
During his tenure at the University of Chicago, he served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the President's Committee to Appraise Employment and Unemployment Statistics.
After moving to Princeton in 1966, he held a number of positions, including chairman of the economics department and the Class of 1913 Professorship of Political Economy. He taught undergraduate and graduate courses on price theory and labor economics. He also served on advisory committees for the Federal Government and the State of New Jersey.
After leaving the Council on Wage and Price Stability in 1975, Mr. Rees returned to Princeton to serve as provost. In 1979, he was named president of the New York-based Sloan Foundation, which at that time had $250 million in assets and gave $15 million in grants a year. The foundation focuses on research in natural sciences, education, management and, to some degree, economics.
 
Wrote Landmark Labor Study
 Mr. Rees retired from the foundation in 1989, returning to Princeton as a senior research economist.
With George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of State and former dean of the University of Chicago School of Business, Mr. Rees was author of a landmark study, called the Chicago Labor Market Project, that was one of the first to collect and analyze data on the wages and employment conditions of individual workers.
Mr. Rees also wrote "Striking a Balance: Making National Economic Policy" (The University of Chicago Press, 1984), "The Economics of Work and Pay" (Harper & Row, 1973), "Workers and Wages in an Urban Labor Market" (with Mr. Shultz, The University of Chicago Press, 1970) and "The Economics of Trade Unions" (The University of Chicago Press, 1962).
Mr. Rees is survived by his wife, Marianne; three sons, David of Denver, Daniel of Kingston, Ontario, and Jonathan of Madison, Wis., and a sister, Anne Rees Held of Freeport, L.I.

HEADLINE: China Rushes From Mao to Markets

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
Perhaps the best-performing financial instrument in the world in 1992 has been a slip of white paper entitling the bearer to buy newly issued stocks on the Shanghai stock exchange. Sold early in the year for $5.50, by the summer these forms fetched nearly $300.
The soaring prices reflect the growing enthusiasm, bordering on desperation, of ordinary Chinese to become shareholders -- preferably rich ones. 
 After six years of on-and-off experimentation with shares, China is accelerating the development of a modern stock market. New companies are being listed each week, the number of investors is surging and hard-line critics have been muzzled.
 
Making a Transition
 "The ideological problems are basically resolved," Wei Wenyuan, the executive director of the stock exchange, said in an interview in an alcove above the trading floor.
A local stockbroker put it more bluntly. "We're in a transition to capitalism, conducted under the leadership of the Communist Party," he said.
That is hyperbole, for the number of stock companies make up only an infinitesimal proportion of the economy. But the stock market is emerging as a central element of the nation's economic reorganization, and popular support seems boundless.
In early August, more than a million would-be investors waited in line -- some for days -- to buy applications for stocks being issued in the southern city of Shenzhen. The applications cost $20 and had only a random 10 percent chance of being approved to buy shares. Even so, the potential investors rioted when the applications ran out.
Some 50,000 people rampaged through the streets, attacking police cars and shouting anti-Government slogans. The police fired tear gas and some gunshots, and there were unconfirmed reports that two people were killed.
 
Leadership Meets
 The clamor of a riot was not the kind of boom that reformers had hoped for. The Cabinet is said to have been worried as it met in the Zhongnanhai leadership compound in Beijing to watch secret police videotapes of the rioting, but so far there is no sign of a big slowdown in the move toward stocks.
"The Shenzhen incident was a problem arising at a technical level," said Wang Poming, the American-educated vice president of the Stock Exchange Executive Council of China. "It doesn't have anything to do with policy, or with the market itself. I don't see any major retreat from the shareholding system."
Mr. Wang said the rioting would probably lead to the establishment of a type of Securities and Exchange Commission to provide improved oversight.
China began to get excited about stocks late in 1986, and Shanghai and several other cities quickly set up rudimentary trading systems. A prominent economist, Li Yining, urged then that most of the nation's state-owned factories be turned into shareholder-owned companies.
 
A Popular Trend
 Progress was slow, however, partly because of the rise of the hard-liners at the time of the Tiananmen crackdown in June 1989. Shanghai opened a much more credible stock exchange in December 1990, and Shenzhen formally opened its own a few weeks later. Now other cities are frantically trying to get Beijing's approval to open exchanges, but the authorities are refusing on the basis that Shanghai and Shenzhen should be national markets.
Foreigners have also been invited to buy Chinese stocks through special "B shares" listed on both the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. Early this year, B shares were all the rage as investors dreamed of getting in on the ground floor of one of the most vibrant economies in the world.
Since then, the B share market has stalled, in part because the shares are relatively expensive and thinly traded.
"These are the ups and downs you get at the beginning of any emerging market," said Timothy Beardson, chairman of Crosby Securities Ltd. in Hong Kong. "China is going to have a very large stock market, one of the largest in the world, in our view. As the market gets bigger it'll get broader, and I think it's here to stay."
 
Foreigners Show Interest
 About 20 stock funds have been set up by Crosby and other foreign brokerage firms to buy Chinese equities, and Chinese companies are also trying to list directly on exchanges in the United States, Hong Kong and Australia.
The Shanghai market now lists 17 A share issues, for Chinese investors, along with 8 B shares. Mr. Wei, the exchange's head, says that by the end of the year there will be 50 A shares and 10 B shares.
Likewise, the number of seats on the exchange has risen to 212 from 46. Soon, there will be 600 seats.
Mr. Wei estimates that 1.2 million people -- a bit more than two-thirds from Shanghai and the rest scattered around the country -- have bought shares through the exchange. Among them are 10,000 to 20,000 professional investors, known as the dahu, who have $100,000 or more in their brokerage accounts.
 
Some Fortunes Made
 Some dahu -- the most famous is a Shanghai resident who goes by the name Millions Yang -- have made fortunes. For while B shares have been stagnating, the A shares traded by Chinese have been soaring.
"A fellow in my office put 5,000 yuan into Gold Cup Company shares a few years ago, and now it's worth 80,000 yuan," an envious official in Beijing said. Eighty thousand yuan is a bit less than $15,000.
These success stories have enticed more people into the market and created what is known here as "stock fever." Books about stocks are selling wildly, night schools on how to trade stocks have been set up in major cities, and newspapers are running columns on how to invest.
 
Ignoring the Fundamentals
 The only tactic that has not been tried has been analysis of fundamentals. Partly because of the unreliability of Chinese accounting, and partly because fundamentals do not matter as long as no one else looks at them either, trading often seems a bit divorced from reality. Price-earnings ratios exceed 100 for most Shanghai A shares, compared with a bit more than 10 for stocks in the less risky Hong Kong market.
Chinese investors seem to have a much clearer concept of upside potential than downside risk, even after a speculator lost $730 and committed suicide by electrocuting himself.
"What a numbskull," a Shanghai journalist said. "If he'd just waited, the market would have gone up again and he would have got his money back."
Restrictions on upward and downward movement of Shanghai stocks were lifted in May, and prices now generally follow the market. The first collapse came in Shanghai in August, with stocks abruptly plunging by nearly half. Some experts said the sharp selloff was a good thing, because it burned a few fingertips and chastened investors.
 
Talk of Intervention
 Officials insist that the authorities did not intervene in the market collapse, but the word among Chinese brokers and journalists is quite different. They say the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, telephoned the Shanghai party leader and asked for smooth trading in advance of a party Congress this fall.
When stock prices continued to slump, the exchange apparently halted trading for 20 minutes -- under the guise of a computer breakdown -- and ordered brokers to buy and support the market. The intervention worked, and prices have returned to their earlier range.
"Privatization" is still a taboo word in China, sending shivers down the spines of Communist hard-liners. But some younger officials use the term "going public" to suggest that share issues are just another form of public ownership.
 
Pace of Change Is Disputed
 "The key thing is that the Chinese have done it right," said William H. Overholt, executive director of the Bankers Trust Company in Hong Kong. "They've taken the time to create the institutional mechanisms for privatization before doing the privatization."
Some economists are impatient with China's relatively plodding steps, compared with the rapid changes in some former Communist countries. But others, including Mr. Overholt, say that China has prudently established a suitable foundation for capital markets.
"The East Europeans have done it utterly wrong, which is to rush pell-mell into reallocating the whole ownership and management of national productivity without having the institutional mechanisms in place to manage it properly," he said. "China will come out looking good."

HEADLINE: European Plane Plan Is in Trouble

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 6

 BODY:
This year's Farnborough Air Show, which opened today, was supposed to be an opportunity for Europe's aerospace industry to show off the European Fighter Aircraft, the region's most ambitious attempt yet to set aside national rivalries and cooperate in the development of an advanced warplane.
But only a mock-up of the fighter is here. The real thing has not yet flown, is months behind schedule and is suffering from a hemorrhaging of political support. And after spending six years and several billion dollars to design the aircraft, the four-nation European consortium behind the plane may never get a chance to produce anything but a handful of prototypes. 
 "Unless you're going to have a true technological breakthrough or somehow going to leapfrog what's already out there, it doesn't make any sense to invest in something new," said Kenneth Cannestra, the president of the Lockheed Corporation's aircraft-building division. "That's especially true when there are already airplanes out there that offer equal capability at the same or better price."
 
Plenty of Alternatives
 Of course, Mr. Cannestra is hardly a disinterested observer. Lockheed is but one of the American aircraft builders -- McDonnell Douglas, Boeing, General Dynamics and Northrop are all here -- hoping to capitalize on the European fighter's difficulties.
And the United States is not the only country dangling alternatives. France is completing work on its own new fighter, the Dassault Mirage. Sweden is aggressively trying to sell a lightweight, inexpensive fighter, the Gripen. And one of the biggest sales forces at Farnborough this year has come from Russia, which brought its MIG-29 and other aircraft, hoping for buyers among its former adversaries.
As a result, industry executives said, it may be difficult for the companies that make up the European Fighter Aircraft consortium to convince their governments that an all-European aircraft warrants investing another $40 billion in development and production of 400 or more planes.
The fighter program has become a case study in how difficult it can be to forge a consensus and maintain a common European approach to crucial economic and technological issues, even as Europe strives for a single market and greater political cooperation. The breakdown in the fighter program has increased the possibility that the participating nations will have to buy aircraft from the United States or elsewhere -- precisely the situation the European fighter was supposed to avoid.
 
Germany's Waning Interest
 The program suffered its biggest blow in June, when Germany decided that the plane was too costly, given the virtual disappearance of a military threat from the former Soviet Union. Germany said it would not proceed in moving from development of the plane into production, but stopped short of ending its participation in the program.
Instead, the German Defense Minister, Volker Ruhe, is pushing the other partners -- Britain, Italy and Spain -- to adopt a less expensive design, perhaps in conjunction with Sweden and France. But Britain and its main contractor on the program, British Aerospace P.L.C., are resisting, saying the fighter as currently designed is the best option for Britain's security needs and for maintaining a viable weapons industry.
Officials in Italy and Spain appear to be wavering. A decision is not expected on whether the program will proceed, or if so in what form, at least until the European defense ministers meet in November.
 
Trying to Save the Group
 Executives of Eurofighter G.m.b.H., the consortium of aerospace companies that manages the project, tried today to present an upbeat picture of the fighter's prospects.
"We are certain that we can offer adequate solutions to the aircraft replacement requirements of the four nations as they will be defined by the ministers," said Roberto Mannu, the consortium's chairman. He and other executives of Eurofighter said they were preparing possible cost-cutting measures and design refinements in an attempt to hold the four nations together on the project.
The Eurofighter consortium is made up of British Aerospace (a 33 percent owner), Daimler-Benz A.G.'s Deutsche Aerospace unit (33 percent), Alenia of Italy (21 percent) and Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain (13 percent).
 
U.S. Makers See Opportunities
 But for the military contractors from the United States and other nations who gathered here to sell their products, the growing doubts about the E.F.A., as the plane is known, have been encouraging news. If the European aircraft program dies, analysts said, Germany will almost certainly consider buying FA-18 fighters, which are built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in St. Louis and the Northrop Corporation in Southern California. Italy and Spain, they said, might also consider the FA-18 or the F-16, which is manufactured by the General Dynamics Corporation in Fort Worth.
The team -- Lockheed, Boeing and General Dynamics -- building the United States Air Force's F-22, its next-generation fighter, has informally discussed whether it could develop a less-advanced version that the Pentagon would permit to be exported.
 
Britain's Last Hope
 But in Europe, as in the United States, military procurement decisions often rest on political factors and issues of national pride. In Britain especially, the E.F.A. is seen as the last best hope for maintaining a world-class aerospace industry. British Aerospace, the mainstay of the industry here, has been pulling back from its commercial businesses, including commuter aircraft, and is banking heavily on the new fighter to maintain the company's size and technical abilities.
Any purchase of a foreign plane "would significantly damage our engineering base in the U.K., and our ability to provide the sort of support that we provided to the front-line fighting forces during their involvement in both the Falklands and the gulf war," John P. Weston, the managing director of British Aerospace's military division, said last week.
Mr. Weston said British Aerospace believed it could build the plane on its own, to supply the Royal Air Force and export markets, even if the other nations abandon the program after the completion of the $10 billion development phase in the next few years.
 
Political Support
 "We've started as a four-nation program and we hope to keep it that way," Mr. Weston said. "But technologically, there is nothing in the airplane we couldn't do in the U.K. if we had to."
The program is supported by all three major political parties in Britain, who are loath to risk the loss of employment that would come with a decision to shelve the E.F.A. The same factors are being weighed by Government officials in Germany, Italy and Spain.
"Clearly, the Europeans face the same situation you face in the United States, and it's a four-letter word called jobs," said Howard Rubel, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc.

HEADLINE: Fed Action Is Limited By Dollar

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
In cutting a key interest rate on Friday, the Federal Reserve was seeking to walk a tightrope, trying to nudge the nation's economy gently forward without pushing the dollar off a cliff.
The dollar has slipped to record lows against the German mark in recent weeks, principally because short-term interest rates are so much lower in the United States than in Germany. And some analysts fear that the Fed's quarter-point reduction in the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks make overnight loans to each other -- could accelerate the dollar's decline. 
 While the latest interest rate cut was sought by the Bush Administration, especially by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the reduction runs the risk of hurting President Bush if it sends the dollar to new lows and spreads turmoil in the stock and bond markets. Mr. Brady favors a weak dollar to help increase exports of American products, though it can help spur inflation by raising the price of imports.
 
Not Generating Jobs
 Still, many economists say that in reducing the Federal funds rate to 3 percent from 3.25 percent, the Fed did what it had to do to lift the long-languishing economy. The Fed pumped money into the banking system on Friday to lower the Federal funds rate just hours after the Labor Department released a dismal employment report, showing that American business lost 167,000 jobs in August.
"The economy is still not generating enough jobs, and the Fed had little choice but to show that it is in an easing mode," said Scott E. Pardee, a former Federal Reserve economist who is now chairman of Yamaichi International America. "But to the extent the dollar continues to decline or goes into free fall, that could become a serious political issue for the Bush Administration."
In an appearance today on the ABC program "This Week with David Brinkley," Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, predicted the dollar would not fall much further and said the Bundesbank, the German central bank, was largely to blame for the dollar's weakness.
"I wouldn't expect a flight from the dollar," he said, adding that investors would not pull out of the dollar because the United States still has the world's leading economy.
Mr. Darman said the Bundesbank was weakening the dollar by keeping German interest rates high.
Economists said that the interest rate cut on Friday appeared to be the first instance in which the dollar's weakness had constrained the central bank's flexibility since Alan Greenspan became chairman in August 1987.
David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities firm, said that were it not for the dollar's dive, the Fed might have cut rates as boldly on Friday as it did on July 2, when the Labor Department issued another disastrous jobs report. On that day, the Fed made cuts of a half of a percentage point in the Federal funds rate and the discount rate -- the rate it charges on direct loans to banks. The discount rate is currently at 3 percent.
"Were it not for the threat of a dollar crisis, the Fed might have been more aggressive today," Mr. Jones said on Friday. "The dollar has become an effective limit on how much further the Fed could ease."
Among foreign exchange traders, there has been talk in recent weeks that if the dollar went into a free fall, the Fed might be forced to raise rates, which would buttress the dollar by helping attract investment dollars into the United States. But a rate increase is one of the last things President Bush wants, since it could further slow economic growth, and the nearly stalled economy could well prove his downfall.
The dollar fell sharply against the German mark on Friday, but remained above record lows. It closed at 1.4015 marks on Friday, down from 1.4135 late on Thursday.
 
Help From Italy and Britain
 The dismaying jobs report and rate cut hurt the dollar, but analysts said its slide was slowed by economic maneuvering in Europe that was aimed at keeping the mark from soaring against other currencies. Italy raised its interest rates to buoy the sagging lira, while Britain arranged to borrow $14.5 billion worth of marks from Germany to prop up the pound.
The flight from dollars toward marks has strengthened the German currency against not only the dollar, but also the lira and pound, which are in danger of sinking below the floor set by the European Monetary System, an arrangement of linked exchange rates.
Analysts suggested that the Fed chose to lower the Federal funds rate instead of the more visible discount rate to reduce the chances of creating turmoil in the currency markets.
The jobs report on Friday was one of several recent reports indicating new softness in the economy. The various data have led more and more analysts to talk about the possibility of a triple dip -- that is, a third dip toward recession. The reports include a drop in factory orders, a drop in consumer confidence and weak department store sales.
Economists said that the Federal Reserve's quarter-point easing would have only a slight stimulative effect and that the effect would probably not be felt for at least four months.
"The Federal funds rate has been cut almost 700 basis points over the past few years, and these cuts have done surprisingly little to stimulate the economy," said Norman Robertson, chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "So I fear that the new rate cut won't do any good at all." A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
"I suspect it might have been made to defuse political pressure," Mr. Robertson added, "to avoid the accusation that the Fed was ignoring the plight of the economy."
 
Some Question Impact
 After the recovery that began in early 1991 stumbled late last year, Administration officials and many economists blamed the Fed for not cutting rates faster, saying it was not being attentive enough to the economy's problems.
Just as some economists said the rate cut on Friday might be too small to help the economy much, some said it was so small that it might not hurt the dollar much. Several economists asked what difference a quarter-point rate cut would make when the spread is already almost 7 percent between short-term American and German rates.
With the Fed's ability to cut rates hamstrung by the dollar's weakness, many economists say there will be increasing pressure within the Administration and Congress to embrace fiscal stimulus -- like increased spending on public works -- notwithstanding the nation's $350 billion budget deficit.
In the view of many Fed watchers, the Fed may be tempted to lower rates further in the next few weeks, but they said the central bank probably first wanted to see whether the dollar steadies or sinks further.
Many American officials hope Germany's central bank will soon lower rates to stop the dollar's fall, steady the markets and lift Europe's economy. While some economists predict that the Bundesbank will lower rates in the next few months because Germany's economy is slumping, others say the German central bank is intent on keeping rates high for a long time to make sure inflation returns to less than 3 percent.
"I think the combination of the falling U.S. interest rates, political uncertainty and an economy that is going nowhere will keep downward pressure on the dollar," Mr. Robertson said.

HEADLINE: Air-Conditioner Sales Hurt by a Mild Summer

 BODY:
Labor Day pretty much brings down the final curtain on what has been a dismal summer for manufacturers and retailers of air-conditioners, who rank high among the very few people who pine for the sweltering dog days.
Despite a late-August wave of brow-wiping heat and humidity, most of the summer in the Northeast and Midwest -- which constitute 60 percent of the air-conditioner market -- has had mild temperatures. And that, coupled with the continued weak economy, has held back sales. 
 Sears, Roebuck & Company has seen its sales dwindle in all regions except the West Coast. While the company declined to release specific numbers, Greg Rossiter, a spokesman, said sales had been very soft.
 
Sales Slow Despite Advertising
 "We've been very aggressive in our advertising, but sales still have not come back," Mr. Rossiter said.
William Trawick, vice president of P. C. Richard & Son, which has 28 showrooms in the New York metropolitan area, said sales were down 10 percent from a year ago.
"Even last summer, when there were a number of 90-degree days, we did not have a very strong season," Mr. Trawick said. "This year, we've fallen even further behind."
Discount sales "haven't made much difference," he said. "If there's no heat out there, people just aren't interested in buying air-conditioners. We'll just have to store them away until next year."
Small stores have been especially hard hit.
Alan Rosengarten, president of Ace Air Conditioning Service Corporation in Astoria, Queens, which has been in the business for more than 35 years, said sales were about half of last year's.
"It's been a rather bad season," Mr. Rosengarten said. "You almost have to give them away, the profit margin is so low. There just weren't enough days of heat, even with the past few hot, muggy days."
Analysts say manufacturers' shipments during the first six months of 1992 dropped to the lowest first-half volume since 1986.
 
Sales Are Tied to Weather
 Mary Gillespie, assistant director of communications at the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, said sales in the industry were inseparably tied to weather conditions.
The 2.4 million units shipped so far this year are within 1 percent of shipments for the comparable period in 1991, Ms. Gillespie said. "There is little movement along the chain, from manufacturer to retailer," she said.
The decision to buy an air-conditioner is often made in the early spring, she said, and now, with other demands on the family budget -- like children's return to school -- few consumers are likely to be shopping for air-conditioners.
The weak sales this year led some manufacturers and retailers to reduce their work forces.
To cut costs and increase operating profits, for instance, the Fedders Corporation, the largest room air-conditioner manufacturer in the United States, announced in August that it would close its New Jersey production operations in Woodbridge and Dover and lay off 600 employees. The company also said it would sell its Maryland compressor plant and consolidate production at its plants in Illinois and Tennessee.
Fedders, based in Peapack, N.J., had revenue of $186 million in the first half of 1991, down 14 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. In 1990 Fedders had a market share of 30 percent, according to Appliance magazine. The company's profit in the first half of 1991 plunged nearly 75 percent to $4.1 million. For the first nine months of this year, the company reported sales of $157 million and a net loss of $6.6 million.
 
Slack Demand Brings Layoffs
 Sal Giordano Jr., the chief executive of Fedders, said the restructuring "is designed to significantly lower break-even volume in the face of continuing low demand, by reducing excess capacity and fixed costs."
Gerry Beatty, the major appliance editor at Home Furnishings Daily, said the poor sales climate had been especially tough on Fedders because it manufactured only air-conditioners. "It was like having all of their eggs in one basket," he said. "They didn't have the advantage of having other appliance sales to fall back on."
But Fedders is hardly alone in feeling pain.
The Whirlpool Corporation in Benton Harbor, Mich., is having a "less than average year" in room air-conditioner sales, said Carolyn Verweyst, manager of marketing communications.
Sales were "very regionalized," she said. "In the South and Southwest, we did very well. But the Midwest had no summer at all. We are well below average." The company declined to release specific figures.
Home Furnishings Daily said the Northeast and Midwest accounted for about 60 percent of total sales of room air-conditioners. Temperatures have been as much as 5 to 10 degrees below normal in these usually high-volume areas.
Mr. Beatty said the number of air-conditioners sold this year would be only about 50 percent of the number manufactured, compared with 80 to 85 percent in a good year. The unsold stock is returned to manufacturers and dealers, who often retain the merchandise until the next season or run special sales.
About 27 million homes have one or more air-conditioners, according to Air Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration News, a weekly trade publication.
 
A Diversified Manufacturer
 At the Carrier Corporation in Farmington, Conn., a decrease in sales of air-conditioners in the United States has been offset by increased sales in Europe and the Middle East. Carrier also makes central air systems, commercial systems and transportation refrigeration equipment, products that tend to be less dependent on hot weather for sales. Room air-conditioners account for less than 10 percent of the company's business.
"It has been a tough year," said John Sandberg, a spokesman for Carrier. "But our earnings have been strengthened by sales of our other air- conditioning systems."
With an estimated $1.2 billion in wholesale revenue, the industry is dominated by nine major companies, which account for 99 percent of unit sales. The industry peaked in 1989 with 5.1 million shipments of room air-conditioners, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, and has been losing steam since, dropping to its lowest level since 1986. In 1990 the industry shipped about 4.2 million units.
"We've probably reached something close to a saturation point in terms of households," Mr. Beatty of Home Furnishings Daily said. "Now the question becomes what do you do to stimulate sales. And the answer is just pray for heat."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Weakness At The Top

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
A Conservative member of the British Parliament, vacationing in America, watched the Republican Convention on television. Afterward, he said he understood the far-out character of the speeches, their right-wing extremism.
"There are speeches like that at our party meetings," he said. "Labor has its 'loony left.' We have the hangers [demanding restoration of capital punishment]. But no Prime Minister -- no Government -- adopts their policies." 
 Yes, British politics has its extreme voices. But there the analogy ends. For in this country the extreme right does not just talk. President Bush listens, and obeys.
Appointments to the Supreme Court are among the most important actions of any President. In the Bush years those appointments have been cleared with the anti-abortion movement and other elements of the right.
Appointments to all the Federal courts have been subject to ideological screening of a kind never seen before. The Justice Department and the White House have taken zealous care to pick men and women -- not many women, and virtually no blacks -- who can be expected to follow the radical legal ideas of contemporary American conservatism.
And ideological tests are not just for judges. Mr. Bush's current Attorney General, William Barr, offered a job as Assistant Attorney General to a Republican Wall Street lawyer -- and then withdrew the offer to him because the radical right thought he might be too protective of environmental regulation.
Then there is Mr. Bush's subservience to the right on the issue of abortion. He approved a Republican platform that calls for outlawing all abortions, even when pregnancy is the result of rape or incest. Only the most extreme right-to-lifers, a small minority of Americans, take that position. Mr. Bush could easily have modified it. He did not.
Moreover, he vetoed a bill to create a fetal tissue bank for use in promising research on such grave illnesses as Parkinson's Disease. He said it would encourage abortions. Even some members of Congress strongly opposed to abortion disagreed.
Mr. Bush's fanatical anti-abortion policy is especially striking because everyone knows it is an entirely opportunist position, not one based on a strongly held personal belief. He used to argue in favor of a woman's right to choose, but he turned his coat when he was Ronald Reagan's Vice Presidential candidate in 1980.
There is the real key to the power of the right in the Republican Party and Administration: the pliancy -- the weakness -- of George Bush. He seems to lack the internal values that from time to time make a political leader say No.
Four years ago Mr. Bush promised to give us a kinder, gentler America. I rather thought he meant it -- meant that the hard edge of conservatism in the Reagan years would be softened, that his Administration would move toward the center.
What we have instead is a politics of hate, exemplified by speakers the Bush people chose to feature at the Republican Convention: Pat Buchanan, Phil Gramm and Pat Robertson, who says feminism "encourages women to leave their husbands, kill their children, practice witchcraft, destroy capitalism and become lesbians."
This election will probably turn on the fact that Mr. Bush has brought us "the worst economic times since the Great Depression," as Pete Wilson, the Republican Governor of California, put it the other day. But the lack of character that makes Mr. Bush bend to every wind from the right is really more important.
Other Republican Presidents of the modern era have handled the right without letting it run the show. Dwight Eisenhower did. Richard Nixon did. Gerald Ford did. On crucial questions of law and social policy, George Bush has caved in.
Now Mr. Bush is portraying himself as Harry Truman. It would be hard to imagine a more grotesquely inappropriate notion.
President Truman was a man with roots, firm in his views, without pretension. When he finished his term in office, he went home to Independence, Mo., where James Reston of The New York Times found him putting his suitcases in the attic. Mr. Bush is so rootless that he claims a hotel room in Houston as his legal residence.
Harry Truman knew who he was. George Bush hasn't a clue.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
