HEADLINE: Now About Job Training for the Other Workers;
Schooling and Earnings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Twins Study Shows School Is Sound Investment" (Education page, Aug. 19), you report that Orly Ashenfelter and Alan Kreuger found a 16 percent rise in earnings for each additional year of schooling. Readers should not too quickly conclude that keeping this country's youth in school for ever lengthier periods will bring us out of our economic morass. 
 There are reasons to question that 16 percent figure. The researchers, despite controlling shared genes and family background, apparently do not hold constant measures of cognitive ability, which may directly influence both length of schooling and eventual earnings. Omitting such measures, even in a sample of twins, can result in a spuriously large association between education and earnings.
Studies suggest that the value added by each additional year of education varies by both the level of schooling (secondary versus college), and by whether or not a diploma or degree is conferred.
More important, however, is the question of why individuals with more schooling earn more. Robert Reich and John Bishop, whom you quote, share the belief, widespread among economists, that earnings differences among individuals whose educational attainment differs arise from differences in productivity attributable to schooling.
If this were true, raising average educational attainment would increase both individual earnings and gross national product. But if education serves primarily to screen potentially more productive workers from potentially less productive workers, then increasing average education only weakens the value of the screen and makes the costs of using schooling to identify more productive workers more expensive.
Worse, if educational credentials are, as many sociologists suspect, used to some extent to satisfy the irrational tastes and preferences of employers and society for traits that are not necessarily related to productivity, then, from a strictly economic point of view, increasing levels of schooling simply wastes society's resources, though it may distribute credentials more equally.
No doubt each of these propositions is to some extent true. Studies suggest that lengthier schooling raises academic achievement, and that academic achievement is associated with increased earnings. Nevertheless, while the relevance of more and better schooling to economic growth should not be entirely discounted, we should not expect education to prove to be a great panacea for business and governmental misdirection and folly.
 
MICHAEL R. OLNECK
Prof. of Educational Policy
Studies and Sociology
University of Wisconsin
Madison, Wis., Aug. 24, 1992

HEADLINE: Now About Job Training for the Other Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was good news for a country battered by a faltering economy when the Presidential candidates began debating job training (Aug. 25, front page). It would be better news, however, if their job training and education proposals addressed the needs of all Americans who need assistance, not just a select group. 
 When President Bush announced his job training proposal, he said we "cannot afford to waste the talent of one single worker." He is right. But Mr. Bush's plan would primarily serve workers who have lost or will lose their jobs, generally because of the United States trade agreement with Canada and Mexico or because of cuts in military spending. But women who find themselves in the job market after years in the home, older Americans, people with disabilities and the long-term unemployed have job training needs that are every bit as urgent.
The plan proposed by Gov. Bill Clinton in his economic strategy for America seems designed to offer broader access to education and job training. It would establish a national trust fund that, it appears, would be accessible to more Americans. But Governor Clinton's plan is too general to assess thoroughly.
Millions of Americans want and need job training to earn a living wage. Among them are 16 million women who, after years of caring for families, must suddenly find paying jobs when they are widowed, divorced or their spouses lose their jobs -- they are displaced homemakers.
In a year in which "family values" is a central campaign issue, displaced homemakers should not be ignored. Women who have taken time to raise families need access to job training.
 
JILL MILLER
Executive Director, National
Displaced Homemakers Network
Washington, Aug. 27, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
BUSH AND CLINTON PULL NO PUNCHES IN HOLIDAY RALLIES

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton opened their fall campaigns yesterday with a struggle over the mantle of Harry S. Truman: Mr. Bush said Mr. Clinton lacked the character to claim it; Mr. Clinton asserted that Mr. Bush was destroying the very middle class that President Truman had helped to create.
Mr. Clinton chose Truman's hometown, Independence, Mo., for the Labor Day kickoff to his campaign, presenting himself as the committed champion of "the great American middle class" in the Truman tradition. In a rousing speech delivered on the courthouse steps in a heavy rain, Mr. Clinton assailed Mr. Bush as a man who did not recognize the nation's economic suffering, its aspirations or its needs, and who had no right to claim political kinship with the Democratic President from Missouri, as Mr. Bush has done in recent weeks. 
 "Harry Truman did not wake up every morning worrying about how to lower taxes one more time on millionaires," Mr. Clinton declared. "Harry Truman gave the special interests hell. George Bush is giving it to you, and it's time you took your future back."
 
Sparring in the Midwest
 Mr. Bush, campaigning at a picnic in Waukesha, Wis., acknowledged that it was an uncertain time in the global economy, but he accused Mr. Clinton of trying "to scare American workers so that he can slip into office with that failed tax-and-spend policy of the past."
The President, who has frequently called up the memory of Truman's come-from-behind victory in recent weeks, talked yesterday of Truman's leadership traits, and asserted that Mr. Clinton fell far short of them. Opening a new line of Republican attack, an energized Mr. Bush declared: "Harry Truman was a man of decisiveness, not equivocation. He'd find little in common with Governor Clinton, a man who hedges or ducks on almost every tough issue."
Mr. Bush also mounted an indirect attack on Mr. Clinton's lack of military service during the Vietnam War, an issue that has dogged the Governor from Arkansas in recent days and that prompted an angry outburst from him yesterday morning. Accusing reporters of engaging in a "feeding frenzy" over an old issue, Mr. Clinton asserted it was time for them to direct their aggressiveness toward Mr. Bush and the Iran-contra affair. [Page A17.]
The day's exchanges came as Mr. Clinton campaigned in Missouri and Ohio before ending the day in Connecticut, and Mr. Bush roared through Wisconsin and Michigan, all considered important swing states this fall. While Labor Day has traditionally marked the start of the general election campaign, the tone of the day underscored a struggle that has been going on for weeks.
The Truman debate arises in a year when voters, implicitly or explicitly, seem to be looking for plain-spoken, truth-telling leadership. Ross Perot evoked many comparisons to Truman earlier this year. And Mr. Bush, when his poll ratings sank this summer, began comparing himself to Truman, who in 1948 won re-election against the odds by beating Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York. Mr. Clinton sought yesterday to reclaim the popular memory of Truman for the Democrats.
Beyond the battle over Truman, the day offered a case study in the themes expected to dominate the next 56 days. Mr. Bush argued that his domestic plans have been stymied by a "gridlock Congress," that he was committed to ensuring "economic security" in his next Administration, and that the nation was on the mend and on the rise.
 
'Beneath the Rhetoric'
 "My opponent will kick off his campaign with a message of fear," said Mr. Bush, who began a full day of campaigning with a walk across a five-mile bridge in upper Michigan, and pressed the flesh with gusto along the rope lines this afternoon. But he urged voters "to look beneath the rhetoric and look at the facts."
Campaigning later in Hamtramck, Mich., where he marched in a Polish-American parade, Mr. Bush also defended his emphasis on foreign policy in his first term.
"There are those who tell me that foreign policy doesn't matter," Mr. Bush declared to an audience composed heavily of Polish and other Eastern European-Americans. "I say, tell that to the immigrants of America. Tell that to our children, who can sleep free of the nuclear nightmare and dream the sweet dream of peace."
Mr. Clinton argued that the nation was at a turning point and badly needed a new economic course. "This election provides Americans their clearest choice in a generation," he declared in Missouri. "A choice between hope and fear, between running in place and moving ahead, between more of the same old trickle down and embarking on a new course to guarantee old opportunities in the American Dream."
Mr. Clinton dismissed the Republicans' charge that his election would mean a throwback to "tax and spend" liberalism. "We've got to go beyond trickle-down economics," he said, "not back to tax and spend, but ahead to invest, and educate, and cooperate, and compete, and grow -- putting people first."
In recalling Truman, he said the former President had left as a legacy "the great American middle class," which he described as "the generation of Americans who went to college because of the G.I. Bill, who were able to buy a home because of F.H.A. and V.A. mortgages, who raised my generation with the hope and the opportunity that all things were possible."
"George Bush's legacy." he said, "is the destruction of that very middle class."
He added: "He has blamed his failures on everything from the Federal Reserve to Saddam Hussein, from Congress to consumers to the press. He says the recession is really over; we just don't know it. And if it's not really over, it is because we have an attitude problem. The buck doesn't stop with George Bush; it doesn't even slow down there."
 
'Waffling and Wavering'
 Mr. Bush, speaking earlier in the day in Wisconsin, set up his own Truman test. He noted that the Missouri Democrat knew what it meant to be a businessman and a political underdog, "and so do I."
The President then proceeded to mine a vulnerability that has caused problems for Mr. Clinton in the past: the charge that he is a straddler. "Whether it was the Soviet blockade of Berlin or the invasion of Korea, Harry Truman never flinched from the tough decision," Mr. Bush said. "Contrast that with Governor Clinton's waffling and wavering about whether he would have followed my lead and stood up to Saddam Hussein and his naked aggression."
Mr. Clinton managed to escape the rain at his second stop of the day, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. rally in Cincinnati, where he was joined by his running mate, Senator Al Gore. Hillary Clinton, who was at the rally as well, received the longest and most sustained applause of the event.
 
Vice-Presidential Campaigning
 Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, spent part of his day at an event that captured the party's traditions: a rally in downtown Detroit, attended by Owen Bieber, the head of the United Automobile Workers, Mayor Coleman Young, and a host of other Democratic luminaries. Mr. Gore said the steel in the bridge that Mr. Bush had crossed in Michigan that morning was made at a U.S. Steel plant shut down earlier this year.
"Mr. Bush, you can walk across the bridge for a photo opportunity, but you've got to be thinking about the jobs of the people who built that bridge that you just put out of work," Mr. Gore declared.
Vice President Quayle, who had begun a Western swing in Colorado, criticized Mr. Gore, asserting that his rival's environmental policies would lead to higher taxes.
Mr. Quayle also told an enthusiastic audience at Mesa State College that Mr. Clinton had chosen as his running mate a man who was, when it came to spending, "bigger than Ted Kennedy, bigger than Howard Metzenbaum, bigger than Tim Wirth." Mr. Quayle also said that President Bush realized that raising taxes was a mistake, and the Democrats "just don't get it."

A1); President Bush getting a glimpse of the crowd from backstage at a Republican Party picnic in Milwaukee. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A16)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: Ruin in the Groves of Florida: Growers May Never Recover

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla.

 BODY:
Harvey Bullis stepped through the hole where his picture window used to be and stared out at 18 acres where $2 million worth of bromeliads, spiky pineapple-like plants, once bloomed. Now thousands lay scorching in the sun, amid the rubble of eight collapsed shade houses.
"There isn't a salable plant on the property," Mr. Bullis said of his crop. "But see this pup here?" He picked up a battered specimen and pointed to a little green shoot poking out of the crusted potting soil. "I could get 25 new plants off this one -- if the sun and the salt from the storm doesn't kill them. In a year, I might have something to sell." 
 Mr. Bullis's chances are not good. With broken irrigation lines, no power to pump water and no relief money in sight, Mr. Bullis, like 1,600 other nursery operators, fruit growers and farmers in Dade County, has little hope of saving what is left.
 
Why Plant at All?
 State agriculture officials estimate that Hurricane Andrew damaged $1 billion worth of crops, foliage plants and towering 40-foot palms. It smashed into processing plants, flinging off metal roofing and twisting it around trees like so much aluminum foil. It blew salt spray over vegetable fields four miles inland, making planting a bad gamble until scientists test the soil.
These farmers are desperate to get going again. But even if they get a crop by late fall, the packing industry is virtually paralyzed. Brooks Tropicals, the largest fruit producer in Florida, lost 45 percent of its buildings. The Florida City State Farmer's Market, which packs $58 million worth of vegetables a year, sustained $9 million in damages.
"We have to get back on line by the 15th of November," said Joe Mitchell, who manages the Farmer's Market. "If the farmer can't process his materials, why plant?"
 
Exotics Are Today's Debris
 While state and Federal officials say emergency funds are on the way, there is no money now for rebuilding and replanting. Because crop insurance is prohibitively expensive, only 5 percent of Dade County farmers have coverage; almost no nurseries do.
Even before Hurricane Andrew, there were serious problems. Growers were staggering from the $360 million in damages caused by the Du Pont Company's fungicide Benlate, which was recalled because it harmed crops, and 120 claims remain unsettled.
They were also recovering from the 1989 freeze that destroyed $500 million worth of winter crops. And this year promised to be a bumper crop. Then came the hurricane, which ripped through 6,000 acres of lime trees, 20,000 acres of avocados and 10,000 acres of other crops: mangoes and lichee nuts, carambolas, papayas and other exotic fruits. When the winds died down, more than $74 million worth of tropical fruits lay rotting on the ground.
For the growers, the timing couldn't be worse. They are already struggling to compete with inexpensive fruits and vegetables flowing in from Mexico, and the pending North American Free Trade Agreement, which will reduce tariffs, will make the Mexican produce even cheaper.
 
A Drop in the Cocktail Glass
 "You can produce malanga here for $8 a box; you can produce it in Mexico and deliver it here for $2 a box," Tom Kirby, the government affairs director at the Dade County Farm Bureau, said of a tropical root vegetable. "I'm afraid people are going to just settle up and get out. Why even bother to put crops in the ground?"
For the most part, the economic impact on the consumer should be minimal, according to industry leaders. The exception is the price of limes: Dade County produces 95 percent of the American crop. For everything from avocados to ficus trees, the nation will find other sources in California, Mexico and the rest of Florida, said Nelson Pew, a spokesman for Florida's Commissioner of Agriculture, Robert Crawford.
So while the rest of the country sips its gin and tonic at a slightly higher price and may have to pay a bit more for a bromeliad, the growers of Dade County have lost family businesses and fortunes that might never be recovered.
Bullis Bromeliads got its start 20 years ago, when Harvey Bullis's father, a marine biologist, found a single bromeliad growing in a conch shell in the house he had just bought.
 
Rare Green Treasures Lost
 "He pulled it out and put it in a pot, and it bloomed," Mr. Bullis said as he stared at his devastated fields. "After that, he started collecting." Soon he had a little business going, and his son, tired of commercial fishing, joined him. Bromeliads, members of the pineapple family, are known for their stiff, leathery leaves and spikes of bright flowers.
"I love them," he said. "I love their diversity, their colors, the foliage and flowers, the ease with which they grow." His wife, Patricia, who was born in Argentina, has collected many new species from South America, in the jungles of Peru and Ecuador.
"She has been doing the hybridizing and we had about a dozen new varieties that were priceless," said Mr. Bullis. "We have some tissue cultures in a lab, but some of them are gone forever." In 20 years, the family had built a $2 million business selling 300 varieties domestically and throughout the world.
But as Mr. Bullis, the father of two young children, led the way through his windowless house, pointing out the holes in the roof, the torn furniture, the fungus already growing on the kitchen ceiling, he said: "My wife hasn't seen this yet. I don't know if she'll be able to take it. She might go back to Argentina with the kids."
 
Harvest of Unemployment
 His father went north to rent a generator and two motor homes and to tell the family, which had fled to Ocala before the storm, that the three who had stayed behind were safe. Harvey and his parents and their black Labrador waited out the storm huddled for hours in a stairwell.
Now Harvey Bullis worked alone because his 21 employees, like everyone else, were struggling to piece together their own lives. But their jobs are not destined to last.
"I can keep them on for a few weeks cleaning up, but after that, I won't need that many people," said Mr. Bullis.
He wants to get back in business. He wants those 21 employees back at work. "But we need low-interest loans and disaster relief to help us," he said. "If not, we'll only be small-time operators. Under the best conditions, it will take five years to get back where we were."
 
Ripped From the Ground
 Fifty blocks north, at a 40-acre fruit grove, Daniel and Jane Lyons, who have four children, told a similar story. "This grove never looked better before the storm," Mr. Lyons said as he stood in the middle of a 10-acre mango grove. "Now it's totaled." The trees lay ripped out of the ground, their sheared-off roots and leafless branches drying up in the sun.
"We put 15 years of our life into this grove," he said. "And an investment of $550,000." There were 3,000 fruit trees on the Lyons place. "I planted every one myself so it would be done right," Mr. Lyons said.
A younger 10-acre grove of mangoes on the Lyons property fared better; some could be replanted. But like the workers at so many other nurseries and groves, the family's crew had gone north. "They wanted to help, but they lived at the Everglades Labor Camp, and now their houses are gone," explained Mrs. Lyons. "All those people have gotten on buses to Pennsylvania and Michigan."
Now the Lyonses -- like their fellow growers -- fear that there will be no Government money to help them rebuild. "We went to the Farm Bureau," said Mrs. Lyons, "and asked about disaster relief, but there isn't any for trees in hurricanes. They said all that was being discussed, but by the time anything happens, these trees will be dead."
 
Recovery Could Take Years
 And so an adjacent 6-year-old grove of tossed-up lichee-nut trees -- which can bring $20,000 to an acre -- lies burning up in the sun. "We set the price on lichees, because Mexican lichees are not as high quality," said Mr. Lyons.
Earl Wells, executive vice president of the Florida Nurserymen and Growers Association, said: "Unless there's some special appropriation of some sort, there will be very little money available for Dade County. Even with Federal cleanup money, the maximum that a grower can get is $200,000, but a lot of growers have a lot more expenses than that."
Climate still favors the nursery business in Dade County, he said. "But it may take 10 years to bring it back. And I doubt it will ever be as big as it was."

HEADLINE: German Pledge Calms European Markets

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
A weekend pledge by Germany's central bank to keep interest rates steady helped calm Europe's jangled financial markets yesterday. And in Japan, stock prices fell today after dropping yesterday.
The Bundesbank made its promise on Saturday at a meeting of the European Community's finance ministers and central bank governors. The announcement appeared to signal an end to a trend of rising German rates. The rate increases have served to stifle economic recovery in other European nations and caused declines in the dollar's value. 
 But the foreign exchange markets chose to focus yesterday on the Bundesbank's resistance to calls to reduce Germany's high interest rates, not just keep them steady.
"Although it's nice to have, the pledge doesn't have that much effect," one Japanese bank dealer said. "The big question is when they are going to cut interest rates."
A huge gap between high German rates and low rates in the United States has driven the dollar to all-time lows against the mark and put other European currencies under pressure.
But the Labor Day holiday in the United States and Canada helped to keep currency trading quiet. The American dollar held fairly steady, being quoted at 1.4030 marks and 123.48 yen at the European close, compared with 1.4015 marks and 123.10 yen on Friday in New York.
With United States and Canadian stock exchanges closed, trading of equities was generally quiet yesterday.
Stocks were lower today in Japan. An the close of the trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues had lost 157.76 points, or 0.86 percent, to finish at 18,282.42. Yesterday, the Nikkei closed 115.12 points lower on profit taking and index-related selling as investors began to worry that the recent rally had run out of steam.
In Europe, traders are expected to remain cautious while awaiting a French referendum on the Maastricht treaty for a closer European union. The vote is set for Sept. 20.
Yesterday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues rose 10 points to close at 2,372.2. Trading was light, and follow-through buying failed to materialize after the futures market proved strong and the pound steadied.
French stocks also took early comfort from the Bundesbank pledge. But the effect was diluted by profit taking after strong gains last week. The CAC 40-share index closed just 0.32 point higher, at 1,779.30.
In Frankfurt, German shares were brought off early highs by worries about squabbles in the Bonn coalition Government over financing for economic improvements in the former East Germany. The 30-share DAX index ended 4.13 points higher, at 1,540.63.
Gold closed at $342.15 an ounce in London, up from $341.10 on Friday.
In oil markets, the October delivery contract for Brent blend, an international benchmark, was up eight cents at $20.27 a barrel in the late afternoon on the International Petroleum Exchange in London.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Even Words Fail In This Economy

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE question is, what to call these hard times. What has been happening to America since 1989 seems momentous enough to enter history as a major economic event of the 20th century. But none of the words and phrases that described hardship in the past seem adequate today. And the nation awaits a name, a label that will evoke the nature of these times.
The name problem comes up often in conversations with economists. There is a pause in the conversation while they grope for a phrase, often producing a euphemism that masks the growing national alarm, including their own, over the persistently weak American economy. 
 "We have this thing that is vaguely reminiscent of the 1930's," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston. The favorite labels are "stagnation" or, a degree stronger, "persistent stagnation." Both fail to capture the gloom of millions of Americans who are falling, not stagnating, having lost their jobs or portions of their incomes.
Almost as popular among economists, but also not catching the national mood, is the very unrhythmical "structural imbalance," also known as "structural malaise." The jargon refers to the obstacles to prosperity that piled up in the 1980's, such things as over-indebted consumers and corporations, now too busy paying off loans to spend freely, and the surplus of empty, unrented office buildings, discouraging new construction.
"Adjusting to the structural imbalances will take a long time," said Robert D. Reischauer, chief economist of the Congressional Budget Office, offering little comfort to the 17 million people who are unemployed, under-employed or too discouraged to look for work. "This is a Sisyphean recovery," he said. Sisyphus, a figure in Greek mythology, was condemned to push a rock up a hill only to have it constantly roll back.
"Recession" comes easier to many Americans as their stopgap description of the national plight, and their own hardship -- until a better label presents itself. "Recession" also has its offspring: "lingering recession," "recessionary period" and "growth recession." The latter is resurrected from the 1960's, when it meant economic growth too weak to create enough jobs for all the people entering the labor force. That is a problem today, but not the only one.
Politicians are more upbeat. The Bush and Clinton camps refer to a "temporary period of slow growth" (Bush) and the "anemic recovery" (Clinton). And then there is the favorite metaphor of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. The economy, he says, is trying to buck a 50-mile-an-hour headwind, which he hopes is tapering off.
Among the very few who resort to the D-word -- depression -- S. Jay Levy and his son David Levy of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College are trying to popularize the phrase "contained depression." With bank failures and other setbacks, the Levys argue, the nation is experiencing a 1930's Depression that is "contained" by Federal deposit insurance and the numerous Federal spending programs that support the economy.
Eliot Janeway, an economics consultant, is not so charitable. For him, recession becomes depression when hard times spread abroad, as they have to Europe and Japan. What's more, he says, the main criterion of a depression has been fulfilled in this country: very sharp contraction in economic activity. Mr. Janeway's contraction is certainly not evident in Government statistics, though their accuracy and timeliness are often questioned by economists, particularly Mr. Janeway.
"I have never seen a deterioration deepen and spread so insidiously without showing up in the data flow," he said.
The hard times that are so difficult to label began in the spring of 1989, when economic growth fell below an annual rate of 2 percent -- insufficient to keep down unemployment, sustain wages and generally make Americans feel prosperous.
For 11 of the 13 quarters since early 1989, the gross domestic product stayed below 2 percent growth. And in three of the quarters -- from July 1990 to March 1991 -- G.D.P. shrank, which means the economy was technically in recession. Not since before World War II has the nation had below-2-percent economic growth for so long.
Technically, the recession is over, but spiritually, it continues. Technically, the nation is enjoying a "recovery," but as the weak growth continues, that word is heard less and less. And always the weak growth suggests that the economy could contract again, restarting the recession.
"People came to use the word depression in the 1930's to mean hard times, and the hard times lasted until World War II," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist. "This period could also come to be called a depression, in hindsight, but I don't think it is severe enough. We need another name."

 NEW YORK CITY
 
FAILING TO HELP TROUBLED CHILDREN 
 New York City's child welfare system has been flooded with thousands of emotionally traumatized children, products of families ruined by crack, AIDS and homelessness. But the system has often failed to diagnose, let alone treat, troubled youngsters who range from depressed to suicidal, defiant to violent. Child welfare experts say that there are simply not enough services for all the children who need help. But some of the problem rests with inexperienced and poorly trained caseworkers. A1.
 
AWAITING THE CROWN HEIGHTS TRIAL
On the eve of the trial in the slaying of Yankel Rosenbaum in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last year, Mr. Rosenbaum's family and the Hasidic community have organized and prepared. But the family of Gavin Cato, the black child whose death touched off the racial unrest in which Mr. Rosenbaum died, has slipped into oblivion, struggling to survive in a shelter for the homeless after a fire burned them out of their home eight months ago. B3.
 
FIGHT ON MEDICAL-WASTE INCINERATOR
A new $20 million medical waste incinerator in the South Bronx, still in the testing stages, has ignited a battle involving questions of political influence, "environmental racism" and safety for the residents of the heavily industrial Port Morris section. Though the fight is in many ways a local one, it has taken on special urgency with the City Council's recent approval of a solid-waste plan for the city. B3.
 
CELEBRATING WEST INDIAN CULTURE
Before the West Indian-American Day parade had even begun, you could hear the drums a mile away, pounding low and deep, hinting at the dancing to come. It was the 25th anniversary for the event in Brooklyn, a testament not only to the longevity but also the growing importance of the West Indian-American community. B3.
 
TOW TRUCK MAY HAVE BEEN DRAG RACING
Police investigators believe that a tow truck was drag racing at more than 80 miles an hour when it collided with a compact car in Brooklyn on Sunday morning, killing a 27-year-old woman, law enforcement official say. B4.
 
3 DIE IN TRIBOROUGH BRIDGE CRASH
Three people were killed and three were seriously injured when a speeding car struck a divider on the Triborough Bridge, the police said. The accident forced the closing of the four Queens-bound lanes for several hours. B4.

A SOGGY SEASON COMES TO AN END
As the summer vacation season drew to a close, many were lamenting that a season expected to be hot and sunny instead turned out cool, overcast and rainy. The weather made for a luxuriantly verdant landscape, with rivers running high and butterflies abounding; but the succession of soggy weekends left would-be beachgoers sour and pale, and disappointed many fishermen, vintners and others whose livelihoods depend on the outdoors. Broad Street, the commercial heart of Palisades Park, N.J., was abuzz with rumor and innuendo as both the police and neighborhood residents tried to piece together the events leading to a knife fight Sunday night that left two high school football players dead and two others wounded. B9.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1336 words

HEADLINE: Builders and Foes Using Bronx Incinerator as Test

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Daniel Politi's eyes beamed from under his white hard-hat as he pointed to two 80-foot smokestacks at the top of a new $20 million medical waste incinerator in the South Bronx. "My first question," he asked proudly, "is which stack are we emitting from?"
Mr. Politi, an official of Resource Management Technologies, a New York City company that built the plant with Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, wanted to show that the incinerator was clean and safe. And in fact, there were no visible signs of smoke from either stack, even though ton after ton of bloody bandages, surgical supplies and other hospital waste was being consumed in a double furnace below. 
 But even without smoke there is fire. The incinerator, still in the testing stages, has ignited a battle involving questions of political influence, "environmental racism" and safety for the residents of the heavily industrial Port Morris section. Though the fight is in many ways a local one, it has taken on special urgency with the City Council's recent approval of a solid-waste plan that relies on mass incineration within city limits.
The plant, a joint project of Resource Management Technologies, or Remtech, and Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, is intended to process medical waste from an unspecified number of hospitals, clinics and doctors' and dentists' offices within the city. Its builders say their work can stand as a pilot program for larger, high-technology incinerators, like the 3,000-ton-a-day waste-to-energy plant proposed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. That plant would be 62 times as big as the one in the South Bronx, which will burn 48 tons a day and is also part of the city's overall waste plan.
Opponents say their work can also stand as a model. They believe their data and tactics for organizing residents, environmental groups and politicians can be used against other incinerators where community opposition is high. Opponents recently won a temporary restraining order that blocks testing at the plant. The judge who issued the order, Howard R. Silver of State Supreme Court, has scheduled a hearing for Thursday to settle issues relating to safety and to determine whether state and city environmental agencies properly issued permits for the start-up tests.
Both the developers and opponents say they look forward to their day in court. Each side believes it is right and that it alone knows what is best for the public's safety and its waste policy.
"This plant has become a precedent-setting test with regard to a combination of sensitive issues," said Robert M. Herzog, a former Koch administration official and the president of Remtech. "If this plant can be stopped at this late date, who will invest the hundreds of millions required to build a major resource recovery plant?"
Planning for the plant began in 1988 with two events. The state passed tougher emissions standards for the roughly 110 small incinerators at hospitals throughout the city, which led many to close. And Bronx-Lebanon Hospital began looking to build a more modern incinerator.
Ronald A. Klempner, Remtech's general counsel, said that his company and Bronx-Lebanon discussed building a regional incinerator to replace the smaller incinerators that closed. The result would be the only medical incinerator not physically attached to a hospital in the city and one of the two largest in the state.
State and city regulators, he said, "have indicated that it is easier to regulate a single incinerator with the best available control technology and continuous emission motoring systems than it is to regulate hundreds of individual hospital incinerators without such protections."
The developers chose a site at 138th Street and Locust Avenue in the Port Morris Industrial Park, one of only a handful of sites in the city that is already zoned for incineration.
 
Too Close, Neighbors Say
 Opponents of the project say that the plant is still too close to the schools and apartments west of the Bruckner Expressway, about a quarter mile from the plant. They charge that building the plant in their community, which is populated largely by black and Hispanic residents, is "environmental racism" -- a long-standing complaint that needed but potentially hazardous public projects like incinerators and transfer stations tend to be concentrated in poor and minority neighborhoods.
They also note that the area is already plagued with drugs, violence and more health problems, especially respiratory ailments, than most other parts of the city.
"We're a lot less politically organized," said Carlos Padilla, a businessman on 138th Street, where the powder-blue incinerator sits, and a member of the Bronx Clean Air Coalition, which is fighting the incinerator. "We're not as strong economically. We're a disaster area here."
Opponents also say that the project was built in secrecy. They say that although it was granted permits by the state Department of Environmental Conservation and the city Department of Environmental Protection in 1989, residents did not know of it until construction began last summer.
And opponents say they believe that some help came from Alberto Urbina, the chairman of Community Board One, who served as a labor consultant to Remtech while he sat on the board. Mr. Urbina is under Federal investigation for his role in the project. Remtech and various governmental agencies have been supoenaed for their records, say public and private officials.
 
Dispute Over Notification
 Mr. Urbina did not return repeated telephone calls to the community board office. A spokeswoman for Otto G. Obermaier, the United States Attorney for the Southern District, refused to confirm or deny the inquiry.
Remtech also refuses to discuss Mr. Urbina, but its officials say that they did not sidestep any procedures for notifying the community. They note that few people attended a public hearing in July 1989 and say that various local officials, including Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, knew of their plans but chose not to oppose the plant.
Clint Roswell, a spokesman for Mr. Ferrer, said that the Borough President was now vehemently opposed to the plant and had not been informed initially about its size.
 
'People Feel Hoodwinked'
 "I think everybody's concerns are first safety, and then the second part is that people feel hoodwinked a little bit," Mr. Roswell said. "You wouldn't get this uniformity of outrage from groups of all political backgrounds, of all political stripes, if indeed the state had been forthright or if the developers of this project had been forthright."
To tangle the saga further, the developers say that the opposition has also been less than forthright. Mr. Padilla, a partner in American International Medical Supplies, has been trying to build a 60-ton-a-day autoclave on 138th Street. Before the medical waste were either recycled or taken to a landfill, an autoclave would sterilize it with high-pressure steam. Like incineration, the process has both supporters and detractors.
For his part, Mr. Padilla said that his plans were no secret and that he had proposed the autoclave in a direct challenge to both the incinerator and to the notion that burning is the only way to dispose of the waste.
 
Questions About Safety
 "I've put a lot of time and effort into the community and if fighting that incinerator turns out to be a benefit to me, I'll take it and I'll address that with anybody," he said.
Occasionally lost in the battle are questions about the plant's safety. Opponents say that even if no smoke is visible the plant will release dangerous levels of lead and other heavy metals as well as toxins like dioxin.
The developers and the state say it is the safest plant money can buy, and that all emissions are well below Federal and state standards. Mr. Roswell said that until the plant's plans were reviewed fully and publicly in court, no one would know.
"The technology may be good," he said. "We still have to see."

We're a disaster area here." (Budd Williams for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Summer Was Here, but Time Wasn't Right;
Labor Day Letdown Seems Just as Great Though the Season Was Rainy

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The tomatoes at Henry Balsamo's fruit stand along Route 202 in Bantam, Conn., "haven't been quite right" this summer, he says. But neither has much else, in a season already being remembered throughout the Northeast as the summer that wasn't.
As the summer vacation season drew to a close yesterday, with pools closing and parents preparing reluctant children for school, many people were lamenting that a season expected to be hot and sunny instead turned out cool, overcast and rainy. The weather made for a luxuriantly verdant landscape, with rivers running high and butterflies abounding; but the succession of soggy weekends left would-be beachgoers sour and pale, and disappointed many fishermen, vintners and others whose livelihoods depend on the outdoors. 
 The equally dreary economy upset the fortunes of some, like Mr. Balsamo -- though it helped some local innkeepers whose rooms were full of savings-minded New Yorkers vacationing closer to home.
"The summer just never got here," said Bob Ransom, an owner of the Rivendell Winery in New Paltz, N.Y., where grapes for his hybrid wines like Seyval Blanc are three to four weeks late. "I kind of wish it would still arrive, but I guess it's too late."
 
'Spotty' Fishing Season
 Judd Barnes -- whose charter-fishing boat, the Seahawk III, sails into Long Island Sound from Westbrook, Conn. -- also blamed the weather for a "spotty" bluefish season, not to mention a costly string of cancellations.
As for the dearth of good-sized fish, he said: "Some of us suspect the influx of fresh water into the Sound, with the rain runoff. The water has also stayed colder than usual. Normally, at this time of year, the water's 72 to 74 degrees, and now it's about 67."
But while the season has seemed far from typical, in fact June, July and August were only slightly wetter and cooler than normal, meteorologists say. The average temperature at La Guardia Airport, 73.4 degrees, was only eight-tenths of a degree below normal, and the rainfall, totaling 11.75 inches, was nine-tenths of an inch above the average year.
"Part of the reason for the perception that it was cold and wet was because we've had a lot of hot, dry summers recently," said Paul Knight, a meteorologist at the Penn State Weather Communications Group. "This is the first summer with below-normal temperatures since 1986."
 
More Rainy Days
 On the summer's hottest day, July 14, the mercury only reached 93 degrees in New York City. There were only seven days when temperatures climbed into the 90's, compared with 12 during an average summer, Mr. Knight said.
Although the total rainfall has been only slightly above normal, there were 27 rainy days in July and August in New York, compared with the average of 18, and nine weekends in June, July and August had at least one rainy day.
Even when it has not been raining, the sun has been in hiding. Typically, Mr. Knight said, New York skies are cloudy 59 percent of the time between sunrise and sunset in June, July and August. Definitive statistics are not yet available, but he said, "I'm fairly confident this summer is somewhere around 70 percent."
One obvious casualty was local beaches. "Attendance was very reduced this summer," said Linda Dockeray, the administrator of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, which includes Orchard Beach.
On the Jersey Shore, business was "a little off" at many seaside inns in Cape May, said Dave Hand of the town's Chamber of Commerce.
And at Jones Beach on Long Island, which attracted a record five million people last summer, officials have counted only a little more than 4.3 million people so far this season.
The dampness has been a mixed bag for others, like Garrett DaRoss, the assistant manager of Riverrunning Expeditions, which rents canoes and rafts on the Housatonic River in Falls Village, Conn.
"With all the rain, most people I guess aren't that hardy to go canoeing," he said. "But at least we haven't had the problem we did last year, when we had seven weekends without significant rain and there wasn't enough water in the river for much excitement."
At least one park regular, Sarah Elliott, who leads birdwatching walks in the New York City parks, was more than pleased with the weather.
"It was good for birding, but even better for butterflies, and the dragonflies were spectacular," she said. Two exotic species never before seen in New York -- the Anax longipes, or red-tailed darner, and the Tramea calverti, or striped glider -- were sighted on Staten Island and Manhattan, she said.
Many country inns within a few hours' drive of Manhattan had a good season. Kees Adema, the owner of the Boulders Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn., said, "People seem to be staying closer to home, taking shorter vacations, spending less money and less time traveling."
But whether at the beach, in the city or in the country, the sense of summer's coming to an end has an inevitable, bittersweet quality.
"There a sense of wanting to get everything in before this weekend is over -- playing tennis, biking, going boating," said Jim Murtaugh, a New York actor who also has a home on Woodridge Lake in Goshen, Conn.

GRAPHIC: Photos: As the end of another summer approached, Jim Murtagh gathered with his wife, Alice, son Patrick and daughter Erin at water's edge Sunday on Woodridge Lake in Goshen, Conn. HEADLINE: A New Era for Windmill Power

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIVERMORE, Calif.

 BODY:
A new generation of windmills that Don Quixote could never tilt at is ready to take its place as an economical and important source of the nation's energy.
Because of striking improvements in technology, the commercial use of these windmills, or wind turbines as the builders call them, has shown that in addition to being pollution free, they can now compete with fossil fuels in the cost of producing electricity. 
 As a result, officials of utility companies from around the world have come, cash in hand, to California to inspect the tops of the ridges here at the Altamont Pass, for example, where new machines that look like sideways helicopters married to computers are harnessing the wind.
In recent months, utilities serving upstate New York Illinois, Iowa, California and the Netherlands have decided to try to use the wind to produce electricity commercially.
 
Competing With Fossil Fuels
 Kingsley E. Chatton, president of U.S. Windpower, which operates 22 new-generation windmills here, said the economics of wind power was at the point where it "will compete with fossil fuel." Others agree.
Edgar A. DeMeo, in charge of renewable-energy research at the Electric Power Research Institute, a nationwide research consortium based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the work in California represented a significant advance. Mr. DeMeo's organization, which is supported by dues from utilities, carries out wide-ranging investigations on new technologies and ways to improve existing technologies involving all sorts of power sources.
"We're beyond Kitty Hawk and into the jet age," he said.
The turbines are a successor to the thousands of crude, flimsy windmills put up by optimistic pioneers of the early 1980's, machines that generated more tax credits than electricity and by now have largely disappeared.
 
Capturing More Energy
 The new windmills capture far more of the wind's energy -- a surprisingly tricky feat. Wind varies greatly, but electricity must be so uniform that a user can, for example, set a clock by it. Uniformity has been largely achieved with durable, high-technology adjustable fiberglass propeller blades directed by computers.
Wind turbines cannot replace fuel-burning plants completely because the wind cannot be ordered to blow. But it can be counted on enough over time to produce substantial amounts of energy and thus reduce conventional generation with its emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and carbon dioxide, the biggest greenhouse gas.
Wind can also be used to save the water behind hydroelectric dams to last through dry seasons. In some locations, wind is reliable enough to be counted on at certain hours of the day or seasons of the year.
The newest generation of windmills thus crosses an economic threshold that will allow their use in many areas of the country, although it will take several years before they produce a large fraction of the nation's electricity. Mr. DeMeo said he would not be surprised to see windmills generate 10 percent in 30 years -- about equal to the share now produced by hydroelectricity.
He predicted that successive generations of windmills, building on the combination of sophisticated blades and computer control, would be bigger and would not need costly items like gearboxes, lowering costs further.
 
A Cold, Noisy Wind
 On a recent morning here atop the Altamont Pass, about 30 miles east of San Francisco, the wind, at 30 miles an hour, was strong enough to whip open a car door as soon as the passenger began to open it. The turbines whined at different pitches, while the cold wind whistled through the 80-foot towers covering the bare hills. None of this seemed to bother the cows or the ground squirrels, but for a visitor it was altogether eerie.
"Kind of a nice day, isn't it?" Chuck Ferguson, a field engineer, said as he opened the power electronics box at the base of one tower. It was generating enough electricity to run about 80 houses with their central air-conditioners going, meaning the 22 machines here can power thousands of homes and businesses.
That's a lot of tilting.
Mr. Chatton of U.S. Windpower said the cost of wind-turbine production, from capital investment to operation and maintenance, was about five cents a kilowatt-hour, roughly half the average retail price for power nationwide. A kilowatt-hour is enough electricity to light 10 100-watt bulbs for an hour. At an oil-fired plant, that much electricity costs about 5 cents in fuel alone, apart from capital investment, operation and maintenance expenses. So a power company that now uses oil could save money by building windmills.
 
Cheaper to Build Windmills
 At existing plants that run on coal and natural gas, generation costs are lower, and the money to build the plants has already been spent. But in many locations, building new wind turbines may be cheaper than building new fossil-fuel-burning plants.
Coal-burning utilities with no need for new capacity also have an incentive to turn to wind. The Federal Clean Air Act limits their sulfur dioxide emissions, often requiring them to buy cleaner fuel at a premium, or to buy "emissions allowances" from utilities that are cleaner than the standard required. Windmills do not pollute.
Not that they are completely benign. Some complain that windmills clutter up the landscape. And in some places, environmentalists have said windmill blades have killed birds.
Here at Livermore, U.S. Windpower has painted some blades with a striped pattern to see if this will keep birds away. Company officials say they have not found dead birds at any of the machines, striped or not.
Still, windmill use is spreading. U.S. Windpower, a subsidiary of the Kenetech Corporation, has recently announced these projects:
*A joint venture with the Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company to develop 250 megawatts worth of windmills, that is, about 600 windmills. A megawatt is a thousand kilowatts.
*The sale of a 50-megawatt plant to the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, which is seeking to replace the output of a retired nuclear plant.
*The construction of a 25-megawatt plant in Holland, with the power to be bought by Energiebedrijf voor Groningen en Drenthe, known as E.G.D., and the sale of a 50-megawatt plant to four utilities in the Pacific Northwest.
U.S. Windpower also plans to have two turbines installed by Nov. 1 for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation in upstate New York, to see how they work in cold weather.
The Iowa-Illinois and Pacific Northwest deals are particularly significant because of the role utilities will play, as owners or co-owners, rather than buyers of power. The utilities can also supply money for capital costs at far lower rates than start-up high-technology companies can obtain.
 
The Last Windmill Maker
 U.S. Windpower, the only American company that builds windmills, has outlasted the others and has 138 patents on its equipment. Some smaller concerns, however, do assemble windmills from imported components. U.S. Windpower's parent, Kenetech, is owned in part by its management and in part by the Hillman Company, Allstate Insurance, F. H. Prince & Company and a variety of other, smaller investors. Last year, the company had revenues of about $350 million.
To produce alternating current at precisely 60 cycles a second, the standard for this country since early in the century, most traditional windmills have been designed to turn at only one speed. If the wind is not strong enough to turn the blades at that speed, no power is produced. If the wind blows more strongly, anything above the minimum amount of energy needed to produce electricity is wasted by the blades. Worse, on a really windy day the machines cannot work at all because they would be damaged.
 
Combining Two Technologies
 The new generation of machines is a marriage of aerodynamics and microelectronics. U.S. Windpower adapted the idea of variable-pitch blades from airplanes and developed a system to let the blades and the generator turn at whatever speed the wind allows. Computers open and close electronic circuits to smooth out the air flow over the blades and create electric current that alternates at the right cycles.
The result: while older machines produce no power until the wind reaches 14 miles an hour, the new ones start making electricity at 9 miles an hour. The older ones shut down at 45 miles an hour; new ones work at up to 60.
Another innovation is size, with new machines having a bladespan of about 100 feet, up from 56 feet in previous designs. That means four times as much power, at a total cost only about two and a half times more. There have also been improvements in the blades, which are now 2,000-pound fiberglass structures derived from sailboat masts.
The ridges where U.S. Windpower's turbines stand are between California's sunny central valley and the cloud-bound coast. Every day, the sun warms the air in the valley and as the hot air rises, cooler air from the coast rushes in to fill the void. This gives the site more predictable winds than most other places.
But the "wind resource," as proponents call it, is not peculiar to California. In fact, by national standards, California is not particularly windy: a strip of states from North Dakota to Texas has far more wind. And although electricity is usually generated within a few hundred miles of where it will be consumed, Texas alone could, theoretically, generate 36 percent more kilowatt-hours from wind than are used in the entire continental United States.

HEADLINE: Gulf War's Cost to Arabs Estimated at $620 Billion

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the resulting Persian Gulf war have cost Arab countries $620 billion, according to an authoritative report issued on Sunday.
The Arab Economic Report, an annual study by the Arab Monetary Fund, the Arab League, the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries and other leading institutions, said the destruction of oil wells and pipelines, telecommunications, roads, buildings and factories cost Kuwait $160 billion and Iraq $190 billion. 
 The report, released at a central bankers' meeting in the United Arab Emirates, said that in addition, the governments of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the gulf emirates made $84 billion in direct payments to the United States, Britain and France for military expenses. Officials said payments to Egypt and Syria, who were also members of the coalition opposing Iraq, may have totaled $3 billion to $5 billion.
Direct logistical support for the 600,000 American and allied troops in Saudi Arabia between August 1990 and March 1991, plus the rush to build military airstrips and camps, cost another $51 billion, which was paid largely by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
Arab officials said the balance was accounted for by estimates from data supplied by several countries, including Jordan, Egypt, Yemen and the Sudan, which suffered severe economic blows from the invasion and the war.
The report said the war contributed to a drop in gross national product for the 21 Arab countries estimated at 1.2 percent in 1990 and 7 percent in 1991.
Much of this decline came from the suspension of oil exports from Kuwait and Iraq and an inflation rate that rose to an average of 20 percent a year as imports and exports were disrupted.

HEADLINE: Managua Seesaw: U.S. vs. Sandinistas

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 7

 BODY:
By removing her most feared police officials, but not her army chief, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has gambled that she can win back support from the Bush Administration and the people who elected her without risking an outpouring of rage and possible violence from the Sandinista Front.
Saturday's action, in which the Police Chief, Rene Vivas, was replaced by a less controversial officer, albeit also a Sandinista like Mr. Vivas, showed that Mrs. Chamorro is trying to reduce the power of the Sandinista Front in a very gradual way. Mrs. Chamorro defeated the front at the polls in February 1990. 
 She and her closest advisers clearly feel that, given that the Sandinistas still control most of the weapons in the country, this is the only way change can be accomplished.
But the other side of the issue is whether the Bush Administration, in a difficult election year, will feel politically able to free the $104 million in aid to Nicaragua that has been held up since last spring, an action that could offend the right flank of the Republican Party.
 
Resistance From Helms
 Most of what remains of a $731-million, two-year aid package was suspended because Sen. Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said that the Sandinistas still dominated the country and that the Government was dragging its feet on the promised return of private property confiscated during the Sandinista era.
State Department officials, though generally supportive of the Chamorro Government, have expressed concerns privately on points raised by Mr. Helms. But the issue became more apparent last week when the State Department sent a delegation to discuss the issues with Mrs. Chamorro. The officials reportedly pressed for the removal of Sandinistas from the leadership of both the army and the police.
Mrs. Chamorro's chief minister and son-in-law, Antonio Lacayo, said in a radio interview today that the Government was not going to make any more changes now and was "confident" that the United States would respond to the latest moves by renewing aid.
Nicaragua, left the second-poorest nation in Latin American by more than a decade of war and socialism, needs the money soon to continue the stabilization program that abruptly halted runaway inflation 18 months ago.
After the Pacific coast of Nicaragua was lashed last week by giant waves that killed at least 116 people, the Bush Administration freed $5 million that had been suspended by aid officials separately from the $104 million.
 
Shadows of the Past
 Mr. Vivas, the police chief Mrs. Chamorro replaced, is identified with the most conventionally revolutionary and radical branch of the Sandinista Front. After the Sandinistas came to power in 1979, he was a member of the inner circle that worked closely with Interior Minister Tomas Borge in setting up the police and the state security apparatus -- with ample advice and training from Cuban security experts.
Mr. Borge is described by other Sandinistas today as the leader least able to accept the collapse of the Communist bloc, from which the Sandinista Front derived most of its support while in power.
But it was not really ideology that made Mr. Vivas such a subject of controversy to many of those who supported Mrs. Chamorro's election and who have since soured on her Government because of its alliance with the Sandinistas.
It was, rather, the fear that they could not count on police help if Sandinista-organized mobs took over their property. There were also allegations that under Mr. Vivas, some provincial police chiefs were responsible for abusive and often fatal treatment of the demobilized Nicaraguan resistance, or contras.
 
New Man Swears Fealty
 The new police chief, Fernando Caldera Azmitia, is a Sandinista, but he was careful to say after his swearing in that he puts his loyalty to Mrs. Chamorro's Government above loyalty to his party.
That is the same attitude taken, publicly at least, by Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the army commander who was retained by Mrs. Chamorro after secret negotiations following her election and who has since forged a close working relationship with Mr. Lacayo, the chief minister.
When Mr. Lacayo said Saturday that no further changes were planned, he implied there would be no change in his collaboration with General Ortega, whatever the attitude of the United States.
General Ortega has taken care to distance himself publicly from the actions of his brother, Daniel, whom Mrs. Chamorro defeated for the Presidency and who has incited much of the mass violence in Nicaragua since. The general, once the Sandinistas' chief revolutionary strategist, also says he has been converted to liberal democracy and free-market economics, the tenets of the Chamorro Government.
 
The Complex Ties That Bind
 But Nicaragua is a country where almost every policy decision is made on the basis of personal relationships, where everything that happens is interpreted as part of a master conspiracy, and it is never clear who is manipulating whom.
It is also a country where officials traditionally use their positions for personal business gain, and many Nicaraguans say the most binding tie between Mr. Lacayo and General Ortega is their joint business affairs.
In the long run, this thinking goes, General Ortega may end up using his growing wealth and his relationship with Mr. Lacayo to resuscitate what might otherwise become a political cadaver -- the Sandinista Front.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Geneva Steel Sees A Return to Profits

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
THERE WAS NO shortage of doubters, five years ago, about the prospects of a shuttered steel operation in Vineyard, Utah, that was bought from the USX Corporation and resuscitated by a group of investors operating under the name Geneva Steel. The plant had none of the efficient steelmaking technology known as continuous casting, and it was still capable of producing steel in open-hearth furnaces not unlike those built at the turn of the century.
But in the years since that acquisition, Geneva Steel has made a name for itself, not only as the only integrated steel mill operating west of the Mississippi River, but also as a company that remained profitable during much of a recession that has largely battered its counterparts in the steel industry. 
 But that profitability came to a crashing end, mainly because of fierce price competition and declining demand, in the company's current fiscal year, which began in October of last year. In the quarter ended in December, the company lost $4.8 million. The loss narrowed to $2.9 million in the quarter that ended in March and declined further in the quarter that ended in June, to $1.9 million.
While the losses have thinned, they have nonetheless jolted a company that had been profitable in every quarter since a group of investors, led by Joseph Cannon -- now a candidate for the Senate from Utah -- bought the company for about $44 million.
In most of those years, the company took advantage of its geographic position to ship to steel customers throughout the West, primarily in California. The company has some notable strengths. Transportation costs of steel can amount to as much as 20 percent of the price a customer pays, making Geneva's steel far more attractive to buyers in, say, northern California, than steel made in a USX or Inland Steel mill in northern Indiana. Also, when the investors bought the operation from USX, they were no longer bound to costly long-term contracts for raw materials and labor.
Further, the company restructured its customer base. The company's products had previously gone almost exclusively to a USX sister plant in California. But in the last five years, Geneva has formed relationships with steel service centers -- the industry middlemen that cut and form steel to their customers' specifications -- to provide Geneva's array of plate steel, used largely in construction, and hot-rolled sheet steel, which winds up in everything from aircraft jetways to furniture springs.
All of this took place during a modernization program that saw Geneva spending a total of more than $250 million in the last five years on new equipment and overhauls of older operations. The efficiency has been enhanced, although Geneva officials decline to provide information on the number of worker hours needed to produce a ton of steel, the industry's bellwether measurement of efficiency.
What ultimately hurt Geneva was the same combination of circumstances that crippled other steel producers in recent years. Prices for many steel products are now nearly 30 percent below their level of just two years ago, and demand for some products has remained lackluster. The company's stock, which traded at $21 in January, closed on Friday at $8.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. And for Geneva, plans to build a vital continuous caster have been shelved until the economy rebounds.
To add to its woes, the extensive modernization program has led to huge debt, making it difficult for Geneva to borrow at a time when profits have vanished. "About 55 percent of their capitalization is in debt, and their financial flexibility is limited right now," said Jordan M. Estra, an analyst with Oppenheimer. "Their operations are efficient, except for casting, but they have been losing money for four consecutive quarters."
The company says that with the modernization in place, it can keep its costs low and return to profitability with an improved economy. "Our outlook is promising because steel sales are tied to the general economy," said Robert Grow, president. "The economy is slowly climbing out of the recession, and we will reinvest the money we make into the steel mill, and our outlook will improve."
Analysts seem to agree. Mr. Estra said he expected the company to report a loss for fiscal 1992, compared with earnings of $1.17 a share a year earlier. But he expected the company to come closer to breaking even in the last quarter of the fiscal year. Moreover, he said he expected that a price increase would come next year and that the rise would hold firm as demand for steel grows. "Assuming the economy recovers, and considering their improved operating costs, I expect them to earn 75 cents a share in the 1993 fiscal year," he said. "If the economy comes back, I expect they will, too."

HEADLINE: Toyota Model Made in U.S. Is Offered for Sale in Japan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation today introduced the Scepter station wagon, the company's first totally American-made import for sale in Japan.
The car, which is known as the Camry wagon in the United States, is built by Toyota Manufacturing U.S.A. in Georgetown, Ky. 
 Toyota describes the wagon, which has a price in Japan of about $24,000, as having all-American features like roominess and roof rails. The company has set a sales target of 700 units a month.
The Scepter will face stiff competition from domestically produced models. But what Toyota fails to achieve in terms of the bottom line, it hopes to make up through improvements in its corporate image.
 
Trying to Ease Trade Friction
 At a reception introducing the Scepter, Toyota made no secret of its hopes to emerge as a champion of American workers. An official read a congratulatory statement from Gov. Brereton Jones of Kentucky that hailed Toyota as an "exemplary corporate citizen."
The company's president, Tatsuro Toyoda, said the Scepter should "increase imports from the United States, contribute to local industry there and promote greater partnership, considering the importance of U.S.-Japan relations."
Importing the Scepter is part of Toyota's overall "international cooperation program" to ease trade friction. Under that program, Toyota plans to import a total of $1.4 billion in auto parts from the United States and to raise local production to $3.8 billion by 1994.
The company is following the example of the Honda Motor Company, Japan's No. 3 auto maker after Toyota and Nissan. Honda now sells about 1,400 American-made cars a month in Japan.
 
Countering the Stereotypes
 Japan has been under pressure to buy more American cars and auto parts, as automobiles account for about three-quarters of Japan's $43.4 billion trade surplus with the United States.
Both Toyota and United States officials are emphasizing the quality of the Scepter and other American-made cars in an effort to reverse the image in Japan of American cars as overpriced, oversized gas guzzlers that quickly fall apart.
But the officials were less eager to acknowledge the shaky prospects for expanding Japanese car sales, which have been shrinking in an economic slowdown. Car sales fell 3.9 percent last year, to 5.74 million vehicles. It was the first decline in 10 years.
Since station wagons of Scepter's size are a relative novelty in Japan, the Scepter is being marketed as a recreational vehicle for the weekend driver who avoids making long commutes on busy roads.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Toyota introduced its Scepter station wagon in Japan yesterday. The car, which is known as the Camry wagon in the United States, is Toyota's first totally American-made import for sale in Japan. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
Tent City for Homeless That Politicians Ignore

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AURORA, Ill., Sept. 4

 BODY:
"What's wrong with our tent city?" Charles Campbell asked under the stars, an open fire shadowing his anger in the night. He had to wonder loud above the noise of a freight train that rumbled past his corner of America, a muddy patch in a tent encampment for the homeless in back of the old Aurora incinerator plant.
Grizzled men were silhouetted against the half-moon horizon at the end of another idle day. The camp gathering of a few dozen homeless people seemed a time-warped tableau from bindlestiff Depression days -- a scene that smacked of the old Hoovervilles more than of the fresh changes that the politicians are promising troubled voters again out beyond the hard times swathing Mr. Campbell's tent. 
 "What's wrong with this tent city?" he persisted under the stars, a 47-year-old jobless steelworker imagining but not quite envying the new tent cities being headlined after the hurricane disaster in Florida.
"These people could use some of that help and attention," he said, gesturing across the lackluster Aurora camp of small and large tents and makeshift plastic hovels.
 
The Hard-Core Homeless
 Doug Ford, a tent dweller, said the attention of the current crop of politicians was not worth it, anyway. "Ain't seen an exciting politician in my lifetime," he said, conceding that at the age of 25 he was a bit extra despairing now that he was a part of the hard-core homeless. This is a category beyond most welfare aid that is so rock-bottom that it was not even included statistically in the latest bad news from Washington about how the number of poor Americans has soared to the highest levels in a generation and how the purchasing power of most Americans is shrinking.
In the dark of the Aurora camp, a man who identified himself as Pete, a pipe fitter jobless and homeless after 19 years of good living, offered a proper Beckett touch to the theme of hapless life that dominated the conversations past midnight. "Homelessness is like a golf course," he said. "It's there but not everybody can play." As if sensing his peers' squinting curiously in the dark, Pete said he meant politicians can't afford to care; they are counting on the homeless "hiding in plain sight" among 250 million Americans, he said.
Mr. Ford preferred more of a Steinbeck analysis. "People out there don't realize how easy it is to go from something to nothing, plain and simple," he said, describing losing his job, then his house to creditors, and shipping his kids out to in-laws.
"Out of work four weeks, and -- boom -- here I am," he said, contributing to the campfire consensus that, since Aurora's homeless have been suffering such a slow-motion, undramatic disaster, the incinerator camp has no instant value for the campaigning politicians working their way toward Election Day.
 
A Long-Running Hurricane
 If there were a hurricane named Aurora it would have a huge bedevilling eye and no departing edge, according to the measure of long-running failures in factories, farms and families witnessed by Rose Marie Lorentzen, a Sister of Charity nun who began to quietly take care of Aurora's homeless a decade ago.
She converted the incinerator plant to Hesed House, with charity winter bedrooms for the homeless. Then, three years ago, she found she had to pitch a tent city for the increasing numbers of summer homeless, and lately she sees an even worse symptom of the problem in the growing numbers of full families showing up at the door like Okies lost in time.
"Ten years this disaster has been going on, Sister Rose Marie," said Mr. Campbell, who lately gets by on tent charity and a few hours of manual labor on a nearby traveling carnival. "I mean, that's a depression, right? Bring back the W.P.A. At least they put a roof over your head and a hot meal in your stomach."
To the contrary, there have been goverment budget cuts lately crimping the operations of Hesed House and its homeless program, Public Action to Deliver Shelter. Illinois has perhaps 100,000 of the nation's estimated three million homeless, a figure widely criticized as conservative by field workers. The word through the night in the Aurora camp, where the first fall chill could be felt in the earth, was that harder times are a certainty.
 
Focus on Middle Class
 "From what I see, I'm honestly afraid the homeless total could double this year in the state," said Diane D. Nilan, the center's program director who has been busy lately with a nationwide voter-registration drive for the homeless.
Homeless organizers say the Presidential contenders have been notable for rarely mentioning the problem this year. "In the '88 campaign it was used a lot as a symbol of the economic issue," said Ted Houghton at the New York Coalition for the Homeless. "But now the economy has gotten even worse, and the politicians have to focus on the middle class worrying about losing their shirts next, not on helping the homeless."
The people in the Aurora camp do talk politics, and with not much more cynicism than can be heard elsewhere in America these days. They routinely fly the American flag outside a tent. "I haven't forgot the country," said Mr. Campbell before delving into a charity breakfast of some excess midnight pizzas from a local restaurant.
"Hell, I got to be for Clinton," he said, offering a reason that has nothing to do with the Democrat's studious promises and populist lures. "I like him because he's suffered everything you can suffer, got pounded plenty with scandal in the campaign, but he stands right there telling them, 'Hey, I'm still here, and I'm running and I'm winning.'
"I got to like that," Mr. Campbell said, celebrating simple endurance as looking like a virtue these nights in the Aurora camp.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Campbell, a 47-year-old jobless steelworker who lives in a tent city in Aurora, Ill., behind the old Aurora incinerator plant. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treasury Will Auction Bills This Week

 BODY:
Treasury financings during this holiday-shortened week are limited to the regular auction of new three- and six-month bills. The auction is normally held on Mondays, but because of Labor Day it has been rescheduled this week for today. By late in the day Friday, the rate on the three-month bill outstanding was 2.9 percent and the rate on a six-month bill was 2.95 percent.
Government agency issues due this week include a $500 million floating-rate note issue that will be priced today. The notes mature March 3, 1993, and will be priced off the three-month Treasury bill, with the interest rate adjusted the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.
