HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Anne-Marie Schiro

 BODY:

Rediscovering Italy
The Italians are coming. In force. To celebrate the quincentenary of Columbus's landing in the New World, an army of designers, jewelers, artisans and manufacturers will be taking part in a series of fashion shows, parties and exhibitions to spur Americans' interest in things Italian.
Not that Americans don't know about Italian products, but there is something called a recession going on, and Italy is feeling it, too. Although exports of wine and machinery to the United States are growing, sales of clothing, shoes and jewelry have all declined in the last five years. For the first six months of this year, Italy's share of the American import market was just 2.3 percent, down from 2.6 percent in 1990. 
 So the Italian Trade Commission, whose goal is to promote Italy's position in the world market, is sponsoring all manner of activities across the United States in a program called "1992: Discovery of Italy."
"The purpose is to promote Italy's image," said Giovanni Battista Peruzzi, the trade commissioner for the United States, Canada and Mexico. "It's an invitation to America to see what Italy has done recently. It's really a rediscovery of Italy."
The program's major event is taking place in New York, starting next week at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, which is being transformed into an idealized version of a 15th-century piazza. Called Piazza Italia, it will be open to the public from Sept. 15 through Oct. 9, with artisans' demonstrations and displays of clothing, fabrics, jewelry and crafts.
Fashion is, of course, an indispensable part of the project, and several major events are planned.
It all starts Monday night with Rock 'n' Rule, an invitation-only party given in honor of Gianni Versace by Bergdorf Goodman and the Italian Trade Commission. After a dinner for 300 (at $1,000 a ticket), the Piazza will resound with a fashion extravaganza: Versace's men's and women's clothes shown with live models, music, videos and special effects. That explains the "Rock" part; the "Rule" remains to be seen. Tickets to the show alone are going for $150, and the evening benefits the American Foundation for AIDS Research.
As a sideline to Piazza Italia, Bergdorf's is opening a new Versace boutique on its second floor next Monday and will fill its windows with the designer's clothes.
Back at the Piazza, a retrospective called "Valentino: 30 Years of Magic" will run from Sept. 23 to Oct. 9. On Sept. 22, a formal preview will be followed by dinner and dancing for 300 guests, who are being asked to make voluntary contributions to AIDS charities. Guests are also being asked to dress in black and white, Valentino Garavani's favorite combination.
Henri Bendel will use the Piazza on Thursday evening, Sept. 24, for a cocktail party and a fashion show of the Genny, Byblos and Complice collections for fall.
Italian jewelry, which has a 40 percent share of the American jewelry market, will take center stage at a benefit auction at the Piazza on Sept. 23. Called "A Jewel for Life," the auction will offer 32 pieces of jewelry made by Italian goldsmiths from designs by Cher, Luciano Pavarotti, Ivana Trump, Chris Evert and Yo-Yo Ma. The raw materials alone are said to be worth $500,000, so the take should be considerable.
Three celebrity auctioneers -- Beverly Sills, Tony Randall and Robin Leach -- will join a professional auctioneer to add fun to the occasion.
 
New Biagiotti Boutique
 What better time for Laura Biagiotti to open her first boutique in New York? Next Monday is the target date for the bronze and glass doors at 4 West 57th Street to let in the first shoppers. The store will showcase the Italian designer's ready-to-wear and accessories and will house a salon run by Sergio Valente, the Roman hair stylist who once presided at Bergdorf Goodman.
There will be more from Italy later. For now, basta!

HEADLINE: Summer Pop Circuit Sees No End to Recession

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE

 BODY:
Some of the biggest names in rock took their acts on the road this summer and pumped a bit of vitality back into the ailing pop concert scene. But even their spark fell far short of a full revival. Genesis, for instance, was unable to fill large sections of some stadiums, and tickets for megastar acts like U2, Bruce Springsteen and the joint tour by Guns 'n' Roses, Metallica and Faith No More were selling more slowly than expected in some cities.
"The recession hit everybody at every level," said Gary Bongiovanni, the editor of Pollstar, a magazine that covers the concert industry. 
 "There are bright spots," he said. "In 1992, we were blessed with a higher caliber of artists. But the impact of the recession, coupled with the traditional seasonal summer overload of concerts, resulted in a lot of shows' doing less-than-anticipated business. Artists considering doing two or three dates at an arena may have done only one. They sold out and looked great, but in better times they might have done more shows."
 
Hard Lessons
 This summer's uneven season follows the worst summer in memory for live pop performances, one that put a number of promoters out of business and left others in a state of near-desperation.
Last summer, stadium tours were almost nonexistent as bigger acts postponed record releases and tours. Fans, who had less discretionary income because of the recession, stayed away. There were cancellations and bankruptcies.
Compounding the situation were higher costs of producing shows, resulting in large part from promoters' fierce competition for the talent that was available, which drove up artists' fees and ticket prices.
It was anticipated that this summer's lineup would spell relief. Not only were such proven concert performers as Genesis, U2, Guns 'n' Roses and the joint concerts of Eric Clapton and Elton John mounting stadium tours, but Bruce Springsteen was also back, playing arenas, and last year's most successful package, the Lollapalooza tour, returned with a lineup that included the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Ice Cube, Soundgarden, Pearl Jam, and the Jesus and Mary Chain.
Concert promoters, meanwhile, had learned a hard lesson. Competition for artists remained intense, but many promoters were more prudent in negotiating and securing artists' contracts. Ticket prices remained fairly stable, averaging about $25. The country superstar Garth Brooks charged only $18.50 for his show last weekend at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.
Pollstar reported that the top 20 tours took in $238.7 million in the first six months of this year, a 15 percent increase over the $208.6 million generated during the same period last year. For some promoters, the stadium tours this summer made the difference.
Jim Koplik, the president of Metropolitan Entertainment, a large concert-promoting concern in Montclair, N.J., said it was "a great summer" because his company had a total of 11 stadium shows, at Giants Stadium and in upstate New York, with acts including U2, the Grateful Dead, Genesis, and the tour of Guns 'n' Roses, Metallica and Faith No More.
However, Mr. Koplik said that business at arenas and amphitheaters, which he called the core of the concert business, was just "mediocre to good." Stadiums have a seating capacity of 60,000 or more, compared with 10,000 to 20,000 seats in amphitheaters, the warm-weather stages whose whole year depends on the success of summer shows.
Genesis appeared in stadiums from Texas to Massachusetts and was the top act for the period from May 1 through July 31, according to Amusement Business, a trade magazine for the entertainment and amusement industry. The English group's gross of $23.9 million for 23 shows reflects the impact that stadium tours can have on the bottom line. The No. 1 group for the same period last year was Guns 'n' Roses, which did 29 shows in smaller venues and grossed $13.2 million.
Yet even Genesis wasn't always a sure bet. After a sold-out concert at Foxboro Stadium near Boston in late May, the group's keyboardist, Tony Banks, said in a telephone interview: "The recession here in many ways is more apparent than in parts of Europe in the way it affects a concert tour. In pockets of the country, we don't sell as many tickets as we thought we would. In other places, we sell more. We're doing better in Europe this time than in America. I reckon the American tour will be subsidized by the European tour."
Following Genesis in Amusement Business's top 10 for May through July were the Grateful Dead, the Cure, Jimmy Buffett, Guns 'n' Roses with Metallica, Eric Clapton solo, Garth Brooks, Harry Connick Jr., Rush and Neil Diamond. The tour of Guns 'n' Roses and Metallica, which was highly anticipated by both fans and promoters, later missed several scheduled appearances after Metallica's singer and guitarist, James Hetfield, was seriously burned by the band's onstage fireworks and after W. Axl Rose, the lead singer of Guns 'n' Roses, was reportedly suffering from throat problems. The Dead, which have toured consistently and been a top money-maker on the road, canceled some dates recently because Jerry Garcia, the band's leader, was ill.
 
Veterans and 'Baby Acts'
 There were some positive signs. Established performers like Bonnie Raitt and James Taylor, who have strong followings, did well at amphitheaters. And country artists like Reba McEntire, Billy Ray Cyrus and Wynonna Judd were playing to increasingly wider audiences, said Ben Liss, executive director of the North American Concert Promoters Association, which comprises the country's leading promoters.
Mr. Liss also said "baby acts," newer performers with strong potential drawing power, had emerged, including the Black Crowes, Pearl Jam and Faith No More. He and others said that developing artists who can attract future audiences was one of the biggest challenges in the concert business.
"The headline mega-megastars, there are fewer and fewer of them," said Louis Messina, president of Pace Music Group and Pace Concerts in Houston. "The B-level acts are the backbone of our business."
Mr. Koplik said that the industry suffered from a cyclical scarcity of strong acts as artists take off four or five years between tours, compared to one year in the 1970's. Genesis's tour was its first in five years, and Mr. Springsteen's shows were his first with a band since 1988.
"And radio stations are not breaking as many artists as they used to," Mr. Koplik said, adding that there would be fewer shows this fall than in past years. "The concert business primarily depends on album rock radio. Out of every three artists played on album rock radio, one artist is already dead, one band is no longer together or touring, and only the third artist is putting out a current product and going on the road."
Many rock radio stations have a "classic rock" format, and much of the music is 20 to 25 years old.
"We need to help build long-term careers for artists who are emerging," Mr. Liss said. "That is the most critical question we as an industry have to deal with. Record companies, talent buyers, agents, managers and record shops must work together. We all have the same consumer, and we're all working for the same artists."

HEADLINE: Little Film That Could: A Hollywood Cinderella Goes to the Festival

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 7

 BODY:
This town thrives on Cinderella stories, and there's probably not a better one this year than that of "Zebrahead."
It is not scheduled for theatrical release until late October, but this film, which cost only $2 million and has a first-time director and writer, and a cast of largely unknown, even untrained, performers, has been gathering momentum for months. It won a top prize at the 1992 Sundance Film Festival, is an entry in the New York Film Festival, as well as those in Deauville, France, and in Toronto, and has been promoted by film makers as diverse as Peter Guber, the chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and Oliver Stone, who hardly needs an introduction. 
 Anthony Drazan, the 37-year-old screenwriter and director, said the early interest in his movie, which has autobiographical overtones, had left him stunned. "To be recognized this way is fantastic," he said. Mr. Drazan recently met with Steven Spielberg, another "Zebrahead" fan, and signed a two-picture contract with Amblin Entertainment, Mr. Spielberg's company.
 
One Director, 2 Coasts
 The bespectacled, aggressively confident Mr. Drazan shuttles between small apartments in Greenwich Village and Venice, Calif. Though the story is more or less based on some of his high school experiences on Long Island, Mr. Drazan has set his film on the fringes of Detroit, just because he liked the looks of the area. The drama focuses on a white teen-ager named Zack, who attends a racially and economically mixed high school and whose best friend is a black youth named Dee. The fragile racial boundaries that define the friendship are shaken when Zack has an affair with a black girl related to Dee.
Those who have seen "Zebrahead" praise the performances by a largely unknown cast of young performers and the street culture details, the fragmented music and the high school cafeteria dialogue that rings true. "The last thing I wanted was a slick look with teen-age stars," said Mr. Drazan, seated in a Beverly Hills hotel lounge and sipping the requisite mineral water.
"After all the time I spent on the research in high school hallways, knowing what I did when I was growing up, I knew that although I was making this movie from a white, middle-class point of view, it had to be faithful and truthful to this community, and this required finding original talent," he said.
 
The Cachet of Oliver Stone
 Mr. Drazan, who received a master's degree in 1985 from New York University's film school, originally wrote the movie for a workshop at the Sundance Institute in 1987. The script floundered and was eventually optioned by the producers Jeff Dowd, Charles Mitchell and William F. Willett. But it was only when Oliver Stone read it and lent his name as one of the executive producers that "Zebrahead" achieved instant cachet.
"It's not an Oliver Stone picture," said Mr. Drazan. "It takes a totally different sensibility. I'm proud to say Oliver likes the film as much as he does."
Perhaps the most significant supporter of the movie was Larry Estes, the senior vice president for acquisitions of Columbia-Tri-Star home video, which financed such independent films as "Sex, Lies and Videotape," "The Waterdance" and "One False Move." The movie has the imprimatur of Sony Pictures Entertainment, whose chairman, Peter Guber, is happily endorsing it (a respectable film that costs only $2 million is an instant candidate for a miracle movie), and whose subsidiary the Triumph Releasing Corporation is distributing it.
 
The Names of the Unknowns
 The cast of "Zebrahead" includes Michael Rapaport, a Brooklyn-born actor, as Zack; DeShonn Castle, a graduate of Yonkers High School with no previous acting experience, as Dee, and N'Bushe Wright, as Nikki, who has an affair with Zack. Ms. Wright grew up in Brooklyn in Bedford-Stuyvesant and is a dancer who studied with the Alvin Ailey and Martha Graham troupes. The only known actors in the cast are Ray Sharkey, who plays Zack's philandering father, and Helen Shaver, in a bit part as one of Mr. Sharkey's girlfriends.
Like Zack, who grows up without a mother, Mr. Drazan lived through turbulent teen-age years. His mother, Carol Klein, died of an embolism at the age of 37, when he was 11 years old and the eldest of three boys. The family lived on Long Island, in Cedarhurst, and Rockville Centre. His father, Stephen Drazan, ran a hardware and houseware business.
By his own choice, Mr. Drazan had a peripatetic high school career, attending Lawrence High School in Lawrence, L.I., South Side High School in Rockville Centre, Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and South Side High a second time. "My father was a very patient man and quite supportive of this weird tangent that his oldest son took," he said. "Whenever I got too happy, I wanted to leave."
Mr. Drazan said of the film: "I was a version of that kid in the film, circa 1973. I lived in a small home with my grandparents in one bedroom, my father and I sharing another bedroom and my two brothers sharing a third. We lived in an integrated area of Cedarhurst. I started getting into the music, like the kid in the film, and made friends with the black kids. Some of the things in 'Zebrahead' came out of that experience."
"What I tried to create, from the beginning to the end, from the music to the casting to the shooting style, was a kind of mosaic, a fabric of life, that brought together different points of view, different worlds," he said. "The idea was to explore the points of view of very different characters and create some kind of single piece."
Mr. Drazan attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he majored in English, and later sold T-shirts at the Public Theater in New York. By his own admission a terrible salesman, he was dismissed for spending too much time watching rehearsals.
"I didn't know what I could do," he recalled of that period. "I was 23 or 24. I wandered around the East Village. I finally enrolled at N.Y.U. School of the Arts because when in doubt, in moments of crisis, go back to school. I frankly had a semi-bogus portfolio. I had very little knowledge of what movies were."
 
Looking Ahead
 At N.Y.U., though, Mr. Drazan who won several awards for a short film about a boy with his single mother on the beach in Far Rockaway. "It was very lyrical and very derivative of Mr. Truffaut's films," he said. But the movie got him an agent and led to several unproduced films that he wrote under contract. With "Zebrahead" -- whose title is a racial reference to black-and-white couples, or to mulattoes -- Mr. Drazan's future seems more secure. His next film will probably be a comedy, set in New York, about a yuppie who witnesses the killing of Paul Castellano, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, in front of Sparks Steakhouse on the East Side of Manhattan.
In the meantime, the entry of "Zebrahead" in the New York Film Festival on Oct. 8 and Oct. 10 is especially sweet. "After all those years of trying to get into the festival when all the films were sold out," he said. "I could never get in. And now -- this. Wow!"

HEADLINE: NASA Plans an Economy Flight to the Solar System's Last Stop

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
Out in the twilight toward the edge of the solar system, Pluto is receding deeper into space. Three years ago, the planet came as close as it ever gets to the Sun in 248 years, and astronomers managed to catch their best glimpses ever, imperfect views of an odd little world.
Smaller than Mercury or even Earth's Moon, Pluto is covered with ice and enveloped by a thin atmosphere of methane. It is tipped over on its side and travels an eccentric orbit, crossing the plane of the other planets at a 17-degree angle and ranging out a lonesome 4.6 billion miles from the Sun. Pluto's recently discovered companion is a satellite half its own size, Charon, forming what scientists characterize as a double-planet system. 
 Not much else is known. For in the broad reconnaissance of the solar system over the last three decades, Pluto is the only known planet not visited by spacecraft. Scientists were beginning to despair that the opportunity would pass as Pluto headed out of reach.
But now the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is pressing to win approval for what it describes as a simple, affordable mission to Pluto. Two small spacecraft with cameras and a few essential instruments could be launched as early as 1998 on flights taking them close to the planet in seven or eight years. Optimism is running high that the Pluto fast flyby, as the mission is called, just might come about.
Describing the plan in an interview, Dr. Robert L. Staehle, the Pluto team manager at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said: "We know there are nine planets out there. We've been to eight. So let's finish the job."
At the World Space Congress in Washington last week, scientists and NASA officials spoke enthusiastically of the Pluto plan, saying it would be a worthy demonstration of the emerging philosophy of mounting missions that are "better, faster, cheaper." The two-spacecraft project is estimated to cost no more than $400 million, compared with the billion-dollar-plus price tags on recent science missions.
The new space agency administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, has given the plan his wholehearted support. After he took office in April, he ordered the crash study leading to the plan. "He made us realize the low-budget way was the only way we were going to get anything new started," a NASA official said.
Whether the mission is included in the next budget, given the nation's tight financial squeeze, is uncertain. But supporters were encouraged when Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the policy-making National Space Council, echoed the language of the new mission-planning philosophy. He told the space congress, "We need to stretch our scarce resources by figuring out how to do things faster, better and cheaper."
The same approach is being taken in planning further exploration of Mars. A spacecraft called Mars Observer is to be launched Sept. 25 to orbit Mars and study its geology and meteorology. Eventually, humans will go to Mars. In between, though, NASA is proposing a more modest undertaking, establishing a network of small automated research stations covering the planet.
Starting at the end of this decade, the Mars Environmental Survey, or Mesur, would put 16 landers on the red planet to observe the surface, weather and seismic activity in the canyons, volcanic terrain and frozen polar regions. Planners have been told the entire network must be kept under $1 billion, with no more than $150 million spent in any one year. The space agency hopes to begin the project with money in the 1994 budget.
Actually, Dr. Wesley Huntress, director of the space agency's solar system exploration division, pointed out, this approach is a return to the ways of the 1960's.
When a premium was put on doing what could be done and doing it fast, to beat the Russians if nothing else, small Mariner spacecraft carrying a simple camera and a few instruments were developed in two or three years and dispatched to Venus, then Mars and Mercury. The Pioneers did the same for Jupiter and Saturn in the early 1970's. The Voyagers were a scaled-down version of more complex spacecraft that lost out in the budget wars, but one of them was durable enough to tour the outer planets all the way to Uranus and Neptune.
Then, as the quick-look strategy of planetary exploration gave way to more elaborate return missions seeking more detailed knowledge, the size and complexity of spacecraft increased, development time doubled and tripled and costs soared. The cost of the planned Cassini mission to place an orbiter around Saturn rose to $1.7 billion before NASA was forced to scale back the project this spring. A companion mission known as Comet Rendezvous-Asteroid Flyby, or CRAF, got so expensive it was canceled.
"It became clear it will be a long time before we get another Cassini-class mission," Dr. Huntress said.
A NASA advisory panel headed by Dr. Alan Stern, a planetary scientist at the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio, examined a number of proposed missions to Pluto in the last two years. A Cassini-size spacecraft was rejected as being too expensive and thus unattainable. At the other extreme, a tiny craft weighing less than 80 pounds and containing little more than a camera was considered too small to be scientifically rewarding.
 
Plan for Quick Mission
 In July, Dr. Stern said, the panel finally winnowed the proposals down to the so-called fast flyby mission involving two 330-pound spacecraft.
As conceived by Dr. Staehle's engineering team at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, the two nearly identical craft would be launched days apart on a direct trajectory to Pluto. This would be the fastest way to get there, taking as little as seven years. Alternative methods involving a gravity-assist swingby of Jupiter would add several years to flight time and limit launching opportunities to coincide with Jupiter's alignment with Earth every 13 months.
The direct flights across three billion miles of space would require the brute force of the nation's most powerful launching rocket, the Titan 4 with a Centaur upper stage. But NASA planners said use of the Russian Proton rockets was also being seriously considered. Dr. Huntress noted that the Protons were reliable, capable and cost less, although their use might extend the required flight time by a couple of years.
The two spacecraft would arrive at Pluto a few months apart, one acting as a backup in case of a breakdown by the other. If both are operating, this would permit the photographing of both hemispheres of Pluto and Charon in especially fine detail. Observations would extend over a month, as the craft approach and depart the planet, but the closest encounter for the best photography would last only a few hours.
In deciding on the minimum acceptable payload for the spacecraft, Dr. Stern's advisory panel drew up a list of the highest-priority scientific objectives. One priority was to characterize the geology and surface features of both Pluto and Charon; so there should be a lightweight imaging system, in this case a camera with extremely sensitive electronic light detectors for the dim conditions so far from the Sun.
Another priority, examining the planet's surface composition, would be fulfilled with a mapping infrared spectrometer. And for analyzing the density and constituents of Pluto's atmosphere, there would need to be an ultraviolet spectrometer. In addition, the craft's radio could supplement these studies by transmitting signals through the planet's atmosphere and inferring its nature by the way the signals are distorted.
 
A 15-Pound Package
 Following these guidelines, spacecraft designers have pared the scientific instrumentation down to a 15-pound package by eliminating any lower-priority items. For example, there will be no magnetometer because it is unlikely that Pluto is large enough to have magnetic fields and no dust detectors because there is no evidence of particle rings circling the planet.
Astronomers, praising the concept, said that even such a bare-bones spacecraft would produce a wealth of information about Pluto and its moon. Even with today's best telescopes, Pluto shows up as not much more than a pale, fuzzy sphere.
"We certainly expect Pluto's going to knock our socks off," Dr. Stern said.
Dr. Richard P. Binzel, a planetary scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is an authority on Pluto, said: "Think of how much we learned about Triton in just the one Voyager flyby, or about any single moon of Jupiter or Saturn. That's exactly what we should be getting from a Pluto flyby."
Indeed, scientists like Dr. Binzel are keenly interested in examining images of Pluto to see if, as some think, the planet resembles Triton, the largest moon of Neptune. According to this hypothesis, Triton was an independent planet much like Pluto, but it wandered too close and was captured by Neptune's powerful gravity. A somewhat similar close encounter could explain how Charon, exceptionally large in relation to its parent planet, came to orbit Pluto. Charon's surface appears to be covered with water ice.
Charon was not discovered until 1978. In Greek mythology, Charon ferried souls across the river Styx to the nether world, which was ruled by the god Pluto. Pluto the planet was itself not observed until 1930, the result of an intense search for the giant Planet X suspected to exist somewhere on the fringes of the solar system. The gravitational perturbations on the orbits of Uranus and Neptune, which fed speculation of a massive Planet X exerting a far-reaching tug, have yet to be explained; Pluto is much too small to jostle planetary neighbors.
 
An Appealing Idea
 The most appealing aspect of the mission for scientists is its promise of the fastest possible trip to Pluto.
"We would like to see Pluto before Pluto freezes out," Dr. Binzel said. That is, as the planet travels deeper into space, it is getting colder and colder in the diminished sunlight. At some point, perhaps in 15 to 20 years, Pluto's thin atmosphere might disappear as the methane freezes and falls as snow on the planet.
A key to reducing costs, mission planners said, will also be drastically reducing the time spent developing and building the hardware. This removes the temptation to overdesign systems instead of relying on available technologies. In this case, the plan is to take advantage of recent advances in electronics, including some technologies developed for the Strategic Defense Initiative, the anti-missile program begun by the Reagan Administration, and to use a leftover antenna from the Viking project to Mars in the 1970's.
In a report on these exploration concepts to the space congress, Dr. Staehle's team reflected on how necessity was forcing a return to the old let's-get-going attitude of the early space age and this could lead to more efficient operations.
"The longer we spend preparing for a mission," the team observed, "the greater the cost will be, as people's efforts get devoted to 'what-if' studies, 'improvements,' trade-off analyses and the like. Given time, we can always make the product better, at a cost. Our question is what is 'good enough,' and then how do we proceed rapidly with implementation with a minimum of deviations?"
That, planetary scientists and spacecraft engineers hope, is the way to get to Pluto soon and complete the initial reconnaissance of the Sun's family of planets.
 

GRAPHIC: Diagrams: "Springtime on a Cold, Cold Planet," shows make-up of Pluto's atmosphere. Pluto shines more brightly than our own Moon, puzzling astronomers because methane in its atmosphere would normally lose its ability to reflect sunlight from chemical reactions with ultraviolet radiation. Fresh deposits of methane "ice" may explain the puzzle. Even on Pluto, summer might be warm enough to vaporize methane, which would condense and fall back to the surface in winter, freezing on the surface as reflective ice.
 
"Spacecraft for a Long Journey," shows construction of proposed spacecraft design. Space scientists want to fly by Pluto before the planet heads out of reach. NASA is proposing a relatively low-cost mission in which two simple spacecraft with cameras and essential instruments would reach Pluto in seven or eight years. Supporters hope the mission will be included in the next budget and completed before the 2020's, when the planet's atmosphere freezes onto its surface for two centuries.

"Clues to the Features of a Faraway World," shows how astronomers have observed Pluto. Scientists have slowly learned about Pluto by noting differences in their observations as the planet and its moon changed position relative to other planets and stars. For example, astronomers discovered Pluto's atmosphere by observing changes in a star's light when Pluto passed in front of it in 1988. The starlight dimed gradually, then abruptly, as light does when it is refracted and absorbed by gases in an atmosphere. Now scientists hope to learn how the atmosphere forms and exactly what it contains.

HEADLINE: Economists Strive to Find Environment's Bottom Line

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
Does environmental protection hurt the economy or help it?
The question is under hot dispute in the Presidential campaign. The Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore, argues that environmental protection boosts the economy and creates jobs; Vice President Dan Quayle, whose White House Council on Competitiveness has sought to reduce environmental regulations, says the Democrats' environmental policies would cost jobs. 
 But the answer to the economy-vs.-ecology question, says an emerging group of environmental economists, is far more elusive.
An Environmental Protection Agency analysis, for example, puts the cost of controlling and cleaning up pollution under Federal regulations at more than $100 billion a year, or about 2 percent of the nation's total annual output of goods and services. But like a number of other analyses, the study does not take into account the economic benefits of cleaner air and water. An analysis of benefits is under way, but not yet complete.
Nor does the study include protection measures that do not involve pollution control, like conserving the ecosystems that underlie all economic activity, such as water, soil, forests, fisheries, wetlands, wild plant species and the complex biological web that supports life itself. Gauging the costs and benefits of such measures is hard but essential.
Environmental economists argue that the economy is merely a subsystem of the planet's ecology, on which it depends for materials, energy and general sustenance. "To me it's just as plain as the nose on your face," says Herman Daly, an economist at the World Bank and a proponent of the view that economies can flourish at steady state, without growth. Traditional economists, he and others contend, ignore this relationship, and with it the economic cost of depleting natural resources, degrading soils and otherwise insulting nature.
Until these "external" costs are reflected both in company balance sheets and calculations of national wealth, say Mr. Daly and his allies, the benefits of environmental protection will be seriously underestimated and the basic health of the economy will be overestimated.
This line of thought is starting to make some headway, as both the United Nations and the United States Department of Commerce move to include the costs of natural resource depletion as an adjunct to conventional accountings of national wealth. Also, regulatory commissions in New York and other states are starting to require electric utilities to factor in the cost of emitting heat-trapping carbon dioxide when deciding how to generate energy.
Including such external costs favors Mr. Gore's side of the argument. But economic studies in general are not so clear cut. A number of economists say the value of environmental protection measures can be assessed only on a case-by-case basis.
 
Benefits That Exceed Costs
 "I don't think you can make a broad, sweeping conclusion" about the economic value of environmental protection, said Dr. William Nordhaus of Yale University. "There are some net pluses and some net minuses."
Among the "good buys" are the air pollution controls enacted in the first Clean Air Act of 1970, according to a cost-benefit analysis by Dr. Paul R. Portney, an economist at Resources for the Future, a Washington research institute. The act placed the first limits on air pollution from smokestacks and motor vehicles. Dr. Portney found the benefits of the Clean Air Act have exceeded the costs.
His preliminary estimate suggests that the same is not true of the 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act, designed to curb acid rain and air pollution in urban areas. Costs will be $29 billion to $36 billion a year by the year 2005, but benefits will probably range from $6 billion to $25 billion, he found. Since the analysis is preliminary, Dr. Portney does not rule out a different final result.
Another good buy, in Dr. Portney's view, is the phasing out of chlorofluorocarbons that destroy the earth's protective ozone layer, which he calls "a small price to pay for insurance against what could be a pretty serious problem." Bad buys, in his book, include some toxic waste sites that pose little risk but will require tens of millions of dollars apiece to clean up.
The issue of economy vs. ecology is also complicated by the fact that environmental regulation distributes both costs and benefits unevenly.
 
Disproportionate Burden
 On costs, for instance, Dr. Dale W. Jorgenson of Harvard University and Dr. Peter J. Wilcoxen of the University of Texas estimate that all Federal environmental regulations adopted before 1990 will reduce the national economic output by 2.5 percent by the year 2000. But the economy does not suffer uniformly, they found; the burden is being borne disproportionately by the chemical, coal mining, motor vehicle, refining, primary metals and paper industries.
Dr. Jorgenson and Dr. Wilcoxen calculate, for instance, that the long-run output of the automobile industry has been cut by about 15 percent as a consequence of controls on motor vehicle pollution.
"The flip side of that is that some industries are going to benefit," Dr. Jorgenson said. An example is companies that produce pollution-control equipment and services, a market estimated at more than $100 billion a year.
Mr. Quayle says thousands of auto workers could be thrown out of work if automobile fuel-efficiency standards are raised, as Gov. Bill Clinton favors, to 40 miles per gallon, from 27.5 miles, to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide. Dr. Jorgenson agrees that achieving the standard would impose substantial costs and thereby cause industry employment to shrink. But this does not take into account whatever environmental and economic benefits might result.
Another difficulty in drawing up an economy-vs.-ecology bottom line is that there may be different answers for the short term and the long term, said Dr. H. Ronald Pulliam, an ecologist at the University of Georgia. "In the short term, there are certainly job losses" in some cases of environmental protection. "But in the long run, decades, there is probably very little conflict between maximizing economic goals and ecological goals."
For instance, he said, some jobs would be lost if logging was prohibited in the old-growth forest habitat of the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest. But if the old-growth forest is clear-cut "those jobs are going to be lost anyway in a decade or two," he said, while limiting logging so that biological diversity is preserved over the long haul "is going to provide for the needs of both the local economy and biodiversity."
 
Looking for Short-Term Success
 In a study of the costs of global warming, Dr. William R. Cline of the Institute for International Economics finds that costs would roughly match benefits for the first 20 to 30 years but would then far outstrip them after the easy ways of abating carbon dioxide emissions had all been exploited. But in time, Dr. Cline found, the benefits would begin to outweigh the costs -- in the second half of the next century if the predicted warming were severe, a century later if it fell in the middle range of the predicted warming.
Politicians, of course, do not generally look too far beyond the next election, a predilection that may be shared by their constituents. In a recent study by Resources for the Future and the University of Maryland, researchers asked people in 1,000 households which of two pollution-control programs they preferred, one that saved fewer lives now or one that saved more lives in the future. The researchers found that the respondents considered six lives saved 25 years in the future and 44 lives saved 100 years in the future equivalent to one life saved today.
Economists find that it is especially hard to assign dollar values to some benefits of environmental protection -- for instance, saving a threatened species or ecosystem. They are trying but "I don't think anyone is particularly comfortable with how far they've gotten," Dr. Portney said.
Environmental benefits have often been portrayed as harder to measure than costs. But Dr. Portney says: "Economists have been much too glib about how easy it is to nail down the cost; there are some economists who make it seem like there's nothing out there that we can't slap a dollar value on. We're making progress on some things, but there is a whole range of things that we're never going to be able to express comfortably in dollar terms."
Dr. A. Myrick Freeman 3d of Bowdoin College, an expert on measuring environmental benefits, acknowledges the difficulties. But, he said: "We have methods that are able to measure within an order of magnitude, or within a factor of two, the benefits of many environmental improvements, and plus or minus 25 percent in some cases. The errors, the bounds, around cost estimates are arguably just as large."
Dr. Freeman notes a philosophical objection raised by some critics to the use of cost-benefit analysis: it values the environment only in terms of its usefulness to people without giving "independent weight to nonhuman species or ecological systems" in their own right.
Nevertheless, he said, there is some information that says something about policy, imperfect as it is. "And it's better than making policy in the dark, without any reference at all to costs and benefits," he said.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Iraq: Hope for Rebels

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
They do not like to talk about it too much, or show their hopes too plain. They have been disappointed so often. They have seen so many of their countrymen die when the hopes turned to ashes in the mouth and bitterness in the heart.
But for the first time since the United States allowed Saddam Hussein to survive after the gulf war, Iraqi civilian rebels who use this city as one of their gathering places are beginning to believe that they can see his end in sight. Not immediate, not inevitable, but strategically and logically in sight and achievable within a year, or less. 
 The reason for this new hope is that they think the chances of a large part of the Iraqi Army moving against him have become better now.
The difference, the catalyst, could be the decision by President Bush to declare parts of southern Iraq a "no-fly" zone for Iraqi planes to protect anti-Saddam Iraqi Shiites from Iraqi bombers.
In the U.S. those journalists and politicians who never liked any military move against Saddam Hussein naturally enough shuddered at the no-fly order.
But it strikes me as of more moment that Iraqi civilian rebels who risk their lives and freedom fighting Saddam Hussein see the decision as potentially a political and military turning point.
The U.S. is now playing catch-up ball with Iraq, demanding a few of the prices that should have been imposed when Saddam lost the war. But with no-fly orders in the north, to help protect the Kurds, and in the south for the Shiites, with teams of inspectors moving about the country, trade internationally controlled, Iraq is no longer a sovereign state.
The Iraqi civilian rebels hope that particular reality will now take hold in the Army -- and the knowledge that under Saddam the wreckage that was Iraq cannot be repaired.
Iraqi rebels do not expect effective coups to center in Baghdad. Saddam Hussein has shown that in Baghdad his massive intelligence corps and his military bodyguard divisions strong can strangle a coup before it gets started.
But relative safety from Saddam increases with distance from Baghdad. Basra in the south and Mosul in the north, already stirring with anti-Saddam hatred, are more likely to see military rebellion against him.
Separately, representatives of the two main rebel populations in Iraq (the non-Arab Kurdish Muslims and Iraqi Arab Shiites) ask the same things from the West: to follow through politically on "no-fly." They ask for some of the blocked Iraqi funds to buy weapons, medicines and communication equipment. They ask for steady political and economic pressures, including step-by-step withdrawal of recognition from Baghdad.
The purpose would be not only to damage Saddam Hussein at once but to show the army officers that sooner or later he will have to go and that sooner will mean less bloodshed -- including their own. Also, the officers will have to be convinced that if they mutiny the U.S. will not show them what it showed Iraqi civilian rebels who rose -- its back.
Some of Washington's Middle Eastern allies fear that the no-fly orders could lead to a breakup of Iraq. It is not Iraq's future they worry about but their own -- the idea that contagious breakaway thoughts could spread to their own minorities.
The Turks, the staunchest of America's Muslim allies, have a large Kurdish population. Turkey fears correctly that Turkish Kurdish Maoist terrorists might demand a separate state. But Ankara plays into their hands by harsh military action not just against the small terrorist movement but against whole Kurdish towns in Turkey.
Assuaging Turkey's legitimate fears is a problem Iraqi Kurds who say they want close relations with Turkey will have to deal with -- they and the U.S.
But there is a bigger one, for all Iraqi rebels. It lies in their very hope of an Army rebellion. Won't that lead to a military dictatorship replacing Saddam's?
Yes, they say, it could happen. Once, when American forces were in Iraq, the U.S. might have been able to prevent a military dictatorship as it did in Germany and Italy after World War II. Now it is a risk.
If it happens, they say, we shall see what we can do about that. But unless Saddam goes, there is nothing for us, no future, no life. Do you have a better plan -- risk-free?

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 442 words

HEADLINE: Focus on That 12-Year Waiting List for Public Housing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "A Half-Hearted Homeless Policy" (editorial, Aug. 24), you criticize the policies of Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration toward New York City's homeless population. You are correct, but your reasoning is wrong -- and ultimately dangerous. 
 As you note, the city had until recently a policy of setting aside as many as 2,000 public housing units for homeless families. Under pressure from the overburdened Housing Authority, the Dinkins administration amended that policy to limit the number of homeless families who may be admitted to public housing. You criticize this change as a stop-gap measure, noting that the "problem of where to house the majority of homeless families remains."
To your credit, you describe the relevant factual background in some detail. You call public housing one of the city's "true success stories." You note that these housing developments provide stability for nearly 600,000 "hard-working poor, middle-class and elderly New Yorkers." And most significant, you note that there is now a 12-year waiting list for such units.
Such an extraordinary fact should be cause for alarm. At the least, it should merit discussion of the obvious question: where do hard-working people go during the 12 years it takes to gain entry into the city's success story? Perhaps some poor, middle-class and elderly people, unable to hang on for the 12 years, find themselves slipping into homelessness. Perhaps the discrepancy between housing need and housing resources suggested by the 12-year wait is related to the escalating homeless crisis.
You instead focus on the 8,000 homeless families who have "elbowed aside" those hard-working others. And you are "upset" by "evidence" that some people, "seizing the new opportunity, have deliberately made themselves homeless to get to the head of the line." In a city where getting into public housing involves a 12-year wait, it seems even more upsetting that you consider this evidence of opportunism, instead of what it obviously is: desperation.
The alarming facts you lay out make clear that the real problem is not that a few thousand homeless families are "jumping ahead" in a 12-year waiting list. The real problem is the extraordinary lack of affordable housing, as well as social services, now battering an increasingly diverse population. The real problem is that there is a 12-year waiting list to begin with.
Instead of fostering divisiveness, you should address the underlying housing -- and economic -- crisis that affects us all.
 
MARIA FOSCARINIS
Director, National Law Center
on Homelessness & Poverty
Washington, Aug. 25, 1992

HEADLINE: Finally, a Facade to Fit Stuyvesant;
A High School of High Achievers Gets a High-Priced Home

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN with EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
On the threshold of a new academic year, the rows of battered old desks lie empty at Stuyvesant High School on the East Side, and the great abstruse formulas that inspired genius have gone to dust on the blackboards. In ghostly classrooms, cracked windows are nailed shut against a prowling wind, and the dim hallway globes that burned for 87 years have winked out.
Tomorrow, as the 1992-93 school year begins, a reincarnated Stuyvesant High opens across Manhattan at Battery Park City for 2,700 students and 103 faculty members: a new, lavishly appointed, 10-story futureschool with state-of-the-art computers and 12 science labs, Art Deco lights, five gyms, an Olympic-sized pool, banks of escalators, glassed-in studios, an auditorium worthy of Broadway and stunning Hudson River views from the classrooms. 
 In an era of tight finances, New York City -- which has budgeted $7 billion this year for the education of one million students in 991 schools -- paid $150 million for Stuyvesant, its first new high school in a decade, the costliest ever built in the city and perhaps in the country. Its polished granite entryway, its stylish interiors of teal, taupe and pink, are a world away from the gray old five-story, Victorian limestone hulk built in 1905 for $1.5 million.
The expenditure of millions on an opulent new school for a relatively few students has renewed a cry of elitism against this highly selective, world-class high school, which flourished for generations by admitting only the brightest young scholars. Unlike past complaints, however, parents in other districts and some reform groups now say the issue is money and contend that it is needed elsewhere in a troubled system.
But Stuyvesant's defenders say there is an even greater need to preserve a place in education that represents the best, that sets standards for success year after year in a city that often seems bogged down in bureaucracy and diluted by compromise.
"A city's character is reflected in its high schools," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "In Texas, the investment goes to the football team. In Los Angeles, it's the parking lots. In New York, we look at Stuyvesant and we see the Westinghouse winners."
 
Best and Brightest
 The old school at 15th Street and First Avenue, which was closed last June, was never much to look at. It held out into old age with minimal maintenance and benign neglect until its peeling paint, creaking floorboards and antiquated laboratories became an embarrassment.
But for generations, it meant something special to New York. In a school system that continually struggled with dropouts, truancy, violence and academic failure, Stuyvesant nurtured the best and the brightest, many of them children of poor immigrants and working-class families, vibrant young strangers from all over town who were eager to learn, desperate to succeed.
And it worked phenomenally. Screening applicants with rigorous entrance exams, using teachers with no special qualifications other than a talent for inspiring students, imposing heavy study requirements in a collegial but highly competitive atmosphere that stressed self-discipline and hard work, Stuyvesant produced Nobel laureates and movie stars, philosophers, writers and giants of the arts and sciences.
Stuyvesant scholars annually win prestigious Westinghouse science prizes -- 80 since the competition began in 1942 -- for papers on subjects like enzyme structures. Many are multi-talented in science, music and literature. Virtually every graduate goes to college, many to the nation's most selective universities, and many have become famous, from Tim Robbins, the actor, to Lewis Mumford, the social critic.
What was it that made Stuyvesant great? Its success story, according to interviews in recent days with teachers, students, administrators, graduates and city school officials, has far more to do with the caliber of Stuyvesant's students than its teaching methods, policies or financing.
 
Not Money, But Expectations
 Through the decades, officials said, Stuyvesant got its share of money, but no more than other schools of comparable size; its teachers were drawn from the same pool as the rest of the city, and it had no special policies other than lofty expectations and heavy workloads for students, who often take advanced courses in chemistry, physics and math and labor at homework six hours a night.
At Stuyvesant, ninth-graders do not simply take five periods of biology a week; they take research biology for 10 periods, half of them in labs working on classical and original experiments. Similar research is offered in physics and chemistry. The best students are paired with professional scientists at places like Rockefeller University, and they spend hours after school and on weekends working on projects.
Most Stuyvesant students are admitted solely on the results of a difficult examination, although about 12 percent who score close to the cutoff and are certified as disadvantaged are admitted each year. This year, some 10,000 applicants took the test for 800 openings in the freshman and sophomore classes.
Abraham Baumel, the principal, said Stuyvesant was even more selective than the two other academically competitive public high schools in the city, which also accept students mainly on the test scores, Bronx High School of Science and Brooklyn Technical High School.
Stuyvesant has been attacked periodically through the years as a bastion of elitism and discrimination. Its student body was all male until 1969 and was overwhelmingly Jewish for many years. Last year, it was about 51 percent Asian, 40 percent white and 9 percent black and Hispanic.
"They can do more than they are doing," said Janet Price, deputy executive director of the Fund for New York City Public Education, a non-profit reform group. She said Stuyvesant and city school officials should work with pupils from poor neighborhoods to insure that more academically talented black and Hispanic candidates are well prepared to pass the entrance exams.
Ms. Price and other critics also disputed the wisdom of spending millions on a new school for Stuyvesant, saying the money was needed elsewhere in a city with many deteriorating schools and overcrowded classrooms. "It's not the kind of school we need most in the city right now," Ms. Price said.
Obah David Ward, a former president of the Parent-Teachers Association at Boys and Girls High in Brooklyn, said the improvement of schools in poorer areas was a more pressing need. "The poor schools get poorer, the rich schools get richer," he said. "The quality of a nation, the quality of a city, is really dependent on what it does for the masses of its people."
But others praised Stuyvesant as a beacon of excellence in public education, an example of what Thomas Jefferson hailed as the aristocracy of talent. Some noted also that Stuyvesant had survived many legislative and Board of Education votes to dilute or dismantle its admission standards, as well as investigations by local and Federal agencies and pressure by civil-rights groups.
Dr. Joshua Lederberg, the retired president of Rockefeller University, who graduated from Stuyvesant in 1941 and won the Nobel Prize for physiology and medicine in 1958 for his research in microbial genetics, argued against any change of standards at Stuyvesant.
Stuyvesant, Dr. Lederberg said, "was the most important socializing experience in shaping my life, a place you could really sharpen your wits on." He added, "It represented part of the system of social mobility that New York City used to be famous for, that has sadly deteriorated. It's sort of the last bastion of that kind of spirit."
As for spending on the new school, he said: "I don't think there is any other school in the country that can boast its level of return on investment. Above all, it lifts everybody up. It's something to be proud of. There are not many other things that New York can point to with pride in the social arena."
 
'I Was Challenged'
 Tony Zirilli, a news-library supervisor for The New York Times who graduated from Stuyvesant in 1963, recalled a traditional, academically rigorous experience that included heavy homework and little socializing with classmates, who were all boys and lived throughout the city. "It was not a neighborhood school," he noted. "I traveled an hour and a half on the bus and subway from Queens."
In a collegelike atmosphere, he said, students were highly motivated and self-disciplined. The teachers used class time for discussion and debate that ranged widely, even outside the course material, into social studies, history, current events and other topics. "They expected you to do a lot more on your own -- to get the course work yourself," he recalled.
"It was a big shock," he said. "I never had to work to be the top of my class in junior high. All of a sudden, I was working harder than ever and I was just an average student. It was the first time I was challenged to think. There were no spitballs or paper airplanes. Cutting classes was virtually unheard of."
If there is such a thing as a typical Stuyvesant student today it could be Jia Lu Yin, a senior who is a violinist, debater, journalist, member of the Governor's Youth Council, vice president of Stuyvesant's National Honor Society chapter and a top student who plans to apply to Harvard, the University of Chicago and the State University of New York at Binghamton.
She is not yet an American citizen. Her family moved to New York from China 10 years ago so she could get a good education. She spoke no English then; her parents still don't. Her father is a waiter in a Chinese restaurant; her mother is unemployed.
 
'Intellectual Atmosphere'
 Ms. Yin praised Stuyvesant as "a great intellectual atmosphere," but she also said it was a place of intense pressure, where hard-pressed students sometimes resorted to plagiarizing reports and exchanging answers on tests.
"There's a lot of cheating going on," Ms. Yin said. "There is so much pressure. There is so much expectation to do well or else you won't go to the Ivy League school of your dreams." She added: "Stuyvesant is like a showcase to say to the public that the Board of Education hasn't failed."
Ms. Yin also was critical of the school for failing to attract more black and Hispanic students, and she said she thought some of the millions spent on the new school should have gone elsewhere. "I don't feel it's fair that we spent all that money on our school," she said, noting that friends at other schools had been shortchanged. "These kids need encouragement the most," she said. "They look around and say, 'Society has already given up on me.' "
But Stuyvesant High -- named for Peter Stuyvesant, the Dutch last governor of New Amsterdam -- opens a new era tomorrow, and many students, faculty members and administrators are feeling good about it. "They are oooing and aaaing," a harried Mr. Baumel, the principal, said amid stacks of paper and cartons of unpacked books. "This is the most extraordinary school I've ever seen."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 9, 1992, Wednesday / September 12, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the new Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the condition and status of the old school building. The former Stuyvesant remains open, housing the High School for Environmental Studies, the Mabel D. Bacon High School, citywide special education classes and adult evening classes.
An article on Tuesday about the new Stuyvesant High School building in Manhattan misstated the size of its swimming pool. It is 75 feet long, the standard for Public School Athletic League competition.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler to Move Its Headquarters

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, which had previously said it would not move its corporate base from Highland Park, Mich., announced today that it would transfer its headquarters operations to its technology center in Auburn Hills, about 50 miles to the north.
Chrysler said the move was necessary because it had eliminated 12,000 white-collar jobs since 1987 and had reorganized its engineers into teams from functional departments. 
 The platform-team concept, organized around individual vehicles, requires that various disciplines, including product design, engineering, manufacturing and procurement and supply, work together under one roof. "Under this organization, it is essential for the entire team to be together in the same location," said Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman. "We can't have our executives traveling 50 miles back and forth for meetings two and three times a day."
 
 
Depressed City
 Highland Park, an economically depressed city of 20,000 people, is mostly surrounded by Detroit. It has been home to Chrysler since the company was founded in 1925.
Deputy Mayor Scotty Wainwright said in response to the Chrysler announcement: "Before the 1987 downsizing, Chrysler was Highland Park's largest employer, and they're right up near the top today. We haven't had a chance to sit down and review the facts."
When the move to Auburn Hills is complete in about three years, Chrysler said it expected to keep only 500 technical and administrative employees in Highland Park of the 5,000 employed there now. Chrysler pledged to work with Highland Park officials in an effort to reduce the economic impact of the move and to determine the best future use for its facilities.
While criticizing Japanese automobile manufacturers for opening United States factories in rural locations, Chrysler opened its new Jefferson Avenue plant on the east side of Detroit last year. The plant produces the Jeep Grand Cherokee.

International
The White House and Congress squared off on the North American Free Trade Agreement. President Bush released the text of the pact with Mexico and Canada and sent his top trade official to the Senate to begin lobbying for it. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Canada Pushes for Pact

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Canadian Government has begun a campaign to promote a free-trade pact with Mexico and the United States, and it published a poll that showed mounting public support for the deal. A Government survey shows that approval of the agreement, which would create the world's largest free-trade zone, grew to 46 percent in August from 29 percent in March. Opposition to the pact centers on concerns about increased unemployment. The Canadian Government will spend $3.1 million Canadian ($2.6 million) on a campaign to promote the benefits of trade and the North American deal.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
U.S. Bond Yields Fall to Lowest in Years

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market rallied sharply again yesterday, continuing the surge set off Friday by the weak employment report and sending some yields to lows not seen in years.
In late trading, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 7.21 percent, its lowest since September of 1986. The bond's price rose 24/32 , to 10012/32 . In the last two trading days, the bond's yield has fallen 14 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. 
 Yields of notes and bills also fell sharply. The two-year note fell to 3.78 percent, its lowest ever and down from 3.86 percent on Friday. And the yield on the 10-year note dropped 10 basis points, to 6.28 percent.
In the weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the discount rate on the three-month bill fell to 2.91 percent, the lowest since May 1963, and the discount rate on the six-month bill dropped to 2.95 percent, the lowest since March 1963.
Corporate and municipal issuers were also active yesterday, taking advantage of lower yields to borrow at lower cost, in some cases to refinance issues with higher rates sold years ago.
Many traders and analysts think the 30-year bond's yield will move down to 7 percent, which would be the lowest since the early 1970's.
"There is good potential for it to do better; to make at least one last move lower," said Mary Rooney, a financial economist at S. G. Warburg & Company in New York.
She said the next economic reports, like retail sales and industrial production, would continue to show that the economy was flat, providing an environment for still-lower rates. The unemployment report on Friday showed a surprising decline of 167,000 private-sector jobs in August.
But while all yields continue to fall, the spread between yields of shorter maturities, like 2-year notes, and the yield of the 30-year bond continues at or near record proportions. That is not good news for the economy, since these long rates have a big impact on the housing industry.
Yesterday, the spread between the yield on the 2-year note and the 30-year bond was 343 basis points, just off its record widest of 344 basis points on July 17.
The 30-year bond is the riskiest of fixed-income investments, and analysts say that its relatively high yield compared with that of shorter maturities shows that some investors are worried about the outcome of the Presidential election and the costs of any economic stimulus program that might be proposed. Any such program would increase the Federal budget deficit, another concern of bond investors, because it could lead to more Federal borrowing. Also, analysts said, investors may not yet be convinced that inflation will remain low.
"The weaker things get, the more stimulative economic package we could get," Ms. Rooney said.
Like the rally in July, the price rise in the intermediate maturities, like the 5- and 10-year notes, came as retail investors chose to buy securities with longer maturities to get higher interest rates. In addition, some traders said there was more selling of longer-term mortgage-backed securities and buying of 5- and 10-year notes to fill the gap in institutional portfolios.
The mortgage-backed securities are being sold because the drop in interest rates raises the threat that the underlying mortgages will be refinanced and paid off early, which can mean a loss for investors.
 
Corporate Issues
 More than $1.5 billion in corporate bonds were issued yesterday, led by a $500 million issue of 10-year notes by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation. In addition, the BankAmerica Corporation sold $250 million of 10-year notes and Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. sold $250 million of 30-year debentures.
"There is a very large shadow calendar out there," said one corporate bond trader, referring to the corporate issues waiting in the wings. "There is a lot of cash out there and a very bullish sentiment."
The activity was less hectic in the municipal bond market but traders said that was just the post-Labor Day holiday calm ahead of an active week. According to Stephen Leslie, a senior vice president at M. R. Beal & Company, just the top 10 issues scheduled to be sold this week total more than $3 billion.
Among the issues waiting to be priced are a $494 million issue by the New York State Medical Care Facility Authority; a $350 million issue by the New York Local Government Assistance Corporation and a $390 million issue by the city and county of Denver, for the airport.
The municipal market has rallied about one to two full points in the last week, since it dropped sharply last month as the rush of issues overwhelmed the market.
Because of the current rally in the Treasury market, some traders think investors will be able to absorb the new issues. But they do not expect anything like the rally in July. And if the pricing gets too aggressive and the yields too low, the market could retreat a little.
"We have a heavy supply and do not have the same investment demand as in July," said Austin Tobin, the president of the Delphis Hanover Corporation.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction of three- and six- month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: Cairo Journal;
Arab Favorite for Nice Times (and Naughty Ones)

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
The temperature is nearly 100 degrees, the bridges over the Nile are a hopeless tangle of bleating horns and snorting motors, and the yellowish air is thick with dust and diesel fumes and something that smells faintly of donkeys.
But none of this seems to faze Mohammed al-Matrud, a happy tourist from Saudi Arabia. Others may prefer April in Paris or autumn in New York, but for Mr. Matrud, nothing can top summer in Cairo. 
 "You can go to a mosque and pray if you want, or you can go look at the Nile, or you can go on a picnic, or you can visit a village," Mr. Matrud said as he sat in the air-conditioned lobby of the Cairo Marriott, a businessman at leisure in an orange polo shirt and black and orange shorts. Or, he added with a sly grin, "you can go and watch the belly dancers."
Mr. Matrud, whose wife and two children are on vacation with him, is among a large and growing army of tourists from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Libya and the rest of the Middle East who in recent years have turned Cairo and Egypt into the Arab world's favorite summer vacation destination.
 
A Tonic for the Economy
 In August and early September, they overflow Egypt's expensive resort hotels and apartment blocks, whole families of veiled women and of men in traditional white robes and headdresses, spending the big money that is a tonic for Egypt's tattered economy.
The Ministry of Tourism has estimated that Arabs will account for 40 percent of the three million tourists who are expected to visit Egypt this year. Most come in August and September, when they are expected to spend in just two months nearly 25 percent of the $3 billion in tourist revenues forecast for Egypt for all of 1992.
While Europeans and Americans prefer to visit Egypt in the winter, seeking a warm place in the sun, travelers from the austere desert kingdoms of the Arabian Peninsula have increasingly made Cairo a summer destination. Their numbers have grown steadily since the 1970's, when civil war in Lebanon forced them to abandon Beirut.
Compared with the scorching summers in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, the blistering summer heat of Cairo is no drawback, and since the decline of Beirut the Egyptian capital is the most cosmopolitan and most seductive metropolis in the Middle East, a clamorous, dirty, sprawling, libertine place that stays open all night, and where anything seems possible at the right price.
Part of Cairo's appeal is that it has traditionally offered Arab tourists from the puritanical Muslim societies of the Persian Gulf -- where drinking and gambling are strictly forbidden -- a chance to let their hair down and indulge in the Arab equivalent of what the British call a "dirty weekend."
 
Discos and Casinos Profit
 They crowd the discotheques and casinos at the Hilton, the Sheraton and the Marriott in Cairo, and fill the front tables in the bawdy nightclubs along the Pyramids Road, where some of the most enthusiastic among them have been known to string $100 bills into necklaces as favors for their favorite belly dancers.
Arab tourists also say shopping in Cairo offers good value compared with the prices they must pay for imported goods in the Persian Gulf.
On a recent Sunday, groups of veiled women glided among the aisles of M. M., a fashionable clothing shop here, examining the sleek displays of Italian shoes, French dresses and Spanish leather goods. Others climbed the stairs to the third floor, where, out of sight of male customers, an assortment of imported lingerie is discreetly displayed.
Yasin Mahmoud Nur, the manager, estimated that shoppers from Kuwait and Saudi Arabia accounted for 50 percent of the shop's annual revenues.
But the flood of high-spending tourists from the Arabian Peninsula has also provoked the ire of some Egyptians, in a country where the average worker survives on wages of barely $40 a month, and beggars squat on the sidewalk less than a block from luxury hotels.
 
Arrogant, Egyptians Say
 A ritual complaint among many Egyptians is that the Saudis and the Kuwaitis are arrogant and that they treat them with disdain bordering on contempt.
"They look down their noses at us, and tell us that we are stealing from them because of the prices we ask for shoes or clothes or apartments," said a clerk in a jewelry shop, asking that his name not be used. "But then they go out to the Pyramids Road and throw their money at belly dancers without a second thought."
Mahmoud Hamid, a taxi driver waiting for a fare outside the Marriott, was even more emphatic. "They don't come here to look at our monuments and they know nothing at all about Eygpt's history and its culture," he said. "I prefer the Europeans to the Arabs, who only want to gamble in the nightclubs and chase Egyptian women."
For their part, some Arab tourists say Egyptians try to take advantage of them. One man complained he had been quoted a price of about $33,000 for an apartment, but when he went back three days later the seller, realizing he was from Kuwait, immediately raised the price to about $73,000.
"Egypt is a wonderful place, one thousand times less expensive than anywhere else," said a man who identified himself as Sheik Khalifa, who was vacationing in Cairo from Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates. "The only problem is that everyone thinks the gulf man is the rich man."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Tells Jews That Rival Would Have Harmed Israel

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Opening a fall campaign to woo Jewish voters, President Bush today told a Jewish gathering that Israel's survival would now be threatened had the United States been led by Gov. Bill Clinton, who "waffled" and "wavered" on whether to confront Iraq.
Mr. Bush also said that assertions that he or others in his Administration harbored anti-Semitic attitudes, because they had at times disagreed with Israeli policies, were wrong and hurtful to him personally. For much of the past four years, the President was at odds with pro-Israeli Jewish groups over his insistence that the Israeli Government curtail settlement building in the West Bank as a condition for housing loan guarantees. 
 "Let me say that it is important that we learn how to disagree," Mr. Bush said to the B'nai B'rith International Convention. "To accuse those who may come to different conclusions on one or another public issue of harboring anti-Semitism is to cheapen the term. That is dangerous. That is deeply wrong. And when those words, without justice, have been aimed at me, I can tell you, they cut to the heart."
The President added that he had not yet made a decision on whether to sell 72 F-15 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia, but he and other Administration officials pointed out that Governor Clinton had already spoken in favor of the sale. The sale could save thousands of jobs in a crucial state, Missouri, where the plane's manufacturer, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, is based.
Mr. Bush said he was weighing all of the national security and economic factors before making a decision on the sale, while Mr. Clinton simply endorsed the deal in answer to a question at a public meeting. But the President left the strong impression that he, too, would back the sale.
 
Grumbling About Clinton
 Mr. Bush's remarks to B'nai B'rith were described by aides as his opening effort to win Jewish voters, who will be crucial in states like California, Florida and Illinois, where the voting is expected to be close. Mr. Bush got roughly 25 percent of the Jewish vote in 1988, and Bush campaign officials contend that despite the tensions between the Administration and Israel in recent years Mr. Bush can do at least as well this time around.
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to address the same group tomorrow, but not in person. He will appear through a television hookup, a fact that had many in the audience grumbling that the Democratic candidate was taking their votes for granted.
The Clinton-Gore campaign issued a statement today that termed Mr. Bush's support for Israel "another election year conversion."
"Less than 60 days before the election," it said, "George Bush is trying to convince the American Jewish Community he's been on their side for the last four years. It won't sell. Since his election, George Bush has been bullying Israel and offending the American Jewish community."
Nevertheless, Abraham D. Foxman, executive director of the Anti-Defamation League, said Mr. Clinton had erred in not addressing the B'nai B'rith gathering in person. The President, Mr. Foxman added, had at least come and touched most of the right bases in his speech, although Mr. Bush still had problems with many Jews because of the repeated Christian references at the Republican National convention, which did not seem very receptive to Jewish concerns.
This gentle criticism of Mr. Clinton comes in the aftermath of other complaints by the leaders of various Jewish organizations that the Democratic candidate had spoken in favor of the F-15 sale, provided it was conditioned on terms that will not diminish Israel's qualitative edge over the Arabs, without any advance warning to pro-Israel groups.
Mr. Clinton endorsed the sale on Aug. 25 in answer to a question at a meeting with voters in Dallas, saying he would support such a sale "under the right circumstances."
 
Listing Accomplishments
 As for Mr. Bush, he got a polite, but not exactly ecstatic reception today. The basic thrust of his address was that while the tone of his Administration's foreign policy may not always have been right, as far as American Jews were concerned, the substance was in fact pro-Israeli. His Administration confronted Iraq, he said, brought about direct peace talks between Israel and its Arab neighbors and helped Russian and Ethiopian Jews emigrate to Israel. He has also recently approved $10 billion in loan guarantees for Israel.
Mr. Bush made no mention of his policy before the Persian Gulf war of building up Iraq's military arsenal in hopes of moderating the positions of that country's President, Saddam Hussein.
"Ask yourself where the Middle East would be today, where Israel's security would be today, if we had followed the counsel of my critics," Mr. Bush declared. "Ask yourself where we would be if we had someone in the Oval Office who would have waffled, who would have wavered and wanted to have it both ways.
"Listen to my opponent's very own words on whether he would have followed my lead, and drawn a line in the sand. I quote: 'I guess I would have voted with the majority if it was a close vote. But I agree with the arguments the minority made.' "
Mr. Clinton now emphasizes that he was a consistent supporter of the gulf war.
