HEADLINE: Dow Retreats 21.34 Points in Light Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market declined yesterday, with investors expressing growing pessimism about the economy after last week's dismal employment report.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 21.34 points, to 3,260.59. 
 Trading was light, but the losses stretched across the spectrum. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 161.4 million shares as of 4 P.M., up from 124.4 million in the previous session. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Big Board's composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 1.38 at 228.37. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.49 at 383.36. The Nasdaq composite fell 2.27, to 571.17.
The Government on Friday reported private employment fell by 167,000 jobs in August while the nation's unemployment rate dropped to 7.6 percent from 7.7 percent in July.
The Dow Jones average fell 10.27 points Friday after the report, and analysts said the long Labor Day holiday weekend seemed to accentuate a gloomy outlook toward the economy.
"It's almost unfortunate we had the weekend to think about that report," said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at the First Albany Corporation. "When you really examine the report carefully and try an find something rosy, or cheery, or positive, you still come up pretty empty-handed."
Bank stocks took the brunt of the selling yesterday as investors worried that a slow economy might stir up further trouble in loan portfolios, Mr. Johnson said.
Chase Manhattan, the Big Board's most active issue, fell 7/8, to 22; Citicorp lost 7/8, to 15 1/2; Chemical Banking dropped 1 3/4, to 31 1/2; J. P. Morgan was off 1/8 at 60 1/8, and BankAmerica was down 1 at 42 7/8.
Other so-called cyclical stocks, or companies whose fortunes are closely tied to economic cycles, came under selling pressure. Alcoa dropped 1, to 65 1/2; Caterpillar was down 1 1/2 at 47 3/4; International Paper fell 1 3/4, to 62 3/8, and Burlington Northern, was down 1 3/8 at 34 1/2.
Alan Ackerman, executive vice president at Reich & Company said many traders were depressed because the market failed to muster a traditional pre-Labor Day rally.
"There's been no spark to get the market going," Mr. Ackerman said. "This remains a very selective, very treacherous market."
G.M., among the most active New York Stock Exchange stocks, fell 1 1/8, to 34. Work resumed at G.M.'s Lordstown, Ohio stamping plant following the end of a nine-day strike on Saturday that shut several assembly plants across the country.
Heinz was down 3/8 at 41 1/2, off earlier lows in the day. It reported earnings of 55 cents a share for its first quarter ended July 29, against 95 cents a share during the comparable period in 1991. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation was down 1 3/8 at 41 1/4 after a brokerage firm downgraded the mortgage concern's prospects.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKET;
Finland's Move Jars Markets

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
A decision by Finland to devalue its currency rippled through the world's financial markets today, setting off yet another surge in the value of the German mark and pushing most European stock prices lower.
The rise in the mark sent the dollar down again in trading in London. The dollar closed here at 1.3915 marks, down from 1.4030 on Monday, and in New York trading the dollar closed at 1.3945 marks, down from 1.4015 on Friday, which was the last day of trading before the Labor Day holiday. 
 Fears that the rise in the mark and the corresponding decline of most other currencies would force Italy, Britain and other nations to raise interest rates rattled equity markets in Europe.
 
2 Declines and a Small Rise
 In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index fell 34.5 points, to 2,337.7. Investors in Paris sent the market there down by 15.63 points, to 1,763.67 on the CAC-40 index. Stocks in Frankfurt had a small gain, closing at 1,544.35, up 3.92 on the DAX-30 index.
"The markets are very sensitive to things European, and there are a lot of implications of higher interest rates," said Robert Barrie, a European economist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. in London.
The devaluation by Finland -- actually a decision to allow its markka to float in value rather than to keep it pegged to other European currencies -- came as investors were already skeptical of the stability of Europe's other weak currencies, including the British pound and the Italian lira.
Investors have also been nervous for several weeks that voters in France may reject a treaty on the next stage of European unification when it is put to a referendum on Sept. 20. A rejection could push the mark even higher, forcing other nations to choose between raising interest rates to defend their currencies or dropping their commitment to keeping their currency values linked within a specified range. A poll released today showed the vote in France too close to call.
 
Pressure on Weaker Markets
 "What's happened in Scandinavia has increased concerns about possible devaluations elsewhere," said Darren Cullen, an economist with Salomon Brothers in London. "As you've had increased challenges to exchange-rate policy in advance of Sept. 20, the weaker markets have come under growing pressure."
Analysts said Finland's move reinforced the belief among investors that the mark was the only haven, forcing the German currency's value up again. The pound, for example, fell to 2.788 marks from 2.795.
Finland had decided last year to peg the value of the markka to a basket of European currencies as a way of reducing inflation and getting the nation's economy into shape in preparation for eventual entrance into the European Community.
But Prime Minister Esko Aho, faced with a deep recession caused in part by a decline in trade with the former Soviet Union, chose today to allow the currency's value to float rather than raising interest rates further or intervening heavily in foreign currency markets to protect the markka. In currency trading today, the markka fell about 13 percent. Finland had devalued the currency once before, in November of last year, by a similar amount.
 
Trouble in Scandinavia
 Finland's decision quickly created problems for Sweden and Norway as well, as investors fled their currencies, worried that they, too, might be devalued. Norway, seeking to avoid a sharp decline in its krone, intervened by buying the currency in the markets. Sweden acted quickly to maintain the value of its krona by pushing interest rates up to an all-time high of 24 percent, from 16 percent.
But with Scandinavian nations mired in recessions, it is unclear how long Sweden and perhaps Norway will be able to avoid devaluations.
"Markets are concerned that the Swedish central bank may be unable to sustain the current parity of the krona," Mr. Cullen of Salomon Brothers said. "The substantial 8-point rate hike should be sufficient to calm market nerves for now. However, Swedish rates are unsustainable at these levels. The Swedish economy is already in the depths of its deepest recession in over 50 years."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Widespread Declines
 In Tokyo yesterday, the dollar closed at 123.28 yen, down 0.17 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 122.65 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 122.85 yen, down from 123.15 on Friday.
In London, the pound rose to $2.0037, from $1.9933 late Monday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $2.0040, down from $1.9960, late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.2355 Swiss francs, down from 1.2525; 4.7470 French francs, down from 4.7785; 1,065.00 Italian lire, down from 1,074.00, and 1.20635 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1985. (AP)

HEADLINE: A Season for Shooting 'Problem' Geese

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND ISLAND, N.Y.

 BODY:
Like football games and falling leaves, goose hunting is a symbol of autumn in western New York. But this year gunfire was heard even before Labor Day, a result of a special 10-day hunting season aimed at thinning the goose population in three counties.
"It's not the migratory geese that are the problem," said Dale R. Dewing, field crop agent with the Cattaraugus County Cooperative Extension. "It's the ones that live here year-round." 
 As the Canada goose population of western New York has grown over the last 20 years, so have complaints from residents, especially farmers and golfers.
 
Fond of Corn
 For farmers, the problem is economic. In Cattaraugus County, Mr. Dewing estimates that geese have eaten "tens of thousands of dollars" worth of crops, mostly corn grown to feed the county's 26,000 dairy cows. "It's certainly not something that's of disastrous proportions, but it concerns the farmers involved," he said.
For golfers, the concern is where there are geese, there are droppings.
"Many times there's no clean area to lay the golf bag down in," said Benjamin W. Morey, manager of Beaver Island State Park, just north of Buffalo. "Many times the ball gets a color other than white."
 
1,000 Kills Expected
 To reduce the goose population, the State Department of Environmental Conservation opened a special 10-day hunting season beginning Sept. 1 in Erie, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua counties. The state's regular goose-hunting season runs for 70 days beginning in November.
Officials estimate there are 9,000 geese in the three counties. As the Labor Day weekend started, the department had issued about 1,500 hunting permits. Each hunter is allowed to kill six birds in the 10-day season, with a maximum of three in one day.
If each hunter bagged the limit, the goose problem -- and the geese -- would be eliminated. But realistically, officials said, only about 1,000 geese probably will be killed.
"I know hunters have been very successful in the southern tier counties, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua," said Kenneth J. Roblee, a senior wildlife biologist with the Department of Environmental Conservation. "But I know as far as Beaver Island and the Niagara River, the take has been very light."
Not everyone favors the hunting solution to the goose problem.
"If something is endangering a human being, we can see why you'd have to kill it," said Valerie P. Will, president of Animal Rights Advocates of Western New York. "But just because it's on a golf course?"
About 15 members of Mrs. Will's group presented a petition against the hunt to state officials on Aug. 27. Five days later, on the eve of the hunt, the group staged a "wake" at Beaver Island park, leaving wreaths on the turf for the geese about to fall.

HEADLINE: President and Congress Square Off On North American Trade Accord

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The White House and Congress squared off today on the North American Free Trade Agreement as President Bush released the text of the pact and sent his top trade official to the Senate to begin lobbying for it.
After 14 months of contentious negotiations, Canada, Mexico and the United States on Aug. 12 announced their agreement on a continental free trade zone that would eventually eliminate customs duties and most other restrictions on the sale of goods and services across their borders. And on the campaign stump Mr. Bush cites the accord as one of his top achievements. 
 But on Capitol Hill today, the pact drew immediate criticism, not only from protectionist Democrats but from free trade Democrats. They accused the President of using the pact as an election-year wedge to split the Democratic Party and portray Gov. Bill Clinton as indecisive.
Mr. Clinton endorsed the negotiation of an agreement last year but since then has refused to take a position, saying he needed to study the finished document, which was classified until now. His stance has prompted Republican charges that he has "hemmed and hawed," yielding to pressure from labor unions, who argue that American jobs will be lost to cheaper labor in Mexico.
 
No Clear Positions
 George Stephanopoulos, the communications director for the Arkansas Governor, said today that Mr. Clinton would not only wait to review the agreement with his aides but would probably also wait for the conclusion of a series of four hearings being held by the Senate Finance Committee.
"We need to hear the hearings," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. The last hearing is tentatively scheduled for Sept. 24.
Like the Democratic nominee, Republican as well Democratic senators on the Finance Committee, who began reviewing the pact today, took pains to avoid establishing any clear position. With Election Day only 55 days away and public anxiety about the economic future crystallizing around the trade pact in hard-hit areas of the nation, many politicians are hanging back until electoral trends become clearer.
Senator Bob Packwood, an Oregon Republican who is the ranking minority member of the Finance Committee and who faces a tough re-election fight, said he would not make up his mind until after the Finance Committee had held four scheduled hearings on the issue. Two Republican Senators whose terms are up in 1994, John C. Danforth of Missouri and Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, took the same position.
 
Accusations of Hast
 Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who as chairman of the Subcommittee on International Trade led free trade senators last year in their successful battle to give the White House the authority to negotiate the accord, led the charge against it. He said the Administration had rushed into a flawed agreement to be able to claim a triumph in time for the Republican convention, which opened in Houston on Aug. 17, five days after the pact was announced.
"It is clear that some important provisions have gotten short shrift," Mr. Baucus said in a speech at the first Finance Committee hearing today. "Despite strong advice from many of us in Congress, this agreement simply does not pay adequate attention to job displacement or environmental concerns."
The President's top trade official, Carla A. Hills, insisted in her testimony before the Senate Finance Committee this afternoon that the agreement would protect the environment and create more jobs than it eliminated, and that the agreement had not been rushed.
Mrs. Hills, the United States trade representative, also said that all issues were resolved before the announcement was made, and that work on the agreement since then had been limited to the drafting of legal text. She and Mr. Danforth pointed out that the Finance Committee routinely votes on amendments and bills while leaving the final legal text to be drafted later.
People involved in the negotiations said that all substantial issues were resolved last month and that the continuing talks among lawyers were limited to narrow points like punctuation and the consistency of legal language from one chapter to the next in the seven-inch-thick agreement.
Exchanges between Mrs. Hills and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee and is the most influential Senator on trade issues, were especially acerbic. Mr. Bentsen said that Mrs. Hills had inaccurately reported the extent of progress on the accord and that Republican attacks on Mr. Clinton threatened the bipartisan majority in Congress in favor of free trade. Mr. Bentsen said he would not give his position on the pact until after his committee's hearings.
Both Congress and Mr. Clinton have plenty of time to make up their minds under the special rules for consideration of free trade pacts. To begin with, the Administration still has not legally submitted the agreement to Congress because some of Mrs. Hills's 40 private-sector advisory groups have not yet finished their reports on it and because some legal details are still being hammered out.
Once the reports and the agreement are ready, probably not until at least next week, the agreement will be formally submitted for Congressional review. Mr. Bush will be able to sign it 90 days later.
Early next year, whoever is President will have the right to send legislation to Congress putting the agreement into legal force. The President drafts the legislation in consultation with Congress, which is not allowed to amend it. Each house will then have 90 Congressional working days to vote on the pact, with a simple majority needed for approval.
 
Provisions Could Be Added
 Congress votes on the legislation, not the agreement, which does not address hot-button issues such as retraining for workers who lose their jobs to cheaper Mexican labor or environmental cleanup along the border. The legislation could legally include many provisions on such questions so long as the provisions do not contradict anything in the agreement.
The main text released today contained detailed rules for the elimination of restrictions on everything from cross-border investments to the purchase of goods and services by Government agencies and state-owned enterprises in all three countries.
The text was as interesting for what it did not include as for what it did. Omitted, for example, were any new restrictions on American agriculture to inhibit competition in the highly protected industry and raise prices for consumers.
An Agriculture Department analysis, scheduled for release soon, concludes that the pact would have little net effect on most Americans' supermarket budgets. The analysis is politically opportune for the Administration because it allows assurances to consumers and farmers that neither's interests are being sacrificed.
The agreement does include lengthy rules that goods be produced within North America to qualify for duty-free treatment. The rules are intended to prevent the evasion of import taxes by exporters outside North America, who would otherwise be tempted to ship all their goods for the Mexican, Canadian and American markets through whichever country offered the lowest tariffs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, lobbying for the North American Free Trade Agreement before the Senate Finance Committee in Washington. A copy of the pact is in front of her. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. D2)
 
Chart: "Principal Provisions of the Agreement"
 Advertising -- American and Canadian companies will be able to do business in Mexico without local offices and hiring local staff.
 Agriculture -- Duties on all farm products will be phased out, some quickly, some over 15 years.
 Autos -- Over 10 years, Mexico's requirement for a rough balance in the import and export of cars and car parts will be phased out. So will tariffs on trucks and on cars if 62.5 percent of the car's value is built in North America.
 Disputes -- Special judges will resolve disagreements.
 Energy -- Mexico will pay performance bonuses to successful oil exploration companies.
 Financial Services -- Limits on American and Canadian ownership of Mexican banks, securities firms and insurance companies will be removed in stages, with all limits removed by Jan. 1, 2000.
 Immigration -- Most professionals from all three countries will be able to work anywhere in North America more easily, but large-scale immigration from Mexico will be barred.
 Jobs and the Environment -- The agreement makes no direct provision for job retraining in the United States, or for environmental cleanup along the Mexican border.
 Tariffs -- Customs duties on nearly 10,000 products will be eliminated over 15 years.
 Textiles -- Garments will qualify for duty-free treatment only if the yarn is made, the cloth is woven, and all cutting and sewing are done in North America. Canada has won a partial exemption from this rule. (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

 NEW YORK CITY
 
 A CASE STUDY
 IN FAILURE
Five-year-old Randi Anderson scrawled on the walls of her foster home with lipstick. She stole money from her foster mother's purse. She broke all her toys. But while three New York City child-welfare workers concluded that she needed counseling, she never got it. And when she provoked her foster mother's 20-year-old son once too often, she was beaten to death. Randi did not fall through a small, isolated tear in the safety net. Although hers was an extreme case, it points up the failings of the city's child welfare system in caring for the thousands of emotionally troubled children who have poured into foster care in recent years. A1.
 
 BYSTANDERS KILLED IN BRONX SHOOTING
An argument at a block party in the Bronx escalated into gunfire that killed two bystanders, including a woman who was seven months pregnant, the police said. The baby was delivered in a Caesarean section but died three hours later. B3.
 
 51 TICKETS AND STILL DRIVING
Despite a long record of reckless driving and the lack of a valid license, a flawed system failed to keep Christopher Devita off the road. A tow-truck driver who has been stopped by the police and ticketed 51 times since 1985, when his drivers license was suspended, Mr. Devita was behind the wheel on Sunday when he plowed into a car and killed a woman in Brooklyn. State and city officials say that government agencies had no way to prevent a similar incident from occurring. B3.
 
 A man wrongfully convicted can sue for damages, a Federal appeals court ruled. B3.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut Visit;
Clinton Tours Plant to Talk About the Issue: Jobs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton campaigned in Connecticut today, focusing on the need to make American manufacturing more competitive. Whether or not people agreed with his proposals, he was talking about what many wanted to hear: jobs and the economy.
Addressing workers at an employee-owned factory in Portland, and speaking outside a restaurant here where he met with Democratic leaders, Mr. Clinton added details to his own economic plan, while accusing the Bush Administration of lacking one. 
 "Unlike our competitors, America has no national economic strategy," he told employees of Standard Knapp, a manufacturer of packaging machinery in Portland. "Instead we have a series of unconnected, piecemeal efforts, and trickle-down economics. Under trickle-down economics, our manufacturing strength has trickled away."
The Arkansas Governor proposed using money saved from military cuts to establish 170 manufacturing extension centers, modeled on the agricultural extension centers that have long aided American farmers, to help small and medium-sized companies.
 
Emphasis on Retraining
 Twenty-five of the centers, he said, should be in areas hit hard by military cuts and devoted to retraining both production workers and scientists from military contractors.
He also proposed rewriting Federal tax laws to provide incentives for investing in new manufacturing equipment, and encouraging more spending on research and development for small and medium-sized companies and on promoting their exports.
"A lot of the problems we face today don't fall very neatly within categories of left and right, or liberal and conservative, or Republican and Democrat," Mr. Clinton said.
"We're living on the post-cold war world," he said, "where we have to fight and compete for every job we get, where nobody can promise you to make it the way it used to be, where no one can repeal the laws of change."
Mr. Clinton at first received a restrained reception this morning at Standard-Knapp, where both machinists' union members and white-collar workers took part in an employee buyout of the company in 1984. Standing on a podium on the shop floor, he spoke for several minutes before applause interrupted him.
But his recounting of the decline of American manufacturing hit home in the factory, whose 200 employees survived some tough years after the buyout. Many have friends and relatives who are either out of work or worried about losing their jobs.
"Family values and all that -- everyone likes to talk about it, but the economy is what everyone's worried about," Cliff Scovill, a machinist, said while waiting for the Governor.
Even a Republican and supporter of President Bush, Jeremy Segal of Bristol, said Mr. Clinton was right in saying that "something's got to be done," and conceded, "I don't know what Bush is doing, really."
But speaking of Mr. Clinton, he went on: "I want to know where he's getting the money. If he takes it from defense cuts, that's going to cost jobs. If he takes it from taxes, that's going to hurt."
Mr. Clinton's emphasis on economic themes should find receptive listeners in Connecticut. Recent polls by the University of Connecticut for The Hartford Courant and by Quinnipiac College in Hamden suggested that the economy was by far the most important issue in Connecticut and the metropolitan region, hard hit by the recession, military cuts and the loss of manufacturing jobs.

Misstatement on Missile
 PORTLAND, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Gov. Bill Clinton misstated the role of the Patriot misile system in the Persian Gulf war in a campaign appearance here today.
Encouraging the manufacturing of successful American products, Mr. Clinton said huge sums are spent to develop new military weapons. "We do all this basic research and people come up with great ideas, and then they turn them into things like the Patriot missiles which will go through doors or down chimneys."
Patriot missiles are used to shoot down other missiles. The Bush campaign issued a brief statement ridiculing Clinton, saying he had "shown his complete ignorance about even the most fundamental defense system."
Mr. Clinton was apparently thinking of warplane camera images from the Persian Gulf war that showed pinpoint hits by laser-guided bombs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cellular Phone Industry Reports Growth

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Despite a persistent recession that has hit its most loyal customers especially hard, the cellular telephone industry reported record growth in the six months ended June 30, with nearly 8.9 million subscribers. The number of subscribers grew 17.6 percent from the December 1991 half and 39 percent from the half a year earlier.
Meanwhile, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's largest cellular service provider, reported that its subscriber base had grown to nearly two million. That is up 17 percent from the December half and up 38 percent from the June half a year ago. The growth has come from new subscribers as well as acquisitions by the Kirkland, Wash., company. 
 The first-half survey by The Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, the industry's major trade group, also said that first-half revenue, including "roaming" fees, totaled $4.07 billion, up 17.8 percent from the December half and 37.7 percent from the half a year earlier. Roaming fees are paid by subscribers when they enter a territory away from their home cellular company.
Cellular telephone companies report that while many subscribers drop service during a recession, heavy users of cellular service, especially business customers, either maintain or increase cellular use, possibly in an effort to drum up business during hard times.
Moreover, the price of cellular telephones has dropped markedly. Car phones, which sold for as much as $600 only two years ago, now sell for $200 or less; pocket phones, which sold for $2,000 or more two years ago, now sell for as little as $200. And the price of service, while not dropping as rapidly, has stabilized at 20 cents to 65 cents a minute, depending on various pricing plans, about 15 percent less than price ranges two years ago.
The average monthly bill has been declining, mainly because of a change in the mix of customers. The average monthly bill as of June 30 was $68.51, down about 6 percent from the December 1991 level and about 8 percent from the half a year ago.
"We are getting more than just the businessman and businesswoman but the consumer as well," said Norman Black, a spokesman for the group.

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Fall Again For Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down sharply in the latest week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based publication.
Analysts at the publication said the Federal Reserve Board might still have to move interest rates significantly lower if the economy continued to slip and slide. In that case, investors may see a one-year bank C.D. under 3 percent, the analysts say. But they also note that the central bank finds itself in a bind: the Fed cannot protect a falling dollar if it lowers interest rates. 
 Should the choice come down to the economy or the dollar, analysts said, the Fed may have to bite the bullet and lose some of that foreign investment money in order to lower rates.
 
Treasury Rates Are Down
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills held yesterday, rates were down sharply, shadowing the drop in short-term interest rates on Friday, when the Fed lowered the Federal funds rate.
The Fed's move was brought on by an unexpected weakness in the employment data for August. The weekly Treasury auction is regarded as a reliable barometer of how banks may set deposit rates in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction for a three-month bill plunged 26 basis points yesterday, to 2.91 percent, while the rate of a six-month bill lost 31 basis points, falling to 2.95 percent. The average discount rates for both the three- and six-month bills are the lowest in nearly three decades. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Bank Money Market: 2.95%
 The combined New York area average for yields in the latest week showed a modest decline, with a money market account and three-month certificate of deposit both off 3 basis points, to 2.95 percent and 3 percent, respectively, while a six-month certificate fell 4 basis points, to 3.19 percent.
At commercial banks, where yields were hammered, a money market account was off 5 basis points, to 2.77 percent. Three-month and six-month certificates of deposit were off 4 basis points, to 2.87 percent and 3.02, percent respectively.
Depositors at savings banks saw the average yield slip a bit less on a money market account, down a basis point, to 3.13 percent. But three- and six-month certificates each dropped 4 basis points, to 3.13 percent and 3.35 percent, respectively.
The largest adjustments of yields in the New York area were by the Bank of Tokyo, which cut its money market account by a quarter percentage point, to 2.28 percent; its three-month C.D. by 31 basis points, to 2.24 percent, and its six-month C.D. by 38 basis points, to 2.27 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks surveyed were not down as sharply. Bank money market accounts and six-month C.D.'s fell 2 basis points, to 2.87 percent and 3.09 percent.

HEADLINE: G.M. Expected to Announce Details of New Credit Card

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Think of it as a frequent drivers card.
The General Motors Corporation is expected to make a widely anticipated announcement today that it will issue a new Mastercard and possibly a Visa credit card designed to build loyalty among car buyers. 
 Although the world's largest auto maker has been tight-lipped about the card, G.M. executives and analysts said the card's features include no annual fee and an interest rate set at 10.4 percentage points above the prime rate, which is currently 6 percent.
That matches the lowest primary rate, which is now offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, although some cards offer lower rates for the best customers. The current average rate for credit cards nationwide is 18.17 percent, according to the RAM Research Corporation of Frederick, Md.
The G.M. card's most noteworthy feature is that it offers users up to $500 a year in rebates toward the purchase of new G.M. cars. A consumer would have to spend $10,000 in one year on the card to receive that amount, based on the 5 percent rebate that will be capped yearly at $500. But the offer is said to be cumulative over three years for a maximum of a $1,500 rebate.
On average, consumers spend $2,400 a year on their charge cards, an amount that would generate a $120 rebate yearly toward a G.M. car. But as industries like health care and supermarkets increasingly accept credit cards, that number may rise.
The terms of G.M.'s card, considered attractive by industry analysts, will make it a competitive threat to not only other credit-card issuers, but also to Ford and Chrysler, which do not issue cards with direct incentives for buying their wares.
Ford offers a credit card carrying its blue oval logo through Associates National Bank, a unit of Ford's financial services group. Like Sears's Discover card, the Associates card offers cash rebates based on annual purchases; the more one spends, the greater the percentage rebate. But because of Federal regulations, Ford cannot offer direct incentives for its own products through a bank it effectively owns.
Chrysler's consumer finance company, Chrysler First, administers so-called private label credit cards for individual merchants. The company declined to comment on why it has not issued its own branded card.
G.M.'s logo may be joined on the card by other companies, an auto industry analyst said. Potential candidates include the Avis and National rental car companies, in which G.M. holds financial interests. The Marriott Corporation seems another logical candidate, because G.M.'s board of directors includes J. Willard Marriott Jr., chairman of the hotel chain. The nature of the incentives offered by such partners is unclear. G.M. is expected to announce details of the card at a news conference today.
Robert B. McKinley, president of RAM, said the low rate and the pledge of no annual fee were certain to appeal to consumers, whose loyalty to particular credit cards has dwindled in recent years. About 8 percent of all credit card holders voluntarily switch their cards every year. "They'll have no problem signing up customers," he said.
G.M. will be competing with many other nonbanks that have issued credit cards. Such cards are part of a larger strategy by many companies, including auto makers, to aim advertising at existing customers, which are considered easier to sell to than strangers.
The GE Capital Corporation, for example, last week introduced a card that offers discount coupons and rebates from 24 large companies. Called the Reward Card, it has a higher percentage rate, 12.4 percent above prime, and a $25 annual fee, which Mr. McKinley said consumers resented. The cards offered by all the major airlines, promising frequent flier mileage, charge annual fees.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Falls Again

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Consumers reduced their outstanding debt in July for the sixth consecutive month, the Government said today in a report indicating that Americans improved their balance sheets but remained cautious about spending.
The $1.12 billion decline translated into a 1.9 percent annual reduction rate and followed a revised five-tenths of 1 percent decrease in June, originally reported as a 1.7 percent drop, the Federal Reserve said. 
 It was the 12th decline in 15 months and illustrated Americans' determination to reduce their debt in the face of sluggish income growth and a stagnant job market.
While economists view the process as needed to lay the groundwork for a healthier economy, they say it is inhibiting spending and holding back the fledgling recovery. Consumer spending accounts for roughly two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The one bright spot in today's report was an increase in automobile loans at a 2.4 percent annual rate. It was the first increase in that category since March and followed a drop at a 12 percent annual rate in June.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, fell at a seven-tenths of 1 percent rate in July. Other loans were down at an 8.3 percent rate. That category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations.
The various changes left total consumer debt not secured by real estate at $721.5 billion in July, the lowest total since April 1990.
President Bush, in a campaign appearance before the international Jewish service organization B'nai B'rith, acknowledged that consumers were cautious but predicted a rebound.
"I have been concerned about the confidence factor because you've had so much gloom and doom about the economy that people are scared," he said. "And, yes, things have been slow but I am not pessimistic long run."
However, private economists see no signs consumers are prepared to start borrowing and spending again in the amounts needed to lift the economy from stagnation.
"It's a slow, arduous effort to restore balance sheets," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist at Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "It's gone on and on so far with no indication that it's ending. In the long run, people will be well positioned, but the long run can be long indeed in coming."

HEADLINE: Women Turn to Self-Help Groups For Abortions, Despite the Risks

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Using aquarium tubing, a mayonnaise jar, a drugstore syringe and a dentist's saliva ejector, three of Lucila C.'s friends gave her an abortion last spring.
The procedure, known as "menstrual extraction," was developed before 1973, when the Supreme Court legalized abortion. 
 In the years since, it has been little used. But a 1989 ruling making it easier for states to restrict abortion rights and a decision in July upholding restrictions in Pennsylvania have led more women to seek alternative methods of ending pregnancy.
This July, for example, menstrual extraction appeared on the program of the National Organization for Women's annual conference in Chicago. In June, it was a topic at the annual Wellness Conference of the Black Women's Health Project. Last spring several NOW chapters held workshops on the subject.
Carol Downer, one of the most prominent advocates of the procedure, said efforts to teach the technique were also under way in Louisiana and in rural areas where access to abortion is limited.
Lucila, a resident of the San Diego area, would speak only on the condition that she not be completely identified. She was unemployed and had no health insurance when she became pregnant. Rather than going to a clinic for an abortion, she went to her self-help group. "The core of my decision was definitely financial," she said.
Many of the women who belong to these self-help groups discovered them through one of the 20 or so Feminist Women's Health Centers, which together form a loosely bound federation. They offer everything from traditional abortion services to literature describing how to do without the services of gynecologists.
Their main office, in Los Angeles, has put out several books and a videotape describing menstrual extraction. Ms. Downer, co-author of "A Woman's Book of Choices: Abortion, Menstrual Extraction, RU-486," which will be published in October by Four Walls Eight Windows, estimates that 1,000 abortions were performed this year using the technique.
But menstrual extraction also has plenty of passionate critics within the abortion-rights movement, largely because of the medical and legal risks it poses. Skeptics also point out that most advocates are well-educated women who could easily get safe and legal abortions anyway.
Menstrual extraction basically involves inserting a flexible tube, called a cannula, through the cervix and pumping a syringe to remove the contents of the uterus through suction. Practitioners say the technique can be used through the eighth week of pregnancy.
 
Back to 'Bad Old Days'
 But Dr. Michael Policar, vice president for medical affairs of the Planned Parenthood Federation, calls the procedure "a regression to the bad old days" when those who performed abortions were not always doctors. He stresses that nonprofessionals, no matter how well-intentioned, would not know how to manage medical complications from an abortion.
Barbara Radford, executive director of the National Abortion Federation, which represents more than 300 abortion providers, concurred, adding that no statistics had been published on the safety or efficacy of the procedure. She contended that the federation's educational videotape "misleads the consumer" by glossing over the potential pain and hazards of the procedure.
But Dr. Cheryl Gibson, associate medical director of Planned Parenthood of Northern New England, said performing safe abortions was mostly "a matter of getting good at a technical skill." If the women doing menstrual extractions had adequate training and a "system of referral" for managing complications, she said, she "wouldn't have a problem with it."
Ellen Yaroshefsky, a professor at Cardozo Law School who is studying the legal implications of the technique, said a "politically hostile district attorney" might prosecute practitioners of the technique for practicing medicine without a license.
But she added that defining the practice of medicine could be muddy. New York State, for example, defines medical practice as "diagnosing, treating, operating or prescribing for any human disease, pain, injury, deformity or physical condition." She said much would depend on whether the procedure was seen as treatment or health maintenance.
But most Feminist Women's Health Centers and self-help groups are still concentrated in urban areas with liberal abortion laws. This does little for the women who live in areas that lack abortion services, which include about 83 percent of the nation's counties. Critics also contend that menstrual extraction is not feasible for most teen-agers, who have not had time to develop a sense of their bodies' rhythms.

HEADLINE: Vending Machines, the Next Generation in Dining

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
IT'S not hard to see the flaws in vending machines. They swallow money and never return it. They promise to drop a package of candy but freeze in mid moment, cruelly dangling something that cannot be reached. Or they offer food that is appealing only to the desperate.
But there are visions of what a vending machine can be: a quick, easy way to get fresh, nutritious food, valued not as a last-ditch choice but as an appealing alternative. There is a growing belief in the food industry that the next few years will witness the transformation of vending from a static, change-resistant business into one that will provide food anywhere people happen to be: in trains, in airports, on beaches or in offices. The food would be what many people want but often can't get from a machine, things like fresh pasta cooked on the spot, perfect cappuccino or the finest frozen yogurt. 
 "There are huge changes coming in vending," said John Patten, the president of the Campbell Food Service Company in Camden, N.J., which sells Campbell Soup Company products to restaurants and vending-machine companies.
Some of the first tentative signs of change are already being spotted: vending machines that grind coffee from beans and brew a fresh cup; machines that dispense cappuccino and espresso, and systems that use debit cards rather than coins, eliminating the problem of bill changers that do not function or coins that mysteriously disappear.
Other changes are on the horizon. This fall, E. C. C. International Corporation, an Orlando, Fla., defense contractor that is trying to diversify, will begin selling vending machines that offer frozen foods that can be bought and then heated in a microwave oven. And Ore-Ida Foods, a potato company in Boise, Idaho, plans to begin production soon of a machine that cooks french fries with hot air. The machine is being tested in 45 sites across the country.
"There are a lot of interesting machines coming," said Jim Watkins, the president of Golden Valley Microwave Foods in Minneapolis, a part of ConAgra Inc., the nation's second-biggest food company. ConAgra executives bought Golden Valley a year ago in part because they hoped its vending experience would help ConAgra put its brands, like Healthy Choice, into machines.
Although radical changes could take years to establish, there are several reasons to believe that they are likely to occur. Vending has long been a dormant area of the food business, which is constantly seeking new areas to exploit. Now, executives at large companies say vending has become a priority. Canteen Corporation, for instance, a large cafeteria and vending company in Spartanburg, S.C., is testing a variety of the new machines, including those that make french fries, dispense frozen food and cook pizza.
Changes in the economy are also creating a demand for better vending in more places. The shrinking of large companies has led to the closing of many company cafeterias. They are being replaced with vending areas, and people who depend on the machines want better food than currently available.
Vending has been slow to change partly because the business for years could depend on what it called the four C's: cold drinks, candy, confections and cigarettes. Most of the items were small and easy to buy with a coin or two. Now, the smallest candy bar seems to take a pocketful of change, which discourages purchases. And a sure source of revenue, cigarettes, has declined from 45.5 percent of the industry's volume in 1960 to 5.7 percent in 1991, according to the National Automatic Merchandising Association, the industry trade group based in Chicago.
It is not clear to all operators of vending machines, though, that their future lies in dispensing meals, rather than snacks or candy. Increasingly, they have been offering entrees, but no matter how fresh or tasty they may be, many consumers seem to believe they will not be good.
"The vending machine is the safest way to hold food, and yet there is that strange public view that things have been in there since the Constitutional Convention," said Tim Sanford, the executive editor of Vending Times, a publication that covers the industry.
The perceptions affect what people are willing to pay and buy. "We are still looked at strictly as a convenience and not as a food source," said David Clayton, the president of Automatic Food Service Corporation, a vending company in Nashville, with about $5 million in annual sales. "People don't expect to go to a vending machine and buy steak and a baked potato."
Mr. Clayton, who is the chairman of the National Automatic Merchandising Association, said that even when shoppers buy well-known brands from machines, they expect to pay less than they would for the same item bought in a grocery store. Maybe that is so because people are more conscious of the price when an item is bought individually, or maybe it's because an item in a machine requires so many coins.
Mr. Clayton's group has been pushing Congress to put a dollar coin into widespread circulation that would make using vending machines easier. Dollar-bill changers, he said, do not take care of the problem because they fail to work 20 percent to 30 percent of the time.
But the real solution may be the cashless machine. After installing a system on the Vanderbilt University campus two years ago that uses debit cards, Mr. Clayton saw his sales more than double. And Canteen has greatly increased its vending business in prisons over the last five years by using cards, a move encouraged by prison officials who do not want inmates to carry cash that can be used in activities like gambling.
A debit-card system also started operating six months ago at the new office complex of Chase Manhattan Bank in downtown Brooklyn. Employees put cash into a machine, which then credits a combination debit and photo-identification card that can be used in the company cafeteria or in vending machines within the building. Barry Zamore, a Chase employee who was buying a Pepsi and a package of Famous Amos cookies one day last week, said the debit system makes it easier to buy because a person does not need to have coins on hand. "I really do buy more sodas at work now," he said.
There are numerous problems, though, that may make the transformation of vending a tough job. Vending companies that set up the machines and stock them with food tend to be small operations that are not flush with cash for buying new, unproven machines. They are not wholly resistant to change, but with most new machines costing at least $5,000, the change has to pay off or they face going out of business.
Bill Buckholz, the president of Goodman Vending Service in Reading, Pa., is wary of some of the new machines. "Every year for 10 years," he said, "we've had someone come up with a french-fry machine." But many of them posed a fire risk because unlike the one from Ore-Ida, they cooked with oil. "It disturbs you when they sell a machine with a built-in fire extinguisher," he said.
Still, the changes Mr. Buckholz is making are indicative of the slow movement in the industry, though it is expected to accelerate. A year ago, he put out machines that make cappuccino and espresso, and they have doubled his coffee sales. "I've never been too high on coffee vending," he said, "because I never thought we had that great a cup of coffee. Now, I'm excited about coffee for the first time."
Consultants said some of the most drastic changes in vending may come from companies that are not in the food business, or from upstarts that have something to gain by challenging current methods of distribution.
Robert B. Noble, the chairman of Noble & Associates, an advertising and public-relations company in Springfield, Mo., that specializes in the food business, believes that vending machines can be situated anywhere. "Food will be wherever people congregate," he said. "If a bank can use a machine to take care of your money transactions, why can't they have a food-vending machine where you can pick up a sandwich? Why not do it all in one stop?"
Mr. Noble considers vending the next generation in a steady shift toward convenience that began decades ago with prepared mixes for making cakes. For the provider, he said, the advantages are clear: "It doesn't have a personality you need to motivate."
Richard Rakowski, a partner at Ryan Management in Westport, Conn., who has been consulting with several companies on possibilities for vending, considers Japan the model for where the United States could go. Vending is more common there and is used for a greater variety of high-quality items, including beer, sushi and even steak.
"My vision is the semiautomatic restaurant," he said. "Imagine taking your debit card and dispensing your own yogurt, or the components of a sandwich." He said he is working with one client on a battery-operated machine that could provide food anywhere, unhindered by the need for electrical outlets.
Meeting the needs of vending customers, though, is not easy. People are extremely impatient even in stores. "If you can't get things to a consumer in a convenience store in two minutes, they won't go in," said Mr. Patten of Campbell. They are at least as demanding when it comes to being served by a machine. "People want quality, homemade food in 30 seconds," he said.
With the microwave, that is theoretically possible to accomplish. It can be used to zap either refrigerated or frozen food held in the machine. James Ferguson, a vice president for new products at E.C.C. International, said that his company has developed a machine that will hold up to 40 selections of frozen food. The company has orders for 30 of the machines, and expects to start delivering them next month.
Mollie Little, who works at Sumitomo Bank in New York, is the kind of customer that the vending industry is trying to lure. She often takes her lunch to work, but said that she would buy from a machine if she could get good sandwiches, salads or entrees from companies like Weight Watchers or Lean Cuisine. Now, though, she sticks to buying soda or trail mix because she does not like sandwiches from machines. "It always seemed," she said, "that the bread was soggy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barry Zamore, an employee at Chase Manhattan Bank, using his debit card at a vending machine at work. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times) (pg. C6)

HEADLINE: 2 Ballet Troupes Discuss Merger

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
The board of American Ballet Theater is to meet today to discuss solutions to the company's financial troubles and its immediate cash-flow problems. One plan that has been under intensive discussion in recent weeks is a merger with the Joffrey Ballet, also financially hard-pressed and with a cash-flow problem. The Joffrey board also meets today to discuss such a merger, a possibility first reported last week in The Washington Post.
In June, Ballet Theater hired McKinsey & Company, New York-based management consultants, to explore the feasibility of such a plan, which was proposed by members of both boards, including a major donor to Ballet Theater. 
 Both companies said they planned to perform as scheduled for the 1992-93 season. Ballet Theater's engagements include a tour of Japan, performances in Buenos Aires, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago, and seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House and at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The Joffrey is scheduled to perform in Germany in October, followed by engagements through July in Minneapolis, Iowa City, San Francisco, Detroit and Chicago, and seasons at City Center in New York and at the Kennedy Center.
 
Dancers Still Unpaid
 Ballet Theater failed to pay its dancers supplementary wages that were due on Thursday and were expected to be paid yesterday. A Ballet Theater board member, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said yesterday that he did not know when the payments, a contractual obligation that supplements the dancers' unemployment benefits during scheduled layoff periods, would be made.
The company is also a month behind in its payment of premiums for the dancers' health and hospitalization insurance. "At this moment, the coverage has been temporarily suspended pending payment of the account," Alex Dube, administrator for dance at the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing the dancers, said yesterday. The insurance is to be reinstated retroactively upon payment of the premium, Mr. Dube added. "Ballet Theater has a good record," he said. "And it's not unusual that some companies with a cash flow problem make late payments."
This is not the first time either company has suffered severe economic problems. Ballet Theater, founded in 1940 by Lucia Chase and Richard Pleasant, was forced to suspend activities twice, in 1948 and 1965. And the Joffrey, founded in 1954 by Robert Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, was effectively dissolved in 1964 when Rebekah Harkness, a sponsor of the company, withdrew her support and took most of the Joffrey's repertory and dancers into a new company of her own. The Joffrey was re-formed the following year. Its future also seemed in doubt in 1990 when a bitter dispute between boards in New York and Los Angeles erupted over control of the company.
The two companies, both major American dance institutions, are confronting the nationwide recession. The Joffrey has a deficit of $2.7 million. Ballet Theater's deficit has been reported at $4 million to $5 million. Ballet Theater owes one of its largest donors, the Gilman Investment Company of New York, a sum that Howard Gilman, the company's chairman, described as substantial. "I think we may be their largest creditor outside the banks," Mr. Gilman said yesterday. He said that under the terms of the loan, made in 1989 to pay for the creation of Twyla Tharp's "Everlast," the troupe cannot refinance loans or borrow new money before paying back the Gilman loan or without the company's permission.
 
Merger's Pros and Cons
 Ballet Theater's problems have been compounded by the fact that the company has also been searching for a new artistic director since Jane Hermann, named co-director with Oliver Smith in 1989, announced in May that she would resign on Sept. 1. One candidate mentioned frequently in recent weeks is Kevin McKenzie, a former Ballet Theater principal dancer who is now an artistic associate, a principal dancer and a choreographer with the Washington Ballet. There have been reports, unconfirmed by either Ballet Theater or the Joffrey, that Mr. McKenzie might become co-director of a merged single company with Mr. Arpino.
The Ballet Theater dancers, in talks with the board two weeks ago, proposed that Mikhail Baryshnikov, director of the company from 1980 to 1989, be invited to return. They are said to oppose any merger.
Dancers for both companies are currently on layoff and are to return to rehearsals late this month. And the notion of a merger raises a number of significant questions. The McKinsey report offered a model for a merged company, which would be formed after both troupes filed for bankruptcy, with 65 dancers and a reduced performance schedule. Ballet Theater now has 83 dancers, the Joffrey about 40. The Joffrey dancers are now working without a contract, but the Ballet Theater dancers' contract does not expire until Oct. 31, 1993. Under the terms of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, which does not stipulate the liquidation of a corporation but permits resumption of business, reorganization would not automatically nullify the dancers' contracts.
 
Stylistic Differences
 A merger might expand the two companies' financial bases, although it is unclear how significant the expansion would be. And a merger would involve two very different companies and repertories, raising serious artistic questions. The Joffrey's profile is of a young, populist classical ballet troupe known for its experimentation with avant-garde and modern dance, as well as its high-speed, joyously explosive style of dancing. It is a profile developed and nurtured by Mr. Arpino, one of the few American ballet company directors who leads a company he also helped to found.
Although the Joffrey has a collection of important ballets of the 20th century, chiefly by Sir Frederick Ashton, Kurt Jooss and Leonide Massine, the heart of its repertory is ballets by Mr. Arpino that are very different in style from anything in Ballet Theater's repertory. Under Mr. Baryshnikov, Ballet Theater began to acquire ballets by modern-dance choreographers, but it was founded as a museum of 19th- and 20th-century international classics. It remains that to a large extent, with a style closer to the classicism of 19th-century ballet. Sorting out the contractual rights to each company's productions could be a complex procedure. It is not unlikely that the smaller, newer Joffrey might disappear altogether in such a merger.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

Linda Ronstadt's Beginnings
Linda Ronstadt's transition from big pop star to small pop exoticist has been greeted with both critical abuse and commercial decline. Where Ms. Ronstadt used to have a flourishing pop career, she's now been making records that delve deep into nearly forgotten pop and folk genres, from her album of standards with Nelson Riddle, " 'Round Midnight" (Elektra), to her more recent "Mas Canciones" (Elektra), an album of Mexican folk and mariachi music. 
 Ms. Ronstadt, who grew up in Tucson, Ariz., and has a Mexican ancestry, has just released an album, "Frenesi" (Elektra), which tries to revive the glory days of Mexican international pop music. In the 1940's and 50's, Mexican pop, heavily influenced by Cuban music, turned out a set of songs that became standards in Latin America, coinciding with a burst of activity in both the arts and Mexican film.
"This is the music I would sing a lot in the living room," Ms. Ronstadt said by telephone from Tucson. "A lot of what's on the new record -- 'Quiereme Mucho' is a good example -- my dad and I would sing. And a lot of that music was on the radio. And when we'd go on vacation in Mexico, we heard it there. I'm crazy about it. I can't get enough of it."
Like Paul Simon and David Byrne, Ms. Ronstadt has been attacked for her lack of authenticity, the idea being that performers have to stick to their background. But Ms. Ronstadt is doing exactly that.
"Actually, the least authentic stuff I do is rock-and-roll, which I came to late in my life," she said. "I was successful, and I wasn't going to argue about that. The success gave me a platform and I learned something about singing American pop music, which I'm glad to know. Look, I didn't grow up in Tennessee, so Dolly Parton is more of a stranger to me than Mexican singers. The stuff I sing with the most authenticity is the Mexican rancheras, which have always influenced my pop style."
Oddly, Ms. Ronstadt says she doesn't know much about the source of the music on "Frenesi": Afro-Cuban music and its modern evolution, salsa. She's more interested in the Mexican manifestation of it.
"I really don't know anything about Cuban music," she said. "I know about the 18th century, that Caribbean mixture out of which so much evolved. Mambos are ideal examples, an absolutely wonderful collusion of taste and sound, a wonderful use of the European orchestra and its Creolization. The sound is made for dancing."
Ms. Ronstadt says she is not making much money doing this. "Frenesi" is the kind of record that makes a record executive cringe. "When I said I wanted to do the project I heard: 'Oh moan. Oh groan,' " she said. "The Spanish-language records sell a quarter of what my English records sell. It's good way to get poor. But I love the music. When I started doing the album I started dreaming in Spanish, so I was overjoyed to just let it flow, and I jumped into this project."
 
Roots and Rhythm
 Roots and Rhythm, a mail-order company, which since 1974 has been the country's foremost source for older American popular and rural music, is the sort of place that offers so many goodies that it threatens the rent.
Run by Frank Scott, an authority on blues and gospel music, the company's most recent catalogue includes the extraordinary eight-CD Louis Jordan box set, a huge selection of Japanese P-Vine imported CD's, including music by Johnny Shines, Lightnin' Slim and Lonesome Sundown. There's music from Peru, Cuba and Okinawa, along with klezmer music. There's country music -- Hank Thompson, Roy Rogers, Hank Garland -- folk and Irish. And there's a huge section of vintage rock-and-roll, along with jazz. The range is from budget-price $9 CD's to $30 Japanese imports.
And for those looking for books, the catalogue includes Erik Raben's monumental jazz discography, and "The Pied Pipers of Rock 'n' Roll: Radio D.J.'s of the 50's and 60's," which explores, among other things, payola. And the company sells rock magazines.
Running across another Roots and Rhythm aficionado is like running across someone who shares the same blissful guilt.
"It's a wonderful resource and clearinghouse for roots music," said Andy McKaie, the vice president of catalogue development at MCA and the brains behind the terrific Chess Reissue series. "Frank does as much with his mail order to sort the good from the bad and promote the high end of the reissue field as anybody. He's a national treasure."
But the company has been bitten by the recession and is badly in need of capital. Mr. Scott, the owner and an authority on earlier American music, is thinking about selling off his collection of rare 78's, a collection that includes records by Robert Johnson, Muddy Waters (his first session, which was with an electric jump band) and Lightnin' Hopkins. And the company, which sends out catalogues so varied and complete that they can virtually serve as discographies, is having trouble working up its next.
"We're in the frustrating position of being far behind on payments because of the recession," said Mr. Scott. "The summer has been pretty slow, just like it has been in other industries. Major labels are not interested in working with smaller stores, so we're in trouble there. We're living day to day hoping that somebody would be interested in investing with us. We're going to survive, but it's going to be hard."
Orders may be made through Roots and Rhythm, 6921 Stockton Avenue, El Cerrito, Calif. 94530; (510) 525-1494.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Plan to Shake Up Their Scouting System

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The bureaucratese was polite and antiseptic, the official announcement loaded with terms like "efficiency" and "restructuring." What the Mets, in announcing a reworked scouting and talent development operation, said today was this:
*The economics of baseball are in potential trouble. 
 *The state of the Mets' young talent was highly questionable.
*The combination is a disaster waiting to happen.
The announcement made today was in itself essentially straightforward: the Mets will replace their "more traditional" scouting format, one that included a formal director of scouting, with an arrangement than will include three regional scouting directors. Those directors will deal closely and constantly with their scouts in the field, enjoying what the organization termed "unprecedented autonomy and responsibility."
"We were looking for ways to improve the efficiency of evaluating and acquiring amateur talent," said Gerry Hunsicker, the vice president for baseball operations who will assume overall responsibility for the system. "Scouting and player development are increasingly important because of the economics of the game. We're going to be relying on them even more."
 
Blunt, Obvious Question
 The blunt, obvious question was then asked: Is the shakeup a reflection of a significant degree of dissatisfaction with the performance of the club's talent development system? The answer was as blunt: yes.
"Over the last five or six years, we haven't had a lot of talent get to the major leagues," said Hunsicker.
The checklist of recent top draft choices makes for fairly embarrassing reading. Gregg Jefferies, selected in 1985, is the last No. 1 selection to make it in the majors as a player of impact. Lee May Jr., Chris Donnels, David Proctor, Alan Zinter -- those were the selections in 1986, 1987, 1988 and 1989. Enough said.
 
Too Tough a Job
 "I choose to use the word restructure to describe what we're doing," said Hunsicker, who was the moving force behind today's organizational recasting. "It was unfair and archaic to ask one man to oversee the entire department."
Hunsicker was thus seeking to discount the notion that Roland Johnson, the long-time director of scouting for the Mets, had been demoted. He underscored that by saying that Johnson would remain as the Northern Regional scouting director. Joe Mason will be assigned the Southern region and Bob Minor the Western.
"If we didn't think a lot of Roland Johnson," said Hunsicker, "he wouldn't be one of the three men we've put in charge of the operation."
 
Highly Regarded History
 The operation, the one that had enjoyed a highly regarded reputation when it was cranking out Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden and Jefferies, has been unmasked of late. The Mets, with their unending rash of injuries, have been forced to draw on their minor league system and thus forced to admit there isn't much there.
It has been an especially disquieting admission given the age of the current club, its debatable future as a real 1993 contender and the specter of a greatly uncertain financial future of the game. The organization's trading of David Cone, for instance, was the first indication that the organization, for all its riches, may find an annual entry into an expensive free-agent market unpalatable and ultimately unacceptable.
"The goal is to find better talent and bring it in," said Hunsicker.
Hunsicker, when asked, said the club had not concluded that part of its current predicament was generated by its specific guidelines for drafting players. He said he didn't think the organization had gone too exclusively for certain types of players.
Hunsicker, though, did say that the scouting emphasis would remain primarily on pitching and would include a more focused search for speed.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Dear David: Don't Even Think of It

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THE smartest man in sports is David Stern. He can explain cable television and salary caps and the future of international basketball better than anybody I know.
David Stern also knows geography. In the National Basketball Association, the West Coast teams are actually in one division, and the new expansion teams in Florida eventually gravitated to the Eastern divisions. 
 This familiarity with the location of American cities would disqualify David Stern from becoming the new gofer of the baseball owners. The owners want a parrot who will chirp obediently, "Atlanta and Cincinnati are farther west than Chicago and St. Louis." They want somebody who will do their bidding.
They do not want David Stern, whose name has been bandied about in the wake of Fay Vincent's forced resignation as baseball commissioner on Monday.
If the owners had any sense, they would abolish the title of commissioner because they have rendered that historical position totally worthless. They should not insult our intelligence by calling anybody else commissioner.
Some people continue to pay lip service to baseball's being a national game, but what is the point? When I covered the coal industry, every time a miner was carried feet first out of a mine, the coal operators did not refer matters to a so-called commissioner who had to pretend he was on everybody's side. They sent out the lawyers and the flacks.
The difference is that baseball bluffs and bullies impoverished cities into building new ball parks and highways.
But maybe this naked commissioner business will encourage the cities and the courts to question the public's relationship with baseball.
The owners could hardly be blamed for considering Stern, who makes $4.5 million a year, including bonuses, seven times what Vincent was paid.
But even if the baseball owners ponied up the money, there is no way the man should even think about it.
The biggest drawback dwells in Tampa. George M. Steinbrenner squeezes the joy out of everybody. The owner of the Yankees was one of the last people to call A. Bartlett Giamatti while the beleaguered seventh commissioner was trying to take a weekend holiday on Martha's Vineyard.
The eighth commissioner, already in trouble with recalcitrant owners, heard rumors that Steinbrenner had been tampering with the hearts and minds of Yankee employees while Steinbrenner was under suspension for consorting with a known gambler.
Vincent promptly summoned Yankee employees to his office, including a reluctant Gene Michael.
In the past, Steinbrenner had made some employees weep from rage and frustration, and now Steinbrenner has contributed to paranoia and a public beheading of a commissioner.
The business end of baseball should also scare Stern, who negotiated the salary-cap agreement with the basketball players. That was a rare blend of circumstances and personalities; Stern and the late Larry Fleisher, the head of the players' association, understood each other; the game was in trouble, and basketball players had a heady blend of independence, intelligence and college exposure that allowed them to accept a new economic concept.
Basketball is thriving now, an exciting night out in a couple dozen cities across the country. Plus, you can pretty much tell the baby sitter what time you'll be home. The sport also has the biggest frontier of any sport in North America.
Stern emphatically denies he has plans for a worldwide league, and he makes a lot of sense when he calls for strong national leagues, bigger world club tournaments, and heightened interest in world championships for national teams. The model exists -- it is called soccer -- and basketball is fast gaining on it.
After years of growth, baseball is stagnant in North America.
Expansion looms as an artistic joke. There is no National League schedule for next year because the Giants are unsettled. The owners have paid foolishly for marginal players, and when the unbelievably high CBS contract runs out in a year, you can expect the following bulletin: Game called on account of bouncing checks.
The owners have dug themselves a deep hole, and they cannot even see the sense in working together. They don't want a commissioner; each of them wants his own private swag man and hit man.
Why would David Stern want to work for them? The challenge, you say? I respond with George Steinbrenner, and that should stop him right there.
