HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
Boom Time for One Industry Amid South Florida's Rubble

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Benjamin Strunk had no steady job and was getting by "just doing odds and ends, helping out friends" in his hometown of Tazewell, Tenn., when Hurricane Andrew hit southern Florida two weeks ago. One look at pictures of the devastation, and Mr. Strunk knew that if he could get here, he had work for as long as he wanted.
So the 27-year-old Mr. Strunk picked up his tools, and with a friend, Michael Coon, and Mr. Coon's pet Airedale, S.J., piled into a Ford pickup and drove nearly 1,000 miles to the disaster zone. Two days ago, at 7:00 A.M., the two men began work as laborers, earning $8 an hour from the construction company that hired them to strip shingles, tarpaper and plywood from houses that need new roofs.
 
'A Shot in the Arm'
 
For the hundreds of thousands of people here whose homes have been destroyed or severely damaged, the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew has become an ordeal to be endured patiently while the reconstruction of Dade County goes on. But for the men whose sweat and skills are essential to the rebuilding effort, the storm has produced a bonanza.
Thousands of roofers, carpenters, electricians, glaziers, plumbers, masons, air conditioning mechanics and heavy equipment operators from around the country are already in South Florida or are on their way. In the streets of towns like Homestead or Goulds, construction trucks from as far away as Texas or New England, sporting logos with unfamiliar area codes and company names, are parked in front of houses, apartment buildings and stores.
"This is a real shot in the arm," for the depressed construction industry, said Thomas Mendez, a contractor based in Boca Raton, Fla., who has already hired 300 craftsmen and plans to hire 700 more. "Two weeks ago there were thousands of unemployed construction workers around here. Right now, anybody who is not working is just plain lazy."
The opportunities appear to be virtually unlimited. Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida estimated last week that at least 85,000 homes in the Miami area were "uninhabitable," and will need either to be repaired or totally rebuilt. Even in a good year, said Charles Lennon, executive director of the South Florida Builders' Association, new construction in Dade County "is not even 10 percent of that figure."
Beyond that, nearly every shopping mall and office complex in Miami's southern suburbs was damaged in the storm. There are also schools, hospitals and government buildings that must be rebuilt. In all, Mr. Lennon estimated, "at least five years" of rebuilding, representing billions of dollars in contracts, will be required before the Miami area returns to "a semblance of normality."
 
'I'm Ready to Go
 Kenneth Gregory, a contractor from Greenwood, Ind., had plenty to do back home, but thought that since the work available here "figures to be a lot more lucrative," he would try for a piece of it. He arrived in Homestead this weekend with a crew of four and five generators to repair his father-in-law's house, which he plans to use as his base of operations until at least Halloween.
"My main interest is to cover as many roofs as I can and go home in a few months," Mr. Gregory said. "I've brought in 400,000 square feet of nylon reinforced plastic in a rented trailer, and I'm ready to go." People were coming up to his truck, he said, and asking how soon he could work on their homes.
Demand for workers has become so intense that construction wages, long depressed, are now skyrocketing. A carpenter who a few weeks ago might have been earning $8 an hour is now making $12 while working 12 hours a day, foremen are earning as much as $15 an hour.
"I can't find enough help," Ernie Bonham, of Bonham and Associates, a custom glass company from Daytona Beach, Fla. "I've called 50 different guys looking, and everybody everywhere is busy."
The labor shortage is just fine with Gilberto Melendez, a Homestead resident who lost his roof as well as his job as a cook in an Italian restaurant when the hurricane stormed through. "I'm making $8 an hour installing roofs," he said, "so I'm not only getting the money I need to put my own roof back on, but I'll be able to do it myself with what I've learned on the job."
But many local business owners worry that most of the benefits of the post-hurricane reconstruction will be short-lived in Dade County. Moreover, they are disturbed by the influx of tradesmen from around the country and contend that local contractors and their long-idled workers should get first crack at jobs.
"We don't need 6,000 unemployed carpenters from Massachusetts clogging up Interstate 95 looking for a job," Mr. Lennon said. "Our position is that the pipeline should fill from the bottom up. Let's first get these unemployed people in Dade County to work, then branch out through Florida, and only then go outside Florida."
For that reason, there was some grumbling last Friday when the Army Corps of Engineers awarded XX contracts of $15 million each, for work ranging from debris removal to school rehabilitation, to Brown & Root Services of Houston and five other companies not based in Miami. But David A. Rich, a spokesman for the corps, said "the contracts require that all contractors give priority to Dade County businesses for supplies, subcontracted services, equipment" and labor.
Spokesmen for the corps said the six companies were chosen because they had proven track record with the agency and it was important to begin rebuilding immediately.
Others contend there is more than enough work to keep everyone busy. "South Dade doesn't have enough skilled people to rebuild this place, and neither does the state of Florida," said Willie Mitchell, a foreman from Kissimmee, Fla., who turned down a job building Atlanta's Olympic Village to come here with his wife Denise and live in a pup tent in a parking lot.
The local authorities are concerned that many of the out-of-state contractors are not licensed to work in Florida, whose building codes are much more rigorous than those of many other states. While they want to see compliance with the codes, they acknowledge that they lack the inspectors to oversee the hugh amount of rebuilding going on.
Some out-of-state contractors are simply evading Florida's licensing rules, saying the qualification process is too time- consuming, expensive and demanding. But others, like Mr. Gregory, are hooking up with longtime friends who have local licenses and are working to their specifications.
For their part, suppliers expect that even after roofs and walls have been rebuilt and the insurance checks have arrived, the need to restore the interior of homes means they will continue to profit. "Business is going to go off the Richter scale," predicted Roger Berry, owner of Berry's Carpets and Paint, a Homestead store that also sells draperies, wallpaper, tile and vinyl flooring.
But the surge in demand for basic building materials has begun to create both bottlenecks in supplies and price increases, most notoriously in the case of plywood.
"I need shingles by the truckload, as well as plywood, building felt, nails and mending plates," said Mr. Mendez. "I have the customers, the workers, the insurance, and the money. What I don't have are the supplies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hurricane Andrew has meant a boom for those whose skills are essential to the rebuilding effort, including roofers, carpenters, electricians, masons and plumbers. A truck along U.S. 1 in Homestead, Fla., advertised construction services on Tuesday. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Check-Off for Debt Lets Citizens Fight Back;
Clinton's Taxes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
George Bush proclaimed in his acceptance speech that his opponent, Bill Clinton, was responsible as Governor of Arkansas for 128 tax increases (transcript, Aug. 21). Such a willfully false and misleading assertion invites refutation.
Three of the 128 so-called tax increases listed by the Bush-Quayle Committee are simply a miscounting of lines of text (Nos. 31, 86 and 91), according to Michael Kinsley's analysis of the list in The New Republic for Aug. 21. No. 78 is a verbatim repeat of a 25-cent-a-gallon increase in the tax on "light wine" (No. 74). Other "increases" include a court cost imposed on convicted criminals (No. 92) and a license fee for abortion clinics (No. 48). Objecting to these as "taxes" makes George Bush look pro-criminal and pro-abortion. 
 Lengthening the dog-racing season (No. 46) was counted as a tax, on the ground that a longer season increased state revenues. A fuel-tax increase was counted twice, once for gasoline and once for diesel; and an alcohol tax was counted five times, including once for wine coolers.
If this represents the depth of knowledge and analysis the President brings to financial matters, no wonder the economy is stalled.
The Bush-Quayle Committee, assessing this spurious list of its own construction, claims that Governor Clinton raised taxes by $397 million. Using the same method of calculation, Mr. Kinsley reckons that President Bush raised taxes by $476 billion in his first term. This is 1,200 times more than the amount attributed to Governor Clinton. On a per capita basis, Mr. Bush raised taxes each year 33 times more than his rival. Whom should we trust? Certainly not George Bush and his statistics.
Such calculations are not necessarily helpful guides to tax policy. The United States is in a dire situation with its national debt. That Germany, France and Japan with their considerably higher tax burdens have been doing well economically shows that what we do with tax dollars is more important for economic prosperity than how many are collected.
Mr. Bush shows little understanding of the connection between fiscal policy and economic performance -- in other countries or at home. We need much more serious and much less superficial thinking about how to finance government services and economic growth.
 
NORMAN UPHOFF
Ithaca, N.Y., Aug. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Saks Names A New Vice Chairman

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The management shake-up at Saks Fifth Avenue that has produced a number of high-profile departures in recent months continued on a more positive note yesterday when Gary Witkin, executive vice president and director of the department-store division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, was named vice chairman of the specialty retailer.
The move from Minneapolis to New York is set for Oct. 1 and will reunite the 43-year-old Mr. Witkin with Philip Miller, his former boss in retailing positions at four other chains. 
 Mr. Miller, who joined Saks as vice chairman and chief operating officer in 1990, is expected to succeed Melvin Jacobs as chairman when Mr. Jacobs retires next spring. In addition to disclosing Mr. Witkin's appointment to his team, Mr. Miller said yesterday that Brian Kendrick, who joined Saks as chief financial officer last year, would take on broader responsibilities and add the title of executive vice president.
 
A New Lineup
 The new moves continue a thorough renovation of Saks's management team: since last spring, Arthur Martinez, Mr. Miller's one-time rival for Mr. Jacobs's job, and five senior vice presidents have departed.
"I would like to think of myself as a partner, but my direct areas of responsibility will be stores, real estate, construction, clearance centers, visual merchandising, and customer development," Mr. Witkin said yesterday. Mr. Kendrick takes responsibility for financial and administrative functions. Both men will report to Mr. Miller, who will continue to oversee Saks's merchandise buying.
Saks currently operates 50 stores in 22 states. The company has been closely held since 1990, when it was acquired from the American subsidiary of Britain's B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. by Investcorp and Saks's management. Investcorp is a subsidiary of the Arabian Investment Banking Corporation.
 
'Entrepreneurial' Opportunity
 Earlier this summer, Mr. Miller said he hoped to double the number of Saks stores by 1997 and take the company public in three to five years. Mr. Witkin said yesterday that the "entrepreneurial" opportunities of working on such a strategy, along with the "tremendous franchise" the Saks name represents, attracted him to the job.
The move is something of a homecoming for Mr. Witkin, who was born in the Bronx and lived in Westchester before going to the University of Cincinnati to study economics and management. He began his business career as a department manager at the White Plains outlet for Wallach's Inc. in 1970, where Mr. Miller was among his superiors. Mr. Witkin later worked under Mr. Miller at Lord & Taylor, Neiman Marcus and, most recently, Marshall Field's in Chicago. Mr. Witkin was president of Marshall Field's when it was acquired in 1990 by Dayton Hudson.
Mr. Witkin and his wife, Judy, have two teen-age children. His hobbies include fishing and collecting antique cars and comic books.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 10, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about management changes at Saks Fifth Avenue described Investcorp S.A. incorrectly. It owns a minority stake in Saks and represents Persian Gulf investors who collectively have a controlling interest. It is not a subsidiary of the Arabian Investment Banking Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
BUSH AGAIN VOWS NO TAX INCREASE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Traveling to Pennsylvania and New Jersey suburbs, President Bush renewed his no-new-taxes pledge today, promising he would not raise taxes again, "ever."
The President campaigned on improving education, but quickly ended up defending his management of an economy that even he conceded, not once but three times, was "lousy." 
 Mr. Bush, who broke his last campaign's no-new-taxes pledge to solve a budget crisis, said he would not agree to raise taxes in a second term. "I went along with one Democratic tax increase," he said, "and I'm not going to do it again. Ever. Ever."
 
'Trying to Get It Done'
 Mr. Bush's comments today made a fine distinction from his prior statements on the subject. He has previously expressed regret over the 1990 tax increase that he approved in a budget deal with the Democrats. In his speech to the Republican National Convention last month, he promised a new, unspecified "across-the-board" tax cut. Today's remarks were the closest he has come to an outright renewal of his no-new-taxes pledge from 1988.
Mr. Bush attributed the country's economic troubles to a Congress that has refused to enact his economic programs and a recession that he said was global, not just American.
"I just have to insist on that," he said, almost plaintively, in a session with factory workers at a tube-turning plant in Norristown, Pa., "and try to make the people understand that I haven't just been sitting there, I've been trying to get it done."
Aides said the President would try again on Thursday to get his message to the public, delivering a speech to the Detroit Economic Club in the afternoon and buying five minutes in prime time on three television networks to explain his economic policies directly to the public.
Mr. Bush will offer some new prescriptions for the economy in his Detroit speech, aides said, but they will be relatively minor adjustments to a series of programs, already in effect, "that most people aren't even aware of."
The President is also likely to announce a toll-free telephone number for requesting a booklet that explains his package for economic growth, a White House aide said.
 
An Unfiltered Appeal
 Mr. Bush has tried several times to describe his plans for reviving the economy, including at innumerable campaign stops and in his State of the Union Message last January, a commencement speech in Texas in June and at the convention.
The latest effort is directed by Robert Zoellick, an economic expert who is deputy to James A. Baker 3d, the new White House chief of staff.
One Baker aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said previous fragmented efforts offered only "an initiative here, an initiative there" without showing how they comprised a larger policy to revive the economy.
The President said this morning, after meeting with Republican Congressional leaders at the White House, that his message was not getting through to the public.
"I've tried to stimulate this economy and been rebuffed," he said, "and I think the American people will see that clearly. I don't think they see it yet, but they will when we get through."
Aides said Mr. Bush's television appearances were intended to deliver his economic message to the public unfiltered by the national press and broadcast analysts, a political tactic that Mr. Baker has used many times.
That Mr. Bush is still trying to explain himself, 55 days before the election and almost 10 months after he first acknowledged that the economy was stumbling, underscores the uphill political battle he is in.
That was apparent even in the Republican strongholds he visited today.
In Norristown, a middle-class city 30 miles north of Philadelphia, Republicans outnumber Democrats by more than 2 to 1. But the Presidential election is still "up for grabs," said Jerry Slater, a history teacher at Norristown Area High School, where Mr. Bush spoke today.
"These are people who want a change," Mr. Slater said. "They want jobs; they want education money. There are only two ways to go: the status quo and change. And Bush has to represent the status quo."
A local Republican committeeman, Steven Rothenberger, said Mr. Bush was gaining ground in Pennsylvania, a crucial industrial state in this election.
But that did not seem clear at the tube-turning factory, Uniform Tube Inc., where Mr. Bush was peppered with pointed questions from about 200 workers and invited guests.
The President told them the nation was in a transition zone, moving from what he called "economic hell" to being "poised, in my view, for a decent and strong recovery."
One worker quickly asked what assurance Mr. Bush could offer that his relations with Congress would be any better in a second term than in his first. Another asked what Mr. Bush would say to workers at "companies like Allied Tank and Anchor Glass -- local people, who have lost their jobs due to plant closings during your tenure in office."
The President replied, "I'd say we've been caught in a very tough economic time. And we've got to move forward now with incentives to stimulate the economy."
Mr. Bush roundly attacked Congress for failing to enact Administration proposals, made in January, to grant tax breaks on new factory investments and to give first-time homebuyers a $5,000 tax credit.
"But let me say this on the economy: It is lousy," he added moments later. "We know that. We've been trying to stimulate it. And we're in a global recession. It's not just the United States. Take a look at Canada. Take a look at England and France and Germany. It has been too long."
Speaking at a Bush-Quayle rally at the Middletown Township Veterans of Foreign Wars Hall, Mr. Bush repeated a longstanding proposal to freeze Federal spending that is not tied to entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid and to cap the growth of such programs.
"That cap would save almost $300 billion over five years," he said. "And we can take those savings and cut taxes across the board.
"And I've already vetoed one Democratic tax increase, and I'll veto another if I have to. I've got a pen right here in my coat to do just that. No more tax increases."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Cancels a Visit to Japan As Dispute Over Islands Simmers

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 9

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly put off a visit to Japan today, only four days before he was scheduled to leave, after negotiations throughout the summer failed to resolve a bitter territorial dispute that has haunted Moscow-Tokyo relations since World War II.
A brief official announcement said only that the decision to postpone the trip to Japan and South Korea, scheduled for Sept. 13-18, was made "taking into account the obtaining circumstances," but it did not spell out the precise reasons. 
 There was no mystery in either Russia or Japan, however. In both countries, conflicting claims to a group of sparsely populated islands in the Kurile chain north of Japan had swelled into heated issues of national honor, blocking any compromise and any chance of a meaningful visit by Mr. Yeltsin.
Also blocked was any chance of Russia's receiving an increase in direct economic assistance or investment from Japan, which Tokyo had made clear would not be forthcoming without resolution of the territorial dispute. Mr. Yeltsin had evidently been hoping for substantial Japanese economic help.
In Japan, officials said they were surprised and somewhat insulted by the Russian leader's sudden action. As late as today, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa was meeting with aides to plan for the visit, and a senior diplomat said he would be "very surprised" if rumors of a cancelation proved correct.
The chief Cabinet Secretary, Koichi Kato, said in a statement that the Government "regrets the postponement," but he used a word that also meant "deplores."
The notice of postponement in Moscow said a new date would be "coordinated through diplomatic channels." But while there were reports from the Foreign Ministry that Mr. Yeltsin would probably reschedule his visit to South Korea for December, when he already has trips to China and Romania planned, there was no indication when he might next try to visit Japan.
 
Islands Seized in 1945
 The islands were taken by the Soviet Union in the closing days of World War II, in accordance with its interpretation of secret arrangements worked out by Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin at the Yalta Conference in February 1945. Since then, they have remained the principal obstacle to the conclusion of a formal peace treaty formally ending hostilities of World War II. A compromise proposed in 1956, by which Moscow would have recognized Japan's sovereignty over two of the islands, was never formalized, and Moscow withdrew it when Japan and the United States expanded their relationship in 1960. Since then, Japan has become increasingly firm on winning recognition of its claim to all four.
The Soviet Union long claimed that its possession of the islands was a just price, along with southern Sakhalin Island, for entering the war against Japan in the summer of 1945. But in recent months the islands have evolved into a burning national issue going far beyond whatever strategic or economic significance they and their 25,000 inhabitants have to either side.
Politicians and commentators from the nationalist and Communist camps painted emotive images of a weakened Russia being stripped of its lands and of a precedent that would lead to territorial claims against Russia from all sides. China, for example, has long claimed part of the Russian Far East.
 
Security Issue Invoked
 The military pitched in with claims that Russia's Far East would be exposed, and politicians from the region invoked lost fisheries and minerals. Mr. Yeltsin's political opponents gleefully seized on all these arguments, making a political banner out of the South Kuriles.
The arguments found fertile soil in a nation humiliated by the collapse of its empire, and public-opinion polls last week showed that up to 60 percent of the Russian population had become adamantly opposed to the islands' transfer to Japan.
That left Mr. Yeltsin with the choice of refusing any deal on the islands and getting cold-shouldered on aid by Japan, or offering some compromise arrangement and fueling a political inferno at home on the eve of brutal new battles with the parliament.
Contributing to his decision were the facts, widely discussed in the Moscow press, that Japan was in any case not prepared to offer significant aid now, and that Tokyo would probably refuse any compromise that fell short of recognizing Japanese sovereignty over all four islands.
The actual territory in dispute consists of three islands, Kunashiri, Etorofu and Shikotan, as well as a cluster of islets known as Habomai. Most of the population lives on the larger islands, Kunashiri and Etorofu.
 
Gradual Transfer Suggested
 Japan has repeatedly signaled that it would be willing to accept a phased transfer of the islands over many years, as long as its sovereignty was acknowledged now.
Mr. Yeltsin was also probably mindful of the political damage to former Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when he returned from Japan in April 1991 empty-handed, then too because of the Kuriles.
Suggestions that postponing the trip might be the wisest course were heard in both Moscow and Tokyo. But the abrupt, 11th-hour decision by Mr. Yeltsin was widely expected to further irritate relations between Russia and Japan and to bolster the hands of hard-liners on both sides.
Mr. Yeltsin had insisted that the visit was on as recently as last Sunday, when he assured the Japanese over television that "my official visit to Japan will begin on Sept. 13 notwithstanding the fact that in Japan there are certain forces which are hyping 'the northern territories' issue too much."
 
Discussions in the Kremlin
 The announcement of the postponement said the decision had been made after "an exchange of views" involving the leadership of the Russian Government, the Supreme Soviet and the Security Council.
The first inkling that the visit was in trouble came when Mr. Yeltsin failed to appear at a scheduled noon meeting with Japanese correspondents in the Kremlin because a Security Council meeting on the visit was "proceeding with great difficulty," as the president's spokesman explained.
The Security Council includes senior officials from the intelligence and military establishments, some of whom have openly campaigned against returning any of the disputed islands.
But it seemed unlikely that Mr. Yeltsin would have bowed to pressure from others unless he himself was already wavering. There were ample signs that he was: a visit to Moscow by Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, ended last week with no sign of compromise, and Japanese correspondents in Moscow said that Mr. Yeltsin's staff never produced a final schedule for his visit.
The postponement was probably a major disappointment to Mr. Yeltsin, who, with his Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, has worked hard to build an international stature approaching that of his Soviet predecessor and rival, Mr. Gorbachev, and to demonstrate a new and more liberal foreign policy.
Mr. Yeltsin had evidently begun planning the trip in Tokyo in early summer assuming that he could advance the debate over the Kuriles and move forward where Mr. Gorbachev had stalled.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Presses Welfare Overhaul, Stressing Job Training and Work

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton today called for an "end to welfare as we know it" and proposed a major program of job training and education for recipients of public aid.
Mr. Clinton said he would quadruple to $4 billion the amount the Government spends on job training for welfare recipients and add $2 billion in tax credits for the working poor. By 1996, he said, the Government would be spending an additional $6 billion a year. 
 In exchange, Mr. Clinton repeated his past promises to demand more of parents. He said he would crack down on fathers who refuse to pay child support and limit mothers on welfare to a stay of no more than two years. After that, he said, they would have to take a job in private business or perform community service to receive Government aid.
"When poverty and jobless rolls rise, we all pay," he said in a speech at the Clayton County Social Services office here. "In the last year, we spent $8 billion more than we were spending three years ago on welfare and food stamps alone."
Mr. Clinton and his aides were mindful of the mixed signals such an announcement could send on a subject that has frequently carried with it racial overtones. The speech was set in the South, and Mr. Clinton surrounded himself with a racially mixed group of mothers and their babies. He delivered it on the same day that he addressed the National Baptist Convention, a largely black denomination.
But the campaign has determined that it can sell a message of welfare restructuring by appealing to middle-class blacks and whites rather than to racial stereotypes and following through on an issue in which Mr. Clinton has been heavily involved in his home state of Arkansas.
Mr. Clinton's speech today amounted to a reiteration of his views rather than an announcement of a new plan. For the past year, he has stressed a theme of mutual responsibility, arguing that the Government should do more to help the poor and the poor should do more to help themselves.
While Mr. Clinton has been vague on some important specifics, many welfare experts credit him with more than a decade of serious study and experimentation with welfare programs in Arkansas. He also played a major role in lobbying for the 1988 Family Support Act, which was signed by President Reagan.
"His proposals address the problems head on, in a way that is consistent with the best current thinking on the welfare system," said Isabel Sawhill, an economist with the Urban Institute, a Washington research organization.
Presenting his current program as a continuation of past work, Mr. Clinton said the act, which provides up to a $1 billion a year in job-training for welfare mothers, has "never been fully implemented and it didn't go far enough."
 
Would Use Military Savings
 He said his program would be paid for out of savings from military budget reductions and increased taxes on the wealthy that he has said would also pay for a number of other domestic programs he has proposed.
"The changing face of welfare and the changing nature of it, and the enormous barriers of people moving from welfare to a productive life deserve special attention," Mr. Clinton said. "Especially now that most people on welfare are young women and their little children." "By the time we're through, we shouldn't have a welfare program in America," he said. "We ought to have a helping hand program followed by a jobs program."
Later today, Mr. Clinton shared a stage with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader and former Presidential candidate who has maintained a cool, almost icy, distance from the Democratic ticket since the July nominating convention.
 
Grim Greeting from Jackson
 At the annual meeting of the National Baptist Convention, Mr. Jackson sat stony-faced behind Mr. Clinton as the Arkansas Governor received a warm reception from the religious groups.
Afterward, Mr. Jackson met Mr. Clinton briefly in a backstage restroom while more than a dozen clergymen milled around outside and guarded the doorway. Mr. Jackson said later that Mr. Clinton agreed to meet with him next week to discuss voter registration plans.
"In the next 55 days, the character and the vision and the will of the American people will be severely tested," Mr. Clinton told the convention minutes before. "The other side represents the same old things except worse. But they're very good at raising the fears of the American people."
Mr. Jackson is supposed to undertake a party-sponsored voter registration bus tour later this month. He has said he is working for the party more than he is for the ticket.
"The partnership I seek is not one for elections and votes," Mr. Clinton said to the crowd. "It's one that will go way, way beyond that."
"Just remember folks, you're fighting in the greatest tradition of America," he said. "The 'We-can' crowd against the 'We-can't' crowd."
Mr. Clinton took only a few, muted partisan jabs at President Bush in his remarks today. In a fact sheet released with his speech, Mr. Clinton's staff faulted Mr. Bush for not mentioning welfare restructuring in the nominating speech he delivered at the Republican convention in much the same way that Republicans have taken Mr. Clinton to task for giving short shrift to foreign policy in his own convention speech.
 
Georgia Governor on Attack
 But the Democratic nominee left most of the direct hits to Gov. Zell Miller, the Democratic Governor of Georgia who has attacked Mr. Clinton's political opponents on his behalf before.
"George Bush, after putting more people on welfare than any other President, is complaining that the welfare system is overlooked," Mr. Miller said. "That reminds me of that Lincoln story of the man who murdered his parents and then threw himself on the mercy of the court because he was an orphan."
After remaining stable for nearly two decades, welfare rolls surged to all-time highs in the past years, fed by both the lingering recession and an increase in female-headed households. About 4.8 million families, or 13.6 million people, receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program. That figure is about from 3.7 million families as recently as 1989.
Bruce Reed, the campaign's policy director, said that the welfare-to-work plan would affect the 1.8 million households that have been receiving public assistance payments for two years or more.
After those people had received the two years of training the program would provide, they would then have to leave the welfare rolls for jobs. Mr. Reed said there was no way to estimate precisely how many people would be affected within the first four years of the program.
Mr. Bush rarely discussed welfare until the campaign heated up this year. Since then, he has said that he wants to give states increased flexibility to conduct experiments.

HEADLINE: State Acquires Landmark Theater To Salvage While It Still Can

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The New Amsterdam Theater, the badly tarnished crown jewel in a string of historic playhouses along 42d Street, has been taken over from the Nederlander Organization by New York State, in the hope of salvaging the building while there is still so much left to salvage.
Structural stabilization of the abandoned, 89-year-old Art Nouveau landmark at 214 West 42d Street is to begin immediately and will cost about $450,000, said Rebecca Robertson, the president of the state's 42d Street Development Project. 
 That will buy enough time for the architectural firm Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates to draw up a longer-term renovation strategy, along with a cost estimate. Price and plan in hand, the state will then look for a new tenant for the New Amsterdam, which has both a cavernous 1,537-seat auditorium and the enormous shell of a 499-seat rooftop theater (although neither hall has seats any longer).
 
Renovation of Nearby Buildings
 Rather than being restored by the Nederlanders, as had been envisioned since 1982, the New Amsterdam will become a more integral part of the state and city's 42d Street project, which includes the rehabilitation of other nearby theaters as well as the renovation of existing commercial buildings for tourist and entertainment uses.
Title to the New Amsterdam had technically been held by the New York City Industrial Development Agency, which issued $4 million in bonds in 1982 to acquire the property. But the Nederlanders were responsible for paying off the bonds, as well as making annual payments in lieu of property taxes of roughly $250,000.
As part of a settlement, the Nederlanders have paid off the $2.6 million remaining principal and interest on the bonds and the state agreed to assume responsibility for $250,000 in outstanding tax payments.
The settlement was reached on Aug. 26 and approved on Tuesday by the Industrial Development Agency board. Title was transferred to the State Urban Development Corporation, of which Ms. Robertson's office is a subsidiary.
"This is the best shot for the New Amsterdam," Ms. Robertson said. "The alternative was to have the theater outside the project area, owned by an organization that seemed to want to get rid of it."
"I believe we will be able to find a good, responsible tenant because we will be able to deliver it in a stabilized condition," she said.
 
From Ziegfeld to Kung Fu
 Once home to the "Ziegfeld Follies," the New Amsterdam had decayed badly in the decade since the last kung fu movie was shown there, although ample evidence remains of its glittering past: robust friezes, colorful murals, naturalistic carvings and sinuous wrought iron and terra cotta.
Preservationists feared for the building's very existence in recent years, given the lack of maintenance and repairs.
But the state was not about to put money into a building that was controlled by the Nederlanders. And the Nederlanders, who had spent $15 million to acquire the building and undertake an abortive restoration, as well as emergency roof repairs, were not about to put more money into the property while waiting for the long-delayed 42d Street redevelopment effort.
In 1983, the Nederlanders began to renovate the Aerial Gardens rooftop theater for Peter Brook's staging of "La Tragedie de Carmen," but that project came to a halt when workers discovered more structural damage than had been anticipated. Last year, the New York City Opera talked briefly and tentatively about moving to the New Amsterdam, but that prospect quickly evaporated.
 
The Decision to Halt
 Last year, the Nederlanders concluded that resuscitating the New Amsterdam "was not economically viable for their organization over the next several years," said their spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein.
Robert E. Nederlander, the president of the organization, said in 1990 that he believed the New Amsterdam "can be made into a viable, legitimate theater, but when that will happen depends on when 42d Street can be built up into an area where there are office buildings and people are not afraid to go."
The office buildings to which he referred were four enormous towers called Times Square Center, which were to have been built at the intersection of 42d Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue as the centerpiece and driving force of the overall redevelopment scheme. Those plans were postponed indefinitely last month in favor of a more modest interim rejuvenation of 42d Street from Broadway to Eighth Avenue.
Yesterday, through Mr. Rubenstein, Mr. Nederlander said, "Safety in the area has improved dramatically and, with the retail space that is planned, that improvement should continue, so that wasn't the motivating factor for not going ahead."
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the City Economic Development Corporation, said public ownership of the New Amsterdam "provides a glorious opportunity to think even more broadly about entertainment activity on the mid-block of 42d Street."
 
'A Sigh of Relief'
 And Laurie Beckelman, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said, "After years of struggling to enforce the most minimal level of maintenance, we can breathe a sigh of relief about the theater's future."
A visit yesterday to the theater, completed in 1903 to designs by Herts & Tallant, confirmed that even though there had been little in the way of upkeep, many architectural features remain in place, although some are badly deteriorated.
Shakespearean and Wagnerian scenes, depicted in a dozen friezes, still greet the visitor on entering the ticket lobby.
An enormous hole can be seen in the dome of the main auditorium, where plaster gave way after heavy water damage. And a 15-foot section of ornamental plaster has fallen away from the first balcony, like flesh removed from a skeleton. Everywhere, paint has peeled scabrously.
 
Peacocks Round the Proscenium
 But even in the musty gloom, it is plain that abundant decoration survives, including 16 peacocks around the proscenium arch, above which is an allegorical mural depicting Poetry, Truth and Falsehood, among others. That mural, with two flanking works, had been restored by the Nederlanders, Ms. Robertson said.
The roof garden, a surprisingly light and airy room, is in much worse shape. There, whole sections of wall have fallen away to reveal the steel structure. Most of the balcony is gone. The section that remains, on the south side of the building, is open at one end to the outside.
"The main problem is to get this sealed," Ms. Robertson said, as she crossed the rubble-strewn floor. "Here is where you can see us spending $500,000."
Downstairs, the oblong rotunda of the men's smoking room and lounge retains much of its ornate character, although all but one of the murals on the dome have fallen off or been removed. Carved around the perimeter are these words, still clearly visible:
"I had rather a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad."

HEADLINE: Comedy Troupe Makes It Up As It Goes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Campaign '92 is shaping up nicely for Chicago City Limits, the improvisational comedy group that has been based in New York City for the last decade.
True, Ross Perot dropped out of the race, dealing a severe comic blow, but the two main candidates look as if they will generate enough material to sustain the company's "Unconventional Wisdom" show, devoted to the absurdities of the political olympics. 
 A recent performance by the company at its theater at 351 East 74th Street on the Upper East Side included a freewheeling Bush-Clinton debate, followed by questions from the audience. "Governor Clinton," one audience member asked, "are you still against the draft?" The answer: "No, I changed my position ever since women have been allowed to engage in active combat."
In a political version of "Jeopardy," the answer to the clue "House of Representatives" was: "What's only slightly smarter than the House of Pancakes?"
 
Defining a Good Routine
 The audience reacted not only to the humor, but also to the difficult circumstances under which it was created. Such is the distinctive dynamic of improvisational comedy.
"In general, a good stand-up routine is 8 on a scale of 10," said Carl Kissin, a resident member, who was interviewed recently after a company workshop. "We'll have 5's and 4's and 3's, but also a lot more 10's."
Behind the 10's lie a specific set of skills and techniques, which the six resident members of Chicago City Limits teach at workshops throughout the week. Some classes are restricted to members of its touring company, while others are open to the public. About 40 percent of the students in the open classes are theatrical actors hoping to develop a greater sense of freedom on the stage, but nearly as many are people in the advertising industry who want to improve their presentations to clients. They have a tough row to hoe. "Someone once described improv as driving a car by looking in the rear-view mirror," said Paul Zuckerman, the company's director.
 
No Script, Just Suggestions
 Seventeen students recently gathered in a studio on West 72d Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to take an advanced class from Judith Searcy, a resident cast member. (In addition to Mr. Kissin, the other members of the company are John C. Telfer, Wendy Chatman, Rick Simpson, Carole Bugge and the company's musical director, Gary Adler.) The workout was grueling. First came an exercise called Emotional Circle, in which each student was required to communicate, with maximum intensity, an emotion that was particularly difficult. The fictional situations, determined by Ms. Searcy, were such commonplace ones as trying to persuade a reluctant teller to cash a check.
"When you're acting, you have a script," Ms. Searcy warned. "In improv, you have suggestions, and it's like the audience is your script."
Some scenes sputtered and died, but others took off. In one scene, a student played the bored pilot of a downed airliner, stranded on a desert island with her flight attendant, a young man named Dylan, who was instructed to act guilty.
Pilot: "So, Dylan, why don't you look around for some provisions while I smoke a cigarette?"
Dylan (dazed and babbling): "I need to get a Coke to Row 6C."
Pilot (yawning): "Dylan, 6C is gone, as is the rest of the airplane."
Dylan (a horrible realization dawning): "Uh, Captain, do you think it's possible for a plane to crash if someone, like, accidentally turns off the rear engines?"
Pilot (after fixing Dylan with a long, steady gaze): "Dylan, I don't think you have a big future in flight attendance."
 
Evolution of an Idea
 Ideally, a well-turned bit of improvisation will take a random suggestion, fold it into the comic premise or the relationship unfolding onstage and, as Ms. Searcy repeated again and again, "justify it."
Improvisational theater evolved in the 1930's at Hull House in Chicago as a way to coax teen-agers into acting. The idea was to take the intimidating sense of structured performance out of the experience. The Hull House method, developed by Viola Spolin, was adopted by her son, Paul Sills, who in 1956 founded the Compass Players, an incubator for such talents as Mike Nichols, Elaine May and Shelley Berman.
Three years later, the Compass Players folded and gave rise to Second City, in which Alan Arkin and Barbara Harris started. Second City then gave rise to similar troupes in other cities, notably the Committee in San Francisco, the Proposition in Boston and the Premise in New York. In the mid-1970's, Second City's branch in Toronto became the home base for a slew of comic talents, including Dan Aykroyd and Bill Murray, and the actors of SCTV.
Mr. Zuckerman came to improvisation in the mid-1970's from the advertising business. Like many of the students who take classes from Chicago City Limits, he wanted to sharpen his ability to pitch an idea to clients. He wound up studying with Second City, and then joined forces with George Todisco, a Second City alumnus, who founded Chicago City Limits in 1977. In 1979, the company went on a national tour that ended in New York City, and the company never left. When Mr. Todisco died in 1982, Mr. Zuckerman took over as director and found a permanent home for the company at the theater on the Upper East Side.
Today, Chicago City Limits performs 52 weeks a year, and it sends a touring company across the country. This fall, as part of its educational program, it will offer 10 workshops. It also appears at corporate gatherings, known as industrials.
 
A Little Laugh, a Little Tune
 The political show, a first for the company, moves back and forth between set pieces and improvisational sketches.
It includes an election appeal, sung plaintively by Mr. Kissin, playing President Bush, to the tune of "Try to Remember":
 Try to remember the Kuwait surrender
I ask each voting girl and fellow
Try to remember I was the Commander
When every ribbon turned to yellow
Try to remember this coming November
Though you're unemployed, eating Spam and Jell-O.
The Need to Comment
Political humor presents both opportunities and pitfalls. "There are so many sound bites out there that you can end up just repeating them, and not commenting on them," said Mr. Telfer, echoing Mr. Zuckerman's cardinal rule, If you're not saying something smart, you're saying something dumb.
Mr. Kissin said, "I don't just want to get up there and repeat the popular view for an easy laugh."
That would be a betrayal of the form, which is built on doing things the hard way, and delivering the unexpected on instant demand.
"There are some far-out stand-ups, like Steven Wright, but in general they take things already in society," said Mr. Kissin. "We can develop ideas that have never been there,"
Mr. Telfer nodded in agreement. "I've always thought of it as like watching a pleasant car crash," he said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Capping of Baseball's Popularity

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
IT is not even necessary to get inside the head of the average American kid to know that baseball is facing a humbling, if not apocalyptic, decline in the 21st century. Just look at what these kids are wearing on top of their heads.
Years ago, a kid was introduced to sports with an unmistakable slice of Americana: the baseball cap with the hometown's initials embroidered on the front. This was a first possession that immediately linked the child with the game; forever, in more cases than not. 
 Today's baseball cap has become a symbol of baseball's dilemma, the crowded market, the numerous choices kids have. Today's "baseball cap" has the Chicago Bulls logo on it, or the Charlotte Hornets, or the Los Angeles Raiders. It has the logo of shoe maufacturers and television networks. Black kids across America sport "baseball caps" with an X, be it social statement or mere trend reflecting the coming Spike Lee film on Malcolm X.
Tennis players like Jim Courier and Andre Agassi have incorporated "baseball caps" into their corporate uniform. Will they be called tennis caps in 20 or 30 years?
About as many people -- roughly 20,000 -- paid their way into the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center for the day session alone yesterday as the combined attendance for ball games Tuesday night in Pittsburgh (7,720) and Montreal (13,704), the teams competing for the National League's Eastern Division pennant. By yesterday afternoon, Madison Square Garden was nearly sold out for a charity pro basketball exhibition, and Michael Jordan was not even on the guest list.
The National Basketball Association playoffs extend deep into June, and a month before the baseball playoffs even begin, there is pro football on television all day Sunday and two nights a week. Twenty-five years ago, in cable-less America, if there was a sporting event on television during the week, it was a baseball game 99 percent of the time.
If baseball could choose its new commissioner, define his role, settle its labor wars and ease its economic pain with a wave of Kirby Puckett's bat, it would have to face the more frightening quandary that it is a game more and more out of step with American society.
"It is a game that still has a tremendous following, but one that is graying," one highly placed executive of a rival sport said yesterday, requesting anonymity.
No one in sports, television or advertising will say that baseball is dying because there has been a cyclical nature in sports and premature deaths of football, basketball and even baseball have previously been announced. But there is no doubt among those who chart these trends that, as the executive put it, "it may be a generalization, but the generalization is that baseball is a game for 50-year-old white men."
Baseball has long been warned that it is alienating America's youth, destroying its future, by refusing to show World Series games in the afternoon. What certainly is an objectionable sellout is also, within the context of Armageddon, a specious argument at best.
To begin with, the late-night World Series applies to one, maybe two, time zones. Generations of kids managed to get hooked on the sport when World Series games were played while they were at school. If putting championship games on late at night tunes kids out, how does one account for the meteoric rise of the N.B.A., which for a decade has begun a large percentage of its championship-round games at 9 P.M. E.S.T.
It has been said that the beauty of the national pastime is its sense of timelessness, but in 1990's America, who has time for that? Baseball may be the family values game, passed down from father to son and daughter, but even the Quayles secretly know this is a country of families with two working parents, or single parents, and kids whose preferences and opinions are predominantly shaped by what they watch on TV.
The MTV Generation gets immediate gratification from the pushing of a computer key or the pressing of a button on remote control. Today's kids read less because reading requires patience and concentration, and so does waiting for the pitcher to cease throwing over to first base or for Buck Showalter to reach the mound and then make up his mind if he's going to make a pitching change.
Play word association, say sports superstar, and today's kids will respond: "Michael Jordan." Jordan is Hammer and Springsteen, and the N.B.A. is the closest thing in sports to a rock concert. Football is a video game played by human gladiators. Baseball is a long afternoon in the sun where the reward is a hot dog and a cap.
The hot dog usually is dry, overpriced and, as stated before, a kid no longer needs baseball to sport a cap.

HEADLINE: Eleanor Raynolds, Business Consultant And an Author, 55

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Eleanor H. Raynolds, an executive search consultant who was honored by the Queen of England for her work for the British-American Chamber of Commerce, died on Tuesday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. She was 55 years old and lived in Stamford.
The cause of her death was a massive staphylococcus infection, said Penny Paul Mooney, an associate at Ward Howell, the executive search firm where she was a partner. She said the cause of the infection has not been determined. 
 Mrs. Raynolds joined Ward Howell in 1985.
 
Founder of Peer Group
 During the early 1980's, she served consecutive terms as president of the British-American Chamber of Commerce, for which she was made a Commander of the British Empire. She was also a founder of the Peer Group, a national association of women in management and the arts, and served as a director of the New York Mission Society, the Women's Economic Round table and Mary Baldwin College.
Together with her husband, John F. Raynolds 3d, former president of Outward Bound USA, she wrote "Beyond Success -- How Volunteer Service Can Help You Begin Making a Life Insead of Just a Living."
Mrs. Raynolds, who trekked in the Himalayas and the Andes and climbed Mount Kilimanjaro, had just returned from a horse-riding trip in Utah when she died.
In addition to her husband, she is survived by two children from a previous marriage, a son, Jayson Kuhn of Silver Spring, Md., and a daughter, Jennifer Irwin of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and by two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Growth Is Harder For Safety-Kleen

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
WHEN the Safety-Kleen Corporation disclosed on Aug. 5 that it was guilty of large-scale permit violations in its storage of liquid hazardous wastes in Puerto Rico, investors hammered its stock. Shares ended the day down $3, to $27.625, on the Big Board as Wall Street worried about the potential for fines and cleanup costs.
But some analysts immediately figured that investors had overreacted to an isolated problem in a small if highly profitable corner of Safety-Kleen's liquid waste recycling empire. Vishnu Swarup of Prudential Securities, for example, quickly changed his "hold" rating on the company's stock to a "buy." For many, though, the incident simply provided another reason to advise clients to avoid the company, based in Elgin, Ill., unless they were taking a long-term perspective. 
 "It's a unique company, but it's still a little overpriced," said David McDonald, who follows the company for Wessels, Arnold & Henderson in Minneapolis.
Safety-Kleen's shares have traded in a narrow range since last month's tumble, closing at $27.25, up 50 cents, yesterday. News that Puerto Rican authorities want to assess a stiff $3.3 million fine pushed shares down less than $1. The subsequent report that the Environmental Protection Agency had no plans to pursue additional punishments was followed by an equally modest rebound.
Analysts say they are less worried about Safety-Kleen's problems in Puerto Rico than about signs that the economic recovery is faltering. Mr. Swarup, for one, dropped his rating on Safety-Kleen back to "hold" last week along with lowering his ratings for several other economically sensitive companies.
"In a slower growth environment, the only environmental stocks I would recommend in the near term are Waste Management, Browning-Ferris Industries, Wheelabrator Technologies and Mid-American Waste Systems," he said. Each of those companies, he said, is trading near or below the average ratio of price to projected earnings per share in the Standard & Poor's 500, while Safety-Kleen is 30 percent higher than the average.
Safety-Kleen was a Wall Street favorite during much of the 1970's and 1980's when it racked up an impressive string of 18 consecutive years of 20 percent or greater earnings growth. The main engine of the growth was the nationwide expansion of its system for supplying garages and auto service centers with solvents for parts cleaning, collecting spent solvents, and cleaning them for re-use. When the Environmental Protection Agency began regulating wastes produced by dry cleaners in the mid-1980's, Safety-Kleen quickly exploited its experience with supplying and processing fluids for small businesses to build another major profit center.
The pace has slowed sharply though since 1988. In fact, although Donald W. Brinckman, the company's chief executive, had voiced hopes two years ago of getting back on the 20 percent earnings growth track in 1991, last year turned out to be first in which earnings actually declined.
Part of the problem has been heavier-than-expected costs to build up the company's newer businesses, including collection of used motor oil for reprocessing into lubricants and fuels and collection of a wide range of fluids from small industrial and commercial waste generators. Expansion into Europe is also moving more slowly than expected.
In addition, Safety-Kleen has nearly saturated the domestic market for its older businesses, leaving less room for growth during a recession than in past downturns.
Safety-Kleen is not the only waste management company proving to be more sensitive to the health of the economy than in the past. But the slowdown has heightened awareness that Safety-Kleen is expensive in relation to other waste management stocks. And the problems in Puerto Rico have served as a reminder that its growing involvement in hazardous waste management could lead to more regulatory problems.
That said, analysts still laud Safety-Kleen's management and its basic strategic goals. "Anyone holding the stock long-term is going to do well no matter what the economy does," said Rosemarie Morbelli, who follows the company for Ingalls & Snyder. Ms. Morbelli sees the stock rising to about $34 a year from now. Jeffrey A. Berg, who follows environmental stocks for Raymond, James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla., has similar projections and a target of over $40 in 1994.
Signs the company's investments in growth are starting to pay off included income from European operations in the 24 weeks ending June 13 of $60,000, compared with a loss of $912,000 a year ago. And Mr. Brinckman said the growing oil recovery business crossed the threshold into profitability at the end of the second quarter.
"The oil business is a big part of the story for the next few quarters," said Douglas Augenthaler at Oppenheimer & Company, who is among the company's steadfast supporters on Wall Street. He rates Safety-Kleen as the only "buy" among the environmental stocks he follows.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Safer Mousetraps, Or Better Ones?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS Congress, stung by White House charges that it is a doormat for special interests, ready to take a whack at what many consider the toughest of Washington lobbies -- the nation's trial lawyers?
The combatants agree that today's vote on product liability legislation, which would tilt power toward defendants, is the best chance ever to draw blood from the plaintiff bar. If 60 senators vote to shut off debate, the momentum could lead to success next year in the House, where the lawyers have had a lock on the Judiciary Committee. But that is about all they agree on. 
 To manufacturers, the bill is an opportunity to limit a legal extortion racket that raises business costs. To Ralph Nader and Public Citizen, the sometime allies of the trial lawyers, it is a conspiracy to rob ill-treated Davids of their best weapons of redress against corporate Goliaths.
All this frustrates economically sophisticated legal scholars, who generally side with business on liability reform, but see the rules as incentives for balancing safety, innovation and low cost. Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution doubts this bill could much reduce "the bane of the system: manufacturers' uncertainty." And those who would also like to use the law as a safety net in injury cases fear it is a step backward. "This game is not worth the candle," said Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School.
While the public views product liability as a way to compensate the injured, economists focus on deterrence. The economists' core idea, largely derived from the work of Guido Calabrezi, now dean of the Yale School of Law, is to balance the damage from injuries against the costs of avoiding them -- and then to place the liability on the party that can avoid the accidents most cheaply.
The ideal law would thus induce manufacturers to build step ladders sturdy enough to avoid most accidents, but probably not sturdy enough to bear the weight of a pickup truck during a tire change. And while this ideal law would surely hold a maker responsible for a missing rivet, it would not look kindly on the claims of a circus juggler injured while balancing the ladder on his nose.
The driving force behind product liability reform is the explosion of insurance premiums. But high or rapidly rising costs do not in themselves impress W. Kip Viscusi, the Duke University economist who wrote "Reforming Products Liability" (Harvard University Press, 1991). There would be nothing wrong with the trend, he suggests, if it simply reflected greater product risks or greater success in compensating otherwise unprotected victims for avoidable product defects.
But there is far more to premium inflation than that. Mr. Viscusi is hardly sanguine, for example, about the impact on some industries, notably small aircraft manufacturers. While the accident rate in general aviation has fallen sharply and some 85 percent of the remaining crashes are apparently caused by pilot error, manufacturers are sued in 90 percent of all accidents, and product liability premiums now average a stunning $100,000 per plane.
Perhaps not surprisingly, the small aircraft industry is on the brink of extinction. "There is a strong argument current law creates incentives to make products that are too safe," adds George Priest of the Yale Law School.
Would the changes in the Senate bill make a difference? Pamela Gilbert, the legislative director of Public Citizen's Congress Watch and the chief lobbyist against the bill, thinks it is "hugely important." Mr. Litan is not so sure.
He sees modest benefits in provisions of the bill that would deny claims where the use of alcohol or drugs is the primary cause of an accident, and would eliminate liability for pain and suffering where Federal agencies had licensed drugs or aircraft. And he likes the precedent of a uniform Federal standard that makes it impossible for plaintiff lawyers to shop around for friendly state jurisdictions. The bill would also reduce uncertainty by setting a two-year statute of limitations on claims -- but would only start the clock ticking after the victim had good reason to know the source and extent of the injury.
The proposal does not, however, touch what Mr. Litan thinks is the most important potential reform: setting guidelines for damage awards. Nor does it go an inch toward resolving Mr. O'Connell's concern: the failure to compensate more than a tiny fraction of those who suffer severe injuries. He would like a variation on "no fault" insurance that eliminates the jury as middleman -- something, perhaps, like the 1986 law that uniformly compensates children injured by vaccinations.
From their perspective, then, the bill's value depends on whether it is a first step, or the last. Mr. O'Connell frets that "we are postponing the real fight for a generation." But Victor Schwartz, chief counsel for the bill's proponents, sees it as "the crack in the dam." It would "break the perception that the trial lawyers own Congress," he said, and set the stage for sweeping reform of liability law.

HEADLINE: Business Is Pessimistic

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
After rising through the first half of the year, business confidence fell sharply over the summer, the United States Chamber of Commerce said today, as fears mounted that a recovery was withering rapidly.
The chamber's latest Business Confidence Index, measuring the attitudes of 5,515 businessmen and women, shows they turned markedly pessimistic by August after six months of buoyant hope. 
 The index, a bimonthly average of three subindexes measuring the economic outlook, business sales and hiring prospects six months ahead, fell to 58 in August from 64.2 in June, when it was last compiled.

HEADLINE: On First Day For Schools, Many Lessons

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City's schools opened their doors yesterday in a spirit of giddiness and dread, with six brand-new schools and 2,000 eager new teachers confronting a stagnant budget, labor turmoil and an enrollment that has swollen ominously to almost one million.
As in most systems in the New York City area, the city system's first day was as bright with promise as the freshly waxed floors of its 1,000 schools and the highly polished shoes of children like 5-year-old Nicky Garland. Sticking close to her father's legs, she made her debut at Public School 23 in the Bronx, a school that was itself making its debut. 
 There were 17,000 to 20,000 more children than last year, lifting enrollment to around 993,000, the largest since 1978 and a barometer of the city's enduring attractiveness to immigrants. There were also six new buildings, most notably Stuyvesant High School's new home in Battery Park City, which delighted students who had attended the crumbling 80-year-old building on East 15th Street.
But there were already rumbles of tensions that could ruffle this year. The new schools will provide 6,000 seats, but those will scarcely hold a third of the growth in enrollment, so the Board of Education is in the position of a rower trying to keep a leaking boat afloat with a tiny cup.
The 2,192 new teachers will provide an infusion of fresh spirit and novel approaches, but many of the 66,000 teachers are growing increasingly restless about working for almost a year without a contract. The presence of picketing teachers at 100 schools yesterday testified to the unease surging through the system, which could boil over into more disruptive actions sometime this year.
"Morale is extremely low," said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, who recently has stepped up her attacks on the Dinkins administration. "When you go into a school year you need a whole lot of positive energy, and it is unconscionable to have them go into a situation where they're starting a second year without a contract."
 
Same Money, More Problems
 While the worst of the budget crisis seems to have passed, the system's $7.2 billion budget is the same as last year's and, because of inflation, that will mean fewer counselors, meager supplies, overcrowded classrooms. Harvey Garner, superintendent of District 18 in eastern Brooklyn, said he has 25 classes that exceed 32 children, which is the Board of Education's technical limit for class size.
While the system is deploying 300 additional guards and squads equipped with weapons scanners at 40 high schools and junior highs, officials are also aware that the tide of violent incidents has been rising.
At Brooklyn's Thomas Jefferson High School, where three students were shot to death and a teacher wounded last winter, students waited on line on the sidewalk to have their pictures taken for new identification cards. The school has also been equipped with electronic doors that are supposed to signal guards when opened by an intruder.
"Me, I feel safer," said Kenisha DeCosta, a 15-year-old junior, of the school's daily weapons scanning. "But some kids don't like it -- those that carry weapons."
At P.S. 23 in the Tremont section of the Bronx, Nicky Garland clung timidly to her father, gazing with a blend of wonder and dread at her brand-new four-story building and at the other children and parents milling on a sun-warmed Bronx sidewalk.
Her father, Cuba Anderson, who had driven in from his bookkeeper's job in Baltimore just to drop his daughter off, shared her nervous anticipation. Like most other parents, he wants his child to "get the best, everything she can, a good education, a good outlook on life, maybe some inspiration."
But, with a school system as uneven as New York City's, he worries as well.
"I hope she doesn't lose the inspiration she already has," Mr. Anderson said.
 
Attention to Curriculum
 The Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, on a visit to P.S. 23, signaled yesterday that beefing up instruction and curriculum will be his top priority this year. He has been preoccupied for more than a year both with issues of safety and with the threat of AIDS, most recently with a new AIDS curriculum that has ignited division on the seven-member Board of Education.
High schools are gradually adopting three-year science and math requirements -- one more year than before -- and beginning to drop general math and science courses in favor of those that require more laboratory work and more abstract skills.
Like most opening days, yesterday was filled with as much confusion and clamor as instruction. Teachers who had not seen one another since June hugged and gossiped while rushing to classes. Parents searched for their children's classrooms. And Danielle Chase, a new immigrant from Barbados attending P.S. 23, woke her mother up at 5:30 in the morning to say she was ready for school.
Outside 335 schools, police officers arrested 179 suspected drug dealers, including five students. At Public School 28, on the southern edge of Washington Heights in Manhattan, 50 or so parents with youngsters in tow crowded the entrance to register their children. Overwhelmed school aides sent many home, telling them to return today.
"I called yesterday, and they had none of her records, and they told us that we had to come this morning," said Sharon Massey, who lost a day of work in her futile effort to register 6-year-old Tamisha.
 
Too Little Space
 P.S. 28's principal, Michele Jones, was beleaguered herself. Working in a district with growing Dominican immigration, she is squeezing 1,500 children into a school built for 300 fewer students. She has put her eight kindergarten classes on split session, with some children starting as early as 7:55 A.M. and others leaving as late as 5 P.M. There are classes in onetime shower rooms and book closets.
And she has one guidance counselor for all 1,500 children in a neighborhood with many troubled and some homeless children.
P.S. 28 is probably one of the only elementary schools in the United States where teachers spent their first day covering "What is a grand jury? What is an indictment?" They had to help their children prepare for the possibility of turmoil on the streets this week because a grand jury has not returned an indictment in a police shooting this summer that set off several days of disturbances.
One fledgling second-grade teacher, Kristen Reid, was almost breathless with eagerness and opening-day nerves as she cheered up the bulletin boards, straightened her desk and unscrewed a balky pencil sharpener. Her biggest jitters were not about the possible disorder on the streets.
"My worst fear is losing control of the kids," she said.
 
A Volunteer
 Ms. Reid, a slender 26-year-old Dartmouth alumna and former banking officer, is a teacher who was trained by the Teach for America program, which seeks out college-graduate volunteers and people in business and trains them.
Like most teachers, she spent much of yesterday establishing rules -- "without order, you can't teach," she said -- and found herself touched by some of the things students told her about themselves.
"These children have such high aspirations," she said. "I have a couple of future doctors, several nurses, a singer and a football player and basketball player who are going to know how to read their multimillion-dollar contracts."
But whatever her worries, she vowed that she was "in education for the long haul."
"If there's any hope for a stronger society," she said, "it lies in education."

HEADLINE: Warning From France On U.S. Wheat Subsidy

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
France, which has long defended the European Community's system of generous farm subsidies, warned today that President Bush's recent decision to increase subsidies for American wheat exports posed a new threat to stalled international trade talks.
A French Government spokesman said President Francois Mitterrand had told a weekly Cabinet meeting that he had written to President Bush to complain about the plan to increase American wheat subsidies by $1 billion as a way of competing with European Community grain exports. 
 The spokesman quoted Mr. Mitterrand as saying that the new American subsidy "reflects an attitude that will create disarray in countries which wish to conclude an international trade agreement, and will certainly delay completion of the accord."
Mr. Bush, who has frequently criticized the community's agricultural supports, announced the new American wheat subsidies during a campaign swing through South Dakota and West Texas last week in what was widely interpreted as a bid for the farming vote in November.
 
Other Countries Protest, Too
 The decision has also prompted protests by other leading food exporters participating in the trade liberalization talks known as the Uruguay Round, which have been taking place for six years under the aegis of the Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Although the talks are dealing with an array of trade areas, they have been paralyzed mainly by the continuing disagreement between the United States and the 12-nation European Community over farm supports. Serious bargaining is now not expected to resume until after the American election.
Australia, which has generally sided with the United States in the farming dispute with the community, announced today that it would bring a formal complaint to GATT's Disputes Council over Washington's plan to increase its wheat export subsidies.
In the complaint, which was released in Canberra by the Trade and Overseas Development Minister, John Kerin, Australia accused both the United States and the European Community of "an escalation of anti-competitive behavior outside the GATT system."
 
Critical Stage for Talks
 Mr. Kerin warned that "an escalation of a subsidy war between the United States and the community at this critical stage would put the whole global endeavor of the Uruguay Round at risk." Argentina said it would endorse the Australian complaint at the next GATT Council meeting on Sept. 29.
France's response, though, was considered crucial because, under pressure from a powerful domestic farming lobby, the country has taken the lead in resisting American demands for a gradual dismantling of the community's system of farm supports and export subsidies.
Nonetheless, early this summer, in what it presented to the world as a concession aimed at rescuing the Uruguay Round, the community agreed to reduce subsidized price guarantees for its grain and meat producers. Since then, however, a widely predicted breakthrough in the GATT talks has not occurred.

HEADLINE: As Students Return, Districts Face Similar Ills

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

 BODY:
Youngsters in the New York City region returned to class yesterday, more absorbed by the first day of a new school year than by the widespread absence of teacher contracts and no-frills budgets that reflect sour economic times.
On Long Island, state-mandated austerity budgets in 13 of the 130 school districts mean more children walking to school and fewer superintendents. In Westchester County, programs are being cut and teachers are being offered incentives to retire early in an effort to reduce staff. 
 In Cherry Hill, N.J., teachers returned to school after settling a weeklong strike, but instructors in 143 of New Jersey's 593 school districts are working without contracts.
"I'm sure they're not happy about it, but as far as we know, everybody is going back to work," said Edward J. Gallagher, a spokesman for the New Jersey Education Association in Trenton, which represents more than 138,000 teachers and other school employees. "Some of the situations are fairly critical, but others are already in the process of mediation or fact-finding."
Of course, younger students left adults to trouble over contracts and budget constraints for the moment.
"To me, school is totally awesome," said Scott MacPherson, a 13-year-old eighth-grader at the Pierrepont School in Rutherford, N.J. "I've been looking forward to it. I have all good teachers, and I'm going to be graduating this year. For me, school is sort of easy."
Bob Cirino, an 11-year-old in Huntington, L.I., made the big leap from elementary to middle school yesterday in a school bus supplied with a bottle of Mylanta and a shot glass up front to ease nervous stomachs.
"We're going to junior high, and it's very different from elementary school," explained Bob. So far, he said, he likes the idea of middle school. "It's fun to switch around and have different teachers. It's a new experience with every teacher."
 
Some Head Starts
 At the Head Start program in Huntington, teachers helped 76 sets of parents and children cross the threshold from toddlerhood to the world of school. "We wiped a lot of tears and gave a lot of hugs and kisses and reassurance," said Ana Carrion, director of the Huntington Head Start program. "We had a great, terrific, hectic day."
Students in much of Connecticut were already into the rhythm of the school year, having started classes well before Labor Day. The schools plan to close for the Jewish holidays of Rosh ha-Shana on Sept. 28 and Yom Kippur, Oct. 7, and Three Kings' Day, a January holiday celebrated by many in the Hispanic community, and so made up the time by opening early.
James A. Connelly, superintendent of the Bridgeport schools, said educators there felt it would benefit the students to return to the classroom early this year. Bridgeport schools were the earliest to open in Connecticut, on Aug. 27.
"Because of the city's financial situation, there weren't many organized summer activities, so we feel our young people need structure and are happy to have it with school opening in late August," Mr. Connelly said.
Westchester County teachers do not face contract negotiations this year, but the atmosphere is strained for future negotiations.
"We have no indication that residents, even of affluent suburbs, are willing to be taxed greatly," said Bruce L. Dennis, superintendent for schools of Bedford, where the teachers' contract expires next June. "Plus, the teachers feel they are fully extended; the teachers themselves are feeling the pinch. So we have a difficult context in which to negotiate -- raised expectations on the part of the teachers and less money on the bargaining table."
