HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bank Profits Hit a Record $7.9 Billion

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Profits at commercial banks soared to a record this spring, pushed up by the lowest deposit rates in generations, the Government said today.
The nation's 11,685 banks earned $7.9 billion in the April-June quarter, breaking the $7.6 billion record set in the first quarter, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. The industry appears on track to break the annual earnings record of $24.9 billion, set in 1988, the agency said. 
 The F.D.I.C. attributed the second-quarter improvement to a modest shrinkage of bad loans and to the fifth consecutive quarterly increase in the difference between what banks pay on deposits and what they earn on loans and other investments.
"It's the best report we've seen for three years from the banking industry," said Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa.
 
Lowest Rates Since '36
 Passbook savings accounts, now around 3 percent, are the lowest since 1936, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. Rates on one-year certificates of deposit have declined by more than six percentage points since April 1989 while interest rates on auto loans have fallen by three percentage points and on unsecured personal loans by about three-quarters of a point.
"You've got to go back to the Great Depression to find deposit rates as low," Mr. Heady said. "The score is banks 1, consumers 0. They said the consumer was going to wind up picking up the tab for the banking mess. Well, the bailout's already begun."
The F.D.I.C. also said the condition of its insurance fund for bank deposits had improved;at the end of June it was negative $5.5 billion, compared with negative $7 billion six months earlier.
Andrew C. Hove Jr., the acting chairman of the F.D.I.C., cautioned that on a cash basis the fund was still paying more for failures than it was collecting in insurance premiums from banks.
 
Troubled Assets Shrink
 The industry's portfolio of troubled assets -- delinquent loans plus repossessed real estate -- edged under $100 billion for the first time in 18 months, falling $3.3 billion, to $99.7 billion.
The agency's problem bank list also declined, to 1,044 institutions with $567.5 billion in assets, from 1,051 with $607.4 billion at the end of March.
The average return on assets -- 0.94 percent -- was the highest since the F.D.I.C. began collecting quarterly income data in 1983. The banks' cushion of capital, at 7.23 percent of assets, was the highest since 1966.
However, the agency cautioned that banks, in taking advantage of lower interest rates, might be setting themselves up for problems later if interest rates were to rise. Instead of making new loans, many banks have been buying long-term Government securities, whose value would fall when rates increased.
Loans outstanding fell by $3.8 billion while securities holdings rose by $18.6 billion during the quarter.
In an accompanying report, the F.D.I.C. said the country's 430 savings banks -- part commercial bank, part savings and loan and mostly in the Northeast -- earned $217 million in the second quarter on top of a $218 million profit in the first three months of the year. They were the first two profitable quarters after 11 consecutive quarters of losses.

HEADLINE: When Storm Got Tough, the Women Got Tougher

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FOUR CORNERS, La., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Surrounded by sugar cane fields that seem to isolate them like green oceans, the people of this poor overwhelmingly black hamlet have been surviving without electricity, insurance adjustors, the National Guard or Federal aid since Hurricane Andrew struck Louisiana. Yet the women who live here have already started rebuilding.
They speak of it as almost a spiritual task because for the past three and a half years local women, united as the Four Corners Self-Help Housing Committee, have poured their sweat into improving their dilapidated clapboard cabins, learning builders' and bankers' skills to provide their families with solid walls and decent roofs. 
 "People were angry and disgusted to see all they had worked so hard at blown down in one night," said Mary Mathews, co-chairwoman of the committee. "But we know that wind was God talking to us. I think he was saying you have to get closer to each other some more, learn to work with each other better, and then you can build it again nicer than before."
 
A Lifetime of Struggle
 Although men in Four Corners have participated in the committee, they have never been its leaders or its primary source of physical labor. Since the group was formed, women have been its driving force and are the ones who gathered the donations, low-interest bank loans and Federal assistance to refurbish 25 homes and to start building a community center.
Then the hurricane hit, extensively damaging several homes and reducing the community center to rubble. Everywhere there is now the sickly smell of rot and mildew, and everyone seems to speak in weary cadences.
"These people are discouraged to start with," said Lorna Bourg, a co-founder of the Southern Mutual Help Association, a not-for-profit group in nearby New Iberia that organized the construction effort here. "And so who knows how this setback, on top of so many others, is going to affect them.
"Right now they are struggling to save all they've invested in their homes. They are ready to work, but they can't keep the rain out of their bedrooms unless they get shingles and lumber -- truckloads of it. That kind of frustration will test anyone's spirit."
Unlike the residents of South Florida, who flocked to the tropical sun with dreams of prosperity, the 400 residents of Four Corners are mostly descendants of plantation slaves who worked the sugar cane fields for generations only to see their poverty deepen as harvesting machines rendered them obsolete and unemployed.
 
Looking for a Reason
 Far from the attention of the national media in the aftermath of the hurricane, they have fallen back on the resources that have carried them through many trials: the iron will and religious faith that reside primarily in the women of this hamlet.
"When I first saw what happened to our community, I was angry," said Irma Lewis, a widowed cook who is secretary of the self-help committee. "Then I thought that if God spared our lives, it must have been for a reason, and so I got myself to work."
Groups of neighbors went about making emergency repairs where possible, like the plastic sheeting that covers the holes in Mrs. Lewis's roof, and they have begun tackling bigger projects, like the community center.
Sitting down to reflect on the storm and its aftermath, Josephine Roberson, one of the community's matriarchs, said, "I don't have the words for this except to say that we don't have excuses anymore for what we do and don't do." Tears gently rolled down her cheeks. "We know the way now. We have to pull ourselves up. Miss Lorna and the sisters have showed us that is the only way."
 
'Leveraged Self-Help'
 Ms. Bourg, 50 years old, and Sisters Helen Vinton and Anne Catherine Bizalion, who are members of Roman Catholic religious communities, have been working in south-central Louisiana communities like Four Corners for more than 20 years. Through Southern Mutual they have waged lawsuits to improve the wages of farm workers and have battled through state agencies to limit the workers' exposure to pesticides.
Working out of an antebellum house on the outskirts of New Iberia, the three women and a staff of three others have recently been developing projects that aim at what Ms. Bourg called "leveraged self-help."
For example, when the Four Corners community center is completed, it will offer classes in math, science and computer skills. Students will be charged commercial rates for the courses but will pay primarily in labor for the self-help committee. On this basis, businesses in nearby towns will subsidize the effort.
At the moment, however, Ms. Bourg is consumed with the difficulties of making quick repairs to the homes the committee had worked so hard to refurbish. While several religious groups, foundations and individuals have helped with building supplies, she said that over all the relief effort was out of kilter.
"I need roofing nails, gable vents and fascia board," she said with a commanding edge in her voice, "and I need it before all those houses are ruined by water intrusion. But people are still sending food and water and clothing, and there's nowhere to store it anymore we have so much. Money is just slipping through our fingers every time it rains because no one is coordinating anything."
Since the hurricane, Ms. Bourg and her colleagues have been devoting hours to wrestling with Federal and state agencies involved in the relief effort and trying to raise money for supplies. But each still spends part of every day with the people of Four Corners, bringing assurances that there is a world beyond the cane fields and that it is willing to leverage their self-help efforts.
Sitting in her breezeway today, Mrs. Roberson said to Ms. Bourg, "It's so nice that you tarry with us, Miss Lorna, because you help us know there are good people who care about this little place, and that makes me sure we'll put things back better than before and real soon too."
In response, Ms. Bourg offered a gentle correction: "Miss Josephine, this is a marathon now, not a sprint. You and me, we've got a long way to go."

The task of repairing a dilapidated clapboard cabin is not new to such residents as Irma Lewis, right, a widowed cook, who showed the repair work that lay ahead to Lorna Bourg, a co-founder of the Southern Mutual Help. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Jewish Voters;
Clinton Swipes at Bush For Lack of Jewish Aides

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, seeking the support of Jewish voters, today painted the Bush Administration and the Republican Party as institutions that were virtually devoid of Jews and dominated by fringe religious and right-wing elements hostile to Jewish concerns.
Alluding to the fact that there are virtually no Jews in the upper reaches of the Bush Administration, the Democratic Presidential candidate told the B'nai B'rith International Convention, "I think I ought to give you an administration that looks and feels like America -- a Cabinet, a White House staff, appointments to the judiciary and to other major positions that reach across racial, and religious, and ethnic, and regional lines, an administration committed to the highest standards of excellence." 
 These remarks, made by way of a satellite hookup, underscored the different approach Mr. Clinton adopted in his effort to woo Jewish votes from that employed by President Bush, who addressed the same audience in person on Tuesday. Mr. Bush's appeal to the Jewish audience was a traditional national security approach, focused on how as Commander in Chief he had been ready to use force to confront Israel's enemy Iraq, how he had worked with the former Soviet Union to organize Arab-Israeli peace talks and how he had helped Russian Jews emigrate to Israel.
Mr. Clinton, by contrast, made a domestic-focused appeal to American Jews. He quickly touched all the usual bases about how he would be supportive of Israel and the peace talks but then shifted his focus to the domestic concerns of many Jews -- from a woman's right to choose an abortion to mounting Jewish anxiety about the way in which fundamentalist Christians and right-wing supporters of Patrick J. Buchanan seemed to dominate the Republican convention.
 
Link to Economic Plans
 Mr. Clinton was also probably the first Presidential candidate to make a link between support for Israel and support for his economic plans, by arguing that it will be impossible for any future President to insure Israel's security without a strong American economy able to sustain foreign aid for strategic allies.
Unlike President Bush, Mr. Clinton did not appear in person. Instead, he spoke to the audience from a wall-size television screen through a link to suburban Atlanta, where he was on the campaign trail. Judging from the fact that Mr. Clinton got much more enthusiastic applause in his video appearance than Mr. Bush got in person, it seems that his line of argument resonated with the Jewish audience.
"There is another threat to Israel that has gone long unaddressed," he said. "It is a threat that can weaken Israel militarily, economically and politically. It can hinder our ability to respond to crises that may affect Israel. That threat is the weakening American economy. Without a growing economy, without a strong, stable and secure American middle class, America's commitment to Israel will always be under pressure."
In a dig at President Bush, who on Thursday in Detroit will lay out some new economic ideas packaged by his new chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Clinton said, "Our plan will begin on the first day of our inauguration, not the last two months before our effort to secure re-election."
 
Old Hot-Button Arguments
 The nature of Mr. Clinton's appeal to this Jewish audience, and the warm response it received, suggests that in the wake of the cold war some traditional constituencies are going to have to be addressed differently. Indeed, many in the audience agreed that at a time when Israel is engaged in peace talks with all its Arab neighbors, the old hot-button security arguments about standing with Israel just do not ignite Jewish audiences any more. And at a time when unemployment is high in the United States, Jews no longer feel comfortable vigorously fighting the sale of military aircraft to Saudi Arabia, when it could mean thousands of jobs for Americans. Therefore, they said, the appeal to Jewish audiences has to be from a domestic angle.
"I think Clinton did well," said Abraham D. Foxman, executive director of the Anti-Defamation League. "It was interesting, though, how much of the positive applause came in response to statements about domestic issues. The most sustained applause came when he said he was pro-choice on abortion and when he criticized the tone of the Republican convention."
Indeed, by far the most vigorous applause for Mr. Clinton came when he declared: "America is not just a place, it's an idea, an idea cherished and given life by Puritans and Catholics, by Jews and Baptists, by Republicans and Democrats, by women and men, by people of all colors, of all races, of all religions. That means an America where hatred and bigotry are not tolerated, an America where we have a Supreme Court which will respect our Constitution, protect women's right to choose, and protect the rights of all Americans."
Mr. Clinton is using this week to appeal to several other influential religious constituencies, including the National Baptist Convention as well as a predominantly Catholic audience at the University of Notre Dame.
 
On the G.O.P. Convention
 Speaking of the Republican convention, Mr. Clinton certainly told his Jewish listeners what they wanted to hear: "I must say I was also deeply disturbed by the tone of the first two days of the Republican convention in Houston, where it seemed that they were more interested in dividing the American people by claiming that some of us have values and others don't than in uniting us in a common effort to overcome our problems.
"I will never do that," he added. "It is the responsibility of our leaders to counter intolerance, bigotry and hatred. No one knows better than you the danger of bigotry, anti-Semitism and intolerance that is on the rise. As President, my commitment to opposing fear and hate and prejudice will not bend with the prevailing political wind."
Mr. Clinton made no effort to dodge the fact, not popular with this audience, that he had endorsed the sale of 72 F-15 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia, which will provide jobs for thousands of workers at the Missouri-based McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
"Clearly, we must meet our security commitments to our coalition partners in the gulf, but any of those actions must be taken in close consultation with the Government of Israel, and any arms sales must not undermine our commitment to Israel's qualitative edge," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Biggest Sale By America's Top Hatter

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Would-be Harrison Fords have worn his Indiana Jones fedoras. And legions of young people have slipped on all manner of his baseball caps to identify with the cachet of their favorite sports teams. But Irving Joel, who in three decades has built the country's largest designer, manufacturer and marketer of headwear, made by far his biggest sale this week.
Hicks, Muse & Company, a leveraged buyout firm based in New York and Dallas, says it will announce today that it has acquired an 80 percent stake in Hat Brands Inc., Mr. Joel's company, for more than $100 million in cash and debt securities. 
 Hicks, Muse, a fairly conservative firm that prefers to make acquisitions in niche markets, has acquired six companies with a total value of $1.8 billion, including Trident NGL Inc., a producer and marketer of natural gas liquids.
 
An Empire of Hat Brands
 Mr. Joel, who is 64 years old, has built a brand name empire that ranges from the sartorially correct Dobbs and Churchill homburgs to Garth Brooks Stetsons. Despite the recession, his privately held Hat Brands recorded sales of $106 million in its fiscal year that ended on June 30, up from $87 million in 1991.
Before interest and taxes, earnings were just over $18 million in 1992.
"We have looked at the business going back 10 years, and it seems to be relatively immune to business cycles," Thomas O. Hicks, the chairman and chief executive of Hicks, Muse, said in a telephone interview.
Indeed, according to projections from the Headwear Institute of America, a trade group, sales of hats and caps this year will reach $2.5 billion, up from $2.25 billion in 1991.
Much of the success is due to caps, an inexpensive fashion accessory cum statement worn by people of all ages. "Caps are the new T-shirts for the head," said Laura Fahrenthold, director of the Headwear Institute.
As part of the deal, Mr. Joel signed a five-year contract with Hicks, Muse to remain as Hat Brands' chairman and chief executive. He retains a 20 percent equity stake in the company.
"We would not be doing the deal if Irving Joel were not going to stay on," Mr. Hicks said. "He is critical to the success of the business."
 
Talks Began 18 Months Ago
 Mr. Joel and Mr. Hicks began talking about a possible combination 18 months ago, a little more than a year after Mr. Joel had bought the John B. Stetson's hat division, which was bankrupt, for $11 million in cash and the assumption of $3.1 million in debt.
The Stetson purchase solidified Hat Brands' position in the recently trendy Western hat market, a niche Mr. Joel initially tapped in 1985 when he bought the financially ailing Resistol brand from Levi Strauss, and a market that now accounts for 60 percent of Hat Brands' revenue.
Despite the surge in popularity for things country and Western, Mr. Joel says demand for Western hats has remained fairly steady. "We are still selling to the same customer today that we did when we came in," he said. "Someone buying a Garth Brooks hat is adding that to the 10 other Stetsons he already has."
The baseball cap business, on the other hand, is "very good," Mr. Joel said. Indeed, making and marketing baseball caps is where he made his start in the hat business when he founded the AJD Cap Corporation in 1960. Licensing agreements with concerns ranging from Coca-Cola to the National Football League expanded the market considerably. The company, renamed Hat Brands in 1973, was sold to Colgate-Palmolive in 1978.
 
Bought Back From Colgate
 Three years later Mr. Joel bought Hat Brands back from Colgate, and in 1984 he acquired Miller Brothers, a struggling hat manufacturer based in Corsicana, Tex.
Hat Brands, with manufacturing operations in Virginia, Texas and Missouri, has about 1,500 employees.
Looking forward, Mr. Joel said he was in "an acquisitive mode." Referring to Hicks, Muse, he added, "I think they are, too."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hughes Shifts Missile Work To Arizona From California

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9

 BODY:
The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it would move its missile production and several thousand jobs, including work on the Tomahawk, Stinger, and Standard missiles, from a number of sites in Southern California to a single plant in Tucson, Ariz.
The move, which had been widely expected, follows Hughes's $450 million acquisition of the General Dynamics Corporation's missile division last month and is intended to consolidate the company's five missile manufacturing plants. Hughes officials said the move will be completed within two years. 
 The combined operations are expected to eliminate duplicated administrative, research and production costs, company officials said. The Tucson plant, which Hughes recently spent $250 million to modernize, cost 10 percent less to operate than those in California, the officials said.
Hughes officials said the missile production lines that the company purchased from General Dynamics would be closed. These lines, which produce radar-evading cruise missiles and shipboard missiles, including the Tomahawk and Standard, are in San Diego, Pomona and Rancho Cucamonga, Calif, and Camden, Ark.
The shift of General Dynamics missile manufacturing to Arizona is the latest blow to California's economy, which is suffering its worst recession since the 1930's, in part because of widespread job losses in the military-contracting industry. In the Los Angeles area alone, employment in the aerospace industry has declined by nearly a third in the last six years, to about 200,000.
Hughes officials said that it was too early to say exactly how many jobs would be moved to Arizona, but defense industry analysts estimated that at least 4,000 jobs would go to Tucson.
Company officials said that 4,000 missile jobs would be eliminated by 1993 because of the consolidation and termination of missile programs. The officials said that some Hughes employees would be relocated to Arizona, but they said the exact number had not been determined.
Hughes currently employs about 14,000 missile workers. Before it acquired the General Dynamics division, which had 7,600 workers, Hughes had 7,000 missile employees. In recent months, the company has reduced that number by 600 employees.
Hughes is a unit of the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which is controlled by the General Motors Corporation.

HEADLINE: Florida Freezes Insurer's Rates in Warning

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Florida's insurance commissioner took the unusual action yesterday of freezing the rates and premiums charged by one of the nation's largest insurance companies, the American International Group.
The commissioner also warned other property casualty insurers operating in the state that regulators would reject any unjustified rate increases sought in the wake of the devastation caused by Hurricane Andrew. 
 The commissioner's action against A.I.G. came as a result of the publication of an internal company memo that described Hurricane Andrew as "an opportunity to get price increases now." The memo was obtained by a consumer group and distributed last week.
The memo, written on the day the hurricane wrought billions of dollars of damage on South Florida, has been cited by consumer groups as evidence that A.I.G., and perhaps other companies, planned to use the hurricane as an excuse to charge unjustifiable rates.
The chairman of the New York-based A.I.G., Maurice R. Greenberg, said the meaning of the memo had been taken out of context. It was written by his son, J. W. Greenberg, an executive vice president, and was sent to the company's top executives.
For years, the senior Mr. Greenberg has argued that premiums charged business customers were inadequate and he said yesterday that the memo simply reiterated the company's longstanding view.
In another announcement yesterday, State Farm, the company with the largest homeowner and private automobile insurance business in Florida, said its losses from Andrew would total $1.2 billion as a result of more than 110,000 claims. William Sirola, a spokesman for the company, said that State Farm had no immediate plans to raise rates.
In yesterday's action against A.I.G., the Florida Insurance Commissioner, Tom Gallagher, said he and Florida's Attorney General, Robert A. Butterworth, would investigate whether the company was actually trying to raise prices excessively and whether it was acting in violation of state antitrust laws.
In any case, a department spokesman added, Mr. Gallagher felt the memo showed a callousness on the part of an executive to the human tragedy taking place in Florida.
"A.I.G. and all of the other companies who sell commercial, property and auto insurance in Florida better get this message now," Mr. Gallagher said. "We won't tolerate any company trying to take advantage of our citizens in the aftermath of this tragedy."
Mr. Gallagher's order froze the rates and premiums set by A.I.G. in the state for 60 days. The commissioner announced he would hold a public hearing to look into the matter. Florida law allows companies to set rates first and then file them with regulators, who can then reject them.
The commissioner also sent a letter today to the chief executives of the 780 companies licensed to sell property and casualty insurance in Florida. In his letter, he warned that his department would reject any efforts by the insurance industry to "capitalize on the misfortune of Hurricane Andrew's victims" through unjustified rate increases.
The memo marks the latest battle in a war between consumer groups and the property casualty industry in states across the nation. Consumer activists, like Robert J. Hunter, the president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, which first obtained the memo last week, and Ralph Nader, have argued that insurers make more than adequate returns with current prices.
 
Worry About Capital
 The insurance industry and most Wall Street analysts and economists who follow the industry say that at least in certain types of insurance that involve commercial customers, competition in recent years has kept prices so low that in the long run, if prices do not go up it will be hard for the industry to attract capital and remain healthy.
Immediately after Hurricane Andrew hit shore on Aug. 24, the stocks of many major insurers climbed in expectation that the storm damage would deplete the industry's capital and change the psychology of the market place so that property casualty rates would rise. But a majority of analysts now say they doubt whether Andrew alone -- which is expected to result in nearly $8 billion in insured losses in Florida and Louisiana -- will cause a climb in premiums.
The A.I.G. memo said: "The industry cannot absorb the loss and cash hit without increasing rates. We have opportunities from this and everyone must probe with brokers and clients.
"This is an opportunity to get price increases now," the memo continued, "We must be the first and it begins by establishing the psychology with our own people. Please get it moving today."
In a statement issued by A.I.G. yesterday, the company's chairman said the company would dispute the charges of wrongdoing at a public hearing.
"Insurance rates are not set in response to any single event, even a disaster as unprecedented as Hurricane Andrew," the senior Mr. Greenberg said. "They are set by the marketplace. Any informed observer of our industry knows that."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
G.O.P. Looks at Clinton Draft Record and Spies Willie Horton

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Have the Republicans found their furlough issue for 1992?
Four years ago, the Bush campaign used a Massachusetts prison release program to chip away at Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, asking what kind of man would give weekend passes to convicted murderers like Willie Horton. The past few weeks suggest that the Republicans are testing to see if they can use Gov. Bill Clinton's draft record, and his shifting explanations of it over the years, in a similar fashion in the next 54 days. 
 Then as now, the goal is to find a single issue that crystallizes broader doubts about the character and the values of the opposition. The Republicans then develop the theme to full force through disciplined repetition by their candidate, his campaign aides, an army of surrogates, and, ultimately, television advertising, to the point where it can shatter a political persona.
The drumbeat on the draft is clearly escalating. On Tuesday, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas was on the floor of the Senate, urging Mr. Clinton to "come clean." On Wednesday, Patrick J. Buchanan was on CBS "This Morning," asserting that a man who "dodged the draft" in Vietnam was unfit to be Commander in Chief. Almost every day, new press releases come from the Bush-Quayle headquarters, accusing Mr. Clinton of contradicting himself or covering up the truth about why he did not serve in the military in the Vietnam War.
 
A Fumbling Response
 There is a potential for backlash in this. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, says his party has spent much of the past few years warning the American people that the Republicans would try to distract them from the ailing economy in this election. "One of the things we've done is get the American people ready for this kind of tactic," Mr. Brown said in an interview today.
Clinton aides also say they relish a confrontation over trustworthiness and candor with a President who promised "no new taxes" and a vibrant economy. And the issue of the Vietnam War itself is not without salience for Vice President Dan Quayle, who fulfilled his military obligation in the Indiana National Guard. Still, the Clinton campaign's handling of the issue has been fumbling and awkward, particularly since a Los Angeles Times article last week prompted new scrutiny of about how he managed to avoid the draft, notably the efforts of a late uncle to lobby on his behalf.
Mr. Clinton gave various responses about when he knew about his uncle's activities, then on Monday angrily lashed out at reporters who pressed him on the issue.
Senior advisers in the Bush campaign see the draft issue, which they all but acknowledge will be used in television advertising, as a rich line of attack in several respects. First and foremost, they say, the issue goes to Mr. Clinton's credibility; they are trying to depict the Democratic nominee as someone who stretches the truth to please the audience of the day, someone so ambitious that he will say anything to win, someone who is, in short, "slick."
 
Character vs. Issues
 "It's not about the draft, it's about the truth, and trustworthiness," said Mary Matalin, deputy manager for the Bush campaign. "It's a very clear illumination of a character flaw." This fits into the overarching concept that Bush strategists have for this campaign: one that revolves not around the economy, or change vs. the status quo, but trust and leadership traits.
Mr. Bush himself implicitly uses the Clinton draft history as a missing ingredient in the Democrat's qualifications to be Commander in Chief: In this week's struggle over which candidate was the most appropriate heir to Harry Truman, Mr. Bush noted that both he and Mr. Truman had served happily and proudly in the military.
Finally, some Bush advisers see Mr. Clinton's lack of military service and the opposition he voiced toward the Vietnam War at the time as an important wedge issue with more conservative voters, like Reagan Democrats and Southerners. Among some voters, the draft could set off the same kind of resonant contrast that the Pledge of Allegiance issue did four years ago, in which the Republicans made claim to the symbols and traditions of nationhood.
 
The Economy as Topic A
 Still, Kathleen Hall Jamieson, an expert in political communication at the University of Pennsylvania, discounts that aspect of the draft issue. "The level of moral ambiguity surrounding that war was sufficiently high that it is difficult for many people to analogize it to the war George Bush served in," she said.
The more serious charge, Ms. Jamieson said, would involve candor and truth-telling, which the Democrats tried this week to turn back on Mr. Bush by questioning his role in the Iran-contra affair.
The broader question, some political experts say, is whether the draft issue can break through the voters' consuming interest in the economy.
"I still think the overriding issue here is the economy and jobs," said Merle Black, an expert on Southern politics at Emory University in Atlanta. But Mr. Black and several other analysts added, "You really don't see the full impact of the draft issue until it goes on television."
In the meantime, the Clinton campaign is trying to return to its message. "Governor Clinton has made his statement, he's answered the questions, it's time to move on to the economy and what the candidates are going to do on issues that matter to real people," said George Stephanopoulos, deputy manager of the Clinton campaign.
But the press releases on the draft keep coming.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Sweden Lifts Interbank Rate To Defend the Falling Krona

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Sweden said today that it was raising a key interbank lending rate from 24 percent to 75 percent to defend the dropping Swedish krona. The news swept the United States dollar up sharply against the German mark.
In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 1.41355 German marks, up from 1.3945 late Tuesday.
Sweden's rate increase helped restore stability to currency markets thrown into upheaval by thesurprise devaluation by Finland of its markka on Tuesday. In the wild trading that followed Finland's move, the dollar had tumbled as investors fled to the mark. The swing to the mark was fueled by fears of a devaluation by other countries with weak currencies pegged to the mark. 
 Sweden's rate increase put intense pressure on speculators who had taken short positions in the Swedish krona in the hope that the Government would be forced to devalue by drastically increasing the cost of financing their investments.
Bengt Dennis, governor of Sweden's central bank, emphasized the Government's determination to defend the currency's exchange rate.
The rate increased by Sweden sets the cost of borrowing between commercial banks and the central bank through short-term money market transactions. Currency traders said the move was reminiscent of those by other European countries in the past to fight devaluation pressures. But economists and traders warned that the high rates could not last long without crippling the Swedish economy.
In other New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 123.13 Japanese yen, up from 122.85 late Tuesday, and the British pound fell to $1.9710, from $2.0040 late Tuesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9750, from $2.0037 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise; Taxables Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week as the supply of municipal debt remained heavy and the money markets reflected the cautious easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve on Friday.
The average yield on tax-exempt funds rose, while the yield on taxable funds dropped. 
 According to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, assets of tax-exempt money funds were up $849.2 million for the week, to a total $95.9 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios increased by two, to 67, the longest in six years.
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
 The seven-day average compounded yield rose seven basis points, to 2.39 percent, while the simple yield rose seven basis points, to 2.36 percent. Over a 30-day period, the average compounded and simple yields both are up three basis points, to 2.25 percent and 2.23 percent, respectively.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield is 3.32 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.46 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said Dreyfus Basic Municipal was the best-performing fund, with a return of 3.25 percent.
Mary Sue Hoban, a spokeswoman for IBC/Donoghue's, noted that the large supply of new municipal securities pushed short-term tax-exempt yields higher. In addition, she said, short-term yields were coming under increased pressure to compete with higher long-term yields.
 
Taxable Assets Gain
 Meanwhile, yields in taxable money market funds fell off sharply as total assets grew by $9.5 billion, to $499.4 billion. As in the previous two weeks, most of the cash flow came from institutional investors fleeing the unstable markets. Institutional funds saw their assets grow by $8.6 billion, for a total of $181.7 billion.
"We were surprised at how fast yields dropped in taxables since it was only last Friday that the Fed eased," Ms. Hoban said. "Normally, it takes time for market developments to show themselves in the yields.
"But a closer look revealed that 29 percent of the taxable portfolio included securities with less than seven days left to maturity, while the tax-exempt portfolio showed 50 percent with less than seven days. That explained the rapid turnover.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market fund was off four basis points, to 3.01 percent, while the simple yield dipped below 3 percent, to 2.96 percent, off five basis points. For a 30-day average, the compounded and simple yields were both down three basis points, to 3.06 percent and 3.01 percent, respectively.
 
Top-Performing Funds
 Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios fell by one, to 63, just under its highest mark in a decade.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, maintained its grip as the top performer among large general-purpose funds with a yield of 3.82 percent. But including funds with assets of less than $100 million that invest only in Government securities, the United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services Advisors in San Antonio, was the top performer, with a yield of 4.10 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account slipped two basis points this week, to yield 2.98 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Jersey Visit;
Bush Finds Fertile Ground for Attacking Governors

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Sept. 9

 BODY:
President Bush today opened a second front in his campaign against what he called tax-and-spend liberals when he attacked Gov. Bill Clinton by way of Gov. Jim Florio.
"I don't have to tell New Jersey about that old saxophone song sounding the familiar tax-and-spend theme," Mr. Bush told more than 2,000 people who had waited three hours in the parking lot of V.F.W. Post 2179 to hear his speech. 
 "You know what a liberal Governor and a liberal legislature can do to wreck an economy," he said. "Florio, in cahoots with the Democratic Legislature, acted as if every day was April 15."
 
New Jersey Viewed as Crucial

 The sharp attack on Mr. Florio and his $2.8 billion tax program that was enacted in 1990 delighted the leaders of Mr. Bush's New Jersey campaign. They said they have been telling the President's advisers that there was still some anger left in the voter backlash against the Democratic Governor's tax program that nearly unseated Senator Bill Bradley two years ago and last November changed the New Jersey Legislature to Republican control from Democratic.
"New Jersey is crucial," said Bill Palatucci, the executive director of the President's New Jersey campaign. "It will be tough to win a national campaign as a Republican without New Jersey.
"We had been urging him to go after Florio. And we're glad that he finally agreed to do it."
Mr. Bush's visit today was his third since the Democratic National Convention in July, and he is expected to make more before Election Day.
With his own re-election campaign coming up next year, the last thing Mr. Florio needs is another referendum on his program this year.
Mr. Bush had no new initiatives to announce in his 15-minute address, but he reminded the crowd that when he campaigned in New Jersey four years ago he promised to end ocean dumping of sewage sludge off the coast and claimed today that he had honored that pledge.
 
Friendly Turf for Bush
 "The last sludge barge left New York Harbor last June," the President said. "Now when you look off shore, you see sailboats, not sludge barges."
 Mr. Bush promised now to pressure New York City to complete construction of sewage treatment plants to further improve water quality offshore.
For Mr. Bush it was a return to friendly surroundings. Mayor Rosemary Peters said sprawling Middletown Township, Monmouth County's largest community, had strongly supported the Reagan-Bush ticket with majorities of 56 percent in the 1980 election and 62 percent in 1984, and gave Mr. Bush 67 percent of its vote in 1988.
The township is largely a bedroom community for commuters who travel to jobs in northern New Jersey and New York City by train or on the Garden State Parkway. It has blue- and white-collar neighborhoods, small businesses and a string of shopping malls along Routes 35 and 36, two of the principal arteries to the state's northern shore resorts and to Gateway National Park on Sandy Hook.
Mr. Palatucci said the President was trailing Mr. Clinton in Monmouth County, long considered vital to a Republican victory in the state, by 10 to 13 points. But he added that Mr. Bush appeared to be narrowing the gap and was behind by about the same amount at this point in the campaign four years ago.
The area residents and high school students who came to hear the President could muster only brief bursts of applause for Mr. Bush's attacks on Mr. Clinton as someone looking to the past for solutions to economic problems.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A DECISION IN FATAL SHOOTING
A Manhattan grand jury has cleared a New York City police officer in the fatal shooting of a drug suspect whose death in July touched off violent demonstrations in Washington Heights, according to a top official in the Manhattan District Attorney's office. But the District Attorney has declined to announce the grand jury's decision while city officials and community groups put into motion elaborate efforts to stave off new violence. A1.
 
A FOSTER-CARE SUCCESS STORY
When the 5-year-old foster child first walked into the psychotherapist's office, he did not know how to play. As the months passed, he learned to express himself, but his games were violent and bizarre. But gradually, the therapist said, his fury diminished and he began to create rather than to destroy. Soon he will be adopted by a Queens family, a happy ending in a foster-care system that too often fails to treat troubled children who have been abused by their parents and separated from all that is familiar to them. A1. 

NEW RATING RULES PROPOSED FOR BANKS
In a fresh effort to pressure lenders to provide more services in poor areas, the New York State Banking Department has proposed new rules that it said would strengthen a controversial law that ranks lenders on the basis of their social responsibility. Although the regulations would be statewide, they would have the greatest impact on efforts to increase banking services in poor neighborhoods in New York City. B3.
 
School to be scoured for lead. B3.
 
REGION
 
A GUILTY PLEA IN FRAUD CASE
John McNamara, the Long Island car dealer and philanthropist, has pleaded guilty to fraud, admitting that he had bilked General Motors in a $6 billion loan scheme and that he had used some of the money to bribe officials at all levels in the Town of Brookhaven to win approvals for his vast real-estate developments. As part of a plea agreement, Mr. McNamara, who faces 20 years in prison and more than $800 million in fines, said he would assist in prosecuting the officials. In exchange, the Government agreed to move for a more lenient sentence and, if Mr. McNamara should request, to help him enter the Federal witness protection program. A1.
 
THE FERRARO FACTOR
Just five days before the New York Democratic primary for the Senate, the strategies of all the candidates revolve around Geraldine A. Ferraro. For her rivals, the question is how to beat her. For Ms. Ferraro, the trick is to hold onto every ounce of support that has made her the leader in the polls so far. News analysis, B4.

Campaigning in New Jersey, President Bush attacked Bill Clinton by way of Jim Florio. "You know what a liberal governor and a liberal legislature can do to wreck an economy," he said. "Florio, in cahoots with the Democratic Legislature, acted as if every day was April 15." A21.

Because of a twist of archeological fate and a minor mistake on an old Connecticut map, a tiny and long forgotten farm family cemetery -- 28 bodies representing generations of a family called the Waltons -- suddenly re-emerged into the 20th century. B7.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M.'s Bold Move Into Credit Cards

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The credit card introduced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation brandishes a long list of features that make it, some industry analysts say, the most important new national card since A.T.& T. introduced its Universal card in March 1990.
Good news for consumers, bad news for competitors. The features are a sign that consumers stand to benefit from the growing competition among banks and nonbanks for trustworthy credit risks. G.M.'s card, whose primary mission is to help the auto maker sell cars by building brand loyalty through offering rebates, is likely to take a toll on some smaller players and continue the consolidation under way among credit card companies. In the last five years, the market share of the top 10 card issuers has increased to 51.5 percent from 37 percent. 
 Analysts say the G.M. card will also weigh heavily on the beleaguered card operations of American Express, whose premium charge cards and Optima credit card are struggling.
"American Express is a loser any time any big player comes in offers a card nationally with no fee," said Robert B. McKinley, president of RAM Research in Frederick, Md.
 
Borrowing Ideas From Rivals
 The G.M. Mastercard borrows pages from the playbooks of several rivals and goes beyond the card that the GE Capital Corporation announced last week -- a card with discount coupons and rebates from 24 large companies, as well as discounts on General Electric products.
"It's a whole new face of credit card marketing," said David Robertson, president of The Nilson Report, an industry newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif.
The G.M. card has no annual fee and an adjustable rate of 10.4 percentage points above the prime rate. Currently, that makes its interest rate 16.4 percent, more than 1.5 percentage points below the industry average and the same as the rate on the A.T.& T. card.
Customers can spend their way to rebates of up to $3,500 on the purchase or lease contract of any new G.M. car or truck except the Saturn models. The 5 percent rebate on most purchases, to a maximum of $500 a year, is cumulative over seven years. If customers transfer the balance on their current cards to G.M., they will receive 5 percent of that amount as a rebate.
In addition, G.M. has joined forces with Avis, the Marriott hotel chain and MCI Communications. Charges with those companies give card users an additional 5 percent rebate -- a $100 car rental charge with Avis would credit users with a total of $10 toward a rebate on a G.M. vehicle. In addition, there is no cap on these rebates, and more such partners may be named at a later date, G.M. executives said yesterday.
The G.M. Mastercard will be administered by Household Credit Services, a unit of Household International Inc. of Prospect Heights, Ill., that has grown rapidly in recent years to become the ninth largest issuer of credit cards. Last September, Household helped the Ameritech Corporation issue a Mastercard, making it the first Baby Bell to offer a credit card that can be used for consumer purchases and to pay for telephone calls.
G.M. executives declined to discuss its financial relationship with Household and its other partners. They did say that Household would administer the card, own the receivables and decide who would get a card.
General Motors said it was mailing packets to 30 million households.
The card is an expensive bet for G.M.; analysts have estimated that it will spend roughly $60 million on the advertising campaign that describes a card "that turns buying power into horsepower, plastic into steel."
Wooing new credit card customers costs, on average, more than $50 an account, analysts said. Household and other partners will undoubtedly shoulder some of those costs.
 
Auto Market Share
 G.M. could use any help the card provides. In the last eight months, the auto maker, as well as Honda, Toyota and Nissan, have lost market share in the United States to Ford and Chrysler. Through the first eight months of the year, G.M. had 34.9 percent of the market, down from 35.4 percent a year earlier and down sharply from historic levels of about 45 percent in the early 1980's.
Some analysts project that G.M. will gain two million to three million card holders in the next year or two. Whether those customers will prove profitable for Household and G.M. is unclear.
Some industry analysts say the lack of annual fee may attract many poor credit risks. And many people with high incomes who buy new cars frequently also do not carry balances on their card, essentially using them as free credit.
"G.M. and Household are walking into a shark's mouth," said William C. Dunkleberg, dean of Temple University's School of Business and Management and a consultant to the credit card industry.

HEADLINE: Banking Dept. Proposes Changes in Rating Rules

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a fresh effort to pressure lenders to provide more loans and services in poor areas, the New York State Banking Department yesterday proposed new rules that it said would strengthen a controversial law that ranks lenders on the basis of their social responsibility.
Although the strengthened law, the Community Reinvestment Act, would affect regulations statewide, the changes -- intended to encourage public review and add incentives for banks -- would have the greatest impact on banking services in poor neighborhoods in New York City. 
 New York's Banking Board, which oversees the Banking Department, has asked for comments on the proposals from banks, citizens' groups and others and said it would not rule on the changes until early 1993. The board can enact the proposed rules without legislative approval.
If enacted, yesterday's proposals would mean that for the first time, the ratings given to the lenders -- from a high of 1 for outstanding to a low of 4 for noncompliance -- would be routinely announced by the state, fostering what officials said would be heightened competition among bankers to serve the poor.
Banks seek to avoid low ratings because they can be cited by citizens' groups or regulators in challenges to mergers and other changes that require governmental approval.
The ratings are public information, but they currently can be obtained only by formal written request under the Freedom of Information Act. State officials said yesterday that few such requests had been made.
 
A Push for More
 While the state's proposals are a clear endorsement of monitoring banking practices in poor communities, the Banking Department said current laws did not go far enough.
"We believe that the reach of C.R.A. has not kept pace," said Derrick D. Cephas, the New York State Superintendent of Banks.
In another change to the Community Reinvestment Act, enacted in 1979, the state's senior banking regulators said they would specify what types of services that banks must perform to enhance their ratings. Although the list may grow, they said, it is all but certain to include lending for low-income housing construction, offering low-cost checking accounts and other services to poor people and increasing lending to small business.
The state's proposals can be expected to provoke a political squall among some bankers and advocates of free-market economic principles, who have protested the various forms of the Community Reinvestment Act enacted by the Federal Government and 13 states, including Connecticut, since the late 1970's. New Jersey has not adopted such regulations.
The Federal law applies to federally chartered or insured banks and thrifts, of which there are 335 in New York State.
Critics charge that the Community Reinvestment Act has at best created cumbersome new reporting requirements and at worst required banks to make risky investments.
"It is simply wrong-headed policy," said Lawrence J. White, a professor of economics at New York University's Stern School of Business, who maintained the Federal and state banking regulations "require or aggressively nudge banks into subsidizing parts of the community."
The proposals "would only aggravate the problem," he added.
But community organizers, low-income housing developersand advocates for the poor applauded the proposals, which Mr. Cephas announced at a news conference in Manhattan.
"The Community Reinvestment Act has clearly served a need in this community, and these changes sound like they would make it better," said Christopher Kui, of Asian American Equalities, a group based in Chinatown and the Lower East Side that develops low-income housing and helps small businesses.
One of the group's recent successes was finding $200,000 in bank loans for a small home-health-care enterprise in Chinatown, Mr. Kui said. "The law makes banks accountable, and we have hundreds of small businesses here that need help," he said.
Among the proposed changes is one intended to insulate lenders that receive the highest rating from citizen protests. Any lender that receives a 1 rating for three consecutive years would qualify.
 
One Mixed Review
 All banks are vulnerable to challenges from citizen groups when they seek to make changes that require government approval, like mergers and acquisitions. But the challenges have been most common when the banks have low ratings.
A citizens' group that has aggressively challenged bank policies, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn, gave the state's proposal a mixed review.
John Kest, the chief New York city organizer for the group, said that although most elements of the plan "seem like an improvement," the provision giving the best-rated lenders special protection could undermine the act. "You just can't take away the right to challenge banks and expect the law to have any meaning," he said.

HEADLINE: Storm's Staggering Load on Banks

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla. Sept. 9

 BODY:
The rebuilding of the southern Florida economy after Hurricane Andrew may require billions of dollars more in financing than the amount covered by insurance and even the new aid proposed by President Bush.
The President's request on Monday for $7.6 billion to assist the storm victims in both Florida and Louisiana will help. Some Federal funds will help hard-hit businesses and homeowners, but much of that money is earmarked for repairing streets, schools, government buildings and an Air Force base here. 
 The banks are being left to shoulder a huge load in financing the recovery in the private sector, and it is clear that this is a load they may be unable to carry.
For one thing, the banks have problems of their own. The collateral on many of their loans collapsed, literally, in the storm. And thousands of households and businesses that have long been dependable customers suddenly lost the ability on Aug. 24 to make loan payments.
The role of the government, bankers and economists say, must be to find ways to make it more attractive for banks and investors to funnel private capital into hurricane-damaged areas by reducing the risks for lenders and investors.
"The challenge of financing the restoration and recovery work will be enormous," said Stephen Morrell, a former banker who is an economist at Barry University in Miami Shores. "The dimensions of the problem really haven't been thought through yet, and a solution is going to require some innovative financing mechanisms on the part of both government and the banks."
One suggestion is for the government to bundle Hurricane Andrew recovery loans and sell them through a government-backed agency, as happens now with home mortgages. Another is to set up a state development bank to provide seed capital for the recovery effort. The Bush package is seen as a step in the right direction but one that is not going to fill the financing gap.
Homestead offers a clear picture of the economic crisis. Just about everyone here lost heavily, a roof, a house, a business. But Kerry L. Herndon, one of the area's biggest flower growers, lost much more than most.
Mr. Herndon, like thousands of other victims of the hurricane, has vowed to make a comeback. And his story helps illustrate the financial fallout from the nation's most costly natural disaster -- the sudden loss of wealth, the sizable uninsured losses, the shortage of funds and the impact on local jobs -- and what a formidable task it will be to find money for a genuine recovery.
The 36-year-old entrepreneur had four million orchids and other flowers growing profitably under 800,000 square feet of high-tech greenhouse space, structures of steel and aluminum where the plants were fed collected rainwater and tended by robots. Today, all that is gone. His modern greenhouses are nothing more than a huge mound of shiny metal, like some child's oversized erector set smashed by a bully.
Mr. Herndon had assumed he had ample insurance coverage, about $6 million worth. His estimate of his actual losses: $16 million. "I don't think anyone could have anticipated this level of devastation," he said.
 
Loss Estimates Vary
 The total loss estimates from Hurricane Andrew have ranged up to $30 billion. But a more detailed reckoning has come from the economics department of Barnett Banks Inc., Florida's largest bank, which estimated the hurricane damage at $17.6 billion. The insurance industry announced last week that it planned to pay out $7.3 billion in claims.
An additional $1.2 billion is public property and Homestead Air Force Base, and President Bush pledges the Federal Government will pay for those. Other Federal programs will provide additional help, such as reimbursements to homeowners for uninsured losses of up to $11,500 for each household and Small Business Administration loans of up to $500,000.
Still, with the experience of Hurricane Hugo in 1989 as their guide, business authorities say there will be substantial losses that are not going to be covered either by private or government programs.
In announcing a $10 million state program to dispense emergency loans to small businesses, Gov. Lawton Chiles said Friday that Florida must "learn a lesson from Hugo" by making sure badly needed funds get to distressed businesses and families.
 
Some Deals Offered
 Most banks here are helping by deferring interest payments for two months on mortgages and commercial loans for borrowers whose properties were damaged. And some banks, like Barnett Banks and the First Union National Bank, have said they will lend money to hurricane victims at below market rates, shaving a percent or two off consumer loans and off commercial loans. These programs, of course, are acts of corporate benevolence to help hard-hit communities revive combined with commercial self-interest in trying to hold on to existing customers and gain market share.
But how much disaster-related lending can the banks do? For the banks there will be both a loss of income from stretched-out repayment terms and write-offs on loans that can no longer be repaid. Banks say it is too early to estimate their own losses.
And while bankers talk of being flexible and working with borrowers on a case-by-case basis, they also stress that they must keep their shareholders as well as hurricane-hit customers in mind when making loans. "You're not going to change the banks' risk standards to make these loans," said Carlos Migoya, president of First Union National Bank of Florida in Miami.
Charles Umberger, executive vice president of the Barnett Bank of South Florida, agreed. "Banks are senior lenders, not suppliers of high-risk venture capital," he said. "To finance the larger rebuilding effort, it has to be a partnership with a large role played by the government."
The means the government might use to encourage added lending to hurricane victims is uncertain. But the goal would be for the government to assume some of the risk on hurricane-related lending so that banks or investors would be more willing to supply financing. Mr. Morrell, the Barry University economist, suggests the bundling of Andrew-recovery loans as securities and marketing them through a government-backed agency.
Mr. Herndon's business, Kerry's Bromeliad Nursery Inc., employs 80 people and last year generated revenues of $5.5 million selling flowers to discounters and supermarket chains including Kmart, Home Depot, Winn-Dixie and Kroger.
Next year, he expected to double sales and increase his payroll to 120 people, since he had expanded his automated greenhouses. But the hurricane destroyed the greenhouses and the flowers that were to have resulted in a banner 1993.
 
Workers Being Paid
 Unlike many smaller companies, Mr. Herndon has kept on paying his workers for the last two weeks. He plans to pay them next week, too. "But after that we're going to have to talk," he said. Mr. Herndon has a $3 million commercial mortgage loan with Barnett. "That giant pile of crumpled metal back there is Barnett's collateral," he said, gesturing toward what used to be his business.
Perhaps, but the bank is pretty well covered in Mr. Herndon's case. His insurance policy has Barnett designated as a "loss payee," meaning the $6 million insurance check will be made out to Kerry's Bromeliad Nursery and Barnett Bank. For his part, the $6 million insurance coverage means Mr. Herndon could, he noted, "pay off the bank loan and walk away with a check for $3 million in my pocket."
But Mr. Herndon says he won't walk away. He still has his ambitious growth plans, including exporting worldwide. Yet his dreams at best will be delayed for lack of funds. Barnett has agreed to renegotiate the terms of his loan, a workout, in bankers' parlance, as they would with Brazil or Donald Trump. Mr. Herndon wants a moratorium on principal payments for one year and a reduction in the interest rate he pays from the prime rate plus a percentage point to the prime rate. He's still negotiating with Barnett.
Had Barnett decided to call the loan, taking its $3 million, Mr. Herndon figured he would be down to 20 employees. Now, he hopes to hold on to as many as possible. "But I'm going to have to spend my personal savings to meet the payroll," he noted.
 
Familiar With Banking
 He would like additional lending, up to $5 million in new loans to bring the business back more quickly, but he says that it is unrealistic to expect that from a private bank on its own. His chief financial officer, Nancy Harter, is a former lending officer at Citibank in Miami, as well as Mr. Herndon's wife. So he is familiar with banking and today's interest rate environment. He notes that at prime plus 1 percent, he is paying Barnett 7 percent on his loan at a time when 30-year Treasury bonds yield more than 7 percent.
'It's lousy, but there's not much reason to lend to me, except that they do want to hold on to their long-term customers," Mr. Herndon said. "To get this business back to strength quickly, what I would really like is a low-interest, government-backed loan of some type."
Some help could be on the way. Senior officials from the Department of Agriculture met with Mr. Herndon and other growers in Homestead on Monday and said that part of the President's aid request to Congress was to reinstate a recently ended program of government-subsidized disaster loans for farmers.
Mr. Herndon seems skeptical. "We're hopeful, but we'll wait and see," he said.

Kerry L. Herndon surveyed the wreckage of his nursery in Homestead, Fla., where he grew orchids and bromeliads. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Is Criticized By Gephardt

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Dealing a blow to Congressional prospects for the North American Free Trade Agreement, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, said today that the labor and environmental provisions were so badly flawed that the pact should be renegotiated.
Mr. Gephardt, one of the most influential House Democrats on trade issues, ran for President in 1988 on a platform that emphasized restrictions on imports from Japan. His last-moment support last year was crucial to the narrow approval of the measure giving President Bush the authority to negotiate the agreement among the United States, Mexico and Canada. Mexico and Canada do not want to renegotiate the pact. 
 Worried that support for the pact could hurt them among constituents anxious about job losses to Mexico, not even the Republicans at a Senate Finance Committee meeting on Tuesday and at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing today made any commitments to back it.
But neither house will vote on the issue until next year, making it easy to criticize now and to support later. "Almost everybody who is carping to you now will vote for it," predicted Representative Bill Thomas, a California Republican on the trade subcommittee.
Mr. Gephardt's call for renegotiation followed a chorus of complaints from Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, about White House attacks on Gov. Bill Clinton for not taking a position on the pact. Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rostenkowski said the election-year attacks had threatened the bipartisan consensus for free trade and the accord's prospects for eventual passage.
 
Protecting Their Candidate
 The complaints reflected Congressional sensitivity to Mr. Clinton's possible vulnerability on the issue. "They're lining up to provide some cover for their Presidential candidate," said Thomas E. Mann, the director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
But George C. Shipley, a Democratic consultant based in Austin, Tex., said he doubted that the issue would affect Mr. Clinton much at the polls because not enough voters were paying close attention to it.
Mr. Gephardt had said, before the agreement was finished, that shortcomings in it probably could be repaired by the legislation needed to put its provisions into American law. Today, he attributed his shift in position to his reading of the text of the agreement and conversations with voters.
President Bush announced the agreement on Aug. 12, and released its voluminous text in two installments on Friday and Tuesday. All drafts had been classified on the ground that public debate might limit the flexibility of the American negotiating team during the 14 months of talks. Though members of Congress were allowed to look at the drafts, many staff members lacked the necessary security clearances.
 
Areas That Raise Objections
 Speaking at a conference here sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and four other environmental, labor and consumer groups, Mr. Gephardt said the agreement failed to address specific pollution and workers' rights issues in Mexico and should have done so.
Asked afterward whether Mr. Clinton should renegotiate the pact if it is left until next year, Mr. Gephardt replied, "A lot of it can be done through the implementing legislation -- I think some of it has to be done through renegotiation."
Mr. Gephardt's criticisms drew a sharp response from the Administration. "The Nafta will generate more jobs, provide more environmental protection and make America more competitive than has any other trade agreement, include trade agreements for which Mr. Gephardt has voted in the past," said Kathleen A. Lydon, the White House's chief spokeswoman on trade issues.
Mr. Gephardt said the agreement should include worker protection rules for Mexico and a special commission to issue bonds for environmental cleanup along the border. He called, as he had in July, for a tax on trade to help pay for the cleanup and to pay for retraining workers who lose their jobs to Mexico.
This tax should be "far lower than the current levy" on imports from Mexico, which averages about 4 percent, he said in the speech. But later he said when talking to reporters, "It may be 2 percent; it may be 3 percent."
 
Opposition to Border Tax
 In her testimony today before the Ways and Means Committee, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, dismissed the idea of a border tax. "The whole purpose of the North American Free Trade Agreement is to lower barriers, not to raise taxes, and to do so would defeat the very purpose of the agreement," she said.
Mrs. Hills also identified for the first time those sectors of the economy that she thought would be most vulnerable to import competition from Mexico as a result of the free trade pact: glass and some farm products during certain seasons. The American household glass and fruit and vegetable industries are labor-intensive and are already having trouble in competing with imports from Mexico.

HEADLINE: Waterford Journal;
The Future of Irish Crystal Is Anything but Clear

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Ireland

 BODY:
In the year 853, Danish Vikings sailed up the river here and, after some battling with with the local Celts, established a port. Some 1,100 years later, after World War II, an Irish entrepreneur imported a band of German, Czech and Italian craftsmen to revive the local glassmaking business, which became Waterford Crystal and quickly spread its glistering elegance to millions of homes, mostly in America, and bringing prosperity.
The crystal boom, which began in the mid-1950's and started to shatter five years ago, also gave a sense of identity to the 38,000 people of this clean medieval city, eight miles up the River Suir from the Irish Sea. 
 Now many people here, especially the workers at the crystal plant, fear that in the current phase of the town's history, the good times are gone forever and that the company itself, part of the Waterford Wedgwood Corporation, may eventually disappear, with production shifted to Germany and elsewhere on the continent. Company officials, mostly Irishmen, wince at this vision.
"We don't have a secret agenda to move production out of Waterford," the company chairman, E. Patrick Galvin, said in an interview. "That is not our intention, not our strategy. We want to produce classic Waterford crystal in Waterford at a reasonable profit margin."
 
Layoffs and Pay Cuts
 To do this, Mr. Galvin has proposed that the work force at the plant, which was 3,200 five years ago and is now 1,900, be reduced by another 500 jobs by the end of the year and that those remaining accept cuts of up to 30 percent in wages and benefits.
Mr. Galvin said the company has lost more than $150 million in the last five years, including another $6 millon in the first half of this year, and he wants 500 workers to volunteer for severance. If they do not, he said, there will be forced layoffs. He said the comany might not survive a strike like the 14-week stoppage in 1990.
The workers and their union have not formally threatened a strike, but say privately that if Waterford refuses to improve the severance plan, there could be one. The workers are also upset that the company has already begun to produce crystal in Germany and Slovenia, and that in the coming years about 15 percent of the company's products will be made abroad.
The job losses at Waterford Crystal contribute to a local unemployment rate of about 25 percent, 5 points higher than the national average, which is one of the highest in Europe. And the probability of even higher unemployment reflects the national situation, where the Government of Prime Minister Albert Reynolds has been looking to the European Community and private industry for money to ease what is called the jobs crisis here.
"Waterford glass manufactured elsewhere would not be Waterford glass," Mr. Reynolds said on a visit here in July. "I want to see Waterford Crystal remain here in Waterford."
 
Who's to Blame
 His words echoed those of both workers and company officials. Leaders of the Amalgamated Transport & General Workers Union blame mismanagement for much of the company's troubles. Company officials blame excessive wage and early retirement settlements made five years ago by a previous management team, and the drop in recent years of the value of the dollar, as 70 percent of Waterford's sales are in the American market.
"It's crazy to think of putting 500 people out, creating jobs in Germany to produce things to sell in the States," said Walter Cullen, the head of the local union.
 "That is the logic of what the company is doing," he said. "They are prepared to risk the brand name, that the consumer will not care whether the glass is made in Waterford."
He said he agreed with the company statement that only a small percentage of the crystal was now produced abroad, and that the lines produced on the continent were new ones, not competitive with the higher-priced lines made in Waterford. But he argued that the company had never responded to a union offer to try to work out a plan to have the new lines produced here at a profit. The company acknowledges this.
Also at issue is whether the crystal produced elsewhere is as good as that made here, and whether the new lines, partcularly the lower-priced Marquis stemware, deserves the Waterford name. A Marquis goblet costs $29.50, about $20 less than a classic Waterford.
The difference is that every line cut in the design of a Lismore is done by hand, by a man at a diamond cutting wheel. The crystal produced abroad is shaped and cut by machines, then finished off by a worker.
John Stenson, a 40-year-old master cutter, held up a centerpiece bowl he was cutting. He pointed to a slight variation in a row of triangular points.
"When its made by hand, the points are not perfect," he said. "A machine will make perfect points. By hand, each piece is individual, with little differences."
He was more optimistic the plant won't close than some of the other cutters and blowers, who are being asked to take cuts that would bring their pay down to a maximum of $700 a week, from about $900. Less skilled workers earn closer to the national industrial average of $400 a week.
Tony Walsh, a cutter who is active in the union, blamed the company, not the high wages, for the problems. He said Waterford, suffering now because the dollar has been losing value, should have long ago exploited the European market.
"There are a lot of rich people in Europe," he said. "With proper marketing I don't see why the world's leading brand name can't be found on the boulevards of Paris, Bonn, Milan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: To the workers in Waterford, Ireland, the name their home has come to represent in glassmaking should harden it from the shifting economic currents in Europe. Ray Lanigan, above, works at his craft, in which each piece is given the imperfections and subtleties of a product made by hand. (James F. Clarity/The New York Times)
