HEADLINE: Currencies Teaching Europe That Unity Can Be Painful

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Europe's plans for further unification may be up in the air, but people from Helsinki to Rome have been learning an often painful lesson in recent weeks about how entwined their economies have already become.
The agent of their discomfort has been the effort by most European nations to link the value of their currencies by maintaining relatively stable exchange rates. In doing so amid a worldwide recession, nations have increasingly been torn between their short-term domestic economic needs and their long-range goal of creating a single European market with stable prices and steady growth. 
 In more cases than not, the domestic needs are losing out, bringing more insistent calls from recession-racked consumers and businesses for governments to rethink their policies.
As a result, exchange rates, once of concern only to international travelers and multinational companies, have emerged as a dominant factor in the economic policies of most European nations. And they are developing into a political issue that seems certain to endure no matter what the outcome of the French referendum later this month on whether to approve the next stage of European monetary and political unification.
The issue has become more visible because of the turmoil that has gripped the foreign currency markets in the last month. To a degree, the turmoil is a result of uncertainty about the French vote on Sept. 20 and what it would mean for closer economic cooperation in the region. But the upheaval has been driven primarily by the surge in the value of the German mark against the dollar and most European currencies.
The United States has paid little attention to the weakness of the dollar against the mark, choosing instead to maintain its policy of lower domestic interest rates in the hopes of spurring an economic recovery. But throughout much of Europe, nations are making exactly the opposite decision.
Despite being mired in a severe slump, Italy has raised interest rates sharply this month to defend the value of the lira. Britain has said repeatedly that it will do whatever is necessary to defend the pound, even if it means raising interest rates, a prospect that has horrified many homeowners and business executives who are calling for lower rates.
Sweden this week pushed a key interest rate up to 75 percent -- a level unheard of among industrialized nations -- to defend its currency, forcing up mortgage rates and the costs of business loans and bringing turmoil to its financial markets.
The hope of those nations is that the discipline of maintaining stable currency values through the European exchange rate mechanism will bring wage and price stability throughout the region and help create a vibrant trading market. Their strategy has been to keep the value of their currencies pegged to the mark. Backed by the Bundesbank, Germany's tight-fisted central bank, the mark has long been the world's standard for anti-inflationary credibility.
"These nations believe that a stable exchange rate system is the best way to reduce inflation and that low inflation is the best basis for growth," said David Roche, an economist with Morgan Stanley International in London. "The worst solution is to allow currencies to devalue and inflation to creep up."
Inflation rates have in fact come down throughout Europe. In Britain, for example, inflation stood at 9.5 percent when the nation joined the exchange rate mechanism just under two years ago. Today it stands at about 4 percent.
But lower inflation has not yet brought the advertised resumption of steady economic growth across Europe. And the theoretical long-term benefits of stable prices seem increasingly lost on homeowners who fear rising mortgage payments, on shop owners who see their business drying up and on the unemployed who want to see interest rates drop, even at the cost of a devalued currency, to stimulate the economy.
 
Pressure to Devalue the Pound
 "They must devalue the pound," said Belinda Handman, a real estate investor and entrepreneur in London. "If they raise interest rates, businesses will be on the floor."
On Britain's Isle of Wight, Derek Pullen, a 50-year-old home builder, has seen his business fall 20 percent in the last year, and he is paying 13.5 percent for business loans. He gives the Government high marks for bringing inflation down, but he sees little gain in further unification with Europe and no reason for the Government to defend the pound at all costs.
"If the Government raises interest rates, it will affect me something wicked," Mr. Pullen said.
Not all nations have chosen to stick to their exchange rates. Finland sent shock waves through the currency markets this week when it decided to let the markka float in value against other currencies, a move tantamount to substantial devaluation.
Officials in Helsinki said they could not afford to defend the currency in the markets, and the nation's economy, battered by a sharp drop in trade with the republics of the former Soviet Union, would have suffered additional damage if the Government had raised interest rates.
Finland is not a member of the European Community or its exchange rate agreement, but had been voluntarily linking its currency to other European currencies in preparation for joining. Analysts said Sweden, which has applied for membership in the community, was sending a signal with its decision to raise rates that it could be counted on by Europe as a partner in a stable monetary system.
"You've got a stark contrast at the moment between weak domestic economies demanding lower interest rates and weakness in the currency forcing upward pressure on interest rates," said Peter Fellner, an economist with NatWest Capital Markets in London.
Much of the tension stems from Germany's policy of keeping its interest rates high to ward off inflation as it absorbs the costs of unification with the former East Germany. Some economists are predicting that Germany will lower rates within the next six months to give a boost to its weak economy. But outside Germany there is a growing backlash against the notion that domestic economic decisions are captive to the Bundesbank.
"France is now paying the economic price of German reunification," said Jean Francois Braunstein, a philosophy professor at the University of Amiens in France.
But Mr. Fellner said that unless members of the European exchange rate mechanism decided that they wanted to devalue their currencies against the mark, they had little choice but to wait until the Germans decided that they could safely lower rates, a step that would decrease the value of the mark.
"The argument that this is a German problem and shouldn't be inflicted on the rest of the E.R.M. countries is a valid one," Mr. Fellner said. "The problem is, how do you get out of it without undermining the credibility of the other nations that are making an effort to stick to their exchange rate commitment."
Although political support for remaining within the exchange rate mechanism remains strong in most countries, a growing number of politicans are breaking ranks with their leadership and calling for devaluation to spur growth and reassert control over domestic economic policy-making.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Up in Mexico

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Mexico's foreign trade deficit soared but inflation dropped sharply in the first six months of the year, according to Government figures made public today.
Exports rose slightly, but imports shot up, raising the deficit to $9 billion for the six months, compared with $11.1 billion for all of last year. 
 A big chunk of imports consisted of technology, machinery and other capital goods as industrialists renew obsolete plants and factories to prepare for greater competition under a free trade agreement that Mexico recently signed with Canada and the United States.
The agreement, which awaits ratification votes by the legislatures of the three countries, aims to create a free trade zone with 3.6 million consumers and $6.4 trillion in total annual trade.

HEADLINE: The Green Card at the End of the Irish Rainbow;
Latest Wave of Immigrants Finds That, Even With Legal Status, Jobs Are Still Tight

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
Last fall, Carol Philbin gave up. Without working papers and out of a job for more than a month, she returned home to Galway for good after three years of struggle in the shadow world of New York City's undocumented Irish.
A letter in her parent's mailbox sent her back again. The letter informed Ms. Philbin that she had won a visa lottery that would allow her to work and live legally in the United States. But since her return, Ms. Philbin -- whose sister Moira and brother Sean have also immigrated to the United States -- has found that while the shadow had lifted, the struggle was not over. 
 "I was very naive in thinking, 'I've got my green card, I'll walk into any job,' " Ms. Philbin, 21 years old, said. "My first six weeks, I couldn't even get a waitressing job. The green card doesn't make any difference. It's not harder but it's not easier. The difference is that here I have the opportunities to do what I want."
 
Talk of Few Jobs
 Among thousands of Irish immigrants in New York, also winners like Ms. Philbin in the unusual lottery, there is a sense that their dream came true -- but at a tough time.
In the city's Irish pubs, the talk at the wooden horseshoe bars is no longer of coveted green cards but of the lack of jobs, particularly in construction where most of the young men work. For many who had received higher education in Ireland, legalization seemed to be synonymous with career advancement, a chance to break out of occupations like construction, waiting on tables and caring for children, but many say they are now being rebuffed by employers because they have insufficient experience in their white-collar professions.
A result is a break in a trend of many decades. Many new Irish immigrants are avoiding New York completely and heading toward Florida, where construction jobs are more readily available.
And in a strange twist, at the moment they become eligible to stay here legally, many young Irish are returning to Ireland. Some simply want to raise their children there. Others leave to wait out the recession at home even though the joblessness rate is more than double the rate in the United States. In Ireland they can live with their families and collect unemployment benefits.
The illegal Irish community in New York City, estimated two years ago at 30,000, a third of the Irish living illegally in the United States, is going through other changes as well, as it is reshaped by a maturing population as well as the recession.
 
Irish Pubs in Trouble
 The most striking differences are in the changing neighborhood profiles. In traditional first-stop immigrant neighborhoods of Sunnyside and Woodside in Queens and Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx, some of the Irish pubs that mushroomed and were revitalized during the illegal immigration boom of the mid-1980's are going out of business. In part, it is because few people have money to spend, but also because the carefree, hard-working, hard-playing partygoers have married, had children and moved to quieter, safer neighborhoods like Maspeth in Queens, Riverdale in the Bronx and Yonkers.
"Five years ago the bars were busy every night," said Debbie McGoldrick, the immigration columnist for The Irish Voice, one of the main Irish papers in the city. "Advertisement in The Irish Voice for pubs and restaurants has gone down from eight pages last year to four this year. An awful lot of people went back at Christmas. They are monitoring the situation from there. It's only a plane ride away."
Adrian Flannelly, president of WNWK, an Irish radio station that has live broadcasts in Ireland as well, said: "Some people have gone back, others have changed their life styles. They've fanned out of the neighborhoods. The pubs are in a recession. There are some areas that give the impression that people are on a vacation. And they are -- an extended vacation."
These types of changes are characteristic of the Irish in particular, a group that since their first wave of immigration 200 years ago has flowed back and forth from the home country and throughout the United States. "There's something in the Irish attitude that says, 'I belong in America,' " said Francis P. Vardy, senior demographer in the Department of City Planning who closely follows the Irish migration patterns. "They don't consider themselves foreigners. They consider the U.S. to be the 33d county of Ireland."
 
Construction Workers Suffer
 The most mobile within the community and the hardest hit by the recession are the construction workers. They follow their trade, many having left New York temporarily to work in France building EuroDisney, in England to build the tunnel under the English Channel and on construction sites as far away as Japan and South Africa. Many are planning to head to Florida, to help rebuild after the hurricane. Those who have remained often spend weeks between jobs.
The close-knit community is expected to change even more in the next few years as the lottery in permanent residency cards plays out. The lottery is a result of a 1990 law that gives preference to immigrants from 34 European countries to counter their underrepresentation during the last 26 years. In the next two years, it guarantees the Irish a total of 48,000 resident alien permits. It is the largest legal migration of Irish since 1965. The lottery's goal is to legalize Irish already in the United States. An estimated 75 percent of this year's winners already live in the United States, said James McIntire, Irish vice consul and immigration liaison officer. Although it is impossible to count New York's illegals, more than 60 percent of them have been absorbed in this drawing, experts estimate.
Next year's lottery rules have been changed, giving Irish in Ireland an equal chance at winning. Instead of accepting applications on a first-come, first-served basis as they did last year, creating mob scenes at a Virginia post office, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is accepting only one application per person chosen randomly by computer during a one-month drawing period that ended Aug. 28.
 
Bridging the Culture Gap
 At the Emerald Isle Immigration Center in Woodside, Martina Newe-Smith works in the newly created employment division. Part of her role is to bridge the gap between cultures, she says. For that purpose, Mrs. Newe-Smith has put together a pamphlet that teaches everything from resume writing to interview etiquette. She is flooded by requests for jobs, particularly by newly legalized Irish who want to find jobs that require their educational background. But many find themselves still in their old jobs.
"I know people who have come back with green cards, have college educations but find it financially more secure to do nannying or waitressing," Carol Philbin said.
Still, having a green card is not taken lightly.
"It's a feeling you can't describe," an older sister, Moira Philbin, said. "Until you actually go through immigration, you feel this is not happening. You look across at the other line and you think, never again will I wonder whether I can get in. And I felt nothing can stop me now."
Among those who remain, there is a tremendous drive to endure. Freda Grealy, 23, studied law in England and just took her bar exam. She works 62 hours a week, as a receptionist and a waitress, unable to find more professional work, but is far from discouraged. "My attitude is that this too shall pass," she said. "Just because you are legal, it doesn't open the golden gate."
 
One of the Lucky Ones
 The Philbin sisters and their brother represent the struggles and dreams of the new Irish-Americans. Moira Philbin, 27 years old, studied computer science in Galway, but in New York she worked as a dog walker, a house cleaner and a receptionist. She considers herself lucky. Many of her friends, out of jobs, have returned to Ireland.
Now she has found a job she likes at a Woodside travel agency, has moved to a new apartment and plans to go to school in January. For the first time, she will not have to work under an assumed name and will receive health insurance and other benefits.
Carol Philbin left Ireland just out of high school and despite her new legal status, has only been able to find baby-sitting jobs. She worked as a housekeeper for two and a half years and now plans to learn the art of makeup for disfigured people and hopes to go to college.
"I used to pray and cry a lot," Carol Philbin said. "I'm very optimistic. I have never consciously thought, 'What will I do if I can't get a job?' "
Their brother, Sean, whose wife is expecting their second child, is toying with the idea of returning to Ireland in the future to raise his children, Moira Philbin said.
"It's a different kettle of fish if you're out there on your own or if you have kids," Ms. Philbin said. "The difference in being legal is that now you know you can go for whatever you want. It's like a weight off your shoulders."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For Moira Philbin, above, who immigrated to the United States from Ireland, life has been a series of jobs that were hard but attainable with a green card. For her sister, Carol, it has been harder. By the time she was picked in the lottery and received legal immigrant status, the jobs had disappeared. (Lee Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
President Bush outlined "a single program, a unified strategy" for reviving the economy. In a speech to business leaders in Detroit, he presented his philosophy as a broad mix of tax and spending cuts, expanded social programs and new free-trade pacts to lead the nation into the global economy. [Page A1.]
Up to 150,000 American jobs could be lost from the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, according to Labor Secretary Lynn Martin. [D1.] 
 The United States was criticized by the International Monetary Fund for doing too little to cut its budget deficit. Tax increases, particularly on energy, were recommended. [D2.]
Clark M. Clifford's Federal bank fraud trial was postponed, allowing a New York trial to proceed first. But Mr. Clifford's poor health may prevent him from ever going to trial. [D1.]
The Senate killed legislation to reduce damages that manufacturers must pay to injured consumers in product liability suits. The Administration pushed the bill; Democrats opposed it. [D4.]
American businesses cut back on investment spending plans, a Government survey showed, and new claims for unemployment benefits rose slightly in late August. [D4.]
Silverado Savings's former chairman and chief executive, who had recruited Neil Bush, the President's son, as a Silverado director in 1985, was indicted on bank fraud charges. [D4.]
A California utility is hoping to replace power once generated by a nuclear reactor with energy from unconventional sources. [D1.]
Eleven large corporations and dozens of small companies will provide $25.4 million to support employee child care. [A26.]
 
International
Europeans are learning painful lessons about economic unity as the effort to link the continent's currencies has caused economic hardships in individual countries. [D1.]
Italy's prime minister asked for special economic powers as the lira's value came under increasing pressure. He also announced the sale of shares in state-owned enterprises. [D2.]
 
Companies
Exxon and Mobil will jointly bid on oil and gas exploration and production projects in Russia's West Siberian basin. [D3.]
Zenith Data Systems, a division of France's Groupe Bull, won a $740 million Air Force contract for desktop computers. [D3.]
Sony introduced its recordable disk music system, which it hopes will become the heir to its successful Walkman. [D3.]
Apple Computer's former chief operating officer will join Tektronix as president and chief operating officer. [D3.]
 
Markets
Stocks extended their rally with their sharpest gain in six weeks. The Dow average climbed 33.77 points, to 3,305.16. [D6.]
Bond prices were little changed in moderate trading. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 7.24 percent. [D12.]
The dollar rose after Britain's prime minister said he would not devalue the pound. Gold prices were mixed. [D13.]
Copper futures plunged amid weak demand in the Far East and sluggish business activity in the West. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
Signs of a retreat by small investors hurt many brokerage stocks, but some analysts say the pullback of individual buyers has bottomed out. Market Place. [D6.]
A new Bergdorf Goodman advertising campaign uses humor to try to give the retailer's fashionable men's store a less intimidating image. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: NEW YORK'S SENATE RACE;
4 Senate Challengers: Excerpts From the Democrats' Debate

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from last night's Democratic Senate debate, as transcribed by The New York Times:
 
Taxes and the Middle Class
 Q Considering the state of the economy, are there any circumstances under which you would agree to a tax increase on middle-class working Americans? 
 FERRARO What's happened over the last 10 years has been that the middle class are paying a higher percentage of their income in taxes than they did in 1981, and the wealthier are paying a smaller percentage. What I favor is a surtax on those people making over $200,000 a year and a tax break for the middle class. It's not going to do very much for the budget one way or the other, but what it will do is it will lead to tax fairness. . . .
HOLTZMAN I think you have to be very concerned about tax increases at this time, even though theoretically they might be necessary for purposes of fairness or tax equity, because our economy is in a very precarious situation and tax increases could spin it in the wrong way. I bring some very special credentials to this race for the United States Senate. I was on the House Budget Committee for five years; as Comptroller of New York City I've been dealing with the Federal and the local economy. I think there's lots we can do to solve the problem of our economy and our deficit, and that doesn't include tax increases.
ABRAMS I don't favor tax increases on people of New York, or this country, at this time. And I think we're at a unique moment in time when we should be slashing the defense budget by 50 percent by the end of the decade. That's what separates me from my major opponent in this primary, Geraldine Ferraro. She's almost like George Bush; she only wants to take advantage of $100 billion cuts over the next five years. I want $282 billion cuts so that we don't have to raise taxes on middle-income people.
SHARPTON To directly answer your question, there's no circumstance that I would vote for a tax increase on the middle class or poor people. I think that was your question. I think that what I would be advocating is, again, for the rich to begin paying their fair share of taxes. It is incredible to me that we can talk about going into the military budget and other things, which I'm clearly in favor of, but no one wants to deal with the fact that the rich have gotten away like bandits. They have been on welfare for the last 12 years.
 
The Death Penalty
 Q Now, over to the death penalty discussion.
FERRARO I took the position on the death penalty when I was Assistant D.A. and feel very strongly that there are times when it is appropriate punishment. I would be very, very careful and there is -- you know, when you're -- when you're practicing law you are able to determine whether or not a person is actually not beyond a reasonable doubt but beyond any doubt guilty of a crime. I would have a bifurcated sentencing hearing.
But in addition to that, let me tell you that it would only be where a person has taken someone else's life and the only way I could demonstrate what I'm talking about is a situation, for instance, with the Richard Dahmer [apparently referring to Jeffrey Dahmer]. Here's a man who committed the worst kind of crime, a bias crime. All his victims were minority. All of them were picked because they were gay. Here he killed 15 people. He goes to plead guilty to his 16th: what does he get? A 16th life term or one for nothing?
ABRAMS Well, it's interesting because I think Gerry wants to get it both ways. She wants to get the popularity of the death penalty from most of the population who legitimately feels insecure about rising crime. But yet seeks to minimize its application and uses it as a major theme of a commercial. And I'm troubled by all of that.
Let me also now correct Reverend Sharpton. . . . I had the record number of hires of African-Americans in my office, two consecutive solicitor generals, heads of bureaus, heads of regional offices, section chiefs, line assistants, all across this state. It's an unparalleled record of appointment of minority people including those from the American-American community.
SHARPTON Certainly I think the death penalty is wrong under any circumstance. I think, as everyone has said, it has been used racially. I think that I would oppose it under any circumstance because it is not used in a fair manner. A, it has not been proven as a deterrent to crime. B, and what do you do when you have the situations that have occurred many a times when you found out later you were wrong? We cannot give a person his life back or her life back.
So I think that we could never support the death penalty and I would take issue in our studies and other studies of both the Attorney General's office and the Brooklyn D.A.'s office of the positions that they've appointed. They have hired a lot of blacks . . . the levels is what I'm questioning.
HOLTZMAN First I'd like to correct the record. Mr. Sharpton has misstated that. First of all I'm very proud of the fact that when I was District Attorney of Brooklyn, we appointed African-Americans to the highest positions in the offices, executive assistant as well as bureau chiefs. We had Latinos in the same position.
In addition to that let me respond on the death penalty. . . . The system makes mistakes. I was a chief law-enforcement officer in one of the biggest jurisdictions in this country. There are other ways to fight crime. We can do something about banning handguns. We can do something to stop the importation of drugs into this country. We can do something about drug treatment programs. We can have better sentencing programs and we -- and if I'm elected to the U.S. Senate, we'll do something about the judges we have sitting on the U.S. Supreme Court.
FERRARO Yeah, because one of the things that Bob has indicated is, well two things, that I have taken a position on the death penalty for the purpose of this election, which I did not. I took it when I was in the D.A.'s office. He said it is a major theme of my commercial. I'm sorry that you missed the point of the commercial. The point of the commercial was to point out, is that I am strongly in favor of gun control and that I have law-enforcement endorsements based upon my integrity and honesty from one end of the state to the other.
But the third thing is in a primary in New York State, in a very liberal primary in which it is, this Democratic primary, this is the unpopular political position. It's just that I'm strong enough to take an unpopular position when I believe it's right.
 
Universal Health Care
 Q Now we're going to talk about health care. Health care is a concern for most of us. All of you support some type of universal health care that would cover all America. Would you support a plan that rations medical care to get a universal health care plan out there?
FERRARO Well I don't support the single payer plan, which is Oregon's plan, precisely because it would ration care and because people would not be allowed to pick their own doctors. It would create a whole new bureaucracy. It would require a tax increase by people. I support what's called a pay or play system, which is the proposal that is supported by Bill Clinton and Al Gore. It is a plan that will move immediately within the first 100 days. We're going to get national health care coverage in this country. We'll cover the 2.2 million people in this state who are uninsured.
SHARPTON I would support the Russo Bill. I think that we are in a disgraceful position of being the only industrialized nation in the world, other than South Africa, that does not have a national health plan for its citizens. The thing I would add, though, to the Russo Bill is putting a ceiling on medical costs. It is absolutely outrageous how medical costs are going up higher and higher. There needs to be a ceiling put on that, as these medical companies are making billions of dollars and as older people are not being able to afford that, and we need to have a universal health payer plan or for every individual in this country. We make enough money as a nation to guarantee that when nations much poorer can do that for its citizens.
HOLTZMAN Well the present system doesn't work. Something is terribly wrong when an individual goes into a doctor's office and the first question is how are you going to pay the bill. Not what's wrong with you. That has to change. If they can have universal health care in France, Germany, Scandinavia, Japan, Australia and Canada we can do it here. I believe we need to have universal health care, I believe in the single payer system. We can do it. That's one of the areas I differ with Geraldine Ferraro. . . .
ABRAMS Geraldine Ferraro's answer to this question shows a fundamental difference between herself and myself. I believe that the present health care system is very sick and I'm not willing to put a little Band-Aid on it. It needs major surgery. We've got to go to a single payer health insurance plan that's administered at the Federal level. That guarantees every New Yorker and every American freedom of choice. You go to the doctor, or dentist, or nursing home of your choice. You get it as a matter of right. And as you move in this direction you actually save money, and that's not Bob Abrams saying that, that's the Government Accounting Office, the independent arm of the Congress. You save $70 billion by moving in that direction. . . .
 
Personal Ethics and Character
 Q Ms. Ferraro, questions of character and ethics have become major issues in this campaign with allegations of impropriety being leveled at every single one of you. Do the character questions undermine you as a candidate against Republican Alfonse D'Amato?
FERRARO I don't think so. And this week, this month, has been horrendous, where both of my opponents who are sitting here today, Liz and Bobby, have been attempting to tear me down significantly. Let me say to you that when we deal with issues of ethics in 1984 during the course of that campaign ethical questions were raised about my filings for the, with the Federal Government. They found 10 technical violations, found I did not do anything deliberately and we amended the returns and that was that.
But if you take a look at really what's going on in this state and what Al D'Amato's problems are. Al D'Amato's problems are that he is taking contributions from people with whom he has done business as a Senator. Both Bob Abrams and Liz Holtzman have been criticized for doing the same thing: taking money. In fact, they currently are being criticized for taking money now in this Senate race: Bob, from people who are doing business with the Attorney General's office, and Liz, from people who are doing business with the Comptroller's office. . . . Take a look at my contributors. We have 63,000 contributors. The average contribution is $35. The people of this state own me.
HOLTZMAN Well, I think that there are very serious allegations that have been raised about Geraldine Ferraro and they were raised initially in The Village Voice and in Newsday. And the allegations were that Gerry, during the 1984 Vice-Presidential race, you promised the people of the United States that a child pornographer tenant in the building you co-manage would be evicted once the lease was up. But when the lease was up, they weren't evicted. You raised the rent. And you allowed them to stay for almost three years. Child pornographers: what is that? These are people who make money out of the pain and suffering of children. Gerry, why didn't you get them out right away? . . . How could you have taken the money? You should answer these questions. You've said, What could I do about it. Let me tell you ----
Q Let's move along.
HOLTZMAN When I was District Attorney and I . . .
Q Let's move along, let's move along. You'll have time. You'll have time. We go now to Bob Abrams . . .
ABRAMS Gerry says that I've sought to tear her down. I mean, Gerry, I haven't torn you down in terms of things that we're talking about. In 1984, you violated the Federal Election Law and you were fined as a result of that. You took illegal contributions. That wasn't me, that was the Federal Elections Campaign Commission appointed by the President of the United States, a bipartisan body. Four years later in 1984, you were found guilty of 10 ethics violations -- not by me, I didn't raise that issue for the first time -- by your own colleagues, your own colleagues on the House Ethics Committee.
And in terms of what you're now saying about me, I run my office in a highly professional and ethical manner. There's a Chinese wall between anything that is done by a campaign committee in any campaign in which I am engaged in, and a Chinese strong wall separating between the government office and the campaign office. So there is total integrity of the operations of the campaign.
SHARPTON I'm amazed at how cozy everyone indicts each other here. But anyway, I think clearly ethics is a serious issue. However, I think it needs to be in perspective -- ethics among the issues that will solve our problems. I am, again, the poorest candidate here, but if I had millions, I wouldn't have spent millions of dollars just attacking the character of my opponents. I would have spent those millions talking about health care, I would have spent those millions talking about the fact that we don't have jobs.
On top of that, I think there are serious ethical questions that have to be answered. Yes, again, as being a minority here, most of mine goes to court where theirs goes to newspapers. But I think Ms. Ferraro should answer about the lease. I also think Ms. Holtzman should answer about the comptroller policy to stop dealing with the First Bank of Boston because of South African ties. And Newsday said after a year that was going on and those executives from First Boston are donating to her campaign. I think a lot of ethical questions should be answered.
FERRARO Let me start first with -- let me start with Bob first.
Q This is a minute now, remember.
FERRARO Well, you know, I got three different charges here so give me a minute per charge and you're O.K.
Q No, no.
FERRARO He said I violated the law and I took illegal contributions in 1984. That is not so. I think what you got to do, Bob, is learn the facts. My campaign committee in 1978 took $138,000 from my children and my husband, which was the law before 1978. I reported it to the F.E.C.; they fined my committee $500. That was that.
The ethics violations in 1984: I talked about those, we amended the returns. Those were -- those were not a big deal, we amended them. But let me go further. When you talk about what you've done, the Feerick Commission has said to you that you should not take campaign contributions from people who are doing business with your agency. You are currently in contempt of that decision by the Feerick Commission, which criticized you for doing it, taking money from lawyers who are doing things, who have condo conversions and co-op conversions. And I've heard your campaign manager, or one of your handlers, say that the reason you're doing it is because this is a Senate race and not the Attorney General. At the very best, you will still be Attorney General until December and there's still business before that . . .
ABRAMS Well, Gerry Ferraro says it's not a big deal about the 10 ethics violations. The House Ethics Committee issued an 800-page report, the official document of the House of Representatives that constituted the report on those violations. Maybe it's not a big deal to you, but I think that's ----
FERRARO Do you know what kind of violations they were?
Q Ms. Ferraro, wait a minute.
FERRARO Do you know what kind of violations they were?
ABRAMS I know what they were.
FERRARO Well, tell us what they were, Bob. Tell that to the public because I think we're entitled to know precisely what they were.
ABRAMS You did not fully disclose all the -- --
FERRARO But what, tell us what?
ABRAMS All the information that was required under the rules of the House concerning financial matters that you had?
FERRARO Could you be specific for the people of this state?

HEADLINE: A Utility's Strategy for Life in a Nonnuclear Age

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
When the voters here decided in 1989 to close the nuclear plant operated by their public utility, many wondered what would replace it. Rancho Seco ran only fitfully, but its generating capacity was half of the total for the Sacramento Municipal Utility District and could meet the needs of all 457,000 customers in Sacramento County if the weather was not too hot.
Three years later the substitutes are beginning to emerge, some literally from the woodwork. Dark wooden roofs are being painted white to reflect the sun and thus lower buildings' air-conditioning burdens. A utility storage yard is filling up with thousands of scrapped refrigerators, as the district pays its customers up to $275 to buy new ones that use 75 percent less power. While the district will use conventional power sources for the near future, in the next few years scores of windmills will sprout on hilltops. 
 The district is also helping finance research in a dozen more exotic technologies it hopes will be practical later this decade. They include two kinds of solar power and three ways to tap the heat of the earth's core, fuel gas from garbage composting and power from fuel cells like the ones used by the Apollo astronauts.
 
An Industry Leader
 After years of putting all the eggs in one nuclear basket, the utility is now building a basket for each egg, confident that enough will hatch.
"What we're doing here ought to give people the courage of their convictions," said S. David Freeman, the district's general manager, referring to the assertions of many nuclear opponents around the country that the technology, apart from its safety worries, is not cost-effective. "There is life after nuclear power," he said.
In finding a post-nuclear future, SMUD, as the district is known, is not alone, only first. Rancho Seco was the first reactor retired by referendum, but so far this year, the owners of four other plants have either retired them prematurely or said that they would soon do so.
"What SMUD is doing, every utility in the United States with nuclear exposure will have to do," said Ralph Cavanagh, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council in San Francisco, who frequently testifies before utility regulators.
While it is too early to determine how these alternative sources will affect rates over the longer term, the management is confident, and so far, it has been right; closing the reactor, investing in conservation and buying power made from conventional sources has allowed the district to stabilize rates.
Because of ever-stricter environmental requirements, nuclear's traditional competitor, coal, which is burned to generate about 55 percent of the nation's electricity, is not an automatic choice. In California, in fact, it is virtually an impossibility. Natural gas will fill part of the short-term need, but utilities are worried that the supply glut that has kept natural gas prices low will not continue forever, and environmentalists are pushing for something still cleaner.
So in the short run, the district will build co-generation plants, which burn natural gas to make steam for electricity and then re-use the steam for industrial purposes. Until these are built, it will buy power from neighboring utilities that is available more cheaply than it was from the reactor. The longer-term plan is a mix of conservation and renewables.
The utility will invest in energy efficiency wherever the cost of saving a kilowatt-hour is 4 cents or less. (A kilowatt-hour, which would keep 10 light bulbs of 100 watts each lighted for an hour, costs residential consumers here about 8 cents.)
The district is now spending more than 6 percent of its revenues on conservation, the highest proportion of any utility in the United States. The money goes for everything from the rebates on refrigerators to the salaries of home inspectors, who, with customers' approval, install energy-saving devices in homes. The district's pursuit of renewables, including sun and wind, also appears to be among the largest, on a proportional basis -- and perhaps the most varied.
 
'Nobody's Mad at Us'
 The wisdom of the utility's path will not be completely clear for years to come. But so far, so good. California's current power surplus means that the wholesale price of power on the open market is low, and the district's rates, which jumped from 2 cents a kilowatt-hour, to 8 cents, to pay for nuclear repairs, have stabilized. Customers are more satisfied, and the threat of takeover by an investor-owned utility, which once seemed serious, has receded.
It has also gained points with its customers. "The proof of it is that nobody comes to our board meetings any more; nobody's mad at us," Mr. Freeman said.
The company's surveys show overwhelming approval of the utility since the Rancho Seco plant was shut, as did a reporter's sampling of customers' opinions at the district's headquarters recently.
"I personally just didn't like nuclear plants; I'm glad they shut the plant," said Lisa Byrd, who noted that rates had stabilized but said she was willing to pay more. Maddie Walker was less sure about closing Rancho Seco. "We have to get the energy from somewhere," she said. The district has made some other bets that seem sure, if slow, to pay off. It has planted 30,000 shade trees in the last two years on the south side of buildings in the county. In another eight years or so, the trees should begin to lower the demand for air-conditioning.
The co-generation plants are also likely to be successful. As long as the price of natural gas stays low, the price of the power these plants produce will be less than power from the nuclear plant. Rancho Seco was only able to operate about 50 percent of the time because of breakdowns.
Without the distraction of the nuclear plant, executives say, there is time to try other technologies. Adjacent to Rancho Seco is a two-megawatt installation of photovoltaic cells, which make electricity directly from sunlight.
The shape of the district's long-term supply is not so clear. "We have quite a bit of confidence that many of these technologies will operate," said Larry A. Wittrup, the utility's manager of generation planning. "Whether they will come in on an economic basis is another question."
Still, he and others here say the new technologies will never reach commercialization unless someone nurtures them through the early stages. And without a strong national commitment to technologies other than nuclear power, they say, it is up to companies like the Sacramento Municipal Utility District to contribute to joint research and to experiment on its system.
The district has not yet sorted out what works from what does not, Mr. Freeman acknowledged, but "we're feeling pretty good about the future."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Urges U.S. to Lift Taxes and Slash Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund's executive board criticized the United States today for doing too little to cut its budget deficit and said that tax increases would be needed.
Coming one day after President Bush vowed never again to agree to raise taxes, the fund's annual report "stressed the importance of fully exploiting the window of opportunity immediately after the elections" to make progress in cutting the deficit. 
 Members of the board bluntly asserted that the United States deficit was slowing long-term growth. While saying that deficit reduction should focus on spending cuts, they urged higher taxes on gasoline and on energy use in general, which they said would raise revenues while promoting conservation and lower pollution.
The report said that the world's economic output declined by three-tenths of 1 percent last year, pulled down by declining consumer confidence, especially in the United States. The economic performance last year, one of the worst years for the global economy since World War II, was hurt by recessions in the United States, Canada and Britain as well as the plunge in output in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics.
 
Improving Confidence
 The fund's directors, a number of whom serve in their nations' finance ministries, said putting together a credible package to cut the deficit could go far to improve confidence among businesses and consumers. Although cutting spending or raising taxes could be a drag on the economy, the directors said the increase in confidence resulting from a deficit plan likely would lead to an increase in demand that would considerably offset any negative short-term impact.
A Treasury spokesman said, "The United States realizes the importance of reducing the budget deficit, but an increase in taxes would be counterproductive and damaging both to growth and deficit reduction efforts."
In recent years, the monetary fund, a group of 169 nations that oversees the international economic system and provides loans to struggling nations, has often called on the United States and other industrial countries to reduce their deficits. While the fund has the power of moral suasion, the wealthy nations often ignore its advice. In contrast, poor countries that agree to monetary fund reform programs often have their I.M.F. loans cut off if they fail to follow the fund's recommendations.
Deficit reduction in the United States, the fund said, was important for making more money available for private investment and hence productivity growth.
Saying that budget deficits were weighing on world growth, the I.M.F. added that Italy, Canada and other countries as well as the United States should cut their deficits to help meet the growing demand for investment money from the former Soviet bloc and many developing countries.
The monetary fund pointedly criticized Germany, urging it to reduce subsidies to farmers and coal mines to cut its budget deficit. Germany's central bank has jacked up short-term rates to 9.75 percent to offset the inflationary pressures caused by hefty wage settlements and a large budget deficit, which is a result of the cost of unification.
Fund officials took pains not to criticize Germany's central bank, indicating that they sympathized with what it was doing, given the inflationary pressures Germany faces.
According to the report, the industrialized world grew by eight-tenths of 1 percent last year, although output in the United States fell by seven tenths of 1 percent. Far worse was the 16.9 percent drop in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, which have taken painful actions to establish market economies.
The monetary fund's staff forecast "a more sustained recovery in 1992 and in 1993" for the industrialized world in light of lower interest rates in North America and Japan, less household and business debt, and stronger economic performance in many developing countries.
With many Russians saying their central bank's strict monetary policy was pushing the nation to the breaking point, the monetary fund's board urged Russia's "authorities to withstand pressures to relax monetary policies." The fund also urged Moscow to adopt a strong policy to prevent "excessive wage growth, particularly in the state enterprise sector."
When the industrial world catches cold, the developing world usually catches pneumonia, but this was not the case last year, when the developing world grew by 3.3 percent. The third world was buoyed by strong growth in China, South Korea, Thailand and other developing countries in Asia as well as a turnaround in Latin America, where many governments have initiated economic reforms that have lifted growth.

HEADLINE: U.S. Businesses Cut Back On Capital Spending Plans

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
American businesses cut back on already modest plans for investment spending this year, the Government said today in a report reflecting renewed pessimism about the economy.
Businesses surveyed during July and August told the Commerce Department that they would spend $551 billion on new plants and equipment this year, a 4.3 percent increase from 1991, but a 4.7 percent decrease from what was projected in April and May and a 5.4 percent decrease from what was planned last year. 
 Meanwhile, a report from the Labor Department showed that new claims for unemployment benefits rose slightly in late August for the second consecutive week. The increase of 8,000 claims, to 394,000, during the week ended Aug. 29 reflected a stagnant job market, analysts said.
The Labor Department also cautioned that recent claims numbers were probably held down artificially by legislation allowing some claimants to file under a special emergency unemployment program. Those claims are not counted in the usual weekly release.
"Manufacturers and businesses generally are still scared," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. "They don't see a big increase in demand coming. So, as a result, they are not anxious to hire and they are not anxious to do anything permanent, and big investment is very permanent."
The increase in investment spending this year, if realized, would follow an eight-tenths of 1 percent decline in 1991, only the fourth drop in 33 years. Spending rose a moderate 5 percent in 1990 after shooting up 11.4 percent in 1989 and 10.6 percent in 1988.
But the economist Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York said he had expected an even greater reduction, given the economy's sluggishness.
 
One Optimistic Analyst
 "I take heart from the fact that businesses in 1992 are still planning a 4.3 percent increase," Mr. Roach said. "Capital spending should play a key role in driving this economy during the next several years, and this survey is reasonably supportive of the belief that that's what's going to happen."
But, at least for now, most manufacturing companies have little incentive to increase their capacity. Despite modest increases in new orders this year, they have reduced backlogs of unfilled orders for 11 consecutive months. Factories operated at 77.6 percent of capacity in July, well below the 1989 peak of 85.1 percent.
Most of the planned investment increase this year is in aircraft manufacturing, where a 17.7 percent increase is expected, as well as nondurable goods manufacturing, like textiles, chemicals and rubber. Durable goods factories, which make items like autos and appliances that are expected to last more than three years, plan a 2.5 percent drop in investment spending.
When adjusted for inflation, overall capital spending was projected to increase 5.8 percent in 1992 after a 1.6 percent drop in 1991.
The four-week moving average of jobless claims, which smooths out the fluctuations of the weekly reports, fell to 409,250 in the latest period, down from 411,500 in the preceding period. It was the lowest since June 6, when it was 406,250.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yield on 30-Year Bond Remains 7.24%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of bond and notes bounced around yesterday but did not change that much on the day. Trading was moderate, and many investors were waiting to see what President Bush would say in an important economic speech in Detroit and in a five-minute paid television broadcast last night.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 1003/32 , up 5/32 to yield 7.24 percent, the same as Wednesday's yield. 
 The price of the current five-year note, however, fell 2/32 to yield 5.25 percent, compared with 5.24 percent Wednesday. The discount rates on Treasury bills also fell slightly.
Although the market has been uncertain for the last two days, it is still trading on a base of solid support, as the economy continues to move ahead only sluggishly and inflation remains low. These positive fundamentals have already pushed yields down to levels not seen in years, and only very little of that gain has been lost in the last two days.
 
Political Repercussions
 But sometime soon, investors and speculators will have to begin paying more attention to the Presidential election and what a Clinton or Bush victory will portend for the bond market.
Investors got a little taste of that yesterday as they waited for the release of Mr. Bush's speech to the Detroit Economic Club, in which he said that if Congress approved his spending cuts he could propose a 1 percent across-the-board tax cut. Investors seemed to react negatively at first, possibly because a tax cut might imply that the deficit would get larger. But later, investors seemed to shrug off the Bush proposal.
"When people realized it was basically the same thing that he said at the convention, people saw the decline as an opportunity to get back into the market," said Michael H. Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America) in New York.
 
Responding to News Reports
 There were also other bits of new information to react to during the day, which pushed the market up and down. The Labor Department reported that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose by 8,000, to 394,000, during the week ended Aug. 29. The report was generally in line with expectations.
There was also news of an apparent violation of the the no-fly zone in Iraq by an Iraqi fighter plane, which traders said might have helped push the dollar higher and provided a little lift for the market.
At the end of they day there was yet another surprise in the Federal Reserve money-supply figures. In the week that ended Aug. 31, M-2 -- a measurement that includes currency, checking accounts and savings accounts -- jumped $7 billion, far more than many forecasters expected. But some analysts immediately played down the increase, saying it reflected the heavy pace of consumer refinancing of home mortgages to take advantage of lower interest rates. The jump in the money supply could be negative for the bond market if it indicated a stronger economy than is now expected.
 
Corporate Issues
 About $8 billion in new corporate borrowing has flooded the market this week and indications are that investors are being a bit choosy in what they are buying. This means that the yields on some of the deals, which have been at relatively narrow spreads over their counterpart Treasury securities, will have to widen a bit.
"The after-market spread performance of a number of these transactions is doing nothing else to the customer base but telling them that they can be more selective," said James B. Quigley, a managing director of the syndicate desk at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Some traders have suggested that the firms that are underwriting many of the new issues are pricing them very aggressively, partly in an effort to guarantee themselves a good share of the business in the important rankings of market share that are closely watched in this very competitive industry.
Mr. Quigley said that in trading yesterday corporate spreads were unchanged to a little weaker. He did not say that the corporate market was in trouble but that it would take a widening of a few basis points in the yields of many of the new issues to get them sold to retail or large institutional investors. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Small Investors Stepping Aside?

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
SIGNS of a retreat by small investors led to much wringing of hands yesterday on Wall Street, where some brokerage stocks took a nasty hit. The selling was prompted by an announcement by Charles Schwab & Company, the discount broker, that said late Wednesday that business had fallen to an average of 18,000 trades a day recently, down from boom levels of 32,300 in January.
Schwab shares were down as much as $4.25, to $18.25, in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, though they rebounded to close down $2.625 at $19.875. The shares of Quick & Reilly Group Inc., another discount broker, were also down, falling 62.5 cents, to $19.375, on the Big Board. 
In an hourlong telephone conference with securities analysts yesterday, Schwab management said that individual investors were feeling jittery about the wobbly economy and the uncertain political environment. "We find customers are very perplexed and are just not trading," said John Gambs, chief financial officer at Schwab.
Competitors at competing discount brokerage firms echoed Mr. Gambs's assessment. "There are days when we're down 40 percent from the first quarter," said Muriel Siebert of Muriel Siebert & Company.
The gloomy news for the discounters contaminated shares of larger full-service brokerage houses, too. Paine Webber, Morgan Stanley and American Express, owner of Shearson Lehman Brothers, also suffered losses yesterday. Merrill Lynch shares rebounded from an early decline after the firm released a statement touting the advantages of its full-service "counsel and advice" to clients. Merrill and other full-service firms took the opportunity yesterday to boast that they were diversified and not so dependent on stock transaction business. Merrill said its customers were not suffering the "investor confusion" of certain competitors, but did not offer any data to back up its contention.
Key to the concern over the cooling of small- investor enthusiasm is the question of how enduring the retreat will be. Pessimists say small investors are headed for an extended hibernation, but several optimists say the pullback is temporary in the face of current economic and political worries.
Individual investors were largely out of the stock market through the entire 1980's boom, said Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates. But in 1991, a reversal took place, he contends.
Small investors, as measured by "odd lot" trading of under 100 shares, were net sellers in all but 18 trading days from 1980 to 1990, Mr. Birinyi said. But in 1991, he said, odd lot traders were net buyers in 95 of the year's trading days. Through the end of August those small investors were net buyers on 108 days.
Such statistics support those who often predict -- with accuracy -- that markets will fall when the public comes in. But Mr. Birinyi makes a case that this shift to net buying by small investors will not be easily stopped. "You want to pay attention to them because they're making a secular change," he said. "The public en masse has come back, and when it's of this persistence and of such magnitude, I wouldn't want to short into them."
In sufficient numbers, Mr. Birinyi said, small investors can be the marginal buyers that keep a bullish trend in place.
If market analysts had not been so distracted by takeover fever back in 1986, they might have noticed that 95 percent of trading in the Dow Jones industrial average took place in the first and last 15 minutes of the trading day, according to Mr. Birinyi's statistics. He said that those marginal buyers were mostly foreigners, coming in at the start and end of their trading days.
Today, individual investors can provide similar marginal impetus, Mr. Birinyi added. "I don't think they came back to stocks for a quick trip," he said.
The decline in trading levels at the discount brokerage firms "could well just be digestion" as brokers and clients adjust to the trend, he said.
In the view of John Markese, director of research at the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago, the drop in small-investor activity is nothing more than "a plateau after a tremendous surge in activity."
Mr. Markese said the loss of business at the discount brokers did not come as any surprise to him: the most recent sampling of the association's 136,000 members found the weakest enthusiasm for stocks since it began polling members in 1987.
For the moment, small-investor activity is weak because most of those who would be motivated to switch to stocks in the face of falling interest rates have already done so, Mr. Markese said. Making things worse, he added, are the uncertain political and economic conditions.
"But I don't think it's a long-term trend down," he said, noting that small investors do seem more committed to owning stocks than they have been in years. Mr. Markese should know. His group's membership has risen to 136,000 so far this year, up from 117,000 at the end of 1991.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 33.77 on Heavy Volume

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market ran up its sharpest gain in more than six weeks yesterday, extending Wednesday's mild rally as President Bush made his proposals for reviving the economy.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had gained 10.80 points Wednesday, climbed 33.77 points, to 3,305.16. It was the best single-day showing since the Dow jumped 45.12 points on July 29. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 11 to 6 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume came to 222 million shares, up from 178.8 million in the previous session.
The Amex market value index was up 1.99, to 384.81, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 6.35, to 581.24, in that market's best and busiest session since late July.
The market advanced gradually all day, picking up momentum as Mr. Bush described his "agenda for renewal," including spending cuts and an across-the-board tax reduction of about 1 percent.
Analysts said stocks also drew support from expectations of favorable inflation news. The Labor Department reports today on the Producer Price Index of Finished Goods, and next week on the Consumer Price Index, for August.
In yesterday's economic news, the Government reported that initial claims for state unemployment insurance rose 8,000, or a little less than expected, in the week ended Aug. 29.
National Semiconductor rose 7/8, to 12, in active trading yesterday. The company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of of 17 cents a share, compared with a loss in the corresponding period a year earlier.
On the downside, the Charles Schwab Corporation tumbled 2 5/8, to 19 7/8. Late Wednesday, the discount brokerage firm surprised investors with a projection of a 50 percent decline in third-quarter profits.
Other securities-industry stocks were mostly lower. Morgan Stanley fell 1 3/8, to 49 5/8; Paine Webber 1/2, to 18 3/8; Salomon Inc. 1/4, to 35 3/4, and Bear Stearns 1/4, to 15 1/2.
However, Merrill Lynch, which said it had not seen among its customers the mood of uncertainty reported by Schwab, gained 7/8, to 52.
Cyclical stocks in industries like metals and forest products made some of the biggest contributions to the Dow's advance. The Aluminum Company of America rose 2 1/4, to 69 1/4, and International Paper gained 2 3/8, to 64 3/4.
Airline issues were also strong. UAL rose 3 7/8, to 112; AMR 1 5/8, to 61 1/4; Delta Air Lines 2 1/8, to 57 1/8, and USAir Group 1/2, to 14 1/8.
Other gainers among the blue-chip industrials included Walt Disney, up 1 1/2, to 36 3/4; American Telephone and Telegraph, up 1, to 43 5/8; Goodyear Tire and Rubber, up 2, to 65 1/2, and Procter & Gamble, up 1 3/8, to 48 1/2.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up as Traders React To British and Iraqi Events

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most major currencies as traders followed events in Iraq and Britain's Prime Minister said he would not devalue the pound. Gold prices were mixed.
The dollar began to rise as Prime Minister John Major repeated Britain's unwillingness to devalue the pound against other European currencies, said Steven Jonathan, a vice president at Citibank. 
 Mr. Major said his Government would not be pushed away from its goal of low inflation. He also said he would not press Britain's partners in the European Monetary System for any sort of realignment, which could affect the dollar's value.
 
Iraq News Helps the Dollar
 News from Iraq also gave the dollar a lift, traders said. In northern Iraq, what appeared to be an Iraqi F-1 Mirage jet fighter crossed into the zone where the United States and its allies had imposed a flight ban to protect the Kurds, Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said.
Mr. Williams said allied officials were not certain that the plane was an Iraqi fighter, since others in the coalition protecting the Kurds fly such aircraft. Unrest generally causes investors to seek a safe haven currency like the dollar.
Traders also said currency markets did not flinch yesterday when President Bush proposed to cut some Federal salaries by 5 percent and overall taxes by 1 percent.
In New York, the dollar closed at 1.4205 German marks, up from 1.41355 late Wednesday. In Europe, the dollar fell to 1.4103 marks, from 1.4105 late Wednesday. Gold prices were mixed.
In New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.9645, down from $1.9710 late Wednesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.9765, from $1.9750 late Wednesday.

WASHINGTON HEIGHTS: BEHIND THE DECISION

He gave the explanation as he issued a detailed 45-page review of an investigation in the July death, which touched off several days of violence in Washington Heights. A1.

HEADLINE: The Big Guns Take Sides in Trade-Policy Debate

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Chances are that if Warren Steibel, the producer of "Firing Line," were entrusted with organizing the Presidential debates, they would turn out to be a lot more enlightening and entertaining than they promise to be this year. Tonight's two-hour debate on a subject that is not often honored in prime time manages to make the pros and cons of free trade, believe it or not, positively lively.
The program was taped last week at the University of Mississippi, where eight men with some knowledge of the matter gathered to argue over the proposition that "United States Industry Does Not Need Protection." ("Firing Line" does not go in for proportionate representation by sex, race or ethnic heritage, but there is plenty of variety in style as well as of opinion on display.) 
 Taking the positive side of the negative resolution are William F. Buckley Jr., the program's resident polysyllabicist; Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State; Jack Kemp, the present Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas. In favor of some degree of protection are Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, who is also the House majority leader; the economist Lester Thurow, dean of the Sloan School of Management at Massachusetts Institute of Technology; James Fallows, Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. Michael Kinsley moderates with an occasional wisecrack and a minimum of interference.
Mr. Kinsley's main jobs are to keep these opinionators to their allotted time limits, and to make sure that the questions they ask of one another are not speeches in disguise and the answers do not become what Mr. Buckley calls anfractuosities. The format of brief statements followed by pointed exchanges allows the debaters to mix it up, and only now and then to mix up the audience.
Illuminating differences appear within the teams, and significant agreements across them. Mr. Kissinger turns out to be no strict free-trader; taking a geopolitical rather than an economic perspective, he supports the recent trade agreement with Mexico on the grounds that it will help that country achieve full democracy. Mr. Brown opposes such agreements largely because he sees them as undermining American sovereignty by giving power to countries like Mexico and to shadowy international bureaucracies.
But the focus, of course, is on America's economic troubles. No one comes out against growth, but while Mr. Buckley and Mr. Kemp stand unapologetically for the blessings of Reaganomics, Mr. Gephardt argues that the United States cannot afford to play by the rules of free trade as long as other countries -- he cites Japan -- rig the market. Mr. Armey, who relies mainly on slogans about free enterprise, is trounced by the facts marshaled by Mr. Fallows and Mr. Thurow, which is the way debates are supposed to work.
Whichever position you find more congenial, for these two hours you may be impressed that it is mainly on Government-subsidized public television that you are likely to find free trade in ideas.
 
'20/20'
'Soldiers of Misfortune'
 ABC, tonight at 10.
 (Channel 7 in New York.)
Tonight's edition of "20/20" begins with a suggestive report that thousands of American servicemen wound up as prisoners in the Soviet Union after World War II. It is largely based on a recent book by James D. Sanders, Mark A. Sauter and R. Court Kirkwood titled "Soldiers of Misfortune" (National Press). The writers make a case that the troops were in German P.O.W. camps liberated by the Russians, who then kept them as hostages for Russian soldiers held by the United States. When exchange agreements broke down, the authors contend, the Americans were sent to Siberian labor camps, and Washington ignored their existence for diplomatic reasons.
Unfortunately, in an apparent effort to bolster an intriguing but problematic account, the ABC correspondent Tom Jarriel passes along shreds of suspicion, speculation and the wishful beliefs of relatives of other missing Americans, some from the wars in Korea and Vietnam. In the rapid shifts, the viewer may find it difficult to sort out fact from supposition. Let's hope that "20/20" is not getting into the bad habit, not unknown on the tube, of hyping the facts in the interests of a more sensational show.
 
'It Happened on Main Street'
 NBC, Sunday at 8 A.M.
 (Channel 4 in New York.)
Anyone who has been following the savings-and-loan debacle will find no revelations in this somewhat belated 90-minute edition of "Today," but it does offer examples of the sort of greed, chicanery, political string-pulling and official negligence that are costing taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.
The program notes, for example, that deregulation of the savings-and-loan industry brought a high time for operators like William Michael Adkinson, who obtained millions from savings-and-loan branches in Pennsylvania and Texas for a Florida development called Emerald Coast, which never developed. Since the lenders knew the Government would cover any losses, however imprudent the loan, they had no reason to be prudent. A visit to Emerald Coast finds only acres of sand dunes.
Another operator, David L. Paul, who once controlled the biggest savings-and-loan chain in Florida, has been charged with diverting $3 million to his own use, and there are intimations that Washington officials interceded to keep the heat off him.
After pointing out that the Senators and Representatives who voted for deregulation in the Reagan years, in effect, encouraged the con artists to cash in, Garrick Utley notes that the savings-and-loan industry contributed more than $11 million to Congressional campaigns in the 1980's. The money went especially to members of the Senate and House banking committees, like Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the Senate committee's chairman, and other members, including the Democratic Senator Alan Cranston of California and the Republican Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, Phil Gramm of Texas and Jake Garn of Utah. In some endeavors, a bipartisan spirit prevails.

PBS, tonight at 9.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Students Get a Saturday Off: Can They Handle It?

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
One of the biggest changes in Japan's education system since it was established 120 years ago will take place on Saturday. Schools will be closed.
Public elementary, middle and high schools throughout Japan are to close for one Saturday a month to give overworked students a break. Government officials say the move is the first step toward a full five-day school week some years in the future. 
 One Saturday off a month might not seem like a whole lot of extra leisure time, but in workaholic Japan the new policy has set off a wave of debate, and even fear.
While some educators, parents and students say it will improve the lives of children, others warn that it is the beginning of a descent into laziness that will undermine the nation's academic achievement and industrial competitiveness.
 
'Some Kind of Plot'
 "I almost tend to think this is some kind of plot to weaken Japan's economic prowess by attacking the final fortress -- education," said Miyuki Ohashi, a professor of sociology at Nihon University.
Others are worried about a more immediate matter: How are the students going to fill this new free time?
"I have nothing to do unless I come to school," said Atsushi Sumida, a 13-year-old seventh grader at Ginza Junior High School in Tokyo.
Concerned that children, or their parents, might not be able to come up with ideas by themselves, the Ministry of Education has called on local governments, corporations and cultural institutions to organize activities for Saturday. And Japan Inc., with a mixture of patriotism and self-interest, is rising to the occasion.
Department stores are organizing tours, story-telling sessions and other activities to help the national cause, and to lure some young customers. A fish cultivation center in Shizuoka Prefecture will allow children to dive into a concrete tank containing 10,000 red sea bream. Even the country's pool halls will throw open their doors on Saturday to let children play free.
 
The Envy of Others
 One thing Education Ministry officials do not want to see children doing this Saturday morning is studying.
Japan's education system is often the envy of other countries because it produces a well-educated and disciplined work force. But some scholars say the system robs children of their childhood and turns them into automatons in matching uniforms and backpacks.
Japanese students attend school 240 days a year compared with about 180 days in the United States. There are about six hours a day of schooling on weekdays and three or four hours on Saturday mornings.
On top of that, many students attend private cram schools, or juku, on nights and weekends to prepare for college and high-school entrance examinations. Getting into the right college is all important in determining one's career prospects.
Critics contend that in addition to the long hours the schooling is geared too much toward rote learning rather than creative thinking.
"Maybe the school education has been too strict, creating kids who are rather uninspired," said Masami Zeniya, director of the elementary school education division at the Ministry of Education. "We should focus more on raising children who can think by themselves and make decisions by themselves, rather than just accepting knowledge."
 
Free Thinking Is the Aim
 The Saturday-off plan, by giving children more time for themselves, is intended to encourage free thinking. It is also part of a push by the Government to make Japanese relax more. Many companies and Government agencies have already gone to a five-day work week.
Not everyone thinks the Saturday closings will result in more leisure. The Education Ministry, they note, has neglected to change the school curriculum, which calls for a certain number of hours to be devoted to each subject a year. To meet the requirements, schools are making up for the missing Saturday classes by having students stay longer on weekdays or by scheduling classes at times once used for sports or club activities.
"I'm not happy at all because the hours we cut on Saturday will be added to the other days," said Shino Ikeda, an eighth grader at Ginza Junior High School.
 
A Principal Is Warned
 As in any revolution, there are those who resist. Many parents are against the plan because it will mean more time taking care of their children and will pose hardships when both parents work on Saturday.
A poll by the newspaper Tokyo Shimbun last spring found 49 percent approving the idea of one Saturday off a month, with 44 percent disapproving. But when it came to the idea of closing schools every Saturday, those opposed slightly outnumbered those in favor.
Government officials are trying hard to stamp out the counterrevolutionaries. A high-school principal in Kagoshima Prefecture, in southern Japan, was reprimanded by the local authorities when he suggested too strongly that students attend voluntary classes that will be offered on the Saturdays school is closed.
Some experts say that as long as the pressure of college entrance examinations remains, it will be difficult to reduce school hours. With public schools closed on Saturday mornings, some students will just go to cram schools instead.
Yoshiya Abe, professor of comparative culture at Aichi Gakuin University, said a more fundamental change might occur because Japan's low birth rate was leading to a gradual reduction in the number of high-school seniors.
"By the year 2005 there will be more places in the universities than there are applicants," he said. "This will really reduce the pressure to work hard for the college entrance exams."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Producing a well-disciplined work force has made the educational system in Japan the envy of other nations. But in an unusual decision by the Education Ministry, Japanese students, like these boys going home after class recently, will now get one Saturday off from school each month. (Koji Sasahara for The New York Times)
