HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Bush's Double Bind

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
When it comes to dealing with the economy as a campaign issue, President Bush is caught in a trap.
If he advocates bold new ideas for addressing the country's economic problems, that raises the question of why, after all this time in office, he is just now getting around to doing something about the situation. 
 If he states, as most economists believe, that the weak economy today is mostly the result of overindulgences of the 1980's, he is in the position of criticizing the policies of the Reagan Administration. He was part of that Administration, and his election campaign four years ago was based in large part on glorifying its economic record.
 
An Economic Mess
 In his speech in Detroit today, Mr. Bush expressed, in the greatest detail and candor of his Presidency, his understanding of what a mess the United States economy is in. And he drew the most complete picture to date of his own economic principles and what he wants the economy to look like in the future.
But for those looking for policy prescriptions or clear insights into what exactly Mr. Bush would do about the economy if he won re-election, he offered little if anything new. One reason perhaps is that the President's basic goals -- cutting the budget deficit, lowering taxes and reducing Government spending drastically without touching Social Security -- are often in conflict.
A recent report by the General Accounting Office stated what is obvious to most impartial economists: "The amount of deficit reduction needed to achieve either balance or surplus will be difficult, if not impossible, to achieve if any major areas of spending or potential revenues are set off the table." So here, the President must avoid specifics.
Mr. Bush's address was probably more successful as a campaign speech. His political goal was not so much to break new ground on economic policy as to counter the assertions of his critics that no coherent theme connected the myriad economic proposals he had put forward over the years. He tried to show that his ideas on taxation, education, welfare, job training and the like were not just random thoughts, but were based on fundamental principles.
On the policy side, although it is 26 months after the recession began and just 53 days before the next election, Mr. Bush suggested no bolder a plan than he had before about how, in his words, to "manage the changes that are transforming our economy" and prepare the country for "an era of great opportunity."
Beneath the new thematic flourishes in today's speech to the Detroit Economic Club are the same vague promises he put forth at the Republican National Convention in Houston last month to cut taxes and spending and keep the Government from meddling in the marketplace and the same programs that over the years have generated little public enthusiasm or Congressional support.
In his convention speech and other addresses about the economy over the years, Mr. Bush emphasized the health of the American economy. Today, by contrast, he began by listing "five profound changes" causing serious economic difficulties but said little about how he would relieve that stress.
He noted the dislocations caused by deep reductions in military spending after the collapse of the Soviet Union, but except in the vaguest terms, he did not indicate how he would help the military-related workers who have lost their livelihoods.
He spoke of how old-fashioned manufacturing jobs were being replaced by positions requiring a highly skilled work force, but he did not say what role the Government should play in training these workers in the new skills.
He said individuals and companies were hamstrung by the vast increase in their debts in the high-rolling 1980's, but he did not mention that the Federal Government's own debt under his stewardship had risen by about $1.5 trillion.
The fourth change he listed was the shaky banking system. But he did not explain why he personally did not push the legislation his own Treasury Department sponsored unsuccessfully last year to overhaul the system.
Finally, Mr. Bush talked about America's increasing reliance on overseas economies and promised to press for new free-trade treaties. But in the next breath, he talked about a company in St. Louis that makes lights for police cars, hardly the kind of high-technology export that even Mr. Bush's own economic advisers think the nation should stress.
 
Repackaging Old Ideas
 Mr. Bush has little choice but to try to repackage his old ideas in a new oratorical wrapping and to try to persuade voters that the economic plans of his Democratic opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton, are downright dangerous.
On the themes, instead of trade policy, he talked today of "challenging the world." Instead of education, he spoke of "preparing our children." Instead of cutting taxes on companies and investors, it was "sharpening business's competitive edge." Instead of job training and medical care, it was "promoting economic security." Instead of welfare, it was "leaving no one behind." Instead of making the Government cheaper and more efficient, it was "right-sizing Government."
But the policies are basically the same. The main way he would improve education, for example, would be to have the Government pick up the tuition of students in private schools. He would attack poverty by "sweeping away the nightmare of crime from our cities, building a core of property owners, creating business incentives and making individual discipline and self-reliance the goal of all of our programs."
 
Talk of Political Mirage
 As for Mr. Clinton's economic plans, Mr. Bush spoke today of "the mirage that my opponent offers of a Government that accumulates capital by taxing it and borrowing it from the people, and then redistributing it according to some industrial policy."
The centerpieces of the Clinton economic platform are higher taxes on households with incomes greater than $200,000 and new spending on a variety of Government public works projects. The Democrat's proposals for cutting the budget deficit are based on calculations as shaky as the President's.
Mr. Bush did propose one wholly new idea today. He said he would cut the salaries of Federal workers earning more than $75,000 by 5 percent. "Taxpayers have tightened their belts," he declared. "The better-paid Federal workers should do the same."
Just two years ago, Mr. Bush argued successfully for a Federal pay increase. Federal salaries, he said then, were so out of line with those in business that competent managers could not be lured to Washington.

HEADLINE: MOUNTAIN TROOPS HELPING IN FLORIDA

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLORIDA CITY, Fla., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Until Hurricane Andrew came along, the soldiers of the United States Army's 10th Mountain Division had planned to spend September in training exercises at their home base, Fort Drum, N.Y. Instead, members of the unit have for the last week been sorting canned goods and other donated items in the ruins of a tomato processing plant here.
"We're infantry soldiers, and we're used to doing that job," Pvt. Anthony Lee, a 21-year-old from Sandusky, Ohio, said as he and his buddies wheeled a pallet of canned vegetables to a truck waiting for a load to carry to a nearby tent city. "It feels good to be here helping people, but this is something totally new and different for us." 
 South Florida may look like a war zone, but the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine troops assisting in hurricane relief efforts are nonetheless operating on unfamiliar terrain. In a deployment of forces that has already eclipsed the 1989 invasion of Panama, combat units have been pressed into service for a variety of humanitarian missions, from rebuilding schools and directing traffic to removing debris.
 
The Call to Action
 As of Wednesday, nearly two weeks after President Bush first ordered units to the disaster zone, 21,922 regular troops and 6,257 National Guardsmen were in South Florida. Assigned to some of the hardest-hit areas of Homestead and Florida City, the 10th Mountain Division is one of the biggest units here, with 4,844 soldiers and officers.
When the call to action came, some of the 10th's soldiers said, they were told only that they were shipping out. Some thought they might be heading off to the Persian Gulf, or Bosnia. Only after they arrived here did they realize they have become part of an historic experiment, whose outcome may help determine whether there is an expanded domestic role for a military in search of new missions.
"They talk about 'the New Army,' and I guess this is it," Sgt. Maj. Stanley Kaminski said as he surveyed a field in the shadow of the Florida City municipal water tower where his soldiers were working on food distribution with city employees and volunteers from a religious group.
Troops stationed here tell of duties that come straight out of the Boy Scout Handbook. They are helping elderly women and pregnant women move furniture from their devastated homes, doing laundry for homeless people now living in tent cities, or sweeping trash from front yards for homeowners.
 
Giving Medical Help
 In a suburban housing development, another group of soldiers from an air defense and artillery battalion have been going door to door, checking to see what houses have been abandoned and asking the remaining residents if they need free tarpaper, plywood or plastic sheeting.
"People have come to us with a lot of medical questions, like how to get prescriptions filled or what to do about cut feet or infections," said Capt. Jeff Przybylak, who has been helping tear down condemned houses in a poor neighborhood. "One lady in my sector is pregnant, and today is her due day, so I've given my medical team advance notice she may have to go in."
There is even a military-run radio station, located at 1610 on the AM dial and called "Radio Recovery." Broadcasting throughout South Dade County in English, Spanish and Haitian Creole, the station provides information about shelter, food distribution locations, medical clinics, legal advice and Federal financial assistance.
"The command and control structure the military has, that's what the key is right now," Col. Bill Martinez, one of the 10th Mountain Division's battalion commanders, said. "The organizational skills, the ability to give a command and move people into a sector, that's what we can contribute. We are their lifeline right now."
 
Not Doing Police Work
 One thing the soldiers are not doing, however, is police work. As Federal troops in an area where martial law has not been declared, they cannot engage in law-enforcement activities and are under orders to call the police if they see crimes being committed.
Gangs here know that, and some have challenged soldiers in the streets and tried to disarm them. In one recent confrontation, heavily armed members of a gang told a squad patrolling their turf to surrender their unloaded M-16 rifles, but they eventually backed off.
Commanders from Lieut. Gen. Samuel Ebbesen, head of the overall relief effort, on down have said repeatedly that theirs is a "support mission," not one in which they issue the orders. Citing the tradition of civilian control of the military, they say they want to work as closely and efficiently as possible with civilian authorities.
In practical terms, said Katie Mitchell, assistant city manager of Homestead, that means that military and civilian officials meet as often as four times a day. "We go over everything, letting them know what we are hearing from our employees in the field and what kind of problems we are having and where we think we need more support," she said.
This week, Ms. Mitchell said, civilian authorities have made their top priority the repair of schools so that classes, originally scheduled to begin Aug. 31, can start on Monday. The military's response has been to send the 10th Mountain Division and Navy Seabees to Homestead High School and other schools designated by city officials, and follow instructions.
"When the military first came in, we had trees all over, and the place was a total mess," said Genevieve Chandler, principal of the Florida City Elementary School. "They have done roofing, pulled up carpet, swept out the parking lot, brought hot meals in for the people working here.
"Everything we've asked for, they have done for us."
Military officers have also stressed that they will phase out their activities as soon as civilian authorities indicate they are no longer needed.
Soldiers on duty here, though, will continue to live almost exactly as they would if they were on the front lines overseas. At an unfinished housing development called Keys Gate, the 10th Mountain Division has 20 soldiers to a tent, sleeping on cots with mosquito netting, consuming cold "Meals Ready-to-Eat" for breakfast and lunch, eating hot rations for dinner, and getting many of the same benefits that would have been supplied by training.
"In a normal training environment, our people will be together for 10 to 12 hours a day and then go home," said Col. Joseph Prasek of the 10th Mountain Division.

James Sosbe Jr. helped Dorothy Wade and her daughter, Wanda Jamison, with groceries secured at a nearby supply tent. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ballet Theater and Joffrey Decide Against Merging

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
American Ballet Theater and the Joffrey Ballet have agreed not to pursue a merger plan that the financially hard-pressed companies had been exploring since June. The decision was reached in separate board meetings on Wednesday and announced yesterday.
Both companies, which have severe cash-flow problems, also announced that they were beginning emergency fund-raising campaigns and that they expected to perform through the 1992-93 season. Ballet Theater also said that next week it would announce an artistic director to succeed Jane Hermann, a co-director with Oliver Smith, who resigned on Sept. 1. 
 A company spokesman, Robert Pontarelli, would not confirm or deny widespread reports that the new director would be Kevin McKenzie, a principal dancer, choreographer and artistic associate of the Washington Ballet who was a former principal dancer with Ballet Theater.
 
On Questions of Payment
 In a statement released yesterday after a meeting with Ballet Theater's dancers and administrative staff, the chairman of Ballet Theater's board, Stephen J. Friedman, said that a revised financial plan for the 1992-93 season would be developed with the new director and that board members had agreed to accelerate donations to enable the company "to immediately resume paying its dancers and staff, and to begin paying its vendors on a cash basis going forward."
Mr. Pontarelli said the money would be used to pay the dancers' unemployment benefit supplements, due last week, and health-insurance premiums, which are two weeks late.
Mr. Friedman said in his statement, "At the same time the board plans to launch a far-reaching fund-raising campaign, with important assistance from the dancers, that will enable the company to finance the remainder of the season."
In a move to reduce its budget, Ballet Theater has canceled engagements in San Francisco and Chicago "because of substantial losses which the company would have to incur to present itself in those cities," Mr. Friedman said. It will perform as scheduled this winter in Japan, Buenos Aires, Los Angeles and at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, along with its annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York, opening on May 3.
The Joffrey Ballet announced that it would appear as scheduled in its two-week engagement at City Center in mid-Manhattan, opening on Feb. 22, in winter engagements in Germany, and in seasons in Minneapolis, Iowa City, San Francisco and at the Kennedy Center.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Owners Lean Toward Lockout

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10

 BODY:
With the battle over Fay Vincent as commissioner apparently ancient history, major league baseball's club owners focused their attention on economic issues today and showed early signs that they were gearing themselves for a self-inflicted shutdown next spring.
"I'd be surprised if there isn't a lockout," one participant in the owners' meeting said after listening to the report and discussion on labor. "No votes were taken, but they were certainly feisty enough about it." 
 Before the owners can lock out the players for the second time in four years, they would have to reopen negotiation on the collective-bargaining agreement by Dec. 11. Either side can take that step, but the players' union has shown no inclination to move in that direction.
Bud Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, who is in charge of the majors pending the election of a new commissioner, said the owners won't make a decision on reopening collective bargaining "for a while." Selig also is the board chairman of the owners' labor body.
 
More Militant Stance
 Talk of reopening and locking out may be premature, but there is sentiment among many owners not to wait for the labor contract to expire after the 1993 season. They want to, in their terms, take back control of the game from the players, and they believe a militant stance is necessary.
Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox, one of the most militant owners, said he didn't know if the owners would reopen bargaining, but, he added, "it's going to be seriously considered."
The owners spent about half an hour on the report from Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, but it was only one phase of their discussion of economic issues.
"When economic issues came up, the focus of attention went up," the participant in the meeting said.
Six or seven clubs, the person said, expressed the view that if they could get out of their agreements, they would drop some of their minor league teams as a way of saving money. But Eddie Einhorn of the Chicago White Sox and Carl Barger of the Florida Marlins, who are on the minor league committee, pointed out that the agreement with the National Association, which represents the minor leagues, says major league clubs will maintain 119 minor league teams, and this can't be changed as long as the agreement is in effect.
 
Discussion on Loans
 On another economic matter, Selig reported that he and another owner will meet with bank officials next week to discuss loans that some officials said could be jeopardized by the ouster of Vincent as commissioner.
Vincent, who resigned under pressure last Monday, was not a topic of conversation at the meeting. Not even his supporters from last week's 18-9 vote said anything. "There wasn't a whisper raised," the participant said.
Selig told the owners that "the press expected us to go at each other and it's been anything but."
On the other hand, at the National League meeting Wednesday, an owner said that Peter O'Malley of the Los Angeles Dodgers raised a question about Selig. "How can he be in charge of so many things?" O'Malley was quoted as remarking. O'Malley and Selig were in the forefront of the move to unseat Vincent.
 
Multiple Roles Unchallenged
 Earlier in the day, Selig was elected chairman of the executive council, which, in effect, makes him the temporary replacement for the commissioner. He is also board chairman of the Player Relations Committee, the owners' representative to the economic study committee with the players, a member of the ownership committee and, as chairman of the executive council, head of the committee that will seek a new commissioner.
No one at today's joint meeting of the leagues challenged Selig's multiple roles, perhaps because at the outset he said, "I know I'm doing a lot, but I'm not going to overstretch myself."
Selig passed up an opportunity to be a member of the restructuring committee that will study possible changes in the role of the commissioner. Fred Wilpon of the Mets and Paul Beeston of the Toronto Blue Jays were named co-chairmen of the committee today.
Other members are Reinsdorf, who was considered the No. 1 instigator in removing Vincent; Haywood Sullivan of Boston; Larry Lucchino of Baltimore; Rusty Rose of Texas; William Bartholomay of Atlanta; Claude Brochu of Toronto; Wayne Huizenga of the Marlins, and O'Malley. The league presidents will also serve, and George W. Bush of Texas will be an ex-officio member.
The resolution in which the owners asked Vincent to resign said the restructuring committee would make recommendations to the clubs by Nov. 1. But Selig said today that the committee would not be held to that deadline.
Tom Werner of San Diego, a successful television producer, was named chairman of the television committee and will negotiate a new national television package aided by Einhorn and Bill Giles of Philadelphia.
"We can't sit here today and consider what we're going to do," Selig said.

Brown Not Interested
 BATON ROUGE, La., Sept.10 (AP) -- Ron Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he had no interest in being the new baseball commissioner. Brown's name had been mentioned in speculation about candidates to succeed Fay Vincent.
"I am totally focused on doing everything I can to see that Bill Clinton will be elected the next President of the United States," Brown said at a news conference.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Fehr Awaits 2 Words: Delay Ball

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Bud Selig, the closest thing to a commissioner baseball has these days, is expressing a bit of puzzlement. He does not understand why the owners' overthrow of Commissioner Fay Vincent is being construed as a signal that management not only intends to reopen negotiations on the labor agreement with players come January, but also plans to manufacture such a confrontation so as to shut down the game for a very long time.
The public that still bothers to care about baseball may be so war-weary as to be beyond understanding how players, or anyone else, have drawn such pessimistic conclusions. Donald Fehr, a person with more than a passing interest in this issue, is more than willing to provide the answer. 
 Fehr, the head of the players' union, says that the players, always suspicious of the owners' motives, are not just wary, they're angry, angrier then they've been since being locked out in the spring of 1990.
Why?
"Have you heard the word 'reconciliation?' " Fehr asked. "Have you heard the word 'partnership?' Have you heard the words 'new understanding?' Have you heard any of that? All you've heard is war."
Fehr expressed his feelings yesterday, speaking by telephone from Chicago, his third stop on his cross-country trek to visit his constituency, a tour that started the day after Vincent resigned.
"There is no public indication that there is the slightest interest on behalf of the owners in doing anything except fighting a war for the sake of fighting a war, of reestablishing their prominence, of making clear their primacy," Fehr said. "So, they throw out Fay. They make it clear they have utter disdain for the public. And so the next group they beat up upon is the players."
Fehr had said little on baseball's upheaval since 18 of 28 owners cast a no-confidence vote against Vincent last week and since Vincent's subsequent resignation on Monday. He had wanted to see what emerged from the first post-Vincent owners' meeting, something that occurred the last two days in St. Louis.
Though the owners were pretty much mum about their labor stance and the extent of their discussions, they issued no statements whatsoever to dissuade Fehr from his dire predictions. In fact, the actions and attitudes emanating from the meeting here may well enforce the belief that baseball is considering making war once more.
According to a participant in the owners' meeting, the owners were pretty subdued until economic and labor issues came up. "The focus of attention went up," the participant said. "In my opinion, I wouldn't be surprised if there is a lockout. No votes were taken, but they were certainly feisty enough about it."
Then there are the recent words of Jerry Reinsdorf, owner of the Chicago White Sox and the power broker being credited with bringing down Vincent and orchestrating the coronation of Selig Wednesday. He was quoted as saying in the Chicago Sun-Times on Sept. 4: "If a commissioner has an obligation to constituencies other than the owners, I don't think he should be involved. When we go to war with the union, I want him to have an obligation only to the owners."
Since Vincent last June refused to waive his powers to act in the best interest of baseball when it came to labor relations, he obviously did not fit the Reinsdorf description. And since major league owners have given no indication that they are about to abandon Vincent's positions on realignment or his perceived opposition to the Giants' move to Florida, it increases the suspicion he's gone either for reasons of incredible incompatibility or because of the issue of labor.
"It is conceivable that Fay would have been thrown out quite apart from lockout issues," Fehr said. "It is, however, accurate that among the people who were instrumental in coercing those 18 votes are the people most interested in fighting a conflict with the players for purposes of fighting a conflict with the players. This way they have no one in position to interfere with that, to raise questions."
Would Vincent have inserted himself into a confrontation with the players? He did in 1990, entering negotiations with Fehr and the players at the request of owners like Selig in an effort to help end a lockout. One spring later, Vincent negotiated with the umpires' union, angering the league presidents.
Now, with Vincent gone, Fehr is convinced there is only one mind-set within management, that qualms over Selig heading the executive council that runs baseball in Vincent's absence, with Selig running the Player Relations Committee, management's negotiating arm, with Reinsdorf having his way, have been muted for good.
"The owners no longer perceive a difference between the P.R.C., the owners as a group, the executive council or Reinsdorf's living room," Fehr said.
So it is that more than 650 players wait for Dec. 11, the date owners and the players must inform each other whether or not they intend to exercise the reopener in the basic agreement a year early. So it is that by Jan. 11, that reopener could be in effect. With Vincent out, the most powerful varsity the owners ever took on prepares for battle.

HEADLINE: For Assembly: Brooklyn, the Bronx

 BODY:
Here are our recommendations for New York Assembly races in Brooklyn and the Bronx where victory in Tuesday's Democratic primary will be tantamount to election.
BROOKLYN.
42d District. The seven-term veteran Rhoda Jacobs has worked hard and well, for instance pressing legislation to help the elderly and homeless, and has earned re-election. Still, two challengers offer promise -- Edward Roberts, a lawyer, and Clarence Robertson, formerly an official in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office. 
 44th District. This race is the nastiest of the season. It began when the Assembly leadership approved new district lines that helped the new incumbent, Joni Yoswein, at the expense of another incumbent, James Brennan. Mr. Brennan has conducted a mud-slinging campaign that turns on Ms. Yoswein's former job as an aide to former Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, convicted last year on fraud charges in connection with his private law practice.
Mr. Brennan raises troubling questions about her role in a possibly improper use of Mr. Miller's campaign funds for his defense. She admits to poor judgment, but denies illegality. Both sides have now engaged in ugly campaigning but Mr. Brennan stepped over the line by trying to tar Ms. Yoswein unfairly with guilt by association.
Mr. Brennan has been hard-working and independent but not notably effective in four terms. We prefer Ms. Yoswein. In her brief eight months in office, she has shown admirable energy and savvy. 51st District. Voters have five qualified candidates to choose from: Beatrice Byrd, an elementary school teacher; Marilyn Kneeland, a lawyer and former legislative aide; Juan Perez, a college administrator; Javier Nieves, an architect who has run an impressive, issue-based campaign, and John Kennedy O'Hara, a lawyer and community leader. In a close call, we support the determined Mr. O'Hara because of his feel for the district and keen interest in stimulating the local economy.
54th District. Thomas Catapano, first elected in 1983, runs a solid district office and serves competently in Albany. Neither F. Louis Caraballo, a lawyer, nor Darryl Towns, a hospital official, offers a compelling reason to unseat him.
58th District. We recommend N. Nick Perry, community board member and an official in the state office of mental health. He understands government and has a special interest in education. His most impressive opponent, Mae West, a nurse and anesthetist, has an admirable record of fighting youth drug abuse but is politically unseasoned.
THE BRONX.
76th District. In this crowded race, we endorse Peter Rivera, an attorney and past president of the Puerto Rican Bar Association in New York. His command of issues and community involvement make him preferable to his two main rivals, George Sanchez, a civilian official in the New York Police Department, and Armando Montano Jr., a lawyer.

HEADLINE: At Last, a Bush Package

 BODY:
President Bush: Welcome to the debate. Yesterday, almost four years after taking office, he issued an "Agenda for American Renewal" that comprises a coherent statement of economic objectives and policies. It calls for making the U.S. a strong exporter, educating disadvantaged children, sharpening competitiveness, cutting government waste, helping the poor and protecting workers.
There's certainly nothing wrong with that list of priorities. And the program's coherence will help frame a more constructive campaign debate. Yet while sensible, the President's agenda is also deficient in two ways. 
 First, candor. Readers would never suspect that economic recovery is nowhere in sight, that productivity has stagnated for 20 years, or that the gap between rich and poor has widened alarmingly.
Second, substance. The agenda offers no ammunition to fight unemployment that traumatizes millions. And what lies behind Mr. Bush's sound priorities are many stale, ineffectual remedies.
The President laid out six issues, into which a myriad of previous proposals are fitted:
TRADE: The plan starts out exactly right. The key to growth is to transform America into a lean, mean competitor. To that end he embraces the recently completed trade agreement with Mexico and Canada and the continuing work on international trade. He highlights his glaring difference with Gov. Bill Clinton, who has provided only grudging support for the talks with Mexico.
CHILDREN: Mr. Bush repeats wise, but inadequate, proposals to pour more money into education and nutrition programs targeted on the poor. The centerpiece of his plan is school choice. Yet the President has not faced up to the tormenting problem of children left behind in blighted schools.
COMPETITIVENESS: Here Mr. Bush descends into irrelevance. Tax cuts here and there might make sense. But add them together and the economy would hardly budge. Twenty years of slow growth is frightening; the economy needs a jolt of investment. Mr. Clinton's plan for widespread investment in transportation infrastructure, communication systems and worker training might not work as advertised, but at least it attempts to confront the magnitude of the problem.
WORKER SECURITY: Mr. Bush calls for more job training. Sound objective, but his specific suggestions, by leaving out most low-skilled workers, don't match his promises.
THE DISADVANTAGED: The President rightly points to the 1988 welfare reform act as the best way to help the long-term unemployed. But he still has not proposed putting up the money needed.
"RIGHT-SIZING" GOVERNMENT: Here Mr. Bush has some fun. He challenges Congress to cut its budget by one-third, which he promises to match.
At the end of his agenda the President lists an eye-catching 13-point plan for education reform, job training, health care reform, tax cuts, government reorganization, legal reform, crime control and election reform. Admirable ideas; they would have been more so four years ago.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Won't Cut Illegal Immigration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "We Gain. Mexico Gains. Canada Gains." (Op-Ed, Aug. 14), Michael Boskin expresses the widely held view that improving the Mexican economy through a Free Trade Agreement would reduce pressures for Mexican illegal immigration across our southern border. 
 That view ignores the driving force behind illegal immigration from Mexico -- the explosive growth of its population and labor force.
Mexico's population of more than 88 million is growing at a 2.3 percent annual rate, thus adding about two million a year to its numbers. If this rate continues, its population will double in 30 years, to 176 million.
Mexico's 33 million labor force is growing even more rapidly, about 3.1 percent annually, throwing roughly one million new jobseekers into the labor market each year. Mexico must therefore create at least one million jobs a year just to keep pace with the growth of its labor force.
But roughly 16 million people -- 40 percent to 50 percent of the work force -- are unemployed or underemployed, according to most reliable estimates. It is extremely unlikely that Mexico can maintain an economic growth rate that will let it create jobs for the one million new entrants into the labor force each year, much less make a dent in the 16 million unemployed and underemployed.
It is very clear therefore that the pressures that drive millions of Mexicans across our southern border illegally each year in search of jobs will continue for the foreseeable future.
Our immigration policy should be based on realistic analysis, not on wishful thinking. We are simply deluding ourselves if we believe that improved economic conditions in the immigrant-sending countries will solve the problem of illegal immigration. That may eventually happen, but the process is likely to be measured, not even in decades, but in centuries.
Until now our Federal Government has done little to halt illegal immigration. That deplorable situation is contrary to our national interest, and must not continue. I would urge the Presidential candidates to address this vital issue.
 
DONALD MANN
 Pres., Negative Population Growth
 Teaneck, N.J., Aug. 27, 1992

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Job Losses Put as High as 150,000

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin conceded that the North American Free Trade Agreement could put up to 150,000 Americans out of work, while Democrats asserted that the President's plan to help them was inadequate.
Under persistent questioning by members of the Senate Finance Committee, Ms. Martin became the first Administration official to provide an estimate of American jobs that would be lost with the elimination of trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. 
 Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has been asked repeatedly for an official figure in various Congressional hearings and briefings but has stressed only the many economic studies showing that job gains would exceed job losses over all.
Some economists suggest that if the agreement changes the mood of American executives toward Mexico, making them more inclined to invest there, then job losses could be heavy and blue-collar wages in the United States could be hurt.
Partly because investment psychology is difficult to quantify, most studies have focused on the tiny size of the Mexican economy, the shortage of educated workers there and the existing low level of United States tariffs on imports from Mexico. These studies have concluded that the elimination of trade barriers will not make a big difference in persuading companies to build factories there to supply the United States market.
Ms. Martin said the Administration would set aside $330 million a year for five years to help workers who lose their jobs because of the agreement, and was prepared to spend up to $750 million a year if necessary.
But Democratic senators criticized the plan because it would require Congress to triple spending on job-training programs next year and because the Administration has not suggested any specific spending cuts or new taxes to pay for this, planning instead to include the programs in next January's budget and pay for them out general revenues.
 
20 Studies Reviewed
 Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, asked Ms. Martin several questions about how the Labor Department calculated the need for the extra money. She eventually responded that the program was based on a loss of up to 150,000 jobs over 10 years, and said this was the highest job-loss figure among 20 studies her department had reviewed, including a University of Maryland study commissioned by the department.
Under further questioning by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, Ms. Martin said that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had predicted the loss of 500,000 jobs but that her department had not included this estimate in its review. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. opposes the free trade accord even if it is coupled with a retraining package, because union leaders contend that there will be few jobs for the retrained workers.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, on Wednesday called for the renegotiation of the pact, saying its labor and environmental provisions were inadequate. Mrs. Hills said at a seminar on Latin American issues at the State Department today that it was not feasible to reopen the negotiations.
Mrs. Hills told Congress this week that if companies sought low wages alone with their foreign investments then many poor countries would be economic powerhouses. She has also asserted many times that nothing prevents American companies from moving to Mexico now.
But the companies themselves have been wary of Mexico's political situation and of the security of new investments there. The pact, the text of which was released on Tuesday, will not only guarantee duty-free access to the American market for factories in Mexico but also provide extraordinary legal protections.
For example, several provisions buried in Chapter 11 of the agreement would allow American companies to appeal to a special bilateral panel if the Mexican Government expropriates their investments or takes other legal actions to reduce their value.
Only nine other countries, all of them developing nations eager to attract foreign investment, allow similar legal recourse for American companies. Most countries only accept such complaints from governments, which forces American companies to embark on the arduous task of enlisting Washington's support.
American companies have already built many factories in northern Mexico because of a rule allowing them to assemble products there from American parts and then ship them duty-free back to the United States. Employment in these factories climbed to 500,000 last year from 120,000 in 1980.
The effects of this shift have been little analyzed. A Stanford University study estimated last year that the average low-wage American worker's annual earnings in the year 2000 would be $50 lower with a free trade agreement than without one. But if heavy investment in Mexico accompanies the agreement then the average annual earnings would be $200 lower, the study found.
The same study found that high-wage workers would gain more than low-wage workers would lose, suggesting that the agreement would have a positive effect on the nation's economy.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 12, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement described Labor Secretary Lynn Martin's comments incompletely. In addition to saying that up to 150,000 jobs could be lost, she cited studies predicting that even more jobs could be gained.

HEADLINE: Homestead, Trying to Get Up, Is Knocked Flat by Base Vote

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 11

 BODY:
Just as the first glimmers of normalcy have started to appear in the hurricane-battered city of Homestead, more setbacks are arising.
A Winn-Dixie supermarket finally opened Wednesday, the Rite-Aid Pharmacy is filling prescriptions and the traffic light is again operating in the center of Homestead's old downtown, small signs to weary people living without electricity and drinkable water since Aug. 24 that life might someday again be normal. 
 But on Thursday came word that despite pledges by President Bush, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Gov. Lawton Chiles and many local officials, the Senate Appropriations Committee voted not to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base, which was virtually destroyed by Hurricane Andrew.
"It's like when you're down and they just keep hitting you," said John Kirkus, a Homestead resident who has worked at the base for 20 years and is now a civilian crew chief for the Air Force Reserve there. "Agriculture's been hit hard, tourism's been hit hard. If you take the base away I think the whole city will fold up."
Today there was more bad news for Homestead. The Cleveland Indians announced that they had put off plans to hold spring training at a newly built stadium in Homestead. City officials said the tin roof over the grandstand was blown off and some sky boxes were torn up, about $10 million in damage.
"We can have the stadium ready, but we can't have the infrastructure back in shape," said Alex Muxo Jr., Homestead's City Manager. The Indians said they weren't sure just where they would be this spring but said they did plan to train in Homestead in 1994 and would play two games here next spring against the Florida Marlins, a new American League expansion team.
Mr. Muxo said the city understood the Cleveland team's decision. But the Senate committee's action on the air base is another matter.
"I don't think it's right to do that," said Tony Johnson, Homestead resident, as he waited at a phone kiosk outside City Hall to talk to an official from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. "What about the people down here?"
The 3,300-acre Homestead base is a mainstay of the local economy and of the town's identity, from the landmark fighter jet that was blown off its pedestal on U.S. 1 to the 8,400 military and civilian personnel it employs and the $405 million it pumps into the local economy each year.
President Bush had included $480 million to rebuild the base in his $7.6 billion rescue plan for South Florida, but the Senate committee voted 12 to 8 to include only $26 million for the base's cleanup as part of a $7.5 billion relief package, which in effect would insure that the base never reopens.
But Homestead is not giving up without a fight. "What people have to understand is that the base shouldn't be an economic issue," said Mr. Muxo. "If the base had a mission prior to Andrew it has a mission after Andrew. We shouldn't take advantage of a natural disaster to close a base."
 
Arguing the Base's Merits
 That was an argument also made by Senator Connie Mack, a Florida Republican, who joined Governor Chiles and Florida's other Senator, Bob Graham, a Democrat, in promising to fight for the base when the President's disaster-aid bill reaches the Senate floor, perhaps Tuesday or Wednesday.
"It's certainly more than just the economic foundation," Senator Mack said in an interview broadcast on Fox Morning News. "It is the base that's the most southern base in the United States, keeping an eye on the Caribbean and on Fidel Castro, and it is also the base that we use for drug interdiction."
Mr. Muxo said that even if the Senate did not reinstate the money, the city would try to persuade the Congressional Base Closure Commission that Homestead should be reopened. Homestead was not included on the commission's list of 34 military bases recommended for closing, but before the storm it was expected to be on a future list.
If all else fails, some here say, perhaps the base could be reconstituted as a second commercial airport for the Miami metropolitan area. But such a solution could be years off, and what the people of Homestead and other towns in south Dade County say they need is help now.
 
Double Sessions at Schools
 The rejection from Washington came after several days of slight, hard-won improvements here. School begins Monday, though 10 schools have been closed. The children from those schools will be sent to other schools, which will hold double sessions.
The Winn-Dixie supermarket was dark today, and many shelves were pockmarked with unfamiliar empty spaces. But the customers did not mind.
"It feels so funny shopping again," said Cynthia McNichols of Homestead. She was in a store, without having to wait in line, for the first time since the storm hit. The first thing she reached for was laundry detergent. "The laundromat's just opened up too," she said.
The supermarket's bakery and cheese shop were up and running, but the fish counter was dark because the store didn't have the water to make ice.
Health officials today lifted orders to boil water before drinking it in all of Dade County except Homestead and Florida City, which could be cleared next week. Banks are open, some gas stations have gasoline and no lines, and the Checkers fast-food restaurant had a line of about 20 people this afternoon.
Up in Goulds, about 10 miles north of Homestead, Kim Marie Ernspiker was looking forward to getting her mail delivered on Monday, even though she has been told not to expect electricity until Thanksgiving. Rod Jude, who grows ornamental plants in Goulds, was expecting a shipment of wood this afternoon to rebuild large sheds blown away by the hurricane.
In Florida City, the Last Chance Saloon, on the edge of the Everglades, was serving beer to shirtless construction workers and bar hogs who have come in to get out of the sun. A sign spray-painted on the plywood over the front windows facing U.S. 1 proclaimed, "This is really your last chance now."
Across the road, Mel Riff, in a striped polo shirt and wearing a diamond-studded Mercedes Benz ring, was busy selling mobile homes even though hundreds of them had been obliterated in the storm's high winds.
"Only four people got killed in this disaster in mobile homes, out of 6,000 units," he said. "That's not good but its not as bad as people are led to believe."
So far, 100 people have put down deposits on new homes since Mr. Riff set up his operation on Sunday.
Judy Allen of Fort Lauderdale was there Thursday with her 76-year-old father-in-law, Gordon Allen, whose mobile home was destroyed. He signed a check for a down payment on a new one costing more than $20,000 that would go in the same space as the old one.
"What he wants is the same comaraderie he had before," said Mrs. Allen. "The same group played poker every afternoon, bingo on a couple of nights and had good-bye parties to the snow birds when they left to go back home."
Mr. Allen wants what he had before and that, in essence, is what everyone here wants, even if they realize how unlikely that is.
"People now are worrying about laundry detergent and deodorant instead of food and water," said Katie Mitchell, an assistant city manager in Homestead. "But are we getting back to normal? Normal radically changed on August 24th."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mel Riff in Florida City, Fla., was busy selling mobile homes even though hundreds like them had been obliterated in the storm's high winds. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
JET SALE TO SAUDIS APPROVED BY BUSH, SAVING JOBS IN U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11

 BODY:
President Bush tore apart his campaign schedule today to put on another demonstration of the powers of the Oval Office, dropping into St. Louis to hand out what the White House called a $9 billion deal to sell advanced F-15 fighters to Saudi Arabia.
It was the second time in nine days that Mr. Bush had dispensed this sort of plum contract to the American arms industry, helping secure thousands of jobs in states like Missouri, Texas and California, where a major part of the battle for the Presidency will be fought this fall. 
 Mr. Bush made the announcement at a time when it poses the least political risk. With the Labor Party's ascension to power in Israel and clear signs of progress in the Middle East peace process, neither the Israeli Government nor American Jews are likely to put up the sort of opposition to the sale that they might have just a few months ago.
 
Congress Unlikely to Block Sale
 Congress, which has 30 days to try to block the sale if it chooses to do so, is unlikely to oppose a job-saving deal of this kind during a campaign that is turning on the nation's sluggish economy and high unemployment rate.
According to the White House, the President has now given out more than $23 billion in Federal subsidies, foreign arms-sales contracts and hurricane-related disaster assistance in slightly more than a week as he campaigns for re-election in a nation gripped by recession and, according to opinion polls, unhappy with Mr. Bush's economic performance.
Some of this largess, notably the disaster relief, comes at the expense of taxpayers. But the arms sales, particularly, bring new money into the country. Last week the President flew to Fort Worth to announce a $6 billion sale of 150 F-16 fighters to Taiwan. Today he canceled an appearance at a trucking company in Joplin, Mo., at the last minute and flew to the McDonnell Douglas aircraft plant here for about a half hour to tell a cheering crowd that he was approving the sale of 72 F-15 fighter planes to the Saudis.
 
Compliment to the Workers
 Standing in front of a newly minted F-15, its cockpit canopy ajar, Mr. Bush told the workers that "the military technology you produce is the finest in the world" -- the same compliment that he paid to the F-16 production line at the General Dynamics plant in Texas last week.
"I am aware that the past few years have been difficult for this company and a lot of Americans as they adjust to a new future," Mr. Bush told the McDonnell Douglas workers here, adding, "In this time of economic transition, I want to do everything I can to keep Americans at work."
White House aides and campaign officials explained today's sudden change of plans by saying Mr. Bush had made his final decision on the sale Thursday night. But it had been widely known in Washington that the decision was made, by and large, after Mr. Bush received assurances from Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin last month that the Israeli Government would not object.
Today the Conference of Presidents of American Jewish Organizations said it was "wary" of the proposed sale but pointedly did not mention any plans to fight it -- especially since the President had given assurances that he intended "to maintain Israel's qualitative edge" in armaments, the organization's statement said.
In Washington this afternoon, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney met with the Israeli Ambassador, Zalman Shoval, apparently to reassure him of Washington's commitment to maintaining Israel's technological edge in the region.
In Congress, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, has made it clear he would support the sale. It would, after all, produce jobs in or near his district.
 
Some Objection Expressed
 But Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, the ranking Republican on the Senate Subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, did offer a commonly voiced objection when he said: "I'm greatly disturbed about it. If we're the world leader and if we're serious about the proliferation of weapons in the Middle East, we ought not be out front selling to Saudi Arabia. We ought to be leaning extremely hard on the British and anyone else not to sell to them."
The announcement lent some news value to what was otherwise a day of small-bore events in small Missouri towns where Mr. Bush promoted his economic programs.
At Missouri Southern State College in Joplin, the glee club warmed up the crowd by singing "It's My Party and I'll Cry If I Want To." Gazing out at the campus lawn, Mr. Bush spoke of the First Family's dog, saying, "I think Millie would like it out here in this oval, I'll tell you."
In Joplin and at a job training center in Excelsior Springs near Kansas City, Mr. Bush tried out a new punch line intended for its television appeal. Borrowing from the popular horror film series "Nightmare on Elm Street" to press his argument that the Democratic nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, is trying to play on fear in his campaign, Mr. Bush said, "Governor Clinton is running a Freddy Krueger candidacy."
 
Speech Before Robertson Group
 Mr. Bush left Missouri for Virginia Beach, where he spoke tonight to the Rev. Pat Robertson's political organization, a chore that Mr. Bush finds politically necessary as he seeks to shore up his right wing.
The speech was at the Founders Inn, part of a convention center complex owned by the Christian Broadcasting Network, and it has a policy of hiring only Christians, said Gene Kapp, the network's media director.
"The hiring policy is the same as that of the Chistian Broadcasting Network" as a whole, he added.
As a matter of policy, the F-15 sale did not carry the same impact as the sale of the planes to Taiwan, which marked a reversal of 10 years of American policy. The United States has sold 93 F-15's to Saudi Arabia over the years, starting in the Carter Administration. But as a matter of politics, both sales carried the same implications as Mr. Bush tries to put the power of his incumbency behind his campaign for re-election.
White House aides and Pentagon officials said the sale would produce $9 billion in revenue, $5 billion for the 72 planes themselves and the rest in contracts for parts and maintenance, and generate $3 billion in taxes. The White House said it would save 40,000 jobs in Missouri, California, Connecticut and 42 other states.
Without the deal, the F-15 production line would shut down in November. The Bush Administration canceled the F-15 program as part of the cuts in military spending.
 
Jobs Termed 'Major Factor'
 The White House insisted, as it has with each measure of Federal largess Mr. Bush has doled out in recent days, that his action today had nothing to do with the campaign. "It provides a credible Saudi defensive deterrent, helps protect vital American interests in the Persian Gulf and reduces the amount of U.S. force needed in the region," a White House statement said.
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the jobs involved were a "major factor" in the decision. But Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, said, "Anybody who says that an announcement of the sale in 1992 is for politics is full of beans."
Mr. Bond predicted that the sale would not be blocked by Congress, which does not have to give its approval but can block the deal with a two-thirds majority vote within 30 days.

U.S. Satellites for China
 WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Waiving legislative restrictions, the State Department announced today that China would be allowed to buy six communications satellites, a decision that could yield worth more than $650 million for United States exporters.
It was the latest of the election-year announcements increasing exports and protecting jobs for American workers.
The export of satellite technology to China has been barred since the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators there in 1989, unless the Bush Administration issued a waiver. The exports affected by today's announcement are for the Apstart, Asiasat 2, Intelsat VIIA, Starsat, AfriStar and Dong Fang Hong 3 projects.
 
 
 
THE PRESIDENT'S PROMISES
 Since the Republican National Convention, President Bush has made a variety of proposals and promises that would provide benefits to special economic sectors or geographic regions. Here is a summary:
 
Sept. 1, Homestead, Fla. -- Visting the Florida sites most damaged by the hurricane, he committed the Government to footing the entire cost of rebuilding the region's shattered schools, bridges, hospitals, roads and other public facilities and pledged to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base. On Sept. 8, he asked Congress for $7.6 billion to help hurricane victims in both Florida and Louisiana, including $500 million for the Homestead Air Force base reconstruction.
 
Sept. 2, Fort Worth, Tex. -- At a General Dynamics Corporation plant, he announced that he had approved the sale of up to 150 of the company's F-16 fighters to Taiwan, a deal that could eventually bring American factories up to $6 billion in contracts and related benefits.
 
Sept. 2, Humboldt, S.D. and Shallowater, Tex. -- The same day, he told farmers he would spend $1 billion to subsidize American wheat sales abroad. He also promised $755 million more in aid to farmers whose crops were damaged by Hurricane Andrew and by flooding in East Texas last spring.
 
Yesterday, St. Louis -- Speaking to workers at the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, he announces approval of the sale of 72 F-15 jet fighters to Saudi Arabia, a sale valued at as much as $9 billion and expected to save the jobs of 7,000 military workers.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Half-price summer air fares were a disaster for the airline industry, analysts say. Although the low fares put record numbers of passengers into airplanes, they did little to help an industry that has lost more than $6 billion in the last two years. [Page 1.]
McDonnell Douglas will be able to retain one of its largest and most lucrative weapons programs and preserve thousands of jobs as a result of the Bush Administration's decision to approve a multibillion-dollar sale of F-15 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia. [35.]
Honda will end its participation in Formula One auto racing to turn its attention to making low-polluting engines. [35.]
A U.S. decision not to build a nuclear plant used to make atomic weapons is a blow to two groups of industrial companies. [5.]
The New York Times announced three major editing appointments. Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor, will become editor of The New York Times Magazine and an assistant managing editor; Howell Raines, Washington editor, will succeed him, and Warren Hoge, an assistant managing editor and editor of the magazine, will take charge of culture and style coverage and other features. [9.]
A bankruptcy judge set a new deadline for resolving who is to own The Daily News. Mortimer B. Zuckerman now has until Thursday to reach agreements with those opposing his bid. [25.]
G. Fox & Company stores will be closed and merged into the Filene's chain by their parent, May Department Stores. [26.]
 
 The Economy
The Justice Department sought a heavy prison sentence for the manager of the Atlanta branch of the Italian-owned Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, who pleaded guilty to charges involving an estimated $5 billion in unauthorized loans to Iraq. [33.]
Prices paid by wholesalers rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in August despite big increases in fruits and vegetables. [34.]
 
International
London's standing as a financial center is being challenged byEuropean unification, the expansion of stock markets on the Continent and the growing dominance of Germany. [33.]
The Commerce Department moved to impose punitive customs duties on steel from certain foreign companies. [33.]
With Italy's lira slipping closer to devaluation and the country's huge deficit swelling, the Prime Minister faces an autumn of discontent after a summer in which he could do no wrong. [2.]
Boris N. Yeltsin denounced the Russian central bank, saying its policies were pushing the Russian economy toward an abyss. [3.]
Ireland's prime minister is coming to the United States to urge companies to open operations in his country. [4.]
 
 Markets
The stock market drifted through an indecisive session, with the Dow average inching ahead 0.54 point, to 3,305.70. [36.]
Treasury bond prices fell despite good news on inflation as investors sold securities for technical reasons. [36.]
The dollar rose against most currencies amid growing pressure on Germany to lower its interest rates. [43.] The forecast for a larger wheat and soybean harvest sent grain prices lower. [43.]

Jake, a 2 1/2-foot gold-plated robot who "sees" in color through a camera in his right eye, "hears" out of both his pointy ears and works a crowd like a politician is a new kind of Hollywood movie star, according to his inventor. Patents. [33.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Lucrative McDonnell Aircraft Gets a Reprieve

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's decision today to approve a multibillion-dollar sale of F-15 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia will allow the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to retain one of its largest and most lucrative weapons programs. The sale, which is expected to be approved by Congress, will also preserve thousands of jobs in the military industry at a time when Pentagon spending is declining.
St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military supplier, has no new orders for the F-15 beyond the 45 that will be delivered to the United States Air Force beginning in 1994. The contractor had said that without the Saudi order for 72 jets, the F-15 production line would close, leading to the loss of as many as 40,000 aerospace jobs, including those of subcontractors nationwide. 
 The Saudi deal, valued at $5.6 billion, is expected to increase McDonnell Douglas's revenues by about 10 percent a year through 1997, aerospace industry analysts said, adding that the deal would allow the company to seek additional F-15 orders. The analysts said that Israel and Germany were potential customers and that the United States Air Force might place additional orders.
 
Analyst Sees a Reprieve
 "The F-15 is one of the most mature and profitable weapons programs around, and the Saudi sale really gives it a new lease on life," said Jerry Cantwell, an analyst who follows the aerospace industry for Wertheim Schroder & Company. Mr. Cantwell predicted that the Saudi purchase would increase McDonnell's revenues by $800 million to $1 billion a year.
The Saudi deal will keep the F-15 assembly line, which was scheduled to close by 1994, open through 1997, saving an estimated 6,000 jobs in St. Louis and Tulsa, Okla., where the two main production plants are situated. McDonnell Douglas officials said yesterday that the sale might allow them to call back some of the 1,000 workers who have already been laid off because of declines in F-15 production.
In California, the contract is expected to save 4,000 jobs and generate $1.5 billion in business for the Hughes Aircraft Company's radar system divisions in El Segundo and Fullerton and 300 other subcontractors in Southern California.
The company, some subcontractors and several labor unions have waged an intense lobbying effort in recent weeks to persuade the Administration to approve the sale.
Nancy Colaguori, a spokeswoman for Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, which makes the F-15's engines, said yesterday that the Saudi contract would preserve 1,300 manufacturing jobs at a Pratt & Whitney plant in Hartford and 200 research and development jobs in Florida.
Saudi Arabia has asked to buy 48 F-15E and 24 F-15H planes. The F-15E is an advanced air-to-ground attack version of the F-15, which the Air Force used during the war with Iraq. The F-15H is a two-seat version for air-to-air combat.
 
Less Radar Capability
 Under the plan announced today, the Administration approved the sale of 72 F-15's, without specifying which version could be sold; that will be determined later. Officials of McDonnell Douglas said the Administration had excluded the F-15E from the sale, so the Saudis would receive a less-sophisticated version of the F-15 that has less radar capability.
As the nation's biggest military contractor, McDonnell Douglas has benefited greatly from the weapons buildup during the 1980's, but it has been suffering of late as three of its largest production programs -- the F-15, the Marine Corps' AV-8B Harrier attack jet and the Army's AH-64 Apache helicopter -- faced cancellation in the next few years.
Analysts said yesterday that the profit margins on the deal should be high for McDonnell Douglas, which long ago recovered its initial investment in the F-15 program.
"As long as you keep the production line open there's always hope that further business will come along in the form of foreign sales," said Paul H. Nisbet, an analyst with Prudential Securities. Mr. Nisbet had estimated that McDonnell Douglas would earn $12 to $13 a share in 1995, 1996, and 1997. He now expects a 10 percent increase because of the Saudi business.
 
'Substantial Benefit'
 John F. McDonnell, the chairman and chief executive of McDonnell Douglas, said the $5.6 billion contract would be of "substantial benefit" to the company. "I really do not want to project earnings but you can assume it will have a normal earnings rate for a production program," he said.
While McDonnell Douglas officials declined to say what the Saudi sale would mean to company's finances, industry analysts speculated that the contractor would use the infusion of cash from the sale to reduce debt. As of this year's second quarter, McDonnell Douglas had $2.8 billion of debt.
Shares of McDonnell Douglas closed today at $42.75, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Challenge to London's Lofty Role

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
This city's standing as a major financial center has survived the end of the British Empire, the rise in economic power of New York and Tokyo and the rapid changes that have swept banking, insurance and the securities business.
Now London is being challenged again, this time by the fitful movement toward European unification, the expansion of stock markets on the Continent and the growing dominance of Germany over Europe's economic affairs. 
 Despite an intense lobbying campaign, London will almost certainly lose out to Frankfurt or another city on the Continent when the European Community chooses a site for the planned European central bank. That loss, though a blow to London's prestige, would be largely symbolic. And if plans for European unification are derailed when France votes on whether to accept the unification treaty later this month, the notion of a central bank might even become moot.
 
Stock Markets Grow
 But London faces other issues that will not fade even if the pace of European economic integration is slowed. The growth and modernization of stock markets in Frankfurt, Paris and other European trading centers is likely to nibble away at the dominance of the City, London's financial district. German financial institutions are ahead in the race to build a presence in Eastern Europe, perhaps leaving London a secondary share of a market that is hungry for financial services. Frankfurt and other cities are trying to develop expertise in emerging markets like the trading of bonds denominated in European Currency Units, a business now centered in London.
"Within Europe the potential competition in financial services comes primarily from Frankfurt and Paris, and it is the prospect of a single market in financial services within Europe that has led to the possibility of significant shifts in market share," said a report on London's future as a financial center that was issued this summer by a team at the London Business School.
A falloff in London's standing would be a major blow to the prestige of Britain, a nation that has difficulty claiming to remain a world power. And the effects of any erosion in London's position could be practical as well as symbolic. In 1989, 620,000 people -- or one out of every six people employed -- worked in financial services in London, making it the biggest employer here.
Government officials and industry executives here and throughout Europe said that London retained formidable strengths and was unlikely to cede to Frankfurt, Paris or any other city its role as Europe's financial capital, at least not anytime soon.
With the world's currencies being roiled by the rise in value of the German mark and the decline of the dollar, it is London that dominates the foreign-exchange markets, with an estimated 25 percent of all currency trading, compared with 17 percent for New York, according to a survey by the Bank for International Settlements, which is a clearinghouse for central banks and a forum for policy coordination.
As the securities and banking businesses have become increasingly global, the number of foreign banks and securities firms in London has continued to grow. The number of foreign banks operating here topped 500 last year, nearly triple the level 20 years ago. The number of foreign securities firms grew to 160 last year, almost four times as many as in 1970.
Executives here said that London might lose some types of business to the Continent, especially in stock and bond trading. But they said that London, which unlike New York and Tokyo is focused primarily on international financial transactions rather than its domestic market, stands to gain business over all from the surge in international finance activities that is accompanying the establishment of a single European market. If Europe does hold to its current plan of having a single currency before the end of the decade, they said, London would be especially qualified to handle the industry's pan-European financing needs.
"Business gravitates to the entity that has the greatest comparative advantage," said the London Business School study, which was commissioned by the Corporation of London, the local governmental authority in the City. "If London has, as its dominance suggests, such an advantage in the production of financial services, then there is reason to believe that freer trade in financial services will be to London's benefit."
 
Gains for Frankfurt and Paris
 Still, many financial institutions that have always seen London as the primary place from which to do business across Europe and around the world said they increasingly saw other cities offering new opportunities that London might not be able to match. Most banks and investment houses are beefing up their presences in Frankfurt, Paris and other cities, although not, so far, at the expense of their operations in London. Merrill Lynch, for example, is moving more heavily into Germany, where it is seeking to expand its business selling German stocks and bonds.
"No one thinks Frankfurt will be bigger than London in a few years," said Peter Dietlmaier, an executive at Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt. "But Frankfurt could be the major place for bankers looking for business in continental Europe, and with the new structures in the stock exchanges it could also be the place for investors on the Continent."
The dominant financial trend in Europe now, industry executives said, is the expansion of domestic capital markets in Germany, France and other nations. More companies are starting to adopt United States-style pension funds, a trend that should increase institutional investing on the Continent. Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. estimated recently that there could be a doubling of assets under institutional management in Europe in this decade.
"There's going to be a flowering of equity market capitalization throughout the rest of Europe," said Giles Keating, the chief economist for Credit Suisse First Boston in London.
Initially at least, those funds will tend to be invested in local markets. German pension fund managers, for example, will tend to invest in German markets, analysts said. That trend will help those local markets grow rapidly and become more liquid, increasing their appeal to foreign investors as well. As a result, some executives said, London could lose some portion of its business.
 
'Bound to Decrease'
 "London's share of financial market activity is bound to decrease as a percentage of the whole," said Herschel Post, the chief operating officer at Lehman Brothers International in London. "The Germans, for example, will take great pride in building their own markets and doing business in Germany with German-speaking personnel."
But Mr. Post said that at the same time, the development of the single European market would encourage more cross-border financial and investment transactions. Since international transactions have long been London's strength, much of that business will flow to the City.
"Within the E.C. the trends are overwhelmingly toward increased interpenetration of markets," Mr. Post said. "That means London has a huge advantage over Frankfurt, Paris and Milan, all of which do their best to make foreigners feel like chumps."
But executives here said that London would have to overcome a number of problems to insure its pre-eminence in international finance. Within the securities industry there has been considerable unhappiness over the slow pace at which the London Stock Exchange has introduced a new paperless settlement system. Some executives said that the national Government had failed to be as responsive to the needs of the financial services industry as governments in France and other nations, which have made concerted efforts to overhaul securities and tax regulations in an effort to attract more foreign investors.
So far, most executives here, while insisting they are not blind to the problems facing London, remain relatively sanguine.
"I think London will settle down to having a good future," said the head of one large investment bank here, who asked not to be identified. "Bits of the business will depart to places like Frankfurt, and bits will go back to New York. This will be a blip that takes a while to recover from, but it's not the end of London as a financial center."

GRAPHIC: Photo: London's powerful financial district could lose ground to Frankfurt, Paris and other European trading centers even if the European unification treaty is not ratified later this month. The NatWest Tower, left, and the Stock Exchange are pictured on Throgmorton Street in London. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)
