HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits with Americans;
2 Old Truman Hands Guard the Boss's Name

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CATONSVILLE, Md., Sept. 9

 BODY:
This year the spin doctors are trying to spin time itself. But amid the confusion of memories welling up lately from 11 Presidential campaigns ago, there is an old whistle-stop speech writer here who recalls with first-hand authority how his boss, President Harry S. Truman, used a word -- "trimmer" -- to tersely dismiss any fellow politician he rated a hypocrite.
"He'd say 'trimmer' for anyone who would say one thing and do another," recalled David H. Stowe, an 82-year-old veteran of the Truman White House. "Like Bush saying 'no new taxes,' " said the weathered partisan who served his master variously, from poker table to the now fondly remembered 1948 campaign. That was the classic come-from-behind victory that, incongruously for this nostalgia-filled retiree, President Bush has lately been invoking. 
 "Trimmer," declared Mr. Stowe, legally blind and somewhat lame lately but still well in tune with the mind of Truman. "He'd say, 'Ah, that feller's just a trimmer.' "
There were a great many elements that made the 1948 campaign something to remember. One was the decision to scrap the boring "Missouri Waltz" and have the high school bands in the first Texas whistle-stop tour play the far more snappy "I'm Just Wild About Harry."
 
Believer in Politics
 This was the decision -- made without benefit of private market testing or op-ed debate about political correctness -- of Donald Dawson, still a far from retired Washington lawyer who can lay claim to having served as the first modern advance man. He was a pioneer on-the-road scout and trouble-shooter, master of a political art both plodding and subtle that he cherishes anew each campaign autumn for the remembered moments with Truman.
"If the Boss saw 20 people out the window, he'd stop the train," Mr. Dawson recalled in his law office, a short walk from past glory down the block from the White House. "The back platform of the train is where he really hit the people. Off the cuff, he was the best. And he was never afraid about politics."
The idea of not being afraid about politics, of a candidate's trusting the process if only he or she could talk plainly and patiently about issues in front of enough people, was central in Truman's 1948 strategy. Mr. Dawson contends people have not really changed and this approach might work again. But Mr. Stowe has his doubts, in this age when a campaign is strained through the television chamois, voters settle for packaged glimpses, and gaffes draw more consideration than policy positions.
"Truman would have considered television sound bites horrible," he said. The very hypothesis of Truman as a modern politician supporting a tax increase as President and then apologizing for it later as a candidate lends extra amusement to Mr. Stowe's retirement.
 
Still Full of 'Dingers'
 "He raised taxes in 1947 and '48, the campaign year, across the board," Mr. Stowe said of a time when the incumbent's task was to remind people of post-war prosperity and not, as with President Bush's lot, of a badly stalled economy. "Truman said it was like running a family: When you have money, you pay your bills," Mr. Stowe remembered of Truman's campaign talk of taxes.
"I think Clinton is saying something like that this year, though he's just talking about the upper 2 percent tax bracket," the old Democrat continued, smiling slightly as he withheld the "trimmer" label from his party's latest standard bearer.
" 'Tax and spend Democrats'? Why is that worse than 'Borrow and Spend Republicans'?" asked the Fair Dealer. Mr. Stowe laughed at the politics of words. "Maybe I should be writing some of the stuff this year."
Truman loved "clean, rough" partisanship and not pretending to be nonpolitical, said Mr. Stowe. He does a perfect imitation of his President reading a fresh speech from "the Boys," his staff. Truman would arrive at a particularly bare-knuckled touch of partisanship and exult: "That's a dinger! That's a dinger!"
 
Grand Old Days of the Party
 "But when he delivered the speech the dinger usually wasn't there and we figured the fine hand of Mrs. Truman might be at work," said Mr. Stowe.
Out in America, Mr. Dawson learned that real crowd-gathering partisanship was rooted in the old party clubhouses and organizations, not in the sort of telegenic amorphousness of today's campaigns.
"The parties collected the money in those days, but now the PAC's do and so candidates are beholden to a 'cause,' not the party," he said ruefully, of modern political action committees. "I meet people now who say, 'My mother was a precinct worker for the party back then in Philadelphia. She had her heart and soul in it.' Well, that's lost now," said the advance man, looking back to when he couldn't wait for the train to pull up before the whistle-stop crowds so Truman could emerge on the back platform to give the other side more hell.
"My job was to be a jump ahead, getting kids out of school early, finding free buses, whatever it took," said Mr. Dawson. "When the President caught up with me at each stop, I'd brief him on the local situation and he'd quickly adapt his direct comments. His spur of the moment stuff was so good. He always wanted to talk about things the people wanted to know.
"Wonderful," said Mr. Dawson, smiling as his memory darted ahead then doubled back like an advance man along one of the most exhaustive and fruitful hustings in history. In a way, he and Mr. Stowe, the advance man and the speech writer, are still working on the '48 campaign, shielding it from myth, protecting their enduring memory of Truman as he worked tirelessly at a kind of politics that seems charming now in the retrospect of the latest campaign.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Truman said it was like running a family: When you have money, you pay your bills," said David H. Stowe, a speech writer for Harry S. Truman, of Truman's campaign talk of taxes. With Mr. Stowe was his wife, Mildred, in their apartment in Catonsville, Md. "When the President caught up with me at each stop, I'd brief him on the local situation and he'd quickly adapt his direct comments," said Donald Dawson, another Truman aide. "His spur of the moment stuff was so good. He always wanted to talk about things the people wanted to know." (Photographs by Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 0.54 in Indecisive Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market drifted through an indecisive session yesterday, making little headway after the rally of the last two sessions.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials inched ahead 0.54, to 3,305.70, finishing the holiday-shortened week with a net gain of 23.77 points. 
 Declining issues led advances by a slight margin on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to 180.6 million shares against 222 million in the previous session.
The day began with some favorable, but expected, news on inflation. The Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index of Finished Goods edged up only one-tenth of a percent in August. The so-called core index, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, dropped one-tenth of a percent after rising two-tenths of a percent in July.
 
Optimism Reinforced
 Analysts said that news reinforced Wall Street's optimism that inflation remained subdued. Similarly upbeat news is expected next week in the Consumer Price Index report for last month.
Stock traders seemed to have other uncertainties on their minds, however, including the recent tumult in European interest rates and currency markets.
National Semiconductor was the volume leader, down 1/8 at 11 7/8, on turnover of more than 2.29 million shares, after rising 7/8 on Thursday, when the company reported first-quarter earnings of 17 cents a share, compared with a loss in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Auto stocks were steady to lower in active trading. General Motors dropped 3/8, to 33 5/8; Ford Motor fell 1 1/8, to 40 1/4, and Chrysler was off 1/8, to 21 3/8.
Biomet, traded in the over-the-counter market, fell 3 1/2, to 18. Analysts noted disappointment over the company's latest quarterly earnings, which were 13 cents a share against 10 cents a share a year earlier.
 
Octel Gains 2
 Octel Communications, another Nasdaq stock, jumped 2, to 22 3/4. The company, which produces voice information-processing equipment, announced an agreement to acquire Tigon, a voice-message service bureau, from Ameritech.
American depository shares of Japanese companies declined broadly after the Tokyo market fell overnight, prompting fears that the rally in Japan since mid-August might have run its course.
Matsushita Electric fell 6, to 96; Kyocera 2 5/8, to 59 5/8; Hitachi 1 7/8, to 63 1/2, and TDK 1/2, to 28 1/4.
Pall, traded on the American Stock Exchange, added 1/8, to 28 5/8, on top of a 1 3/4-point gain Thursday, when the company posted higher earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Aug. 1.
The Amex market-value index rose 1.64, to 386.45, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.77, to 583.01. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.37, to 419.58, and the New York Stock Exchange index gained 0.02, to 230.80.

HEADLINE: As Military Cuts Back, It Still Seeks Recruits

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
At a time when the Pentagon is actually paying people to leave the services, the military is having trouble signing up tens of thousands of new troops, in part because of the overwhelming perception that new recruits are not needed or wanted.
Not so, military officials say. While they are thinning out the middle and higher ranks for a smaller, post-cold war force, the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps still need recruits to insure that the armed forces are properly proportioned for the future. 
 Indeed, the Army alone is aiming to bring in 85,000 new enlisted troops next year; right now it is about 10 percent behind in the number of recruits it has signed up.
In the last five months the Marine Corps has met its goal three times, the Air Force twice and the Navy once; the Army has not reached its goals in any of the last five months.
Through August the Army had met 91 percent of its overall signup goal for 1992, the Air Force 95 percent, the Navy 101 percent and the Marine Corps 103 percent. Strong recruiting earlier this year masked the more recent negative figures.
With the military's recruitment advertising budget nearly cut in half in the last four years -- to $79.4 million next year from $154.9 million in 1989 -- military officials fear that the trend will only worsen.
"I'm not panicking, but the numbers are disturbing," Maj. Gen. Jack C. Wheeler, the head of the Army's recruiting command, said recently. "We're not satisfied with our contracting goals, and it's across the country."
In response, the military is trying new tactics and sweetening incentives. Recruiters have increased signing bonuses to as much as $8,000 for such specialties as nurses and military intelligence analysts. For the first time in two years, new recruits can choose their first post. And recruiters are spending less time on the phone and more time shaking hands in shopping malls, speaking to civic groups and knocking on doors in neighborhoods with children of high school age.
"The last few years we've used more passive techniques," said Brig. Gen. Michael G. Vergamini, commander of the Air Force's recruiting service. "Now recruiters are having to knock some of the rust off" their other recruiting methods.
The military is in no immediate danger of running short of recruits. Every year each service determines how many new enlisted personnel it needs. Recruiters then try to sign up slightly more than they need because 10 to 20 percent of signups drop out at the last minute because of medical problems, a change of heart or other reasons.
Enlisted men and women make up about 85 percent of the 1.9-million-member force on active duty. There are no shortages of new officers, who come mainly from the service academies and Reserve Officer Training Corps programs.
 
Decline Despite Recession
 "The principal problem is that people don't realize we're still hiring," said Rear Adm. Jon M. Barr, the Navy's head of recruiting.
Even more puzzling, recruiters say, is that the decline has come during a recession, normally a boon for recruiters, who can offer educational benefits, job security and training skills to prospective soldiers, sailors and airmen.
"There's a lot of concern right now because it doesn't make sense, given the economy and our incentives," said Col. Rob Enyeart, who is responsible for Army recruiting in 10 Southern and central states.
Recruiters also say the Persian Gulf war vividly illustrated the horrors of combat, and has scared off some prospects.
Some lawmakers think recruiters have had it easy in the last several years and could learn some lessons in efficiency. The services typically maintain separate recruiting offices in the same city. Some lawmakers say the services should share office space, but interservice rivalry for a dwindling pool of prospects makes that unlikely.
The House of Representatives has trimmed $75 million from the military's $542.5 million overall recruiting budget for the fiscal year 1993, which begins on Oct. 1, and the Senate is threatening to cut even deeper. Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, has introduced legislation to reduce recruiting costs to $4,700 per recruit, compared with the Pentagon's request of about $5,700 per recruit for the next fiscal year.
 
Fewer Recruiters, Too
 In response, military officials say they have already tightened their belts. National radio and print advertising has been sharply curtailed, and the military plans to resume using television commercials this fall for the first time in about a year.
The number of recruiters will decline to 19,600 next year from 21,726 in 1989, and the number of recruiting stations to 6,300 from 8,100 in the same period. But the number of new recruits the military needs has also dropped.
Even in recruiting strongholds like northern Florida and the rest of the South, recruiters are feeling the pinch. Sgt. 1st Class James M. Ray, the commander of the Army recruiting station in western Jacksonville, said his station had usually surpassed its monthly signup goal.
Last spring, however, the station squeaked by, making its goal only in the last few days of each month. In August the station signed up only one of its nine assigned contracts and will probably miss its quarterly goal of 23 contracts by the end of September.
Staff Sgt. Tony Connell, an Army recruiter here, was filling up at a gas station one day recently when he leaned across the pump and asked another motorist if he would like to join the Army.
"My first reaction was, this guy must be desperate or we're going to war with Saddam Hussein again," said the motorist, Richard Leiva, a 23-year-old hairdresser, who was impressed enough by Sergeant Connell's sales pitch to consider joining the Army if he passes an aptitude test.
Recruiting prospects are so bleak that two of the station's recruiters spent $50 of their own money to print 500 fliers they taped to phone booths, grocery store bulletin boards and laundromats, Sergeant Ray said.
 
'A Miserable Existence'
 In Panama City, 255 miles west of Jacksonville in the Florida Panhandle, Sgt. 1st Class Michael Boatwright's recruiting station has not run a newspaper advertisement in 18 months, has seen its budget for $1,000-an-event promotional dinners dry up, and has cut recruiters' monthly mileage allowances to 1,400 miles from 5,000 miles.
Nonetheless, the station is still surpassing its monthly goals, largely because he works 12 hours a day and six days a week. "It's a miserable existence right now," Sergeant Boatwright said.
Inside the student lounge at Gulf Coast Community College in Panama City, two dozen pairs of curious eyes follow Sgt. Thomas Johnson and Sgt. 1st Class Scott Nicgorski as they stop at tables to introduce themselves and hand out pamphlets.
At one table Sergeant Johnson finds a receptive audience in Paul Ruffino, a 19-year-old student who was willing to listen to the prospects of a military career in criminal justice. But at another table, Tia Barker, 18, who is studying to be a coroner, was not persuaded by Sergeant Johnson's offer.
"The trick is to try to think like a teen-ager," Sergeant Johnson said. "They're thinking, 'Is it cool to talk to an Army recruiter?' Some mind, some don't. Some wait till you're gone, their friends are gone, and then sneak back to pick up a pamphlet."

HEADLINE: Ireland's Prime Minister Coming to U.S. to Prospect for Jobs

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Preparing for his first trip to the United States since he took office seven months ago, Prime Minister Albert Reynolds has no emigrant illusions about the streets of New York and San Francisco being paved with gold.
In the last few years, the American and European recessions have driven tens of thousands of Irish immigrants back home, where they aggravate this country's serious economic problems. These become growing political problems for Mr. Reynolds, whose Government is grappling with what is called a crisis here. The Irish unemployment rate is 20 percent, more than double that of the European Community and about triple that of the United States. 
 But the 57-year-old former Finance Minister and wealthy businessman said in an interview on Thursday that he would try to stir up millions in new American business for Ireland when he talks to company officials after he arrives in New York on Saturday. During his weeklong visit, he is to meet privately with company executives in New York and San Francisco in an effort to persuade them to move part of their operations to Ireland.
 
350 U.S. Companies in Ireland
 There are already more than 350 American companies operating in Ireland, providing more than 40,000 jobs. Mr. Reynolds made a fortune operating dance halls (where he sometimes dressed as a cowboy and sang country and western songs) and a pet-food company (where he is said to have eaten the product to test it).
He said his efforts in the United States would not be a matter of siphoning off American jobs for Ireland in the midst of an American recession. Rather, he said, "these are companies that are going to Europe" anyway. Some of them, he said, are "companies coming close to decisions to come to Ireland and to Europe."
"Sometimes when you're there, you can push the decision over the hill," he said. "The idea is to get more business for Ireland."
He also wants to create a council of Irish-American business leaders who would "help us confront unemployment in Ireland" with expert advice.
He said the companies he would talk to did not want to disclose their names, as this might help competitors. He said the areas of expansion of American business in Ireland would include tourism, particularly the luxury incentive bonus trips that companies give their top performers.
Asked if he would meet any American national political leaders, he said: "Not in an election year. You have to stay out of it." He said he would meet with Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York.
He acknowledged that Mr. Dinkins had championed the cause of Joe Doherty, an Irish Republican Army guerrilla who was convicted of murder in Northern Ireland, escaped and fought extradition from the United States for years until he was finally sent back to Britain last summer. Mr. Doherty, a hero to many Irish-Americans in New York, is virtually unknown in the Republic of Ireland, where the I.R.A. is outlawed and most people express revulsion at its violent campaign in the North.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
CLINTON SAYS FOES SOW INTOLERANCE

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTH BEND, Ind. Sept. 11

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton today accused his Republican opponents of promoting a renewed "intolerance" that would divide the nation along religious lines.
Speaking at the University of Notre Dame in a tone that was at times confessional and at times like a homily to the converted, Mr. Clinton, a Southern Baptist, emphasized his ties to Catholicism. He also extemporaneously defended himself against repeated shouts and heckling from anti-abortion demonstrators scattered around the Stepan Center here. 
 "I want an America that values the freedom and the dignity of the individual," Mr. Clinton said. "All of us must respect the reflection of God's image in every man and woman. And so we must value their freedom, not just their political freedom, but their freedom of conscience in matters of philosophy and family and faith."
Mr. Clinton's speech represented his most extensive formal remarks on "family values" since the Republican National Convention, where many speakers criticized the Democrats as less committed on such matters than President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle.
"I want an America that does more than talk about family values," said Mr. Clinton, who was accompanied today by his wife, Hillary. "I want an America that values families."
Mr. Clinton said that public service should be an essential component of American life, and that supporting "family values" meant supporting family leave legislation, creating jobs and lifting families out of poverty by creating "a real family wage."
Quoting President John F. Kennedy, the only Roman Catholic President, he said diversity should be encouraged rather than repressed, and he stressed the connection that he said existed between Southern Baptists and Catholics. Kennedy preached against intolerance to Baptist ministers in 1960.
Mr. Clinton's campaign aides also hoped to contrast his message and the audience that heard it with Mr. Bush's appearance tonight before the Christian Coalition, the group founded by the conservative evangelist Pat Robertson.
"We all have the right to wear our religion on our sleeves," Mr. Clinton said. "But we should also hold it in our hearts and live it in our lives. And, if we are truly to practice what we preach, then Americans of every faith and viewpoint should come together to promote the common good."
 
'Voices of Intolerance'
 In much the same way that he indulged the Jewish audience he spoke to through a satellite television link at a B'nai B'rith convention on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton said he was "deeply drawn to the Catholic social mission."
"That is why, like so many Americans, I've been appalled to hear the voices of intolerance that have been raised in recent weeks, voices that proclaim that some families aren't real families, some Americans aren't 'real Americans,' and what this country needs is a religious war," he said. "America doesn't need a religious war. America needs a reaffirmation of the values that for most of us, are rooted in our religious faith."
Mr. Clinton was referring to a speech delivered by Patrick J. Buchanan at the Republican convention on the convention's first night.
"There is a religious war going on in this country for the soul of America," Mr. Buchanan said. "It is a cultural war as critical to the kind of nation we shall be as the cold war itself, for this war is for the soul of America. And in that struggle for the soul of America, Clinton and Clinton are on the other side and George Bush is on our side."
Mr. Clinton's appearance here was one of the most raucous of his campaign, as his supporters sought to shout down not only the abortion protesters, but also a sizable contingent of supporters of President Bush who booed lustily.
"We know that in this room at least, our supporters can win the cheering contest," he said at one point when the din threatened to drown him out. "I would hope that in this great university, we would also prevail in the civility contest. I hope if my opponents or his running mates show up at this great university during this campaign, I hope you will go there and quietly express your support for me, but I hope you will let him speak.'
The university has become a popular site for political speakers in recent years. Mr. Bush received his own share of applause and jeers here in 1988, and he returned last spring to deliver a commencement speech in which he began the "family values" offensive by declaring that the family was "an institution under siege."
In his speech, Mr. Clinton sought to establish a link between the Catholic tradition of social service, family values and the economic plan he espouses.
In an effort to quiet some of the abortion protesters, who shouted throughout the speech and followed him outside as he shook hands afterward, Mr. Clinton told the story of a woman he met in South Florida when he toured the hurricane damage who had adopted an AIDS-infected baby.
"I respect this debate we are having in this country about life," he quoted her as saying. "But how I wish we would reach out and help the living."
On the stage, Mr. Clinton surrounded himself with Catholic public officials, including the Rev. Edward A. Malloy, the president of the university; Senator Harris Wofford, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, who opposes abortion.
"To go into the most Catholic college in America and get this kind of reception is a very encouraging sign," said Mr. Flynn, who has been campaigning on Mr. Clinton's behalf in Pennsylvania. "The abortion issue is still a big issue in this country. Don't kid yourself. But when people are unemployed, when they can't afford to put bread on the table or pay the tuition for their kids, these are critically important issues too."
Campaign aides said they chose Notre Dame for the speech because they wanted to have Mr. Clinton talk about tolerance and how it enforces his secular views. They said he read pastoral letters from the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and speeches delivered at Notre Dame by both Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Cuomo favors abortion rights; Mr. Casey does not.
"If we truly believe -- as almost everyone says no matter what they believe on certain issues -- that children are God's most precious creation, then surely we owe every child born in the U.S.A. the chance to make the most of his or her God-given potential," Mr. Clinton said.
"I want an America that offers every child a healthy start in life, decent schooling and the chance to go on to college or to job training worthy of the name, not only because that's essential for our economic success but because providing opportunities is how we fulfill obligations to each other and the moral principles we honor."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
U.S. Workers to Sue if Bush Cuts Their Pay

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The organization representing most of the Federal Government's highest paid employees -- those making $90,000 to $112,000 -- said today that it would sue President Bush if he cut their pay.
The group, the Senior Executives Association, said Mr. Bush has "broken faith with senior Federal executives" by proposing that Government employees making more than $75,000 a year take a 5 percent pay cut. 
 Carol Bonosaro, the association's president, said the group is asking Congress for legislation to safeguard them from "partisan political manipulation" and is prepared to sue Mr. Bush if he reduces their salaries, which he has the authority to do. Ms. Bonosaro said lawyers were exploring grounds on which a suit could be based.
Mr. Bush presented a plan Thursday designed to lift the nation's economy through a 1 percent across-the-board tax reduction and spending cuts that included a 5 percent reduction in the salaries of Federal workers earning more than $75,000 a year.

HEADLINE: U.S. DROPPING PLAN TO BUILD REACTOR

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
As part of its program to shrink the American nuclear arms industry, the Department of Energy said today that it would immediately scrap its effort to build a new nuclear reactor to produce tritium, a radioactive gas used in atomic bombs.
The announcement was made in a letter from Energy Secretary James D. Watkins to Senator Strom Thurmond, the senior Republican lawmaker from South Carolina. The Savannah River Plant, a nuclear arms manufacturing center near Aiken, S.C., was considered the likeliest site for building the new reactor, which would have cost at least $6 billion. 
 The decision, which was expected, comes almost a year after the White House ordered the Energy Department to explain why it needed the new reactor. According to the Energy Department, $1.2 billion was spent in the last three fiscal years on research and design work, and the program's cancellation will save about $1 billion the department had planned to spend in the next three fiscal years.
Mr. Watkins said actions taken by President Bush and the Russian leader, Boris Yeltsin, to substantially reduce the number of nuclear warheads had led to a sharply diminished need for new supplies of tritium, which increases a bomb's explosive power.
 
Reserves for Two Decades
 Mr. Watkins said a new study by the Pentagon and the Energy Department had found that existing reserves of tritium were sufficient to meet national security needs until at least 2012 without any new production at all.
"Accordingly," Mr. Watkins said, "I have decided that the existing new production reactor program should be deferred immediately and the reactor design efforts should be brought to a prompt and orderly closure."
The decision is a blow to two groups of industrial companies, led by General Atomics and Ebasco Services Inc., that had assembled teams of engineers to develop competing designs for the new reactor. It is also a blow to the civilian nuclear industry, which had been counting on the Energy Department project as part of its own efforts to develop a new and safer design for the next generation of nuclear power plants.
At the same time, the cancellation of the program is a victory for national and regional environmental and disarmament groups that have been arguing that the reactor was an unnecessary expense.
"Much of the money already spent on the new production reactor could have been saved if the Department of Energy had not held so tightly to this cold war relic," said Brian Costner, director of the Energy Research Foundation, an environmental group in Columbia, S.C., which opposed the project. "The program should have been canceled years ago given the pressing issues facing our country."
The new production reactor was an important facet of the Energy Department's multibillion-dollar program to repair and rebuild the Government's capability to produce tritium for nuclear weapons. Only four years ago, after the shutdown of three old reactors at the Savannah River Plant, the Energy Department reacted as if a national security emergency existed and began a crash program to repair the machines and design a new reactor.
 
$5 Billion in Rebuilding
 The dual efforts have cost more than $5 billion, and only one of the old reactors at Savannah River was repaired. In his letter to Senator Thurmond, Mr. Watkins acknowledged today that the old reactor is no longer needed.
The cancellation of the proposed reactor is another milestone in the Energy Department's costly transition from a producer of fearsome weapons to one of the Government's chief civilian research and environmental agencies.
Over the last four years, the department has shut down weapons production plants in Colorado, Idaho, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee and Washington State. Last month, the Senate voted to end atomic weapons testing permanently at the Nevada Test Site near Las Vegas. Earlier this year the House voted to suspend weapons testing temporarily at the end of the year.
Almost half of the $12 billion budget for the atomic arms industry is now focused on cleaning up radioactive and chemical poisons scattered across the 12 states where the industry's main plants and laboratories operated. The project, one of the largest public works programs ever undertaken by the Government, has turned closed nuclear weapons plants in Washington State and Ohio into field laboratories for environmental cleanup techniques.

HEADLINE: Black Baptists Are Buffeted From Within and Without

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, SEPT. 10

 BODY:
Heart-felt amens echoed late into the night off the walls of a hotel ballroom here as hundreds of black Baptists answered a lineup of preachers dueling for their souls with hoarse but inspired shouts that were, by turn, slyly comic and deeply pious.
Like handicappers, the more knowledgeable of those in the audience, touted the relative strengths of the lineup. 
 There was the Rev. E. L. McKinney from Memphis, a fireplug of a man whose crescendos were rated among the best. There was the Rev. A. Louis Patterson of Dallas, who gave his sermons a scholarly and intellectual cast and built to an emotional finish. And finally, around 2 A.M., there was the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who spoke of being humbled by the preaching talents of his fellow ministers, then set the audience to rocking and shouting with his own hourlong sermon.
The late-night services were spiritual nourishment for the 112th annual gathering of the National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc., which drew 15,000 delegates and more than 40,000 other visitors from among the 8 million black Baptists worldwide.
But the pulse of the convention was not driven by the preaching alone; delegates talked of being buffeted by a host of secular concerns. The Presidential campaign and visits to the convention by the candidates and their representatives drew the most attention from delegates this week.
"This is a political year, and as black Baptists we have enough sense to know that our problem in this country is an economic problem," said the Rev. S. Amos Brackeen of Philadelphia after Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential candidate, addressed the session. "And that would seem to favor Governor Clinton over President Bush among this group."
Still, throughout Mr. Clinton's speech, Mr. Jackson remained stone-faced. He later repeated his criticism, albeit restrained, that the Clinton campaign was trying to shore up support among moderate Democrats by not showcasing many of the issues favored by the party's traditional faithful, including blacks and labor.
The Rev. W. L. Richardson, general secretary of the group, said: "One of the problems Clinton has in the black community is the perception that he is trying to create his own black leaders to deal with, and we told him that in a private meeting here."
Nevertheless, Rev. Richardson said he supports Mr. Clinton, adding: "He is a soul mate on the one hand, but he is practicing a strategy aimed at a large, white constituency which has little or no tolerance for black Americans. We understand that, but it could be a problem for him."
While politics dominated many conversations, delegates also discussed the recession, joblessness and poverty in their urban congregations, and the suffering caused by Hurricane Andrew.
Still others found themselves pondering the denomination's internal troubles. Its leader of 10 years, the Rev. Theodore J. Jemison faces trial in October on Federal perjury charges growing out of an alleged bribery attempt in connection with the Mike Tyson rape trial.
 
Hurricane Damage to Churches
 The economy was the main concern for Rev. James Wise of Goulds, Fla., until Hurricane Andrew hit. After the roof was blown off of his church, he considered canceling this trip, he said, but several other ministers from South Florida had encouraged him to attend to report the area's plight.
"I'm glad I came, because they have been taking up collections to help us," he said.
Concern about another kind of damage dominated the thoughts of Mamie Reed of Joliet, Ill., who wondered aloud about the future of Rev. Jemison, given the charges the 73-year-old preacher from Baton Rouge, La., faces.
The denomination's leader aided in the defense of Mr. Tyson, the former heavyweight champion who was convicted in February of raping Desiree Washington, a contestant in the Miss Black America beauty pageant in 1991. He later came under Federal investigation when Miss Washington and her family said that an unnamed person had offered her $1 million to drop her charges.
Nothing came of that investigation until July, when Rev. Jemison appeared as a character witness for a defendant in an unrelated Federal case in Lafayette, La. A prosecutor in that case, seeking to undermine the preacher's credibility, asked Rev. Jemison about the Tyson allegations. The minister denied offering a bribe to Miss Washington. He later was indicted for perjury on the basis of a recorded telephone conversation with Miss Washington's father.
 
Pall Over the Convention
 In interview after interview, delegates to the convention said that their leader's legal problems had cast a pall over the convention and had already weakened him. They noted that under new rules for the group, Rev. Jemison will not be able to succeed himself as president when his term expires in two years. Many said that they had expected him to try to reverse those rules, but that the indictment had weakened his position and had distracted him. As a result, three candidates for the post of president of the convention were openly campaigning this week, in what was widely seen as a preemptive strike.
"We're unified, but sometimes we let ambition run away with us," Rev. Jemison said Thursday in his annual address to the group. "Some have started two years before the vote to campaign, but they ought to wait for orders from God."
Rev. Jemison in the past explained his support for Mr. Tyson as part of an effort to protect black men and highlight their plight at the hands of the criminal justice system. Now his supporters portray him as another black victim of the criminal justice system.
"This nation has made a practice of bringing down the black race, and so it is a philosophical thing and a product of our experience to rally around and support Rev. Jemison," said Rev. Brackeen. "If white America is looking for us to abandon and tear down our leader because of these charges, they won't see that."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN:;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech at the University of Notre Dame yesterday
"On a hot summer afternoon 29 summers ago, I met President Kennedy in the Rose Garden of the White House as a 16-year-old delegate to America Legion Boy's Nation. That afternoon turned me toward public service. After President Kennedy was killed, another Southerner, Lyndon Johnson, succeeded to the Presidency with the promise to enact John Kennedy's program to get America moving again, and to bring America together. 
 Because I wanted to be in public service, watch the Great Society unfold and get a first-class education, I enrolled in Georgetown University, the nation's oldest Jesuit college. I wondered when I went there whether I would be out of place, a Southern Baptist who had rarely been far from home. Thankfully, both the students and the faculty there held to the scriptural commandment to befriend the stranger in their midst. And together we found much common ground that Baptists and Catholics could walk together. And in the end I felt completely at home in the Catholic tradition of Georgetown.
I was then, and I remain today, deeply drawn to the Catholic social mission, to the idea that, as President Kennedy said, here on earth God's work must truly be our own. I have seen it in the work that Catholic politicians like Mayor Flynn of Boston, and Senator Wofford, whom I admire, have done."
 
PRESIDENT BUSH
In a speech to Job Corps students and employees in Excelsior Springs, Mo., yesterday
"My new plan is comprehensive, filled with specific answers to questions Americans are asking around their dining room table these days. And one of those questions is how will we stay ahead of the changes in the world economy.
According to some studies, just 2 percent of you will work the same job from now until retirement. The average worker can expect to change jobs 10 times during the course of his career. You need real-world security, skills you can put to work now and 10 years from now.
But just as you can't drive a nail without a hammer, you can't build a dream without a job. And you're here at Job Corps because you know that it takes more and better skills to earn good jobs. And you decided you were going to do something about that.
Well, America has work to do. And we can't let your drive go to waste. Maybe 50 years ago a strong back might have been enough to get a good job. In our changing economy it's not enough anymore. What you earned yesterday with sweat you got to earn tomorrow with skills. And that's why, and that's why last month I announced new initiatives to focus Federal job training on the kind of real-world skills Americans like you and Americans of all ages need in this new world economy."

HEADLINE: Deaths From Accidents Reach a 67-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ITASCA, Ill., Sept. 11

 BODY:
The number of accidental deaths in 1991 was the lowest in 67 years, with road accidents still by far the leading cause of such deaths, the National Safety Council says.
Reporting on the decline Tuesday, the council attributed it to greater safety awareness, technological advances, improved enforcement of traffic laws and the economic downturn, which has resulted in fewer drivers on the highways at the hours of highest risk. 
 The organization, based in this Chicago suburb, estimated that 88,000 people died accidentally last year in the United States. The toll was the lowest since 1924, when 85,600 accidental deaths occurred among an American population that was less than half its current size of 252 million.
Traffic deaths, which account for almost half the overall accidental death total, fell 7 percent from 1990, to 43,500, the lowest level since 1962, the council said.
Work-related deaths dropped to a record low of 9,900, the council said. Deaths from falls, drowning, suffocation, fires and burns also decreased.
The council was formed in 1912 by industries, railroads and insurance companies meeting in Milwaukee as the First Cooperative Safety Congress. Congress chartered the council in 1953 to lead an effort to reduce accidents.

HEADLINE: Slight Rise In Producer Price Index

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Prices paid by wholesalers advanced a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent in August despite big increases in the cost of fruits and vegetables, the Government said today.
The slight increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index matched the gain in July and was attributed to drops in the cost of gasoline and fuel oil, tobacco and children's clothing. 
 For the year so far, prices have advanced at an annual rate of just 1.7 percent. For all of last year, prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent, but that number was heavily influenced by the drop in oil prices after the Persian Gulf war.
In August, food costs jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent, pulled up by a 16.9 percent increase in fruit prices, the worst in 20 years, and a 30.2 percent rise for vegetables. Labor Department officials said bad weather affected farms in California, New York and New Jersey.
Energy prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent, the second consecutive decline after a 2.3 percent jump in June. Gasoline prices fell 1.7 percent and fuel oil dropped 4.4 percent.
Excluding the volatile food and energy components, prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent after a rise of two-tenths in July.
Economists say the virtual standstill of economic growth has kept a lid on both prices and wages. Faced with lagging sales, most businesses have found it all but impossible to push prices higher and many have been forced to cut prices.
The various changes left the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods at 123.5 percent of its 1982 base of 100, up from 121.5 a year ago.
Through July, consumer prices have risen at only a 2.9 percent annual rate.
Analysts see little prospect in the immediate future for a faster pace of price increases.
There are, however, at least two factors that are keeping price pressures from disappearing entirely: Hurricane Andrew and the weakness of the dollar.
The storm destroyed offshore oil and gas drilling rigs in the Gulf of Mexico. It also sent the price of plywood and other construction supplies higher. Both developments should show up in the wholesale price report starting with the data for September.
As for the dollar, in late August it fell to its lowest levels since World War II against the German mark. A declining dollar helps the American economy by making its goods cheaper on overseas markets. But it adds to inflation by increasing the price of imports.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Producer Price" shows index of finished goods prices, March 1991-August 1992. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher Amid Flurry of Mark Sales

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday as mounting pressure on Germany to lower its interest rates prompted a flurry of selling marks and buying dollars. Gold prices fell.
"The mark is just starting to fall out of favor and people are starting to buy everything else in sight," said Ziggy Zborowski, a trader at Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York. 
 Germany's Bundesbank raised interest rates in July to a level about six percentage points higher than United States rates. The move was intended to keep inflation under control. As a result, the mark rose against major currencies, while knocking the dollar to record lows and spreading turbulence to other currencies.
High interest rates make a currency more attractive to investors, who get a bigger return on their money.
Germany has resisted calls from European neighbors for lower interest rates, although it promised European finance ministers last weekend that it would seek to avoid further increases.
But the dollar's rise yesterday gave little relief to the weaker European currencies, as the mark held firm against sterling and the Italian lira.
Traders said the main news driving trading in Europe yesterday was a speech Thursday by Prime Minister John Major of Britain in which he warned of the consequences of a weak dollar and rejected the idea of realigning European currencies.
In New York, the dollar rose to 1.4485 German marks, from 1.4205 late Thursday, and to 124.25 Japanese yen, up from 123.525 late Thursday. The British pound was quoted at $1.9225, down from $1.9645 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.2875 Swiss francs, up from 1.2625; 4.9270 French francs, up from 4.8400; 1,108.50 Italian lire, down from 1,087.00, and 1.21585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.21795.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $340.90, down $1.30 from Thursday. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $340.90 a troy ounce, off 70 cents from Thursday.
On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.679 a troy ounce, down from $3.701 Thursday. Silver traded in London at a bid of $3.69 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $3.74.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages plunged to 7.84 percent this week, their lowest in 19 years, according to a survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. The rate fell one-tenth of a percentage point from 7.94 percent a week earlier. The last time rates were this low was in June 1973 when the 30-year rate was 7.73 percent. Rates on 15-year mortgages also fell, to 7.44 percent, from 7.51 percent a week ago.

HEADLINE: New Sound Of Music In a Hall Renewed

BYLINE: Special to the New York TImes

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
For more than 10 years, opening night of the San Francisco Symphony was an event to be seen, but not necessarily heard.
The wide, high spaces and U-shaped seating pattern of Davies Symphony Hall provided excellent views across a starched and sequined audience. The annual event, coupled with the opening of the opera, led off a musical season that has long been the jewel of the city's cultural crown. 
 But the imposing characteristics of the 12-year-old hall also worked to dampen the orchestra's sound. The horns, reverberating between the dentilled tiers, stumbled over one another. The strings, lingering in the arch of the concrete ceiling, rarely descended to human ears. Listeners complained of dead spots. Musicians, catching only the echo of their colleagues, accused one another of poor timing.
And so, as happened to Avery Fisher Hall in New York and a number of other contemporary concert halls, acousticians were invited to prescribe a remedy for San Francisco.
In a two-year, $10.2 million renovation project, the interior of Davies Hall has been opened up with aisles and tightened with new walls and fewer seats. The floors have been replaced, the orchestra has been elevated and the ceiling has been reformed into an armor of plexiglass shields.
 
A Positive Reception
 On Wednesday, Davies Hall reopened to the strains of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. By the time the music ended and the applause died down, the consensus among the audience and musicians was one of tempered approval. Gone from the orchestra was what Larry Kirkegaard, an acoustician who has worked on the post-renovations Carnegie Hall and the remodeling of Orchestra Hall in Chicago, called "the brontosaurus effect": "you kick it in the tail, and two weeks later the head turns around."
As part of the post-concert hoopla, the audience also heard choirs and college bands, applauded Chinese banners that were whipped through the aisles, and cheered the performance of a singer teetering beneath a hat bearing the model of the San Francisco cityscape.
In the ears of local critics, the concert pleased as none in Davies had before. Robert Commanday, music critic for The San Francisco Chronicle, praised an "excellent and exciting symphonic sound." Allan Ullrich, music critic for The San Francisco Examiner, gave a more cautiously positive review, saying that while many of the original problems had been corrected, "warmth, weight and sonic mass were in short supply."
 
 
Early Signs of Trouble
 While the largely successful completion of the project would seem to signal the continued strength of the performing arts in the city at a time of economic recession, the outcome was far from certain.
Even before 1985, when the symphony's current music director, Herbert Blomstedt, was appointed, the problems of the hall were more than apparent.
At that time, Mr. Blomstedt recalled this week, he could sit among the violas and not hear what the first violins were playing 10 feet away -- an experience he called "not very rewarding." But Mr. Blomstedt, his musicians and his audience faced some difficulty in convincing the symphony's board that the space would have to be refurbished only five years after the $27.5 million hall was completed.
"It was not the world's easiest job," said Nancy Bechtle, the symphony's president, about the second fund-raising campaign. "Among some board members, there was a sense of 'Why didn't you do it right the first time?' "
Ultimately, the board was swayed. A crucial element in the escalating complaints about the sound quality was the fact that among the hall's 3,063 seats, the best -- those with the clearest sound -- were the cheapest, nestled in the nearly invisible reaches of the second tier.
Overall attendance was 15 percent below the hall's daunting capacity. Built on a scale that rivaled the country's largest halls and exceeded many of the country's best, Davies Hall better reflected the grandiose aspirations of the 1980's than the hard economic realities facing the city's 81-year-old symphony.
But while the problems were evident, the solution was not.
Even Mr. Kirkegaard, who was eventually selected to replace the original acousticians, Bolt, Beranek & Newman of Cambridge, Mass., conceded that his profession is "a mystical science or a black art."
In his preliminary surveys, Mr. Kirkegaard toured with the symphony, gathering data from the musicians and measuring their sound in halls throughout Europe. He also consulted Lothar Cremer, the late acoustician of the Berlin Philharmonic, from which Davies Hall had derived its unusual seating arrangement.
In two consecutive summers, Mr. Kirkegaard worked with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, one of the two architecture firms involved in the original construction of the hall, to solve the hall's problems. In the process the seating capacity was reduced by more than 300.
The changes won him the support of the musicians, even that of Herb Holtman, a second violinist, who described himself as "the most cynical guy around."
"I didn't think they could do it," Mr. Holtman said. "But I think they've really done an admirable job, given the size of the hall."
 
Reserving Judgment
 Gene Morrison, a veteran of more than 1,000 Davies concerts, zigzagged his way through the entire hall: the boxes along the side and back, the two tiers, the orchestra and the thin strip of seats above the sides of the stage. He admired the cherry paneling surrounding the stage, the risers for the musicians and the newly raked orchestra floor.
"This used to be a vast wasteland," Mr. Morrison said, waving his arm out over the orchestra. "Now it's certainly worth checking out."
And while Mr. Morrison said he thought the evening's concert "had better balance and everything sounded richer," he and a number of other regulars reserved final judgment for evenings of less spectacle and more music.
"Next week we'll hear Mahler's Second," he said, "and in a year or two I'll tell you what I really think."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The San Francisco Symphony playing at the reopening this week of Davies Symphony Hall in San Francisco. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
T.A.C.'s Longtime Leader Is Facing Job Evaluation

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The strongest challenge yet to Ollan Cassell's leadership of track and field in the United States will be considered this weekend in Denver, where the executive committee of The Athletics Congress plans to review his performance against newly developed criteria for the job of executive director.
Cassell, a 52-year-old former Olympic quarter-miler, has been T.A.C.'s only executive director since the organization grew out of the Amateur Athletic Union in the late 1970's. That makes him the longest-serving chief of any governing body within the United States Olympic Committee.
 
A Survivor
 As such, he has often been a target of disgruntled and critical factions within the track and field community, several of whom have tried to unseat him. But each time he has survived, always emerging stronger, and that could well be the case again this time in the most formal procedure ever used to evaluate his performance as the T.A.C. executive director. 
 The basis of the review will be analyses by seven members of the executive committee, who were asked to rate Cassell in various aspects of the job on a scale of 1 to 3, with a 3 representing "exceptional or meritorious" work.
The overall average of the evaluations will then become the basis upon which the executive committee of 22 would recommend to the board of directors that Cassell either be retained for another three years or be replaced. His current contract expires in March.
In either case, the 100-member board, which meets again in December, would have final say.
After a rousing summer of competition, highlighted by successful trials for the Olympics and the outstanding performance of the American team at the Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, the sport has never seemed healthier in the United States.
Evie Dennis, the executive board member who presided over those doing the evaluations, said the responses have been largely favorable toward Cassell. But the evaluations she had seen were not without criticisms.
"If there was one thread in the responses," she said, "it was a frustration over a lack of information and communication. People are feeling that the office is a little too secretive in the way it serves its people and associations."
In any case, she said, the overall review of the executive director's job in the generic sense would lead to greater efficiency from whomever served in the position, a critical need in a tighter economy.
Cassell, speaking from his office in Indianapolis, said he would prefer to wait until the meetings had concluded before speaking publicly.

HEADLINE: A Wise Labor Pact

 BODY:
New York City's tentative settlement with its firefighters sets a prudent but fair tone for talks with other unions. By giving the union a 4.5 percent increase over 30 months, the administration took an indispensable first step toward keeping municipal wage increases to a minimum as the city rides out the recession. The next step: to remain firm in talks with other unions.
That will not be easy, but the pact with the firefighters gives city negotiators a useful weapon by setting a precedent for moderation. The city simply cannot afford to pay workers the substantial increases labor leaders are demanding. Mayor David Dinkins learned the pitfalls of a weak labor policy when he granted the teachers' union a 5.5 percent one-year wage increase in 1990. That set a slippery-slope precedent for other union negotiations at the worst possible time -- just as the city began suffering the lost revenues and increased costs imposed by the financial downturn. 
 To his great credit, the Mayor learned from his mistake. His current budget calls for no increase in the fiscal year that began July 1 unless unions "buy" any increase with greater productivity or concessions. The firefighters' pact largely carries out that policy: the 30-month contract, retroactive to July 1, 1990, phases in the wage increases for 1990 and 1991 and includes no increase in the current fiscal year, which began July 1. Moreover, the settlement, largely the patient work of Labor Commissioner James Hanley, calls for firefighters to finance a small part of their increase with concessions. They'll work one additional 15-hour tour a year and lose a day of personal leave; new firefighters will get less vacation time.
The settlement benefits both sides. Firefighters, who must still ratify the deal, would get an increase in their annuity fund, support for legislation improving their pension fund and a chance to reduce their workweek to 40 hours from 42 if they finance the change with productivity savings.
It's unfortunate that the pact uses pension funds to pay for just under 1 percent of the increase. That means changing assumptions about the interest the funds will earn in future years, a risky business both for union members, who draw pensions from the fund, and for the city, which would have to step in if the fund ran into trouble.
With the exception of that flaw, the contract is good news for firefighters, for the city and for what it reveals about the strength of Mr. Dinkins's commitment to fiscal integrity.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Money's Best Friend

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Nobody can go wrong by running against lawyers and bureaucrats so I wasn't surprised Thursday when President Bush lashed these wretched devils with the limp noodle of his campaign oratory.
The luncheon audience of high capitalists at the Detroit Economic Club hooted with delight when the President suggested that lawyers will get a nasty comeuppance in a second Bush Administration. The audience applause suggested most would gladly give up dessert if the sacrifice could persuade the President to have a half-dozen lawyers hauled to the podium, stripped of their briefcases and birched with wet writs. 
 This being a political campaign, it is unsporting to call attention to Presidential nonsense. On the other hand, what's wrong with being unsporting when both candidates hold to the proposition that anyone who doesn't want the Presidency desperately enough to kill for it is unworthy to lead us toward fulfillment of the American dream?
The President said lawyers cost the nation billions in wealth. He mentioned a specific number of billions, which I instantly forgot after checking the amount of brain space still available for storing fraudulent statistics and finding none left.
Surely seven maids with seven computers computing for seven years couldn't make a sensible estimate of how much money lawyers are costing the country. Such statistics are cooked up by political "researchers" to fit the transient needs of candidates.
The fact, of course, is that the most formidable and most expensive lawyers are almost invariably employed by corporations. Their duties include lobbying to shape the law to their employers' advantage, adjusting corporate policy to the ever-changing whims of the tax laws, and glowering at the occasional impertinent citizen trying to make trouble for the corporation.
The typical upstart who takes his grievance to a lawyer tends to settle cheap when confronted by the mountainous array of corporate legal power so obviously capable of bankrupting him with the astronomical costs of American justice.
In short, the prime function of the infamously overpaid lawyer in the United States is to help the rich get richer. It is not just comically ironic to see a gathering of capitalists cheering a Presidential assault on their loyal, if extravagantly paid, flunkeys. It also smacks of corporate ingratitude for people who devote their lives to the corporation.
Well, of course it's not the corporation lawyer whom good capitalists want undone. It is the so-called "trial lawyer," who rejects the corporate offer and insists on a trial, which sometimes ends with a huge jury award depleting the corporate till.
Such juries are usually said by corporate types to be "sentimental" and "foolish." Such lawyers, usually working only for a very large percentage of the award, are denigrated as "ambulance chasers." It wasn't clear from the President's speech whether the "billions" lawyers cost the country are composed of jury awards against corporations or the amount corporations pay their own lawyers, or the sum of the two.
In his ceremonial bashing of the bureaucrats, the President promised a 5 percent cut in the salaries of government workers who earn more than $75,000. This may or may not be a good idea, economically speaking, but the politics of it is weird even by the standards to which the Bush campaign has accustomed us. Why?
Well, because what is the President proposing here but an income tax on a clearly defined population group? And who is the fellow who says he once made a terrible mistake by raising taxes but will never, ever raise taxes again? That's right: It is Mr. President, the same fellow who is simultaneously promising to put an income tax on upper-income bureaucrats.
Is it not captious to dwell on these Presidential absurdities? Yes, if we agree that what is said and done in pursuit of office is merely circus, just ritual game-playing that is not meant to deal with the world as it really is nor tell us anything at all about what will be done once the game is lost and won.
Being serious about serious business is bad taste in America.

HEADLINE: Women of Russia, Unite!

BYLINE: By Katrina vanden Heuvel; Katrina vanden Heuvel, an editor at The Nation, writes about Russian politics and society.

 BODY:
As the Soviet welfare system collapses, the feminization of poverty may become the new Russia's largest and cruelest problem.
In Moscow, 70 percent of the newly unemployed are women between the ages of 45 and 55. When I visited one of Moscow's recently established unemployment offices this summer, women in line described the kind of discrimination they now face in the job market. Some were turned away because they were too old -- in their 40's. Others had been told that their maternal responsibilities made them unreliable workers. 
 Women's economic desperation is visible on Moscow's streets, too, where the overwhelming number of peddlers are older women and young mothers.
Although anti-discrimination legislation still exists in Russia, it is not being enforced. Sexist (and ageist) job advertisements are commonplace. Alisa, a new brokerage house, published announcements seeking woman aged 18 to 21 for secretarial positions. Applicants were told to come to the interview wearing a miniskirt.
An advertising firm requested that applicants for a receptionist position submit a full-size photo, preferably one showing them in a bikini to display their "full super-attractiveness."
Still worse, legislation being discussed by the Parliament, and likely to be adopted this fall, would prevent women from participating equally in the emerging market economy. Mothers of children under the age of 14 would be allowed to work only a limited number of hours a week, thereby disqualifying them from the best jobs. The legislation is supported by a coalition of Russia's new democrats and old-style conservatives.
In addition, the Parliament and some city governments are dismantling the once elaborate Soviet system of child care. With fewer outside services, women will be compelled to leave the workplace. The Moscow City Council, for example, proposes to close about a third of the city's day-care centers in the next two years. While Russian politicians argue that women resented having to combine full-time work and full-time homemaking under the old Soviet system, a recent poll shows that only 20 percent of Russian women want to stay at home.
Regardless of personal preference, millions of Russian families will not be able to survive without two incomes, as inflation grows. In 1992, women's earnings account for 40 percent of family incomes, while every fifth Russian woman is the family's only breadwinner.
Not surprisingly, Russian women are forming activist and self-help groups. In some ways, their struggle is reminiscent of the American women's movement in the late 1960's. On the other hand, unlike the American economy of the time, Russia's economy is disintegrating and offers few new opportunities. And Russian women are unlikely to find allies among the overwhelmingly male political class.
Should the U.S. care about the plight of women in Russia? The Bush Administration has rightly argued that we must give financial support to Russia's reforms. But most of the aid is conditional on the Yeltsin Government's making drastic budgetary cuts. The cuts, of course, will lead to higher unemployment and fewer welfare provisions, which will victimize women first and foremost.
It would be wiser, more humane and more consistent with our values and laws to make all such aid intended to promote a market economy in Russia conditional on practices that will provide equal opportunity for all citizens. Women should be present at the creation of the new Russia. As my friend Anastasia insists, "Democracy without women is not democracy."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Asheville

BYLINE: By RICK MASHBURN; RICK MASHBURN lives in North Carolina and is a frequent visitor to Asheville.

 BODY:
For many people, a getaway in North Carolina's Blue Ridge Mountains means a remote campsite or cottage, a place where the pileated woodpecker is the biggest noisemaker around. Travelers who take smaller doses of wilderness may prefer Asheville. Hiking trails, whitewater rivers and the meandering Blue Ridge Parkway are all within easy reach, yet so are out-of-town newspapers, imported beer and the occasional foreign movie.
Not by accident is Asheville's professional baseball team called the Tourists. The city has catered to visitors since the mid-19th century, when it began to be known both for lavish hotels and sanitariums. 
 A number of its present-day attractions were built by people who visited first, then decided to stay: George Washington Vanderbilt was so enchanted with the sight of Mount Pisgah that he bought 125,000 acres surrounding it, then situated his 285-room estate, Biltmore, to give him an unblemished view.
In turn, some of Biltmore's most talented designers and craftsmen also settled in the city and continued to contribute to a body of architecture that is strong in the Art Deco and Gothic Revival styles.
Created by and for outsiders, Asheville, with a population of 60,000, has an unusual sophistication for a city in the southern Appalachians.
 
Events
 On many chilly mornings in early fall, heavy moisture settles in low-lying areas of the city and surrounding valleys. Viewed from above, the fog is a thick white sea through which the mountain peaks rise like blue-green islands. The sight is well worth an early climb on foot or by car. More predictable are the first blushes of color in the trees at higher elevations. The show descends and intensifies until its peak in mid-October.
To help counter the lull between summer vacationers and the throngs of leaf-watchers, numerous man-made events have been scheduled for the next few weeks. The complete calendar is available from the Asheville Convention and Visitors Bureau, Post Office Box 1010, Asheville, N.C. 28801; (800) 257-1300.
Representatives of 50 Indian tribes from all over the country will attend Kituwah: the second annual American Indian National Arts Exposition from Sept. 24 to 27 in the Asheville Civic Center. Some 150 juried craftsmen will sell their work, and there is a schedule of dance competitions and workshops on cultural and historical traditions. Admission for a half-day is $10; write High Country Art and Craft Guild, 46 Haywood Street, Asheville, N.C. 28801. Information, (704) 252-3881; tickets, (704) 251-9999.
Thomas Wolfe stayed away from home for eight years after he outraged the town with his thinly disguised autobiography "Look Homeward Angel." Now he is the city's most revered native, and his birthday is celebrated with an annual festival, this year from Oct. 1 to 4, when dramatizations, concerts, art exhibits, lectures and workshops will be held in a variety of locations. Walking tours include "Thomas Wolfe's Asheville." "An Evening at Dixieland" will offer music and period costumes at the Thomas Wolfe Memorial, the boarding house Wolfe's mother owned; now a museum, (704) 253-8304, the house is worth a visit at any time. Most events are free; for a schedule write the Wolfe Memorial, Post Office Box 7143, Asheville, N.C. 28802.
Fifteen miles east of the city, at a summer camp near the town of Black Mountain, dancers and music lovers will converge for the Black Mountain Fall Festival from Oct. 9 to 11 and 16 to 18. Twenty musical groups perform each weekend, headlined by the David Grisman Quintet. The mix includes cajun music, blues and a percussion ensemble that plays instruments made from trash. Workshops on swing and contra dancing, drumming and musical instruments are held during the day. While some people are listening to the stage performances, other enthusiasts are in the old dining hall, where they dance until dawn. Tickets for each weekend are $55 in advance, $65 at the gate; order from Post Office Box 216, Black Mountain, N.C. 28711; (704) 669-4546.
 
 
Sights
 For a visual introduction to the city, drive west through the clutter and chaos of Tunnel Road. You'll pass through Beaucatcher Tunnel, then emerge to a stately view of the downtown skyline. Thanks to a recent rejuvenation, downtown is spirited and hospitable. There are narrow, angled streets and spacious open squares filled with cafes, galleries and boutiques. At Pack Square, the heart of downtown, the recently opened Pack Place Education, Arts and Science Center, (704) 252-3866, has provided a new home for several of the city's small museums.
Architecture enthusiasts will want to seek out the pink-roofed Art Deco City Building at 70 Court Plaza, and the Gothic Revival Jackson Building, a pencil-thin skyscraper at 22 South Pack Square. For a more comprehensive look, a two-hour, guided walking tour begins at the Downtown Welcome Center, 14 Battery Park Avenue, (704) 255-1093, and costs $7.50.
Biltmore Estate should certainly be visited, even considering the $21.95 admission charge. Built in the 1890's and designed by Richard Morris Hunt after 16th-century French chateaus in the Loire Valley, the splendid stone mansion is filled with original furnishings and art objects collected by George Vanderbilt in Europe. The 8,000-acre grounds, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, include lavish formal gardens and a conservatory. Lunch at one of the two restaurants on the estate and a winery tour can extend the visit to nearly a full day. The house, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. (tickets must be purchased by 5); grounds close at 8 P.M. (800) 543-2961.
The rough boulders of the Grove Park Inn in Asheville stand in sharp contrast to Biltmore's gargoyled facade. The rustic hotel was built in 1912 of stone carved from the mountain on which it sits, and the original structure remains largely intact despite the addition of two new wings. The terrace has dozens of rockers and a sweeping view of distant mountains; it is especially pleasant at sunset. On chilly days, comfort can be found by two huge stone fireplaces in the lobby. Visitors who are not staying at the hotel can sit on the porch and in the lobby. Many of Grove Park's original fixtures and furnishings were made by the Roycrofters, a well-known name in the American Arts and Crafts Movement; in addition, an impressive collection of arts and crafts furnishings now decorates the public areas of the new wings. At 290 Macon Avenue; (800) 438-5800.
At the Folk Art Center on the Blue Ridge Parkway, 15 minutes from town, one can finger a hand-carved bowl or chat with a broom maker as he works. The shop sells works by members of the Southern Highlands Handicraft Guild, and an exhibition gallery is on the second floor. Shows for the fall include a retrospective of sculptural glass works by William Bernstein, which runs to Sept. 30. At Parkway Milepost 382, open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; (704) 298-7928; free.
 
Where to Stay
 Reservations can be hard to find during the height of the leaf season, mid-October.
All glass and steel, the Radisson Hotel Asheville at One Thomas Wolfe Plaza, (800) 438-3960, is a jarring sight next door to the Thomas Wolfe Memorial, built in 1883. Even so, the 281-room hotel is conveniently situated and offers views from its upper-floor rooms and restaurant. One complaint: the carpets were annoyingly stained during a recent stay. A double room is $79 ($52 for people attending the Wolfe Festival).
The Swiss Chalets, 5 Delano Road, (704) 253-6062, are all but hidden by the woods on Beaucatcher Mountain. They are 600 feet above downtown but still only moments from Pack Square. The six modestly furnished cottages have one to three bedrooms, and all are equipped with kitchens, cable television and a deck with grill. A one-bedroom chalet is $75 a night.
In addition to being a historic and esthetic landmark, the Grove Park Inn is a full-fledged resort hotel. It has 510 rooms, three restaurants, golf course and indoor sports center. Rooms in the oldest section retain their original furniture; they are smaller but more appealing. A room for two is $115 to $185.
Richmond Hill Inn, 87 Richmond Hill Drive, (704) 252-7313, is among the most carefully restored and handsomely furnished of the city's inns in old homes. A bit out of the way, it sits alone on a steep hill over the French Broad River. The century-old house has a paneled hall and library, and some of the 12 guest rooms have fireplaces. Nine cottages, also with fireplaces, have been built around a nearby croquet court. Rates for a double room, $115 to $275, includes a full breakfast. The inn's restaurant also serves dinner, afternoon tea and Sunday brunch.
Budget: Motels of every description can be found along Tunnel Road. Econo Lodge, at 190 Tunnel Road, (704) 254-9521, has 53 rooms; the rate for two is $50 until Oct. 9, when it rises to $60. Days Inn, 199 Tunnel Road, (704) 254-4311), has 77 rooms for $35 to $59 on weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 One of Asheville's most ambitious and successful restaurants is 23 Page, 1 Battery Park Avenue in the Haywood Park Hotel, (704) 252-3685. A recent menu included fried quail on a savory lentil cake with pineapple and scallion salsa, beet ravioli with lobster beurre blanc, and Thai pork with papaya and peach salad. The stylish dining room is open and airy, despite a lack of windows. Dinner for two, including a modest wine and a tip, is about $80.
The thoroughly improbable Windmill mixes Italian, German and Indian cuisines in a grotto-like setting under the Innsbruck Mall, 85 Tunnel Road. (704) 253-5285. A popular item on the regular menu is chicken schnitzel with sour cream and dark cherries. A frequent special is the German sampler. Dinner for two with wine is $50 to $60.
The Latin Quarter at 76 Haywood Street, (704) 252-6602, offers dishes inspired by the cuisines of Spain, Cuba and the Caribbean. Paella and Jamaican jerked pork are popular, as are plantains stuffed with black beans, and chayote squash baked with cheese. Live jazz on weekends. Dinner for two with wine or beer is about $45.
Stone Soup, at both 50 Broadway, (704) 255-7687, and 8 Wall Street, (704) 254-0844, offers soups, salads and hefty sandwiches on wholegrain breads. Even the desserts seem healthful. Only the Broadway restaurant, by far the more laidback of the two, is open for dinner. Stir-frys, omelets and other special entrees are added to the self-service line in the evening. Dinner for two $20; wine by the glass $1.30.
One attraction of the Hot Shot Cafe, at 7 Lodge Street at Biltmore Village, (704) 274-2170, is that it is open 24 hours (closed Monday). Another is its country-style steak special. What's more, this place keeps country music on the jukebox and serves wholly acceptable biscuits. Two full meals will cost about $15, at most.
