HEADLINE: THE PARTY CRASHER

 BODY:
Lowi is mistaken when he claims that "the two-party system has long been brain dead." In fact, the two-party system is in the process of rejuvenation. For over two decades, scholars of American politics have claimed that realigning elections -- America's surrogate for revolution -- have become extinct. Historically, such elections have served as a pressure valve for our political system, and at various crises in our history, roughly every 30 years, they ushered in new eras of social and political change.
The election of 1800 marked the beginning of our two-party system; in 1828, white male suffrage was achieved; the election of 1860 insured the maintenance of the union; 1896 ushered in the Industrial Age; active government in the form of the New Deal emerged in 1932, and the struggle for civil rights was settled with the election of 1964 -- the last critical realignment. 
 Each of these elections was triggered by a negative economic or political event resulting in the polarization of the parties. When the critical realigning election occurred, it was characterized by high voter turnout, with a majority of voters reaffirming or changing their party identification. This in turn triggered major changes in the policy agenda, ending stagnation by bringing about dramatic social change for a generation to come.
 
RALPH DA COSTA NUNEZ
Associate Professor of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: THE REPUBLICANS

 BODY:
It is easy to feel frustration for the present ineffectiveness of the Bush Administration. But I would rather sit waiting in the gridlock than go hurtling down the road and straight over the cliff. Do people really have such short memories that they cannot remember the shambles created by the last Democratic Administration? How about 21 percent interest rates, 13 percent inflation, 8 percent unemployment, gas lines and an all-time low in respect internationally? 
 Contrast this to a 30-year low in interest rates, similar unemployment, 4 percent inflation and the fall of Communism. Yes, the choice is certainly disappointing, and yes, Bush has betrayed the conservative cause, but those who put Clinton in the White House will deserve what they get. Unfortunately, the rest of us will have to suffer through it as well.
 
RICHARD J. WERTHER
Novi, Mich.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: In Place of Tennis Bubbles;
New Stores for Woodside

 BODY:
Recession or not, the Meyer family can't resist a chance to develop a piece of Queens. It is now involved with store construction in the Woodside section, a $1.5 million project at Northern Boulevard, 51st Street and Broadway. The family-run Cord Meyer Development Company of Forest Hills is the developer of what it chooses to call the Woodside Shopping Center.
"The community was underserved in the retail segment," said Scott E. Mollen, a spokesman and lawyer for Cord Meyer. 
 The 73,000-square-foot triangular lot is occupied by a 5,200-square-foot Citibank. There were also three tennis bubbles on the land, which have been demolished for what will be a 17,000-square-foot Staples office-supply outlet and a 3,200-square-foot McDonald's. Groundbreaking for the McDonald's is scheduled for next week and for the Staples store next month. There will be parking for 89 cars.
All the structures will be easily visible from Northern Boulevard, said Stephen Sanders of Stephen Sanders & Associates Architects in Manhasset, L.I., although the Staples store will be set back from the street.
The project will be completed by late spring. Another Cord Meyer project -- a 100,000-square-foot expansion of the Bay Terrace shopping center in Bayside -- will be finished by the end of 1993.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Yale Recitals Usher In New Season

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
A RUSH of concerts next weekend suggests that the winding down of summer is just about complete. Friday evening at 8, the first in a cycle of free Yale University faculty recitals offers a performance by the musicians Sidney Harth and Peter Frankl in a program of three violin and piano sonatas Brahms. On Sunday evening at 8, another member of the Yale faculty, the organist Charles Krigbaum, opens the Sunday Evening Music Series at Woolsey Hall, playing works of Ives, Parker and Widor. A $3 donation will be requested at the door (432-4157).
Another Friday evening recital, this one at 8:30 P.M. at the Pequot Library in Southport, finds the Sartory Trio playing Dvorak, Mendelsohn and a new "Jazz Semi-Suite" by Joe Utterback. (227-6943 or 226-1076). Saturday evening at 8, Robert Cumming, founder and director of the Connecticut Gilbert and Sullivan Society, plans to include at least one Sullivan anthem in his recital of "Sacred Song Masterpieces" but works by about a dozen other composers, including Mr. Cumming, will be represented as well. Accompanying the program at the First Church of Christ Scientist in Guilford is the organist of the church for the last 16 years, Esther Barto, and since the concert has been designed as a benefit for Meals on Wheels of Guilford, donations to that organization constitute the admission charge (421-4098). 
 Three Connecticut communities will be the beneficiary of the New World Chamber Ensemble's ninth season, the programs once again balancing musical rarities with audience favorites. Saturday's 8 P.M. opening concert at the Porter Memorial in Farmington offers variations on the latter theme, via a group of "Performers' Favorites." The violinist Anhared Stowe, for instance, has chosen Kreisler's "Schon Rosmarin" and the Meditation from Massenet's "Thais," while the cellist Eric Dahlin has chosen the beautiful though infrequently played sonata by the early 20th-century English composer Frank Bridge. Several of Debussy's etudes are the preferred province of the ensemble's pianist, Gary Chapman, and presumably by unanimous vote, the concert concludes with the Ravel Trio.
The October recital brings the New World back to the Porter Memorial, but in 1993, the ensemble has scheduled a January recital at Westminster School in Simsbury, while a February program (including the world premiere of Stephen Bryc's "Fantasy on a Theme of Bela Bartok") and the March finale will both be in Hartford, at the Unitarian Meeting House and the newly refurbished Aetna Theater respectively. For subscription details or single-ticket reservations, call 658-7909.
Campus concerts in New Haven and Hartford at 3 next Sunday afternoon have the decided advantage of being free. In the library court at the Yale Center for British Art, the violist Mary Hammann, the flutist Laura Gilbert and the harpist Barbara Allen -- or, collectively, the Aureole Trio -- will be exploring the chamber music of Sir Arnold Bax and Alan Rawsthorne (432-2858). At the Austin Arts Center, meanwhile, principal singers of Connecticut Concert Opera and the Trinity College Concert Choir, prepared by Gerald Moshell, will be offering a variety of Italian arias and choral scenes (561-2670).
The Schubert Club of Fairfield County, a nonprofit organization offering a variety of youth and adult programs to encourage participation in and appreciation of music, opens its season next Sunday afternoon at 3, presenting a recital by David Korevaar.
There will be no Schubert this time but the Norwalk-based pianist has promised the three Brahms Intermezzi of Opus 17, Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, the Barcarolle and Fourth Scherzo of Chopin, and the premiere performance of his own solo-piano transcription of Liszt's Symphonic Poem "Festklange" ("Holiday Sounds"). Tickets will be available at the door, but for more information about club activities, call 966-8770.
The Norwalk Symphony does not begin its season until mid-October (with an all-Beethoven concert, featuring the violinist Erick Friedman) but it has been a busy backstage summer, beginning in June when Morton Gould, the composer, conductor and president of ASCAP, presented the organization's award for adventursome programming to the orchestra, its music director, Jesse Levine, and Richard Epstein, chairman of the program committee.
Despite the recession the orchestra has expanded its staff and is planning more extensive outreach services. "The Norwalk Symphony provides more to the community than a fine concert series," said its newly elected president, J. Robert Flagg. "Our mission is to let people understand our role in arts education and to give them many good reasons to be committed to their symphony, to be involved in its growth."
Indicative of that growth is the appointment of Rosemary Cook to the newly created post of executive director, her primary challenge to initiate programs and activities that can build a more diversified audience. The orchestra has also sent out a call for new members: both professional and volunteer musicians are invited to try out for permanent or substitute positions. For an appointment, call 966-6847; the reservation and subscription information number is 866-2455.
The Danbury Music Center and the Connecticut Ballet Theater School have both sent out tryout calls for their annual productions of Tchaikovsky's "Nutcracker" ballet. The principal roles in the presentation will be taken by professionals, but about 100 youngsters, ages 5 through 18, will also be part of the cast. "Prior dance experience is helpful but not essential," said the artistic director Brett Raphael. Open auditions are being held today between 11 A.M and 6:30 P.M. at Klein Memorial Auditorium in Bridgeport (259-3930).
In Danbury, according to the center's executive director Nancy Sudik, "all roles are open to all area dancers from age 6 through adult," with interested applicants invited to perform for the dance director Julianne La Fond next Sunday or the following Saturday, Sept. 26.
There is a $20 audition fee that is refunded if the center cannot find a part for the auditioner. For more details, call 748-1716.

HEADLINE: Keep-It-Simple Retailing Catches On

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
MINIMALIST retail design reached an apogee in New York this year with the opening of the Equipment shirt store: a stainless-steel shelf in the center, a mahogany cabinet to one side and not very much else except the boldly patterned, brightly colored product.
But while this happened in Madison Avenue's rarefied atmosphere, the impulse toward spare design, where architectural features are subordinated to the merchandise, can be found almost anywhere one looks or shops. 
 There is A/X Armani Exchange in SoHo, as well as 32 other locations nationwide, with its concave corrugated aluminum ceiling faintly recalling the quonset hut of a post exchange. Also in SoHo is Pure Madderlake, a flat-black void in which antique and contemporary furnishings and household objects are grouped in small islands, under theatrical lighting. On North Michigan Avenue in Chicago, there is the Sony Gallery, its neutral-colored expanses punctuated by color television screens.
"There are three major things in retailing and it's not, 'Location, location, location,' " said C. Bradley Mendelson, senior managing director and director of retail leasing at the Edward S. Gordon Company, the brokerage that represented Sony. "It's location, design and product."
"The tendency is big, open, clean space -- high ceilings, highly visible, with lots of glass, lots of exposure," said Gary Alterman, executive vice president of the New Spectrum Realty Services brokerage in Manhattan.
And Kenneth H. Walker, chairman and chief executive of the Walker Group/CNI, an architectural and design firm that has worked on the Saks Fifth Avenue and F. A. O. Schwarz flagship stores, as well as Galeries Lafayette on East 57th Street, said: "I think, basically, we're in an antiglitz period. Glitz is out."
Notable exceptions abound, where dark burled woods and heavy brass fixtures are still the rule. Even Equipment's cutting edge is only a block away from Ralph Lauren's richly cluttered, Anglo-clubby Polo store.
But simplicity seems to be the rule.
Esthetics are not the only force behind minimalist store design. Real estate and economic concerns come into play as well.
Simpler stores are by and large less expensive to build. When architectural elements are stripped away to make room for merchandise, retailers benefit from having to rent less stockroom space. They also gain the ability to rearrange the selling floor with relative ease, which helps keep the store looking up to the minute.
Open plans and large windows not only increase visibility from a street or concourse, making greater use of smaller frontages; they also mean that fewer employees are needed to keep watch on the goods.
Moreover, a merchant may have no choice but to preserve a voluminous, high-ceilinged space. If the building has already used up all the floor area it is allowed under zoning rules, a mezzanine -- no matter how devoutly desired -- would not be permitted.
"There's no question that in anything that's involved with real estate you're looking for efficiency in every square inch of space, because there is no room for waste," said David P. Manfredi, a partner in Elkus/ Manfredi Architects, based in Boston, designers of the Sony Gallery.
"The Limited was to my knowledge the first retailer on a national scale to put merchandise up to the ceiling, far beyond what was accessible," Mr. Manfredi said. "What that did was create the illusion of being surrounded by the merchandise, being enveloped by it. At the same time, you were putting stock in the selling space."
Merchants who keep their inventory on the sales floor "don't have to pay high-rent numbers for stock space," said Michael H. Ratner, president of the Richter & Ratner Contracting Corporation of Maspeth, Queens, which specializes in retail construction.
"You can go into a store like the Gap and see the entire store," Mr. Alterman said. "It all pops out at you. You can see from the front to the back because they use low tables, as opposed to shelves and aisles, and all the high stuff is along the perimeter walls. For the retailers, it's a much easier store to manage, because employees can see everything that's going on. In this day and age, that's important."
The Gap was cited as a trend-setter by a number of brokers and architects. "The Gap's got the right idea," said Charles Aug, president of the Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing retail brokerage in Manhattan. "They're fresh, clean, light. And they seem to be doing very well."
But the San Francisco company is reluctant to talk. "We really don't do real-estate stories," said Richard Crisman, a Gap spokesman.
He declined to furnish specific information, saying only that stores are designed by an "in-house team" and "an outside company that we work with." There are "a couple" of prototype stores, he said.
Absent any official confirmation, the Gap's design philosophy might be summed up as: Let the product speak for itself. And many others are following the same course.
"To really see retail trends, go to a mall," Mr. Walker said. "You'll see less complexity, less architecture for architecture's sake, and more attention to merchandising and visual presentation. A store that would have paid $100 a square foot is now looking to spend $75, by simplifying the presentation and letting the merchandise be the hero."
A walk through Roosevelt Field in Garden City, L.I., bears out his observation. Shopfronts tend to be little more than sheets of plate glass, showing off interiors where colors and textures and patterns are provided by the merchandise, not the architecture.
Looking rather incongruous in this environment is Structure, a menswear unit of the Limited. Here, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe -- father of the dictum, "Less is more" -- is one of the featured icons in a more-is-more decor that creates a kind of clublike environment based on the theme of architecture.
Structure stores have colossal fluted columns (made of Fiberglas but looking like marble) that are topped by Ionic capitals with scrolls the size of serving platters; vastly oversized blueprints that cover entire walls; seating areas with Mies's Barcelona chairs, Le Corbusier's Gran Confort chairs, and architectural journals and monographs on coffee tables; entablatures with egg-and-dart moldings; a Grecian urn or two and even quotes from Mies, Corbusier and Frank Lloyd Wright on the walls.
THERE are now 299 Structure stores, including one at 7 West 34th Street that opened about a month ago. "Of all the businesses we have, this was more successful from the get-go than almost any other," said Charles W. Hinson, president of store planning for the Limited, in Columbus, Ohio. He credited the final design development to Debbie Urton, vice president of design.
Mr. Manfredi, one of several architects who worked on a prototype of the Structure store, said the structural elements were meant to "reinforce the quality of architecture as a masculine profession."
"The design is of such solid substance that it will have staying power," Mr. Hinson said.
Staying power is a considerable concern when it comes to retail design. If a store stops appearing fresh, it may find itself in trouble.
That was one of the reasons that Tom Pritchard, an architect, and his partner, Billy Jarecki, chose a bare-bones approach to Pure Madderlake, a flower and housewares store on Broadway, near Broome Street.
"Since the architecture is so minimal, we can reconfigure it," Mr. Pritchard said. "We're not married to a system. We can bring things forward or push them back. People can come into the store two weeks later and feel it's a whole new experience."
But the design also fit with the store's philosophy. "We have a number of extraordinary objects that are each individually beautiful," Mr. Pritchard said. "It was not at all about store design per se but a setting in which the objects themselves could be seen to best advantage."
The architect of the A/X Armani Exchange store, Naomi Leff, of Naomi Leff & Associates, also said it was the nature of the merchant -- not the currency of the esthetic -- that dictated the design.
"A STORE is a three-dimensional representation of the business," she said. "The Giorgio Armani esthetic has to do with simplicity. It's a modernist, minimalist esthetic."
For pure minimalism, there would seem to be few rivals to Equipment, which has three stores in Paris, two in London and one at 872 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street, which opened five months ago. The architects were David Chipperfield, of London, and William Fellows and Anton Martinez, of the Manhattan firm Fellows Martinez Associates.
In the center of the space is a stainless-steel frame, 5 feet high and 18 feet long, with frosted-glass shelves on which shirts are fastidiously arranged in piles of three. As a counterpoint, there is a mahogany cabinet closer to the rear wall, with more shirts. The cash-register stand is steel. The walls are white and the floors are gray limestone.
Unlike Structure, where Mies is invoked, Equipment has a truly Miesian feeling in its austerity, rectilinearity and sparing use of luxurious material. The goal, Mr. Martinez said, was to "create a background for the merchandise without having an architecture that's too self conscious."
But he said that Spartan design was hard to sell to the higher quality boutiques. "They want more marble, wood trim, Essex green," he said. "The English storefront -- that's what they're looking for."
That approach seems to have paid off at Coach for Business, at Madison Avenue and 44th Street. In this leather goods and accessories shop, part of the Sara Lee Corporation, one is enveloped by dark wood cabinetry. "It's a much warmer feeling," said Mr. Ratner, whose firm was the contractor. "It's like being in your own library -- you should be so lucky as to have a library like that."
Mr. Mendelson, who represented the owners, said there had been a clothing store in the space, with an all-glass facade, that did poor business. "Coach took over the lease and put in more money per square foot than anyone else on the block," he said. "I have tenants on that block who cry that business is terrible. And then Coach comes along and does better business than anyone."

HEADLINE: Primaries Find Party Lines A Bit Blurred

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
IN an election year that finds Connecticut voters struggling with unemployment and higher taxes -- and little hope that either will be alleviated soon -- primary elections in four of the state's six Congressional districts on Tuesday are offering candidates whose attempts to satisfy as many people as possible often leave the contenders straddling party lines.
The most dramatic example is in the First Congressional District, where Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a five-term Democrat from Hartford, has enjoyed wide popularity in a largely Democratic district. A time-honored belief is that no Republican can win in the First District (the last one was elected in 1956 and trounced two years later), and to counter that, the state Republican Party this year has endorsed a Democrat to run against Mrs. Kennelly. That candidate, Robert F. Ludgin, a former deputy mayor of Hartford, is running on the slogan "A Choice for a Change," and faces a Republican primary challenge from Philip L. Steele, a Hartford lawyer. 
 Explaining the highly unusual move, state party chairman Richard Foley said the only Republican to declare his candidacy, Mr. Steele, had failed to make much contact with state party officials until just before the convention in July. "We thought we should be looking for the guy's picture on a milk carton," Mr. Foley said. The convention's endorsement vote was deadlocked until its chairman cast another vote in favor of Mr. Ludgin, whose record in Hartford -- a pair of tax cuts and an emphasis on basic services -- held appeal for some Republicans. Mr. Steele said he believed that Mr. Foley pressured convention delegates to support his opponent, but said he thought he had wider recognition in the district and therefore a better shot at winning the primary. "Are we building up the Republican Party, or are we going to throw it all away by sending a message to the voters that says we can't even field a candidate?" asked Mr. Steele, a former candidate for mayor of Hartford. The crossover seems to have caused problems for Mr. Ludgin as well. Some Republicans, he said, seem suspicious of a Democrat who wants to represent their interests. "I'm trying to say, they ought not to consider what uniform I'm wearing, but whether I'm willing to go to bat for them and hit a home run," said Mr. Ludgin, who had been known to break with the Democratic establishment while a city official. As for where he would sit if elected to Congress, he said that although he had spent 31 of the last 52 years as a Democrat, he thought he would sit with the Republicans and vote with them on many issues. "I've got a reputation in Hartford for being an independent cuss," Mr. Ludgin said. "I'm not signing up for the Army. I'm running for Congress, for myself."
In addition to the four Congressional primaries on Tuesday, Republican voters statewide will choose a candidate for the United States Senate and voters in both parties in scattered districts across the state will pick candidates for the State Senate and State House of Representatives. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.
 
U.S. Senate
 In the Republican race for the United States Senate, Chris Burnham, a two-term State Representative from Stamford, has been endorsed by the state Republican convention. But his opponent, Brook Johnson, a businessman and political neophyte who lives in Greenwich, is mounting a sophisticated campaign, replete with television commercials urging voters to support him as someone who would bring badly needed business acumen to the Senate.
Both Republicans have fairly similar positions on many issues, favoring tax incentives to revive the battered Connecticut economy and supporting a balanced-budget amendment. The greatest differences are in their resumes, their campaigning styles and their war chests, with Mr. Burnham spending just over $400,000 so far on his method, which has included a 150-mile trek on foot around parts of the state, and Mr. Johnson already up to that level on television and radio advertisements alone.
The winner will face Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat who is completing his second six-year term, in November.
 
Fifth Congressional District
 Perhaps the most vociferous primary campaign is being waged by two Democrats in the Fifth District, a bat-shaped portion of the state's western half that includes battered industrial centers like Waterbury and Ansonia, but also bucolic suburbs like Wilton and Monroe. There Lynn Taborsak, a State Representative and licensed plumber from Danbury, has been engaged in a war of rhetoric with her Democratic opponent, Jim Lawlor, a probate judge from Waterbury.
Aides to both Democrats say the incumbent, Gary Franks, a freshman who is the only black Republican in Congress, is extremely vulnerable. But in the meantime, the primary has taken on elements of a schoolyard fight. In particular, Ms. Taborsak has been put on the defensive over a bill she had sponsored that would have required the teaching of masturbation in public school sex-education courses, according to the Lawlor camp. "She authored it, and it's outrageous," said Chris French, a spokesman for Mr. Lawlor, offering to fax a copy to a reporter and adding, "Jim Lawlor finds it tasteless and he won't discuss it."
Karlyn Sturmer, the campaign director for Ms. Taborsak, called the legislation "a nonexistent entity that has taken on a life of its own." Ms. Taborsak wrote the bill in 1990 only to block another amendment, offered by a conservative colleague, that would have required schools to teach abstinence for curbing teen-age pregnancy and the spread of AIDS, she said. "It was a means of saving the rest of the bill, and it killed that amendment," Ms. Sturmer said. "These conservative, right-wing guys were not going to get up and discuss the M-word."
The two Democrats are far apart on other issues as well. Ms. Taborsak supports the right to an abortion, and Mr. Lawlor does not. He emphasizes developing businesses in cities that have lost jobs, like Waterbury, and his campaign accuses Ms. Taborsak of being a "tunnel-vision, tax-and-spend" politician. Ms. Taborsak, on the other hand, has accused Mr. Lawlor of accepting donations from lawyers who might appear before him in court. Mr. Lawlor had received the endorsement of the district Democratic convention, while Ms. Taborsak has been endorsed by A Connecticut Party, the third party formed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. when he ran for office. Thus, even if she loses the Democratic primary, Ms. Taborsak could continue in the race as a third-party candidate,
 
Second Congressional District
 In the Second Congressional District in eastern Connecticut, two Republicans are vying for the right to challenge Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat, in November. One of them, Glenn T. Carberry, ran against Mr. Gejdenson four years ago and lost decidedly, but thinks he may do better this year.
"The major issues are jobs and our economic future," Mr. Carberry, a New London lawyer, said last week. The district, which covers most of the eastern half of the state, includes many rural communities as well as cities and towns long dependent on military contracts for jobs. Mr. Carberry has never held public office before, although during the Persian Gulf war he engaged in efforts like handing out bumper stickers that read "I Support Our Troops in the Gulf."
His opponent in the primary, Ed Munster, is a statistician who has served in the State Senate. A man who bears a remarkable physical resemblance to former Democratic Presidential candidate Michael S. Dukakis, Mr. Munster said he thought he had the experience and the recognition in the district to win both the primary and the November general election.
"I've been involved in local government and been elected State Senator," Mr. Munster said. "Glenn Carberry has never been elected to any office." He added: "I have two kids in college, a mortgage on my house and a note on my car. I'm very much like the other people in this district." If elected, he said, he would continue an effort to help small businesses through tax abatements and other programs.
 
Sixth Congressional District
 The situation in the Sixth District is reminiscent of that in the First, with a popular incumbent, Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a five-term Republican from New Britain. The district, which covers the northwest quarter of Connecticut, is being fought over by a pair of Democrats, Gene Slason, an accountant from Southington, and Alan DiCara of Winsted.
Mr. Slason, who has been endorsed by the district Democratic convention, said in a telephone interview that he believed he was ahead in the primary and could beat Mrs. Johnson in November. "There's never been a more volatile electorate," he said. He supports a national health insurance plan and reforms in Congress, such as a 12-year term limit for members of the House and restrictions on spending, and says he will promote Connecticut's economy if elected.
Mr. DiCara, a 42-year-old political newcomer who works for a garage-door installation company, said he would decline the most recent pay raise for members of Congress, push for quality health insurance for all Americans, and promote an economic plan that calls for slashing defense spending by $500 billion and allocating the savings toward a tax cut and a reduction of the Federal deficit. "I expect to win the primary in a landslide and go on to win in November," Mr. DiCara said.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 780 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The American Banknote Company Building;
A Bronx Hybrid: Mill, or an Arsenal?

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
IT'S a point of reference for millions of motorists, the biggest building on either side of the Bruckner Expressway. But the sprawling hillside complex in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx has always had a mysterious, fortified air -- a cross between a textile mill and an arsenal.
Now the American Banknote Company Building at the corner of Tiffany Street and Lafayette Avenue is up for landmark designation. The owners are not protesting. They have the larger problem of keeping the Bronx Apparel Center filled with tenants. 
 The American Banknote Company was founded in 1858 as a merger of several engraving and printing firms. Until the Bureau of Printing and Engraving was established in 1877, it printed currency and stamps, in addition to securities and other documents for foreign and American customers. By the turn of the century it occupied factory-office space at 78-86 Trinity Place, behind the Trinity churchyard.
In 1908, seeking to expand on less expensive land, the company bought a large irregular block in the Bronx bounded by Tiffany and Barretto Streets and Garrison and Lafayette Avenues. The new plant, completed in 1911, brought in over 2,000 skilled laborers earning $40 to $75 a week to a section still largely open for development.
The firm of Kirby, Petit & Green had already designed a new neo-Classical executive office for American Banknote on Trinity Place; it gave the newly separated factory operation an unabashedly industrial look.
The building is T-shaped, with a red-brick facade and great windows set in massive arched bays. The upright of the T is a chubby, three-story building for the printing operations, with banks of sawtooth skylights on the top. The top member of the T is skinny, five stories high, with a central crenelated tower, running 466 feet along Lafayette Avenue. Lafayette rises steeply to the east along this front, perhaps 40 feet, and the slim factory outlined by this steep grade and capped by the tower is an unmistakable juxtaposition of architecture and topography.
In 1909 The New York Times noted that the building was planned with only one entrance although it has over 1,500 feet of street front. Architecture & Building magazine remarked on its "arsenal-like appearance with a pervading sense of strength and security." Indeed, this is the element that marks the American Banknote Building as a hybrid. It has wide, factory windows and a typically open factory plan. But it also has the fortified look of an armory -- and it has no prominent gate.
Until 1941, Joseph R. Ford occupied a room in the tower with a special mission -- he attempted to counterfeit, under the most favorable conditions, the company's currency, stock certificates and other products. His efforts were carefully analyzed to improve the company's engraving, papers and inks. By 1961, The Saturday Evening Post reported that in one day over 5 million pieces of paper were processed. The company was at that time printing half of the securities of the New York Stock Exchange. By 1980, food stamps were 8 percent of sales.
IN 1985, the company moved to Blauvelt, N.Y. Walter Cahn and Max Blauner, already active in textiles and real estate, bought the building and created the Bronx Apparel Center, drawing manufacturing refugees from high Manhattan rents. "Labor supply here is the best," says Mr. Blauner. "In the beginning it was very good, we filled up in three years." There are good subway connections and the building has sweeping views of Long Island Sound and Hell Gate.
But now as rents have fallen to $7 or $8 a square foot in Manhattan, the $4 a square foot that makes the 425,000-square-foot Bronx Apparel Center profitable is no longer competitive; Mr. Blauner says that offers come in at $2.50 a square foot. He feels part of the problem is reporting about crime in the Bronx. "In Manhattan, they just say the individual street but up here it's just 'the Bronx,' " he says.
In June, the Landmarks Preservation Commission held hearings on designating the American Banknote Company Building as part of the effort by Laurie Beckelman, its chairwoman, to expand activity beyond Manhattan.
The owners of large industrial buildings generally do not consider landmark designation economically valuable. But the owners of the American Banknote Building did not appear at the hearing to oppose it.
"Once they start something you have to spend a lot of money to fight it" says Mr. Blauner. "We'd lose -- and anyway it's a beautiful building for preservation. But the city has almost tripled our real estate taxes in five years and we've just lost tenants for 200,000 square feet. We are in a bad way."

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: Focus: St. Augustine, Fla.;
A Golf Community, Plus P.G.A. Complex

BYLINE: By RUTH REJNIS

DATELINE: ST. AUGUSTINE, FLA.

 BODY:
AT a 6,300-acre site eight miles north of downtown, yet another scenario is about to be enacted on how to market a residential community based on golf.
But the developer of Saint Johns, as the community will be known, says he is offering more than usual -- a different layout plus a 450-acre business-entertainment complex that will be built on the site by the P.G.A. (Professional Golf Association) Tour Inc. 
 How different a layout? For one thing, said James L. Davidson Jr. of Jacksonville, Fla., the Saint Johns developer, homes will be set away from the golf course.
"Golfers won't have to feel as though they're playing in someone's backyard," he said. And for residents, golf won't "take over the residential experience." And unlike other golf courses, he said, this one won't emphasize water-oriented hazards.
Saint Johns will rise in the county of the same name in northeast Florida. Straddling Interstate 95, it will consist of 7,200 residential units, predominantly one-family, detached houses selling for $125,000 to more than $350,000, plus some rental apartments renting for about $600 for a two-bedroom. The breakdown of for-sale and rental units has not yet been determined.
There will also be 2.5 million square feet of office space, 562,000 square feet of retail space and 2.46 million square feet of industrial space, 1,225 hotel rooms, and pools, tennis courts and an 18-hole golf course.
Mr. Davidson said commercial lots would go on sale next spring and residential lots in the fall of 1993.
A 70-acre regional park is planned, and the community will include more than 2,700 acres of environmentally protected land. The community, which is expected to take 15 to 20 years to complete, will have an elementary, middle and high school and eventually have a population of 18,000. No architect has yet been selected.
Construction of an 82-acre clover leaf interchange that will direct visitors to Saint Johns will begin at the end of the summer at I-95 and Nine Mile Road. Next spring, work will begin on the $140 million P.G.A. business-and-entertainment complex. Still in the design stage, it will have a golf Hall of Fame, a golf academy, a resort hotel and offices for P.G.A. Tour Productions, which produces national television programs and videos about the sport. All will be in separate buildings around two 18-hole golf courses.
"If you're building on a large scale in Florida in the 1990's," said Mr. Davidson, "and you have access to I-95 or I-75 or some other major highway, it's clearly an economic plus to have a tourist-like attraction in the development. We have that with the P.G.A. complex."
Residential communities wrapped around headquarters buildings for golf associations are hardly new to Florida. In Palm Beach Gardens, a dozen miles northwest of Palm Beach, the P.G.A. National Resort and Spa opened in 1980 and is still building homes for $134,900 to over $700,000. The headquarters for P.G.A. of America, which oversees golf club professionals, is in that complex.
That resort also offers five 18-hole golf courses, a 335-room hotel, 19 tennis courts, a shopping center and what P.G.A. National says is the largest croquet complex in the Western Hemisphere.
THE Ladies Professional Golf Association, based in Daytona Beach, about 50 miles south of St. Augustine, also has a golf headquarters linked to a residential community on the drawing board. Like St. Johns, it will be along heavily traveled I-95. where it crosses I-92, in Volusia County.
Now in temporary quarters in Daytona Beach, where it relocated from Texas in 1989, the L.P.G.A. has targeted a 4,000-acre site for a planned community that will be built jointly by the city and the private sector.
The project is in the approval stage on some phases, said Kathryn H. Milthorpe, director of finance and administration for the L.P.G.A. The city began construction last June on the first of two municipal golf courses that will be on the site.
The name, for the time being, is L.P.G.A. Daytona Beach Resort.
Residential and commercial facilities are under the aegis of Indigo Development Inc., the development arm of Consolidated-Tomoka Land Company, which owns many citrus groves in the state.
The Saint Johns site is owned by William B. Dunavant Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Dunavant Enterprises, the world's largest cotton brokerage, with headquarters in Memphis. The company has developed smaller commercial and residential communities in other parts of the country. Cummer Land Trust, a family property holding based in Jacksonville, has a small ownership stake in the site.
Mr. Dunavant hired Mr. Davidson in 1987 to take over the development, then in the planning stage and known as Saint Johns Harbor. At the time, Mr. Davidson was with Arvida Corporation, developer of residential and business communities in several southern states. Arvida also developed Sawgrass, the resort community at Ponte Vedra Beach, about 10 miles east of the Saint Johns site.
Sawgrass is the home of the P.G.A. Tour, which is the sanctioning body for men's professional golf. The headquarters of P.G.A. Tour, a nonprofit, tax-exempt organization, will remain in Sawgrass.
Mr. Davidson noted that the Saint Johns community, exclusive of the P.G.A. buildings, "requires no financing" and "is a debt-free project, with 100 percent equity."
He expects that when it comes to selling homes his principal competition will be Ponte Vedra Beach and Jacksonville, a city of 635,000 whose southern limits are 15 miles north of Saint Johns.
He expects minor rivalry from Palm Coast, a similar community minus a high-profile tourist attraction, about 35 miles south and also off I-95. ITT Community Development Corporation began developing that 48,000-acre site, with homes in many price ranges, some 20 years ago.
ALL of northeast Florida has experienced sizable growth over the last decade, with Jacksonville, its largest metropolitan area, showing a nearly 25 percent increase in population since the 1980 census. The Jacksonville International Airport recently underwent expansion and a nearly $3 million expansion plan was announced earlier this year for the St. Augustine Airport, about five miles from Saint Johns.
Lightly settled, St. Johns County has a population of just 90,000. St. Augustine, the nation's oldest permanent European settlement, and the principal tourism attraction for the northeast corner of the state, is the county seat and, with 12,000 people, has the second largest population in the county, after Ponte Vedra Beach, which has about 25,000 residents..
There are other mixed-use communities in varying stages of development in northeast Florida, although none on the scale of Saint Johns. One is about 20 miles to the north and west of the Saint Johns community, in equally sparsely populated Clay County. Ground-breaking took place earlier this summer for a 2,600-acre residential and commercial project on Fleming Island, a peninsula along the St. John's River.
That $150 million planned community, which will be developed in the next 12 to 16 years, calls for 4,600 residential units -- most of them one-family homes ranging from $100,000 to $350,000 -- plus retail, commercial and industrial space. And an 18-hole golf course.
Co-developers of the project, known as the Crossings at Fleming Island, are East West Partners of Richmond, Va., and Champion Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of Champion International Corporation, a paper company based in Stamford, Conn. The site is a former tree farm owned by Champion.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
For Florida, a 6,300-Acre Golf Community

BYLINE: By RUTH REJNIS

Co-developers of the project, known as the Crossings at Fleming Island, are East West Partners of Richmond, Va., and Champion Realty Corporation, a subsidiary of Champion International Corporation, a paper company based in Stamford, Conn. The site is a former tree farm owned by Champion.

HEADLINE: At 91, State's Senior Citizen of Year

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
WHEN R. Eugene Curry found out that he had been selected 1992 New York State Senior Citizen of the Year by the State Senate and Assembly Standing Committees on Aging, he was, he said, "absolutely surprised." But the selection of Mr. Curry, now 91 years old, came as no surprise to those familiar with his work over the years.
"He is the founding father of aging services in Westchester," said Mae Carpenter, director of the Westchester County Office for the Aging. "He was instrumental in starting one of the first advocacy offices for the aging in this country. He accomplished this before the Federal funding came through to officially start such an office in 1973." 
 But Mr. Curry, a man whose trademark is a flower in the lapel of his jacket, rejects the founding father title. "That is a misnomer," he said in a recent interview in the Armonk home he has shared with his wife, Margery, for 64 years. "I was working with others who were having these great ideas. I was part of it but not the founding father. I just helped others carry out ideas."
Mr. Curry began working with the elderly in 1947 as administrator and treasurer of the still-functioning private Osborn Retirement Community in Rye. Born in Kansas, Mr. Curry settled in Westchester in 1927 and went into real estate. He managed the properties of the Osborn Home before becoming administrator of the home. He stayed as administrator until 1971.
 
A Growth in Regulations
 "There were wonderful people there," Mr. Curry said of the home's residents. "They had wisdom and wit. It was most interesting to be associated with them, and I enjoyed it very much."
In those days, there were few regulations governing the operation of a nursing home. Mr. Curry pointed out that the only inspections involved the County Board of Health's checking the faucets of the milk dispensers. Today, nursing home operators face myriad regulations, all part of the "necessary balances" in Mr. Curry's view. "The abuses of the past cried too high too often, and the deceit and fraud perpetuated on the old was not right," he said.
Public attitudes toward aging were also much different back then. "When I started out, people felt themselves older at 70 than they do today," he said. "Today at 70 they want to keep working and have laws to allow it."
While working at the Osborn home, Mr. Curry got involved in many issues affecting the elderly. He became a member of the Westchester Council of Social Agencies, a volunteer advisory body, and was chairman of the Westchester County Committee for the Aging and Chronically Ill from 1954 to 1974. While on the council, Mr. Curry helped establish the Senior Information and Referral Service, which later became the model for the County Office for the Aging. He also helped form the New York State Association of Homes and Services for the Aging.
 
A Conference Organizer
 When he retired from the Osborn Home, he continued working in the field. Mr. Curry organized several counties in the state in 1971 to participate in that year's White House Conference for the Aging.
"Aging was not as popular an issue back then as it is now," said Daniel Sambol, head of social services for the Andrus Retirement Community in Hastings-on-Hudson. Mr. Sambol worked with Mr. Curry on the White House Conference and other matters. "Gene Curry made an enormous contribution. He was a driving force on behalf of the elderly. He is a very fine, decent human being."
In addition to his work with the elderly, Mr. Curry has been involved in many other community projects, ranging from being chairman of the Mianus Gorge Preserve for 13 years to co-founding the Banksville Community House, a recreation hall for youths in Armonk, in 1937.
He also taught as an adjunct professor of economics at New York University from 1930 to 1973. An avid painter since 1947, he received an associate degree in fine arts from Westchester Community College at the age of 87.
 
Inspired by His Wife
 Mr. Curry credits his wife of 64 years, Margery, as being his inspiration and support. Together, they raised four children, Margaret C. Gregg, Janet C. Harrison, Dr. Renwick E. Curry and John P. M. Curry. They have 14 grandchildren and 8 great-grandchildren.
"I try to keep thinking ahead, not backward," Mr. Curry said. "You can't let your mind dwell in the past or you won't get very far. There is still so much to be done for the elderly on issues like home and residential care, day care and Meals on Wheels supplements."
Mr. Curry is the second consecutive Westchester resident chosen as Senior Citizen of the Year. Last year's award went to John Winer of White Plains.

HEADLINE: For Dr. Grebstein, There Comes a Time'

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
DR. Sheldon N. Grebstein, a literary critic and scholar who has served as the president of the State University of New York at Purchase since 1981, announced last Wednesday that he will resign the post in July. In making official the news that he had told the faculty here some weeks ago, Dr. Grebstein said he was not leaving in defeat or to protest the budget cuts that have plagued the 64 State University campuses but because "it's time."
"I will have been in the job for 12 years, which is more than twice the national average of college presidential terms," Dr. Grebstein said. "There comes a time when it's good for the university and good for me, too." 
 Dr. Grebstein said his approaching 65th birthday in February had also influenced his decision. He noted that his 19 years as an administrator -- including 6 years as the dean of arts and sciences at the State University at Binghamton and its undergraduate liberal arts division, Harpur College -- had not left much time for "teaching, scholarship or the exploration of new fields of knowledge." He hopes to join the Purchase faculty as a professor of literature, he said.
 
Guardian of Academic Programs
 The tweedy president, a specialist in 20th-century American literature who has written or edited 6 books and published 32 essays and reviews, has been widely praised throughout the Purchase community for safeguarding academic programs during a time of steep cutbacks in the State University budget. Citing figures from the university chancellor, Dr. D. Bruce Johnstone, Dr. Grebstein said the university had absorbed $283 million in permanent cuts during the last four years alone.
Noting what he termed the "unique mission" of the Purchase school as "a first-rate quality public college oriented to the visual and performing arts," Dr. Johnstone said Dr. Grebstein had shown "extraordinary leadership in the toughest decade this university has faced."
Richard Maass, chairman of the Purchase College Council, which will choose a new president, said, "One of the surprising things" that Dr. Grebstein did was to lead the college's first capital campaign. "He never did it before, and he did a hell of a job," Mr. Maass said of the drive -- called the Campaign for Creativity -- which raised $6.13 million for the school from September 1991 through last May.
During Dr. Grebstein's tenure, the campus here -- although seen by some as remote and austere -- has become an important focus for local performing arts groups and adults enrolled in the division of continuing education. Although the school's efforts to balance community needs with the needs of its academic divisions have not pleased everyone, local arts leaders say the Performing Arts Center, a four-theater complex on the campus, is now an indispensable community fixture.
 
Praise From Conductors
 "Without the Performing Arts Center, there would be no professional symphony orchestra in Westchester County," said Paul Lustig Dunkel, the music director of the New Orchestra of Westchester. The orchestra will begin its 10th season on Sept. 19 in Theater A. Richard Kapp, the music director of the Philharmonia Virtuosi, which has performed at the center since 1977, said Dr. Grebstein's "balanced position" had been largely effective in assuring community access to the theaters.
Dr. Grebstein also reached out to the county's schoolchildren with the SUNY Purchase Westchester School Partnership, a multifaceted program for academically gifted and disadvantaged students, and for teachers.
In a conversation in his office here on the college's opening day last Tuesday, Dr. Grebstein said he had held fast to academic positions while letting maintenance, administrative and clerical jobs go. Noting that New York State is ranked 34th in per capita allotment of state funds for higher education and 47th in the percentage of state tax revenues earmarked for public colleges and universities, Dr. Grebstein said he was "very disappointed in how we've been treated budgetarily" by the administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The university must lobby the state government for its budget, while individual campuses appeal to the chancellor for their own needs. The Board of Regents must approve any new degree programs at the university but exercises no control over the university budget or student issues.
The Legislature reduced its contribution to the State University this year by $143 million, an amount that was expected to be offset partly by the third tuition raise in two years. Full-time tuition for undergraduates is now $2,650 for state residents and $6,550 for out-of-state residents.
 
Divisional Rivalry Persists
 All was not so bleak in the early years of the college, said Michael A. Trolen, an associate professor of visual arts who joined the faculty in 1972. He recalled the school then as "a burgeoning, growing, optimistic institution" whose forward movement was thwarted by "escalating oil prices and out-of-sight inflation."
Dr. Grebstein said that when he took the helm, "this was a young school that was supposed to be growing and developing." He added, "There was supposed to be a lot of money available, and we were supposed to be getting 37 new faculty members."
Instead, he said, "we lost 11 staff positions the first year and 65 the next."
Shrinking funds have not helped the rivalry between the college's two divisions, the School of the Arts and the College of Letters and Science, and some say they hope a new president will resolve "the persona issue" and bring the school's identity into focus.
 
The Arts and More
 "We're known for the arts, but we do a lot of other important things, too," said Dr. Alfred N. Hunt, Dean of the College of Letters and Science, where students study economics, biology, math, literature and history. Mr. Maass, the council chairman, said that while such well-known alumni as the actor Wesley Snipes, a 1988 Purchase graduate, brought recognition to the school, achievements by alumni of the College of Letters and Science were less well publicized.
Dr. Grebstein said that one of the most "difficult and challenging jobs" facing a new president was "to keep the original vision of the college and create a marvelous synergy between the arts and the liberal arts." He conceded that such a synthesis, in which the two divisions enriched and complemented each other, had not been attained during his tenure.
"It takes money to create programs in which arts and liberal arts students and faculty work together," Dr. Grebstein said. He added that if he had the money, he would create "a whole curriculum" to give students from both divisions "a common experience."
That was one deferred dream he would work on this year, he said. Also, he would continue to lobby the State Legislature for permission to build faculty and staff housing on campus. "No one can afford to live around here," the president said. "It's hard to recruit and keep faculty in the natural sciences," especially, "because they've got to live close to their labs."
 
Deterioration Cited
 Dr. Grebstein said the money raised in the Campaign for Creativity would be used for scholarships, student performances and exhibitions, visiting-artist and scholar programs and scientific research. The Melville Scholars Program, a tutorial program for minority students considered "at risk," has already begun, he said.
"Not a penny" of the money would be used to replace missing state dollars or to shore up loose bricks, Dr. Grebstein said, although the widespread deterioration of the campus is often and loudly lamented.
Students describe leaking hot water pipes in residence halls, music practice rooms so cold that young musicians get tendonitis and "apartments on campus that are falling apart," one senior said. Full-time enrollment is 2,900, and there are about 1,300 part-time students. Of those, 1,625 live on campus. Undergraduates in all departments said they loved the college and believed they were getting an excellent education there.
"I respect the teachers here a lot," said Andrew Dancescu, a senior majoring in music composition and classical guitar. "It's a great faculty," agreed Laura Heady, a sophomore in the dance division. "We work as a unit to get around budget cuts."
 
A Comparison With Yale
 John Doherty, a senior majoring in design technology, said the theater division was "starting to be compared to Yale and N.Y.U.," although budget cutbacks had eliminated some of "the Broadway people who used to come here to teach" as adjuncts.
Helene Tyler, a senior math major, said, "All the emotional and intellectual things are here in as full force as ever." She said she was concerned, however, that the academic and cultural diversity of the campus, which had originally drawn her here, would be hurt by rising tuitions. "A lot of my minority friends in the city aren't coming back," said Milton Mino, a political science major from Brooklyn.
The Purchase College Council will recommend a new president to the Chancellor, who must pass the recommendation to the university's Board of Trustees. Mr. Maass, the council chairman, said that a search committee would be in place by the end of September and that a choice would be made in about six months. The group would seek "someone who recognizes the uniqueness of the institution" and could balance the needs of both divisions, he said.
Dr. Nathaniel H. Siegel, senior vice president for academic affairs, said there was no doubt who should follow Dr. Grebstein. "We're going to look for a messiah," he said.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

FREE-TRADE LECTURE
 The North American Free Trade Agreement, if ratified by the participating countries of the United States, Canada and Mexico, will eliminate customs duties on thousands of products and create changes in other areas of trade. 
 A comprehensive discourse on its ramifications will be given by Rodman C. Rockefeller, chairman of the United States Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee, at the World Trade Club of Westchester on Friday. The luncheon meeting will be held at the Tarrytown Hilton Inn at 455 South Broadway and will begin with an 11:30 A.M. reception.
The committee made contributions to the agreement in liberalizing Mexican trade policies. Mr. Rockefeller, an advocate of economic development for minorities, is also director of the United States-Mexico Commission for Educational and Cultural Exchange.
A resident of Westchester, he serves on the boards of numerous institutions, including the Americas Society, Council of the Americas, Phelps Memorial Hospital, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Museum of Modern Art.
Tickets for the luncheon are $40 and can be reserved by calling 948-6444 no later than Wednesday.
 
PAINTING EXHIBITION
 Renee Kahn is well-known in Connecticut, particularly in her hometown of Stamford, for saving worthwhile old buildings as head of the Historic Neighborhood Preservation Program, which she founded almost two decades ago. In some instances she has been instrumental in providing low-cost housing through the restoration of old residential stock.
In addition, she has taught preservation theory and technique at area colleges and universities and testified at local and state hearings on the historic significance of threatened buildings.
In her spare time she paints, using her educational background in fine arts. A showing of her roguish pictures opens at the Schoolhouse Gallery on Owens Road in Croton Falls today with a reception from 2 to 5 P.M.
She said that she has been influenced by Max Beckmann, George Grosz and Marc Chagall but that her work is not as ferocious as that of Beckmann or Grosz's or as whimsical as Chagall's. In a series on the Seven Deadly Sins, she depicts Envy as two portly matrons eyeing two younger and more lissome women in a dressing room at Loehmann's.
The exhibition, which includes a collection of cartoons from the 20's through the 40's, will remain through Oct. 11. Viewing hours are Thursday through Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. Call 277-8477 for more information.
 
BROADWAY HITS
 Patrick A'Hearn, Loni Ackerman, Marcy Degonge and Julie Waldman- Stiel have appeared in various roles in the Broadway productions of "Les Miserables," "Cats," "Evita" and "The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber," eminently qualifying them as starring members of the cast of "A Night of Broadway's Greatest" at the Yorktown Performing Arts Theater onSaturday at 8 P.M.
The single performance consists of excerpts from musicals that have won Tony Awards, and the soloists will be joined by singers, dancers and the orchestra of the Yorktown Regional Theater Company.
The theater is on Veterans Road in Yorktown Heights, and tickets are $13, $15 and $18. Call 962-6665 for reservations.
 
GERMAN FILM CLASSIC
 When "Madchen in Uniform" was produced in Germany in 1931, and shown in many countries including the United States, it received universally favorable reviews.
The film stars Mady Christians and has an all-female cast, most of them young girls portraying students in a German girls' school where discipline and psychological manipulation are now viewed by film scholars as early portents of the Germany to come.
It will be shown on Friday at 8 P.M. in the Academic Arts Building of Westchester Community College in Valhalla. Admission is $4; people 65 and older pay $3. The college is at 75 Grasslands Road. Call 285-6700 for more information.
 
PLANT SYMPOSIUM
 The Nutraceutical Revolution is what Dr. Stephen L. DeFelice of Harvard's Biomedical Research Management Program calls the current emphasis on proper food and organic remedies, rather than chemicals, as the path to good health. He is one of several academicians and practicing doctors who will participate in the third yearly symposium on "Healing Plants: Myth, Magic and Medicine," scheduled on Friday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
Geared for lay people as well as professionals, the program will explore the healing potential of plants; Belize and Polynesia as prime sources of medicinal plants, and cancer prevention through diet, among other topics.
The speakers are Dr. Paul Cox, professor of botany at Brigham Young University; Dr. Mark Micozzi, director of the National Museum of Health and Medicine in Washington; Dr. Rosita Arvigo, co-founder of the Ix Chel Tropical Research Center in Belize, and Dr. James McChesney of the University of Mississippi.
Admission, a box lunch and program book cost $98.
In connection with the symposium, Dr. Arvigo will conduct a workshop on healing herbs Saturday from 2 to 4 P.M. at a cost of $24. Barrie Kavash, a naturalist, author and board member of the Institute of American Indian Studies in Washington, Conn., will hold a Native American Healing Herbs workshop next Sunday from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., priced at $36.
Chinese herbalism and aromatherapy will be explored in another Sunday workshop from 2 to 5 P.M. with Edwin T. Morris, an expert on Asian healing arts. The cost is $36. Call (212) 220-8720 for reservations or more information about the symposium or workshops.
 
COFFEE CONCERTS
 A variety of gourmet coffees and pastries and a social hour with the musicians set the mood for the Philharmonia Virtuosi's Sunday Coffee Concerts series, beginning today at 2 P.M. in Theater C of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase.
The pianist Anton Nel will be the soloist in a program of Faure and Dvorak. Tickets are $18 and can be reserved on Visa or Mastercard by calling 693-5595. A complete schedule of the five Coffee Concerts, which are available at a series price of $70, can be obtained by calling the same number.
 
YOGA CLASSES
 A series of seven yoga classes will begin on Wednesday and continue through Oct. 28 at the Hammond Museum in North Salem. Noncompetitive breathing and relaxation techniques and the basic postures of yoga are said to improve the body's flexibility and vitality.
Diana Cote, the instructor, requires students to bring their own mats or thick comforters and to wear white clothing. The one-hour classes begin at 7:30 P.M. The cost for seven sessions is $70.
The museum is on Deveau Road. Call 669-5033 for more information.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Economic Mismanagement, German Style

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Misery on behalf of principle is justified, especially if someone else is doing the suffering.
That would seem to be the operating policy for government leaders in almost all of Western Europe this year. Having adopted a policy of European integration and monetary convergence, they will stick to it no matter what pain is inflicted on their populations by high interest rates and rising unemployment. 
 There are few economists, or politicians for that matter, who doubt that Britain and most of the rest of Europe would be better off with lower interest rates, or who doubt that at the moment those currencies are overvalued relative to the German mark. The result is slower growth, or no growth at all, for many countries.
So, you might ask, why not lower interest rates and devalue the currencies against the mark?
Because, say the politicians, it would be wrong. "All my adult life, I have seen British governments driven off their virtuous pursuit of low inflation by market problems or political pressures," thundered John Major, the British Prime Minister. "The soft option, the devaluer's option, the inflationary option, would be a betrayal of our future." So the present can suffer.
The decision of Europe to tie itself to the German mark and essentially to cede many decisions to the German central bank, the Bundesbank, was made in the name of monetary union, in the belief that a financially unified Europe could better compete with the United States and Japan, and in the confident expectation that Germany's fiscal policy would remain prudent and responsible.
Now, the politicians believe, to diverge from that course would destroy their credibility. Never mind that fiscal responsibility went out the window in Germany when it completed a leveraged buyout of East Germany on extremely generous terms. The Bundesbank, which warned against the deal, is keeping interest rates high to control inflation, which may make sense from a German perspective, but not from a European one.
The French will vote next Sunday on the Maastricht treaty, and approval might buy some time for Europe to try to keep the current system patched together. Rejection would probably lead eventually to currency devaluations and to lower European interest rates.
Almost everyone west of the Rhine hopes that the Germans will change their policy, and it is possible, as Merrill Lynch strategist Chuck Clough suggests, that such a move could spark a rally in stock and bond markets in both Europe and the United States. But so far the Bundesbank has sent no signals of such intentions. And the other Governments feel powerless to protect their own countries from the consequences of Germany's current policy.
There is nothing wrong with the idea of economic and monetary union in Europe, but the lesson of this fiasco is likely to be that such an arrangement must be the result of governments' following similar policies, not a substitute for such coordination.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: How Big a Disaster Can Insurers Survive?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
As insurers add up the damage wrought by Hurricane Andrew, what is striking is not only the unprecedented size of the losses but also the frightening thought that the toll could have been much worse. Now American insurance companies and regulators are asking troubling questions: Just how big a natural disaster is possible? And is the insurance system strong enough to endure it?
For more than a decade, some large insurers say, they have been horrified by the prospect of a giant earthquake in a major city -- perhaps the size of the quake that struck San Francisco in 1906. Such an event, some economists argue, could result in insurance claims of $40 billion or more, and it could result in widespread insolvencies and a disruption of insurance markets across the country. 
 Now, even as it appears that claims from Andrew's damage may climb above $8 billion, many industry leaders say the private insurance system can easily survive a beating from the most expensive storms.
But one executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group, recently voiced his dissent. "If Andrew had hit the south coast of Long Island," he said, "you would no longer have the strongest insurance industry, you would have the longest insurance industry -- some companies would be flat on their backs."
Less than two weeks before Andrew struck Florida, Congress held hearings on a bill that would make the Federal Government a reinsurer to the insurance industry in the case of giant earthquakes.
As bad as Andrew was, the insurance companies involved appear equipped to pay their policyholders. The companies that announced the largest losses -- State Farm, with an estimated $1.5 billion in claims, and Allstate, with $1.2 billion -- have plenty of capital on hand, analysts say. The worldwide system of catastrophe reinsurance, in which insurance companies pass on a certain part of their losses to reinsurers who in turn pass on some of their losses to their own reinsurers, appears to have worked well.
But a study last year prepared by Howard Kunreuther and Neil Doherty, two professors at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, found that in the case of a very severe earthquake, the insurance system would not fare so well. The study made projections about the impact of a quake of 8.3 on the Richter scale occurring at midday in San Francisco and assumed insurance losses in 1987 dollars of $40.3 billion. Of 18 companies studied, five would become insolvent and all would experience losses of 10 percent or more of their surplus, or capital. Based on limited data, the authors said they believed the reinsurance market would be hit even more heavily.
Perhaps the most significant impact for the nation would be a sudden reduction in the availability of insurance after such an earthquake, said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institute in Washington, who has also studied the issue. Insurance companies are limited in the amount of new insurance they can write by their levels of surplus: a company can write no more than $3 of insurance for every $1 of surplus.
"The real big one comes and lops off $40 billion or $50 billion in capital from an industry with a capitalization of $159 billion," Mr. Litan said. "You are going to see a national cutback in coverage. Many people, a lot of smaller businesses, nonprofit concerns just wouldn't be able to buy insurance."
Other industry-sponsored studies have estimated that insured damage from a very large earthquake in Los Angeles would be $40 billion or more, and similar losses might be expected in some of the 39 other states that seismologists say are vulnerable to earthquakes. A severe quake along the New Madrid fault in the Midwest, as happened in the last century, for example, could be particularly damaging to a city like Memphis, where building codes have not been adapted for earthquakes as they have in California.
In California, the anxiety of scientists is growing. Four years ago the United States Geological Survey said there was a 60 percent probability that a huge quake would strike the southern end of the San Andreas fault within 30 years. But after a quake of 7.4 in southern California in June, some experts expect a big earthquake much sooner.
Until recently, insurance industry studies indicated that the largest likely damages from severe hurricanes would be significantly smaller than those from a severe quake. One reason earthquakes are more expensive is that large commercial buildings like high-rise office towers can be destroyed by earthquakes but survive high winds.
Nonetheless, coastal development between 1980 and 1988 alone increased insured value along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts by an estimated 70 percent. Last year, D. G. Freidman, who heads the Natural Hazards Research Program for the Travelers Insurance Company, presented a paper in which he estimated that Hurricane Hugo, which caused $4.2 billion in insured damages when it hit offshore islands and the Carolinas in 1989, would have cost insurers roughly $20 billion if it had hit New York City.
Even if the private insurance market could withstand such a blow without insolvencies, Andrew is likely to make safety experts consider including hurricane damage in a Federal insurance program, said James L. Taylor, the assistant administrator of the Federal Insurance Administration, a part of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. A hurricane or earthquake program, he said, would require localities to set standards for making houses more resistant to disasters.
To deal with the insurance consequences of the largest earthquakes, a House bill backed by insurance companies and sponsored by more than 60 members of Congress would create a national program of earthquake insurance for homeowners, sold through private insurance agents. Like the national flood insurance program, an earthquake program would establish "mitigation standards" to improve building codes around the country.
The bill would also create a reinsurance pool for insurers to pay part of the losses on a big quake. If the pool were exhausted, insurers would borrow from the Treasury and pay the loan back with interest over time.
"The key question is whether we are going to prefund these disasters," said Mr. Litan of the Brookings Institute. "Should we have some sort of social insurance mechanism that puts money aside for a rainy day?"
The Bush Administration questions whether the bill's standards are tough enough. James Barth, a professor of finance at Auburn University, agrees. He adds that if people believed the Government would always be there to pay a large portion of the bill, insurance companies would be less likely to build up capital to withstand a big earthquake, and citizens and localities would be less likely to make property quake resistant.
"In one way it could be like the savings and loan situation," he said. "People may engage in socially undesirable behavior if they know the Federal Government will be there to bail them out when things get really bad."
 
 
WHY NOT FEDERAL QUAKE INSURANCE?
 Proponents of a Federal insurance program for damages from severe earthquakes point to the success of the National Flood Insurance Program, which has about 2.5 million policies in force in 18,000 communities around the nation. Property owners buy the policies in addition to private coverage for damages from other causes. The program has allowed the Government to require localities where the policies are sold to adopt building codes and procedures intended to reduce flood damage.
James L. Taylor, the assistant administrator of the Federal Insurance Administration, said that communities participating in the program had suffered 70 percent less damage from floods than other communities. Since the program was established in 1969, he said, the Federal Government has saved $2 billion in disaster relief payouts. The program has not required taxpayer funds to pay claims or operating expenses since 1985.
One former administrator of the Federal Insurance Administration, Robert Hunter, who now heads the National Insurance Consumer Organization and often criticizes the industry, said he would favor an expanded program for consumers to cover damage from hurricanes, earthquakes and other disasters. But he said he would oppose a reinsurance part to the program unless there were provisions protecting taxpayers against having to bail out insurers who have taken too many risks in disaster-prone areas.
