HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech to the Black Family Reunion celebration at the Washington Monument yesterday. 
 " You look at the statistics for the black families and for the rest of the families in America. Where there is a good job, the families are more likely to stay together, to be stable, to raise their children successfully and to have a good future. Where there is decent health care, the families are more likely to have healthy children who do better in school. Where there is an effort to help people succeed, that changes the lives of individuals in families; the families tend to do better. And then, on the other hand, there's all kinds of evidence that as our economy has continued to deteriorate and poverty has exploded, and more and more people have lost jobs, many times for the first time in their entire lives, that puts enormous pressure on the families.
We are being called today, you and I, to measure up to the real family values of America, which is to value our families and help each other raise our children and strengthen our families, and broaden the horizons of our community so that we can all live up to be what we were meant to be. That is the challenge that we face today in honoring the family. "
 
VICE PRESIDENT DAN QUAYLE
In response to a question yesterday about money from Congress to rebuild Homestead Air Force base in Florida.
" I hope we will get that turned around. It may be difficult. The budget is tight, but I'm convinced when they reflect on the issue that they'll come around to supporting our position for two major reasons. One, it's in our security interest. The Homestead Air Force Base is critical to us. When you look at Latin America, look at Cuba. We invest in national security, we invest in national defense, and build other Air Force bases and other military bases because it is in our interest. There's another benefit, and that is jobs and economic development in the local area. But the first reason is what is in our national interest and it is in our national interest to make sure Homestead Air Force Base is rebuilt. "
 
SENATOR AL GORE
In a speech to the Ohio Democratic Convention in Columbus yesterday.
" Jim Baker went on to say in that same speech, and I will quote him again, he said, 'It's amazing what George Bush can do when he really concentrates.' You know, think about that a minute: It would be nice to have a President who can really concentrate; concentrate on us, on our country, on average working families, instead of worrying about everything else under the sun. Well, apparently that speech that he made at the convention, after he started concentrating and targeting America, didn't go too well. The next morning the stock market went down. The dollar is still going down, unfortunately. So, just a few days ago they decided they'd better do it again, and the President bought a million worth of television time to announce what he wanted to do for the economy. Well, my first question was, Where you been the last four years? "

HEADLINE: Cuomo Creates Commission to Study Judges' Pay

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been tangling with New York State's Chief Judge for a year over financing for the judiciary, has announced the creation of a commission to examine how much state judges should be paid.
But the Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, pointing out that a commission had recommended raises for judges five years ago, called Mr. Cuomo's move "just a bureaucratic way of avoiding what must be confronted." 
 Last January, in what seemed a finale to what a Federal judge had called "an unseemly conflict," the Governor and the Chief Judge dropped lawsuits against each other after Mr. Cuomo committed himself to providing money to restore the courts to their former strength. Judges' salaries were not part of that package.
Last week, while Mr. Cuomo was on a five-day trade mission to Israel, Judge Wachtler released a letter repeating calls for judicial raises.
The Governor, in a press release on Thursday announcing the commission, said: "The salaries of state judges should be examined to determine if they are adequate. This examination needs to take into consideration the State's current economic condition and potential cost savings within the courts."
The release said the commission "has been asked to report as soon as it can, consistent with a thorough study." The commission chairman will be James R. Jones, chairman of the American Stock Exchange; the other members have not been named.
Judge Wachtler said that a commission had recommended salary increases for judges in 1987, "and the Governor cast it aside." He continued, "The judges are the only permanent employees of the state who have been singled out for no salary increase for six years."
A spokesman for the Governor, Tom Conroy, said that the previous commission was for the three branches of government, and "none of the branches has had raises for quite some time."
But Judge Wachtler said, "There are 5,000 employees of the executive branch who receive increases every year and who are earning more than the average judge." The average judge is paid $84,000 a year.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Vice President;
Quayle Visits Hurricane Victims in Tent City

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 12

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle came to this hurricane-flattened city today to hear from victims of the disaster and to reassure wary Florida voters that the Bush Administration cares.
"We're still committed to Homestead," said Mr. Quayle, who was accompanied by his wife, Marilyn, and two of the couple's three children. "We've come to hear from the people and see what kind of requests we get." 
 President Bush has twice visited the areas devastated by the Aug. 24 hurricane, but it was Mr. Quayle's first visit.
 
Base Called 'Linchpin'
 Among the Federal aid President Bush promised was $480 million to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base, which the Pentagon estimates added $405 million a year to the local economy before it was destroyed by the storm. But on Thursday, the Senate Appropriations Committee cut that money from the President's $7.6 billion fund for rebuilding South Florida.
Mr. Quayle today called the base "a linchpin to the community" and said that it should not be "closed by Mother Nature."
He later visited a tent city, where he took part in a discussion with eight residents, and toured two disaster application centers and a Red Cross kitchen.
Under a lowering sky with a thunderstorm threatening, the Vice President and his wife listened to the tales of the hurricane's homeless.
Many, like Carmen Melchor, were thankful they were sheltered and fed and alive. "We're fine," said Mrs. Melchor, whose husband, Jose Ortiz, was off helping with volunteer cleanup work.
 
'I Used to be a Housewife'
 An onlooker, Maritza Gonzales, had arrived in the camp with her three children and her husband, John Gonzales, three days earlier. She said the apartment they had been sharing with 14 other people had become too crowded. "I used to be a housewife, but now I don't have a house," she said, adding that she had money to rent an apartment but could not find one.
Danny Cox, 32, with two of his three children in his arms, confronted the Vice President with his problems.
"We're not used to this," said Mr. Cox. "There's tension on the family. We need some privacy. When we came they told us there would be family tents."
Earlier today, Mr. Quayle, who heads the White House group that makes space policy, visited Cape Canaveral for a space shuttle launching.
He found a political opening when he was asked by a local television reporter why little had been said about space programs during this Presidential campaign.
Mr. Quayle responded that he hoped it was because there was a bipartisan consensus on NASA, but added: "I don't believe that's really the case. As you know, the Democratic Congress attempted to kill the space station again this week. We were able to stop that.
"I'm afraid that if George Bush isn't re-elected, we're going to see rather dramatic cuts in our space exploration budget. And that will not be good news for the people of Florida."

HEADLINE: Where Friends of Money Are the Best of Enemies

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CIZRE, Turkey

 BODY:
The truck driver fired up his rumbly diesel engine and headed out to break a little international law in Iraq.
His truck, designed to cart things like vegetables, had been modified, like many others in this remote and grimy border town in southeastern Turkey. Its flatbed had been raised on jacks to the level of its cab and propped up by wooden supports so that two gigantic extra fuel tanks could be slung below, one on each side, almost touching the ground, capable of carrying seven tons of fuel between them. 
 The 39-year-old driver, Ulker Akbulut, said the customizing was in the good cause of profit.
 
Big Profits in Smuggling
 In the northern Iraqi oil town of Mosul, diesel costs only pennies a gallon. In Turkey it retails for about $2.70 a gallon. After paying odd, informal "taxes" to such collectors as armed Iraqi Kurdish insurgents and Turkish border policemen, Mr. Akbulut said, he could make a profit 30 or 40 times his outlay. So he drove south with food for sale in both Kurdish- and Iraqi-controlled areas of northern Iraq, and returned with diesel.
Technically, the export of oil products from Iraq contravenes the sanctions imposed on Baghdad after the Persian Gulf war. But Turks, Iraqis, the Western allies and just about everybody else seem ready to avert their gaze from the activities of Mr. Akbulut and hundreds of others.
"They told us: you cannot carry fuel on top of your trucks," Mr. Akbulut said, "so we carry it below in extra tanks for our own use." Then he roared off in his truck to make some money.
 
Political Lines Shift
 It would be uncharacteristic of this volatile region, however, if the adventures of Mr. Akbulut and his many colleagues were unrelated to some political derring-do.
In the era before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, Turkey maintained a close economic and political relationship with Iraq. And both agreed that nationalism among the fractious Kurds whose clans straddle their borders -- and those of Iran and Syria, too -- was a bad thing.
Ankara gave no succor to Iraqi Kurds. Baghdad permitted Turkish warplanes to fly hot-pursuit missions against insurgent Turkish Kurds taking refuge in northern Iraq. And, with Iraq exporting much of its crude oil in pipelines across Turkey -- and Turkish trucks also exporting some refined products -- the relationship prospered.
Then came the Persian Gulf war.
Turkey was one of the first to side with the American-sponsored coalition. The truck traffic stopped. People like Mr. Akbulut fell on hard times.
These days the lineup is different. While Turkey pursues its own conflict with a Turkish Kurdish insurgent group that operates from northern Iraq, it fetes the leaders of the Iraqi Kurds in Ankara. And, according to both Iraqi Kurds and Turkish leaders, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has joined two of his adversaries, Iran and Syria, in supporting the Turkish Kurds battling his onetime allies in Ankara.
A result has been that one set of Kurds has turned against the other, while the powers that control their destiny fight it out among themselves. The situation is reminiscent of earlier days, when pre-revoluionary Iran sponsored the Iraqi Kurds against Baghdad, only to ditch them when relations improved.
Throughout the summer, the relationship between Turkish Kurds and Iraqi Kurds has soured as the Turkish Kurdish insurgents of the Kurdish Workers Party have sought to escalate their war with Ankara from refuges in northern Iraq and elsewhere.
The Iraqi Kurds, dependent on the road route from Turkey for food, have tried to restrain them. In mid-summer, the Turkish Kurdish insurgents retaliated by telling drivers like Mr. Akbulut not to make the run to northern Iraq. They burned some Turkish trucks to make the point.
 
Conflict Over Land
 For a brief period, supplies dried up as the Turkish Kurdish insurgents pressed their demands for tenure in northern Iraq, while Iraqi Kurds laid claim to the same areas to resettle their own displaced people.
Massoud Barzani, one of the two main Iraqi Kurdish leaders, visited Ankara recently to discuss the Turkish Kurds with Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel.
"We are not ready to endure any more the illegal existence of the P.K.K. in the Kurdish area," he told reporters in northern Iraq, referring to the Turkish Kurdish insurgents by their Kurdish initials. "If they want to deny our authorities here, we will use force against them. Either we must leave the area for the P.K.K. or they must leave it for us."
Behind such statements is Realpolitik.
Ankara has befriended the Iraqi Kurds and permits the allies to fly deterrent flights over northern Iraq from the Incirlik air base in southeastern Turkey because it wishes to maintain its long alliance with the West and to prevent a new influx of Iraqi Kurdish refugees.
But it frets that the latest Western moves to create a second air exclusion zone in southern Iraq will hasten Iraq's disintegration and thereby lead to the creation of a Kurdish state in the north. That might embolden the separatists among the six-million-strong Kurdish population in southeastern Turkey -- one tenth of the overall population .
Against this backdrop, people like Mr. Akbulut are allowed to ply their trade in northern Iraq because, by United Nations estimates, the trucks that take food south to Mosul, a city under Baghdad's control, supply one third of Iraq's food -- a point that Ankara will underline, Western diplomats said, when it comes to patching up relations with Baghdad. Trading in food and medicine is permitted under the Gulf War sanctions.
The diesel that burdens Mr. Akbulut's truck, by contrast, represents only a miniscule proportion of Iraq's pre-war oil exports.
"It's a job," Mr Akbulut said, shrugging off the politics. "It is how we live."

HEADLINE: Facing Voter Rebellions, Incumbents Hope to Eke Out Victories

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
In a year marked by fierce anti-incumbent sentiments nationwide, several members of New York's Congressional delegation are locked in testy primary battles. But as the races enter their last days, the voter rebellion has been overshadowed by racial and ethnic appeals and tempered by redistricting, which has sent incumbents scrambling into new territory.
Just days before Tuesday's primary, some voters in some of the most hotly contested Congressional districts -- from Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant across Queens and the Bronx to suburban Great Neck on Long Island -- are still undecided. In a sign of the volatility of the electorate, people railed against any and all officeholders, but then admitted that they knew little or nothing of the challengers. 
 "I'm a Perot person," said Felix Navarro, a 45-year-old bus driver who lives in Queens. "I'm tired of these crooked politicians. What I want is change. I would vote just for anyone who is new, just to have a change." He laced into the incumbent Democrat in his district, Representative Gary L. Ackerman. But of Mr. Ackerman's opponent, Rita Morris, a librarian from Westbury, L.I., he said, "Who is she? Rita Morris? She should have more visibility."
The usual voter uncertainties have been sharply heightened by Congressional redistricting, which, because of population shifts, reduced the New York Congressional delegation by three seats this year. The partisan battles over how to redraw the state's Congressional districts were settled in July, twisting many districts into bizarre shapes.
The result has been confusion that sometimes approaches comedy. Anthony Lancellotti, 81, was railing "out, out, out" against incumbents at a center for the elderly in Corona this summer. He had just finished announcing, "This is the Ackerman area, I want him out too," when another incumbent, Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, came by and shook his hand. "Yes," Mr. Solarz told him. "I'm part of Corona now."
Political analysts say the new districts have tempered the throw-the-bums-out mentality, since the so-called bums have already been thrown out -- into somebody else's district. And many of the incumbents who might have been the most endangered are leaving office. In New York State, eight incumbents will not seek re-election this fall, costing the state the seniority that is crucial to committee chairmanships and prying loose Federal money.
Five Congressional incumbents, all of them Democrats, are facing significant primary challenges: Mr. Ackerman and Mr. Solarz, as well as Edolphus Towns in Brooklyn, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake in Queens and Eliot L. Engel in the Bronx. Charles B. Rangel and Ted Weiss, both Manhattan Democrats, and Susan Molinari, a Republican, are facing token primary challenges. With the Democratic primary tantamount to election in New York City, only Mr. Ackerman, whose district stretches into Nassau and Suffolk counties on Long Island, would face a second significant race in November should he win the primary.
Mr. Solarz and Mr. Towns, the two Brooklyn Democrats in the most closely watched primary races, broke with the year's conventional wisdom and stressed their seniority and familiarity with Washington, as a tactic in contests that have taken on racial and ethnic overtones. "Steve Solarz is using the experience and power he has right now, for us," says the voice-over on one of Mr. Solarz's 30-second television spots.
 
Stressing Experience
 Mr. Solarz, a nine-term member of Congress, whose former district was carved into six pieces, has stressed his incumbency and Washington savvy as a theme to counter the charges by his Hispanic opponents that he is thwarting minority empowerment.
Mr. Solarz is seeking re-election in the 12th Congressional District, which was carved out of Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan's Lower East Side specifically to enhance Hispanic voting strength. He has argued that voters should consider who has the most influence to bring Federal dollars to their impoverished neighborhoods.
In the 12th District, where Hispanic residents make up 49 percent of registered Democrats, some Hispanic voters agree. At a variety store in Williamsburg, Joe Rodriguez, who was wearing a baseball cap emblazoned with the words "I'm a citizen," said the Hispanic candidates in the race "have no experience." He added, "Solarz has been around a long time. Experience is what counts."
But many other Hispanic residents in the shops on the Brooklyn side of the Williamsburg Bridge insisted they wanted a representative of their own ethnicity. "He should leave the Spanish to the Spanish," said Evang Gonzalez. "We don't want outsiders. He doesn't even live around here."
Five Hispanic candidates are running in the 12th district. Polls have shown Nydia M. Velazquez, former United States secretary of Puerto Rico's community affairs office, as the leading Hispanic contender. But Elizabeth Colon from the lower East Side has also waged a strong race. They have portrayed Mr. Solarz as a junketeer who wrote 743 overdrafts on his House Bank account. But neither has the financing to match the $2 million war chest of Mr. Solarz. Political analysts say the vote will be split enough to let Mr. Solarz eke into office.
"I think he's going to win," said Norman Adler, a Brooklyn-based political consultant. "If he doesn't win, it will be viewed as a major upset."
In Brooklyn's neighboring 10th Congressional District, Mr. Towns, who is seeking a sixth term, has also stressed his seniority in a message that could appeal to both his traditional black base, as well as to predominantly white neighborhoods like Brooklyn Heights that were moved into his district under reapportionment. "I want people to think he happens to be black but he's an effective member of Congress," Mr. Towns said last month, denying that race was a major factor in the contest.
 
408 Check Overdrafts
 But Susan D. Alter, one of his two white opponents, has pulled close to Mr. Towns in recent weeks by criticizing his voting record, his close ties to the tobacco industry and his 408 check overdrafts on the House Bank. Frank Seddio, a lawyer from Canarsie, is also running.
With the race now considered too close to call, Mr. Towns has moved to solidify his standing among black voters, who make up 56.6 percent of the district. His campaign has latched onto a mailing by Mrs. Alter that shows two brains, one of them pea-sized, and suggests that Mr. Towns underestimates the intelligence of voters. The Towns campaign -- in an appeal to black voters -- has branded the flier as "racist code literature."
But at least some constituents have shown that they are considering more than race. Big Red News, a black weekly in Brooklyn, has endorsed Mrs. Alter, a member of the City Council. And the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, the umbrella organization for the area's large concentration of Hasidic Jews, is supporting Mr. Towns against Mrs. Alter, who is Jewish.
Along Fulton Street, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, many black voters said they were torn by the choice between a black incumbent and a white challenger. "We need new faces and we need more minorities," said Patrick Nelson, a 54-year-old unemployed carpenter.
In the Fifth Congressional District, weaving through Queens, Nassau and Suffolk, Mr. Ackerman, a four-term incumbent with his base in Queens, has been challenged by Mrs. Morris, who is seeking to benefit from the anti-incumbent mood and from a nationwide wave of support for female candidates. Strategists say that Mr. Ackerman's recognition in the Queens section of the district gives him the edge in a Democratic primary. But many voters seem largely unaware of the contest and still others say they have yet to decide.
 
A Warning to Mr. Flake
 Also in Queens, Representative Flake is being challenged in a Democratic primary by Simeon Golar, a former city official who has the backing of the Queens Democratic organization. Officials of the party machine concede that Mr. Flake, the 47-year-old pastor of Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, is likely to win, but they describe the race as a warning to Mr. Flake that he cannot mount grass-roots challenges to party district leaders and still expect support.
In the 17th Congressional District in the Bronx and Westchester, anyone who wants to throw out the incumbent would only get the former incumbent -- the one who went to prison in 1989 after he was convicted of bribery and extortion.
Mario Biaggi, the 74-year-old former Congressman who was released from prison because of poor health well before he completed his eight-year prison term, is challenging Representative Engel, who calls his opponent's race "preposterous" and grumbles that Mr. Biaggi "must have gone to Lourdes."
Mr. Engel is favored to win, but Bill Lynch Jr., a political adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins, cautions, "you never know." With voters showing signs of disaffection and indifference to politics, the primary on Tuesday is expected to have an exceedingly low turnout. That could scramble all the primary contests. "In a low turnout race," Mr. Lynch said, "anything can happen."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Noncandidate Still, Perot Could Still Be a Spoiler

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Ross Perot is tantalizing his remaining supporters with suggestions that he might resuscitate his Presidential campaign, but experts think his most significant role in the race may be the threat he poses of taking a few percentage points away from President Bush in their home state of Texas.
Mr. Perot's name seems certain to be on the ballot in all 50 states, according to Richard Winger, editor of Ballot Access News, a San Francisco newsletter. Petitions have been filed in 49 states and are due to be handed over in Arizona on Friday. Mr. Perot is spending about $500,000 a month to maintain offices in every state for petition drives and to support local candidates who share his views. 
 A reduced but nonetheless sizable band of volunteers remains ready to do his bidding. He pops up frequently on television to plug his new book and scatter hints that he may revive his aborted Presidential candidacy.
If so, he could influence the overall results -- most importantly, a number of political analysts believe, by taking enough votes from the President to tip Texas, with its 32 electoral votes, into Mr. Clinton's column.
 
Not Saying No
 "If the volunteers said, 'It's a dirty job but you've got to do it,' I belong to them," the Texas billionaire said on Friday on a call-in program on C-SPAN. "Let's try to get the two parties to step up to the plate. If they don't, we'll do what we have to do. But there's no plan for an October surprise or a September surprise. There is nothing planned."
Mr. Perot can be bluntly plain-spoken when he wants to, but all of his recent comments about his intentions have been as clear as mud. There is method in his murkiness, says one of his oldest, most intimate associates.
"Keeping his options open until the last conceivable moment has always been Ross's M.O.," said the associate, who asked not to be named. "There's no need for him to make a decision until next month, and I don't think he's made one. He could still go, and he could still not go."
Edward J. Rollins, the Republican political consultant who briefly worked for the Perot campaign, said, "I fully expect him to get back in."
 
Erasing 'Quitter' Label
 "He hates the fact that people called him a quitter," said Mr. Rollins, who was hired to help run the Perot campaign earlier this year but resigned in disgust in July, just before Mr. Perot pulled out of the race. "The only way he saves his reputation is to jump in again, and there's nobody left in Dallas to tell him not to do it. He knows he isn't going to be President now, but he wants to be able to say, 'I stood up, and I laid out the tough agenda.' "
His principal lieutenants, Morton H. Myerson and Thomas W. Luce 3d, are no longer involved in Mr. Perot's political movement, which he has renamed "United We Stand." Mr. Myerson has returned to running Perot Systems, Mr. Perot's computer services company, and Mr. Luce has returned to his law practice. His relations with Mr. Perot are reported to have been badly strained by an overnight visit he made to the White House late in July, for which Mr. Perot upbraided him.
No longer are there millions of volunteers. Many were deeply disillusioned when Mr. Perot pulled out, like the caller on the C-SPAN show who said she cried when she heard the news and demanded, "What are you doing?" But there remain hundreds of thousands still ready to march.
A major element in Mr. Perot's ultimate decision may be his appraisal of Mr. Bush's chances. He has spoken with increasing contempt of the President's economic record and programs. On Friday he recalled angrily that Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, had called him "a monster," and rattled off statistics to demonstrate what he called 12 years of economic failure under the Republicans.
 
Victory Seems Improbable
 "All of this is called trickle-down economics," Mr. Perot said, only 24 hours after the President announced his big economic initiative, "but the truth of the matter is, it didn't trickle down. We're just handing out candy bars."
He has spoken much more gently about Democratic shortcomings.
A recent Gallup Poll suggested that with an active candidacy Mr. Perot might approach 20 percent of the total vote nationally, which would be better than either George C. Wallace or John B. Anderson did in their third-party candidacies and enough to have a significant impact in many states.
But few political professionals believe he could do that well after the waves of negative publicity generated by his pullout on July 16. Candidates with no real prospect of winning the Presidency almost inevitably fade in the final weeks, and a Perot victory seems wholly incredible now.
Mr. Perot's political strength appears to be concentrated in the Southwest, the Mountain States and the West. Polls in California and Arizona late last month put him in double digits, and in his home state of Texas, on which the President is counting heavily, a Dallas Morning News survey early this month showed what amounted to a three-way tie, even with no active Perot electoral effort.
 
Threat in the West
 To some degree, those figures represent disenchanted Bush supporters who are not prepared yet to back Mr. Clinton. Many will eventually decide to go with a major-party candidate, if past experience is any guide.
But if Mr. Perot campaigned actively next month and mounted an extensive television campaign, argues Kevin Phillips, the Republican analyst, he could win as much as 10 percent in Arizona, California and Texas -- mainly from areas like Orange County in Southern California, Silicon Valley in Northern California and the Phoenix, Dallas and Houston suburbs. Such votes, Mr. Phillips believes, would be cast by Republican centrists and "would come disproportionately from Bush."
Florida, Colorado and New Mexico are other targets of opportunity.
There is not universal agreement that a renewed Perot candidacy would hurt the President. For example, Mervin Field, the California poll taker, said he thought that some of the Perot vote that switched to Mr. Clinton in July remained soft and could switch back to Mr. Perot, helping Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: In a Field Studded With Novices, 2 Senate Candidates Vie in Primary 1

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 13

 BODY:
Connecticut voters, battered by the recession and angered by a new income tax, are a weary and irascible group whose reactions to this year's candidates for Congress are far from certain.
In the primary here Tuesday, Republican voters will choose a candidate for the United States Senate, as well as candidates in two Congressional districts. Democrats also have a choice in two Congressional races. 
 Political novices abound in both parties this year. Several candidates have never set foot in the political arena before, but are doing so because they think they could be the antidote to voter disgust with career politicians.
 
Senate Primary
 The Senate primary has been a somewhat lackluster race, with little controversy or mudslinging until recently. In a debate televised last Sunday the candidates, Chris Burnham and Brook Johnson, traded insults, with Mr. Burnham, a two-term state representative, accusing Mr. Johnson of plagiarizing many of the ideas in his 28-page economic plan. Mr. Johnson responded by telling Mr. Burnham that despite being in the race for a year, "you have yet to produce any plan for anyone to read."
In the same debate, Mr. Johnson described himself as having served on a Greenwich school board. This week, his campaign issued a correction, saying he had served on the board of his children's private school, Greenwich Country Day School. In fact, the school's administration has said, Mr. Johnson served on a committee but may join the board later this year. In another debate broadcast over the weekend, Mr. Burnham attacked Mr. Johnson for the misinformation. Mr. Johnson later called his opponent "a whiny kid talking about things he's absolutely wrong about."
 
Similar Positions
 The two Senate candidates, who are vying for the chance to oppose the Democratic incumbent, Christopher J. Dodd, have similar positions on major issues. Both are emphasizing job creation for Connecticut and reducing the Federal deficit. Both favor abortion rights and both want a balanced-budget amendment. Mr. Burnham, an investment banker on leave for the campaign, has served two terms as a state representative from Stamford. Mr. Johnson, who has never held public office, is a millionaire who lives in Greenwich and runs a towel and bedding company. Mr. Burnham has trudged around the state on a shoestring budget, spending $450,000 so far; Mr. Johnson has spent about $900,000, half of that on television commercials to try to make himself a household name.
In what may be either a canny political move or an act of outright desperation, the state Republican Party has endorsed a registered Democrat, Robert K. Ludgin, in the race for the Congressional seat in the First District, centered on Hartford. Mr. Ludgin, a former Deputy Mayor of Hartford, is a self-described "independent cuss" who has broken with his own party on other issues in the past. His challenger, Philip L. Steele, is a lawyer and radio host, also from Hartford, who contends that Mr. Ludgin's endorsement sends the wrong message to Republican voters.
Both Republicans acknowledge that unseating the incumbent, Barbara B. Kennelly, a five-term Democrat who is the daughter of John Bailey, who was state party chairman from 1946 to 1975, will be difficult. No Republican has been elected in the First District since 1956, when Ed May was swept in on the coattails of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, then swept out again two years later.
In the Second District's Republican primary, Glenn T. Carberry, the party-endorsed candidate, faces Ed Munster, a state senator. Mr. Carberry ran against the incumbent, Representative Sam Gejdenson, four years ago and lost. Mr. Carberry, a lawyer from New London, has never held public office. Both he and Mr. Munster, a statistician for the Pfizer Corporation when he is not in the State Legislature, say they would make creating jobs a priority. This is a major issue in their district, which covers much of eastern Connecticut, where military contractors have long been concentrated, but where layoffs are rife as Federal military spending shrinks.
 
Franks's Opponents
 In the Fifth District, the state's most highly charged primary battle has shaped up between Jim Lawlor, a probate judge from Waterbury, and Lynn Taborsak, a state representative who is a licensed plumber. The two Democrats seek to oppose the incumbent, Gary Franks, the only black Republican in Congress. They stand far apart on some of the major issues. Mr. Lawlor, for example, is against abortion rights, while Ms. Taborsak supports them.
The two Democrats have traded personal attacks all summer. One of the most persistent is an accusation that Ms. Taborsak introduced legislation that called for schools to teach masturbation as part of a sex-education course; her staff says that the amendment she filed was intended to block a more conservative agenda put forth by a colleague, which would have insisted that abstinence be taught as the only means of preventing AIDS and teen-age pregnancy. Ms. Taborsak has charged that Mr. Lawlor improperly accepted campaign contributions from lawyers whose cases could come before his court, which the Lawlor campaign has denied.
In the Sixth District, a much less volatile race has taken place between two Democrats seeking to challenge a popular Republican incumbent, Representative Nancy L. Johnson. The Democrats, Gene Slason, an accountant from Southington, and Alan DiCara of Winsted, are both political newcomers. Both advocate job creation and term limits for members of the House of Representatives.

HEADLINE: In Domestic Violence, These Charges Stick

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWTON, N.J.

 BODY:
Albert D. rolled his eyes and grimaced when he was told he had to spend Labor Day weekend in the Sussex County jail.
"If a married couple wants to patch things up between themselves," he moaned, "why get the law involved?" 
 What Albert and his wife Lillian wanted to settle between themselves was her call to the police a few days earlier, saying her husband had punched and kicked her when she threatened to leave him and take their three children with her. Now she wanted to drop the complaint.
No way, said the police, prosecutor and judge. In Sussex County, in northwest New Jersey, if the authorities are called to break up a family fight, the assailant is arrested on an assault charge and goes before a Superior Court judge. Even if the victim wants to drop the charge, the prosecution goes ahead with the case.
 
All Fights Go to Judge
 No more letting couples make up and leaving the police to wait for the next time tempers flare.
Some other jurisdictions in the region have adopted a "pro-arrest" policy in recent years to crack down on domestic violence, instructing the police to arrest and jail a batterer if evidence of assault is observed. But only rural Sussex, population 140,000, insists that all criminal cases stemming from family fights be resolved in Family Court before a judge.
In civil cases, as when a family member obtains a restraining order to keep a threatening spouse at a safe distance, the person filing the complaint is also required to appear before a judge and at least sit down with a counselor from a local victims advocates group before the case is closed. He or she may be held in contempt if the court date is not met.
"The court takes the position that we do not dismiss these cases lightly," said Superior Court Judge Lorraine Parker. "First of all it is very frustrating and demoralizing to police officers who are called to the same house time after time to break up a fight only to have the complaint dropped by the victim the next day.
 
Almost Always Some Jail
 "But more importantly we take the view that it is unacceptable for quarrelling husbands and wives to slap each other around," she said.
If they are permitted to plead guilty to a reduced charge of simple battery, first offenders like Albert D. almost always get a few weekends in jail to drive home the point. They also are ordered as part of probation to attend 29 weekly sessions by Domestic Abuse Services, a local nonprofit victims support group, to understand why they use violence or intimidation.
Dennis O'Leary, the Sussex County Prosecutor, said the policy was inspired, but not mandated, by New Jersey's tough new domestic violence act that took effect last November. A community task force recommended the tough line after studying domestic violence, a leading cause of police complaints in Sussex that often were not prosecuted until bones were broken or the victim died, he said.
"If the violence is serious enough to call in the cops, the criminal-justice system will not let go of the case until one or both parties get help with their problem," said Mr. O'Leary.
 
Takes Burden off Victim
 There is preliminary evidence, he noted, that the new policy is reducing repeat offenses in these types of cases. Another important side effect of "pro-prosecution" is it removes responsibility from the victims, nearly all women, to punish the abusers.
Women, domestic-violence experts say, are often intimidated by fear of future beatings or don't like to see husbands get caught up in the criminal justice system since the victims may suffer the social or economic consequences of a jail term or fine as much as their male abusers.
"What these women want most is for their men to get help with their problems," said Jeanine Ferris Piro, a Westchester County judge in New York, who hailed the Sussex experiment and said it bore watching. Judge Piro is a former prosecutor who headed the domestic violence and child abuse bureau in Westchester, where 21 of 43 police departments follow a "pro-arrest policy."
But overloaded dockets and overworked judges discourage some courts from prosecuting these cases unless the victim is a willing witness.
 
'Coerced Prosecution'
 In New York, some officials are ambivalent "about forcing a woman into a coerced prosecution and making her a hostile witness," said Karla DiGirolamo, executive director of Governor Cuomo's Commission on Domestic Violence.
Sussex officials recognize that what works in a small rural county in New Jersey's highlands may not be feasible in a large urban one. It wasn't all that long ago that Sussex had more cows than people. But as new highways in the last 20 years cut travel time to New York City, commuting families moved in, as well as workers in new ski resorts and amusement parks.
The new policy has about doubled the number of domestic violence cases heard by the Family Court, forcing a delay in divorce and custody proceedings, said Judge Parker.
Bruce LaCarrubba, an assistant county prosecutor, spends Thursdays -- called "Family Feud Day" in the courthouse corridors -- handling about 20 criminal domestic violence cases filed the previous week. He handles each case systematically, huddling first with the victim to hear what outcome she wants, then giving the offender a package deal if he will plead guilty to a reduced charge.
 
Often, Professional Help
 "Usually we try to get the guy some professional help to deal with what are obviously deep-seated problems," said Mr. LaCarrubba. In cases involving serious injury, evidence is presented to a grand jury to consider a felony indictment.
Lillian D. had made it clear she did not want her husband, an electrician, to go to jail. Mr. LaCarrubba, conferring with her, insisted some jail time was necessary, in addition to counseling and psychological evaluation at county expense.
"Given what he did to you," he told her, "he should spend more than one weekend in jail."
He relented, however, and minutes later was telling the husband that because of his wife's intervention he would go to jail for only one weekend. "I wanted four weekends but she nagged me down to one."
 
'I Told You She Was a Nag'
 The husband, without hestitation, responded: "I told you she was a nag. Pretty soon you're going to want to belt her."
Mr. LaCarrubba's eyes narrowed as he measured the hefty man standing before him. For a few seconds there was a feeling the electrician had talked his way back into four weekends in the county jail.
The husband, sensing trouble, rolled up his sleeve and exhibited a livid scar on a forearm. "She did that with a fork," he explained. He then hitched up a trouser leg, exposing an older wound. "Screwdriver."
Mr. LaCarrubba let the single weekend sentence stand, a decision affirmed minutes later in a brief hearing before a judge, and in minutes he was in conference with another emotionally confused and torn victim, alternately consoling her and insisting on an apt punishment for her batterer.

HEADLINE: New York's Budget Chief Asks Reduced Requests

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
New York City's Budget Director said yesterday that he would ask city agency heads this week for detailed plans on how they would help cut expenses by $500 million next year to meet a projected $1.6 billion budget gap for fiscal 1994, which starts next July.
The Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said the anticipated cuts to balance a 1994 budget of $29.5 billion would not affect all agencies in proportion to the size of their budgets, but would probably reflect the priorities of Mayor David N. Dinkins in promoting education, social services and the police. 
 In the complex world of municipal budget making, Mr. Michael's request for plans on how to save the $500 million is a bit like an opening bid in a game that will see counterproposals, lobbying and intense negotiations before the final judgments are decided.
 
Trims Via Attrition
 The Budget Director declined to say how the cuts might affect hiring or the size of the city's work force, which is just over 200,000 and has been cut by 8,000 in the last 15 months. The Dinkins administration pledged last January to trim thousands of additional jobs through attrition in the next three years.
"The Mayor is determined to stick to fiscal stability, regardless of how painful it might be," Mr. Michael said in an interview. "Maybe on a national level the strategy is to spend billions they don't have, but on our level the Mayor is not going to spend money he doesn't have."
Asked about the size of the projected cuts, Mr. Michael said they represented only 1.7 percent of the budget, adding: "We've done so much cutting in the last three years that an agency reduction in the $500 million range is quite deep."
 
Detailed Targets Are Next
 The request for long-range budget-cutting plans, reported yesterday by Newsday, will be made in a letter over Mr. Michael's signature asking agency heads to respond by Oct. 1. Later this fall, in a process that involves much give and take, Mayor Dinkins will set the detailed targets for each agency.
The size of next year's cuts and of the projected deficit were spelled out earlier this year when city officials made budget plans for fiscal 1994. Those projections have changed little in recent months, but could be adjusted up or down depending on the performance of the city's economy, the size of state and Federal aid and other factors.
Mr. Michael called his letter part of a continuing process of financial planning. The city, he said, modifies its plans and projections quarterly, looking ahead not only to the next fiscal year but several years beyond.
Current projections anticipate deficits of $1.7 billion in fiscal 1995 and $2.2 billion in fiscal 1996. But these are so far into the future that most city officials and budget planners take them with a grain of salt, noting that much could change along the way. Last spring, Mayor Dinkins announced that a $550 million surplus had been found that would help balance the current budget.
Plans for closing next year's projected $1.6 billion budget gap, Mr. Michael said, were made months ago. They anticipate $200 million more in Federal aid and $600 million more in relief from Albany through increases in the so-called commuter income taxes, a state takeover of Medicaid costs and more aid to education.
In addition, the city had planned to issue bonds next year to borrow $300 million for operating costs. Municipal bonds are ordinarily sold to finance construction and other long-term projects, not to cover operating costs, and after wide criticism city officials said they would drop the bond plan if other sources of money were found.
Mr. Michael noted that alternative sources were found. A month ago, a refinancing of municipal debt gained $100 million, and new projections of an improved city economic performance has allowed fiscal planners to project $200 million more in tax revenues for fiscal 1993 and 1994, making a total of $300 million available and clearing the way to cancel the bond plan.
That money, plus the $200 million from Washington and the $600 million from Albany, adds up to $1.1 billion, leaving the city still $500 million short in closing the $1.6 billion gap in fiscal 1994. That $500 million is the amount that current projections say must be cut by city agencies next year.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Anne Eldridge and Colm Connolly

 BODY:
Anne Elizabeth Eldridge, the daughter of Mrs. Carleton G. Eldridge Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Eldridge, was married there yesterday to Colm Felix Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix P. Connolly of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Bedingfield officiated at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Joseph McLaughlin, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.
Mrs. Connolly, 26 years old, was until recently a clerk for Judge Jay C. Waldman of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. She is to join the Philadelphia law firm of Dechert, Price & Rhoads as an associate next month. She graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College and received a law degree from Duke University, as did her husband. Her father was a partner in the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers. 
 Mr. Connolly, 27, is to become an assistant United States attorney in Delaware in the fall. Until recently he was a clerk for Judge Walter K. Stapleton of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame and received a master's degree in politics from the London School of Economics.
His mother, Rita C. Connolly, owns A Touch of the Orient, an Asian antique import store in Yorklyn, Del. His father, now retired, was an Asia-Pacific regional director for the Delaware-based Du Pont Company in Tokyo.

HEADLINE: Raising the Stakes In a War of Plastic

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The plastic thicket of credit cards has grown denser in the last two weeks with announcements from General Motors and General Electric that they will market new cards.
More junk mail can be disorienting for anyone trying to find the best terms available, but the new cards are nevertheless welcome news for consumers. Taken together, they provide a good indication of how the growing competition in the business has forced credit-card issuers, including a growing number of companies that are not banks, to offer better terms to attract or hold on to customers. 
 The cards' many features also highlight how sophisticated the industry has become since the first charge cards were issued four decades ago. Visa U.S.A. said the resulting confusion among consumers -- and no doubt the threat of new competitors like G.M.'s Mastercard -- had prompted it to develop a 24-page credit card "Owner's Manual" that it plans to announce tomorrow. The free booklet uses the Cathy cartoon character to dole out advice with a light touch. Recommending that customers prepare a realistic budget and manage their credit, for example, the booklet shows Cathy itemizing her expenses: "Food $50, Shelter $600, Medical $10, Miscellaneous $7,000."
While the features offered by G.M. and G.E. are for the most part not new, G.M.'s features in particular are considered a potent force in combination; analysts predict G.M. will issue roughly 3.5 million cards within two years (Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover card is the top issuer, with 41.2 million; Citibank is second with 30 million and the American Express Company has 25 million, according to the Nilson Report, an industry newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif.)
Consumers, for example, can transfer the balance on their existing credit cards to the G.M. card. With its 16.4 percent interest rate, about 1.8 percent lower than the national average, some customers may see this offer as a free refinancing of their debt. The G.M. card requires no annual fee; G.E.'s is $25.
Some banks have offered balance transfers for a year or two. But the feature has mushroomed in popularity in the last six months, driven in part by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Universal card, which introduced the feature in April. A.T.& T. has continued the offer in spite of earlier plans to end it in June.
The G.M. and G.E. cards also promise rebates or discounts on purchases of certain consumer goods and services. In the case of G.E., its credit card promises discount coupons and rebates from 24 large companies, including G.E. itself, Kmart, Macy's, Northwest Airlines, Sprint and Hertz.
Users of G.M.'s card can apply a rebate of 5 percent of their annual charges toward buying or leasing a G.M. car or truck (excluding the Saturn). There is a $500 yearly cap, but the rebate can accumulate over seven years to $3,500. And there is no cap on the additional 5 percent rebate offered by G.M.'s partners in the new card -- Avis, Marriott and MCI Communications. And G.M. says it expects more such partners in the future.
Again, such partnerships are not new. In 1987, United Airlines started issuing Mastercard and Visa cards that now earn one frequent flier mile for each dollar charged. But frequent-flier cards typically have high annual fees and many restrictions. By contrast, G.M. and G.E. have few restrictions on their rebates and incentives, which are intended in large measure to increase customer loyalty.
A car company issuing a credit card to help sell more cars is a long way from the roots of the charge card industry. They date to 1951, when Franklin National Bank of Long Island issued cards with a customer's account number. Merchants who also banked at Franklin copied the card number onto a sales slip, or called the bank for approval if the amount exceeded a pre-determined limit. The funds would later be shifted to the merchant's account, with a discount for processing the transaction.
By 1959, about 150 banks were offering these cards, which carried no annual fee. Initially, the cards' balances had to be paid off in full within a month or two. But soon banks started offering extended credit in return for a monthly finance charge.
American Express entered the business in 1958 with its first charge card. In the mid-1960's, banks started forming alliances that could offer cards under a common label to a wider number of customers, for acceptance by a broader base of merchants.
These alliances gave rise to the BankAmericard, which in 1977 became the Visa card, and to the Master Charge card, which evolved into Mastercard in 1979. At the same time, the high interest rates charged by the banks prodded many consumers to pay off their cards monthly. To replace the lost interest income, banks began to charge annual fees.
Those fees annoy consumers, who liken them to paying a cover charge to shop at an expensive convenience store, said Robert B. McKinley, president of RAM Research in Frederick, Md.
Many credit card issuers started dropping annual fees in the late 1980's because interest rates in general had fallen; jumps in the average balance consumers carried on their cards supplied the banks with more interest income.
For example, the average balance on bank credit cards increased more than 50 percent from 1987 to 1992. It currently averages about $1,260 for Visa, Mastercard, Discover and Optima cards.
As consumers started to carry larger balances on their cards, and as the market grew more saturated, credit card companies turned to a host of gimmicks to distinguish themselves from competitors.
Visa issued its gold card in 1988, setting off a battle to offer new features. The result of those skirmishes included programs under which consumers who found a product on sale at a price lower than that at which they bought it could file for the difference if they were willing to do the requisite paperwork. Extended warranties and insurance coverage for broken items were also added. Many are still in place today, although they now carry more restrictions.
The rise of "affinity cards" also underscored the saturation in the industry. With such cards, an organization like a university or environmental group that lends its name to a bank card can receive a few pennies from each transaction. Affinity cards have been issued to appeal to Elvis Presley fans, bowlers and members of minority groups.
After exploding in popularity in the late 1980's, however, affinity cards have waned as banks have in many cases been unable to attract enough cardholders to make the ventures profitable.
In recent years, companies outside the banking industry have developed an interest in acquiring credit card companies, an interest encouraged when the Visa and Mastercard consortiums relaxed their rules on non-banking companies issuing their cards.
These companies saw the potential in promoting their products through credit cards. But David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, said only companies with the profile of an A.T.& T., G.M. or G.E. have the name recognition and credibility necessary to succeed with a national card.
In recent years, many faltering banks reluctantly sold their profitable credit card businesses as sources of ready cash. Such acquisitions helped G.E. increase its bank credit-card business from nothing in 1987 to more than $2 billion in receivables today.
Household Credit Services of Salinas, Calif., which is administering G.M.'s credit card, also elbowed into the top 10 issuers of credit cards, primarily through its acquisition of 19 credit card portfolios over the last five years.
Although credit-card interest rates have remained high despite the falling cost of money, credit card issuers seem to be taking widespread criticism to heart and have lowered rates for many customers. Citicorp, for example, last June lowered its rates for roughly nine million cardholders who have been profitable customers.
 
 
 
SQUARING OFF AGAINST A.T.& T.
 General Motors' new credit card is considered the most important card introduction since A.T.& T. first offered its Universal card in March 1990.
The two cards, in fact, will be competing almost head to head. Both advertise a primary rate of 16.4 percent, the lowest among nationwide cards, which charge more than 18 percent on average. If the prime rate is still 6 percent on Tuesday, A.T.& T. is expected to drop its rate to 15.9 percent.
By several measures, the upstart has been a success. It started operating profitably in June, 27 months after it was introduced and faster than some analysts had expected. With 15 million cards issued and 9.9 million accounts, it is among the largest issuers in the industry. And it is also reaping some benefit, just as G.M. hopes to, by having so many people carrying cards intended to increase loyalty to its primary product, telephone services.
Still, problems remain for A.T.& T. For example, the mix of customers who carry balances and those who pay off the cards every month "is out of whack," said David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report, an industry newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif.
For most credit card companies, three-quarters of the customers carry balances from month-to-month, and a quarter pay in full each month. For A.T.& T., the mix is roughly the reverse.
To help correct that problem, A.T.& T. started promoting a "balance transfer" feature in April, which allowed people with other cards to switch their balances directly to A.T.& T.'s account.
The A.T.& T. program is nowhere near as profitable as more mature credit card programs, and it has a long way to go before it recoups A.T.& T.'s original investment in the card -- roughly $600 million by some estimates. Still, Mr. Robertson said, "it is absolutely successful."

HEADLINE: Competition, the Japanese Way

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The analytic viewpoint in "A Lower Gear for Japan's Auto Makers" (Aug. 30) might be reconsidered. Consider the conclusion that flat growth may make lifetime employment, a pillar of worker loyalty, untenable. From an American perspective, a threat to the lifetime contract is at least plausible. A leveling in demand for autos in the United States is only one in many volatile market swings. 
 But we need to try to see the subject through Japanese eyes. Domestic Japanese demand is indeed significantly more stable, but to focus on that would simply perpetuate the American bias. No, the phenomenon that reflects Japanese practice is a capacity to adapt. Lifetime employment is perfectly amenable to zero growth, if the whole system adapts. Whether the Japanese will succeed this time, only future history will reveal. But the record makes clear how fundamental is adaptability in the Japanese success.
The article also suggests that the Japanese may respond to current problems by beginning to compete on technology. American auto companies, sadly, have not always been able to envision their industry as one driven by technology; corporate finance and individual salesmanship seem to be a good bit more popular as organizing principles. But the Japanese have practically redefined autos as a technology-driven industry. We cannot accurately say they will shift to competing on technology.
Competition itself is defined in dramatically different ways. In the United States, wishing a business competitor ill is simply part of standard economic warfare. In Japan, commercial contention is, if anything, more intense. But getting ahead means doing the best possible work. The emphasis is productive, not destructive. And the welfare of all is integral to the formula. If a company gets into trouble, competitors may even help. Japan manages to have the advantages of both intense competition and ties among fellow voyagers on the economic boat.
 
DAVID ALLEN
Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 3
 
David Allen is a fellow at the Center for Business and Goverment at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

TYPE: Letter
